passage_content: והנה כשנגזרה גזירה על ישראל בימי יואל שיבואו עליהם הארבה ילק חסיל וגזם להשחית יבולם, הרגישו שרי האומות בגזירה ההוא והביאו מכל פינות העולם ארבה ילק וכו' על ישראל, כ"א משרי ע' האומות הביא ממה שהוא תחת ממשלתו ומשרשו, כי כולם רצונם להרע לישראל, וכמ"ש רז"ל דבקי"ס באו כל שרי ע' אומות לעזור למצרים וללחום בישראל, ומעתה א"ש דברי התרגום יוב"ע ומקושר עם פשוטו של מקרא דמיירי בארבה ילק וחסיל וכו' שבאו על ישראל, אמנם שורש הענין הי' משרי מעלה של אומה"ע שהביאו עליהם הארבה בגזירת השם, וע"כ בא הבטחת השי"ת ואשלם לכון שניא טבתא חלף שניא דבזו יתכון פלחי כוכביא אומיא ולשניא וכו' דשורש העונש הי' על ידיהם, וארבה שלמטה הם משורשם כנ"ל.
translation: And behold, when a decree was issued against Israel in the days of Joel that locusts, young locusts, and grasshoppers would come upon them to destroy their produce, the princes of the nations felt that decree and brought locusts, young locusts, etc., upon Israel from all corners of the world, each one from the princes of the forty nations brought what was under his dominion and from his root, for all of them desired to do evil to Israel. As our sages of blessed memory said, all the princes of the forty nations came to help Egypt and to wage war against Israel. From now on, I understand the words of the translation, which is connected with the simple meaning of the scripture that speaks of locusts, young locusts, and grasshoppers, which came upon Israel. However, the root of the matter was from the heavenly princes of the nations who brought the locusts upon them by the decree of the Holy One, blessed be He. Therefore, the promise of the Holy One, blessed be He, came, and I will repay you for the years that the locust has eaten, the young locust, and the grasshopper, etc., for the root of the punishment was through them, and the locusts below are from their root, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the divine decree against Israel during the time of Joel, where various forms of locusts were sent to destroy their crops. It highlights that the leaders of the seventy nations, motivated by a desire to harm Israel, brought these locusts from their respective regions. This reflects a deeper theological insight that the root of the punishment stems from the celestial powers of these nations, acting under God's command. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that the earthly manifestations of suffering, such as the locusts, are connected to their spiritual origins in the heavenly realm.

passage_content: ובזאת ירווח לנו לפרש כוונת דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ ואחריו לא יהי' כן, שהקשה ואותו שהי' בימי יואל שנא' כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם למדנו שהי' כבד משל משה, ותירץ כי של יואל הי' ע"י מינין הרבה שהיו יחד ארבה ילק חסיל וגזם, אבל של משה לא הי' אלא של מין אחד וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' עכ"ל, והקשו בעה"ת והרמב"ן ז"ל שהרי מפורש בס' תהלים ויתן לחסיל יבולם ויגיעם לארבה, וכתוב א' אומר אמר ויבא ארבה וילק ואין מספר, הרי שגם במצרים היו של מינים הרבה, וצ"ב דברי רש"י ז"ל דשל משה לא הי' אלא מין אחד, ולדרכנו יתבאר על נכון דהנה הארבה והילק וכו' שבמצרים לא הוסיפו עליו שרי האומות להביא גם מארצם, כי לא יחפצו ברעת המצרים להוסיף מכאובם, ובא הארבה רק מרוח א' כמ"ש ורוח הקדים נשא את הארבה, אמנם נשתנה מכת הארבה שבימי יואל שהי' כ"א מד' מינים הנזכר מארצות שונות כי נזדרזו כל שרי האומות להרע לישראל כנ"ל ובאו מכל הרוחות ומכל פינות העולם.
translation: And with this, it will be easy for us to explain the intent of the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And after him it shall not be so," where he questioned that the one who was in the days of Joel, as it is stated, "like him there shall not be from the world," we learned that he was heavier than Moses. And he answered that Joel's was through many species that were together: locusts, grasshoppers, and beetles, but that of Moses was only of one species, and like him there was not and will not be. Thus far his words. And the commentators and Ramban, may his memory be blessed, questioned that it is explicitly stated in the Book of Psalms, "And He gave to the grasshopper its food and to the locusts their portion," and one verse says, "He said, and the locust came, and there is no number," hence also in Egypt there were of many species. Therefore, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that of Moses there was only one species, are difficult to understand. According to our path, it will be explained correctly that behold, the locust and the grasshopper, etc., in Egypt did not add to them the princes of the nations to bring also from their land, for they did not desire the evil of the Egyptians to increase their pain. And the locust came only from one wind, as it is said, "And the east wind lifted the locust." However, the plague of locusts in the days of Joel was each one of four species mentioned from different lands, for all the princes of the nations hastened to do evil to Israel, as mentioned, and they came from all winds and from all corners of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the locust plagues during the times of Moses and Joel, emphasizing that Moses faced a singular type of locust, while Joel encountered a diverse array of four types from various nations. This diversity signifies a collective effort by the nations to harm Israel, contrasting with the more isolated nature of the plague in Egypt, which was not compounded by external forces. Theological insights highlight the unity of divine judgment and the interconnectedness of nations in their opposition to Israel, reflecting a deeper understanding of the spiritual dynamics at play in these events.

passage_content: והנה כתב רש"י ז"ל (בפ' בראשית) ולמקו' המים קרא ימים, והלא ים אחד הוא, אלא אינו דומה טעם דג העולה מן הים בעכו לדג העולה מן הים באספמיא, מבואר דקרא הכתוב לעצם אחד רבים ע"ש חילוק המקומות, וכל מקום יש לו שורש וע"כ טעם הדג העולה מן הים בעכו אינו דומה לטעם הדג העולה במקו"א אף שמינו אחד שרשו וטעמו שונה, וע"ש כך נקרא הים ימים ע"ש חילוק ארצות, וכמו"כ בארבה ילק חסיל וגזם שבאו בימי יואל הי' כל אחד ממינים הנזכר משל מינים הרבה, אבל של משה אף שהי' ג"כ ילק וחסיל כמפורש בס' תהלים, אבל כאו"א הי' רק מין א' ולא עירבוב מארצות שונות, ובזה יתורץ קושית הראשונים ויתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל עד"ז, כי של יואל הי' ע"י מינין הרבה שהיו יחד ארבה ילק חסיל גזם, ר"ל הד' מינים הנזכר כאו"א הי' ממינים הרבה ע"ש חילוק ארצותם, וע"כ אמר כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם, אבל של משה לא הי' אלא של מין א', ר"ל כ"א הי' ממין א' וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' רבוי כזה.
translation: And behold, Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Bereishit) wrote: "And to the place of the waters He called seas," and is it not one sea? Rather, the taste of the fish that rises from the sea in Akko is not like the taste of the fish that rises from the sea in Aspamia. It is explained that the verse refers to one essence with many names due to the distinction of places, and each place has its root; therefore, the taste of the fish that rises from the sea in Akko is not like the taste of the fish that rises from anywhere else, even though they are of the same species, their roots and tastes are different. And for this reason, the sea is called seas due to the division of lands. Likewise, in the locusts, the grasshoppers, and the beetles that came in the days of Joel, each one of the mentioned species was from many species, but that of Moses, even though it was also locusts and grasshoppers as stated in the Book of Psalms, each one was only one species and not a mixture from different lands. And with this, the question of the earlier commentators will be resolved, and the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified accordingly, for that of Joel was through many species that were together: locusts, grasshoppers, beetles, meaning the four mentioned species, each one was from many species due to the division of their lands. Therefore, he said, "like him, there will not be such a multitude in the world," but that of Moses was only of one species, meaning each one was of one species, and like him, there was not and will not be such a multitude.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the various types of fish and locusts mentioned in the Torah, emphasizing that while they may belong to the same species, their flavors and qualities differ based on their geographical origins. This reflects a deeper theological insight that each place has its unique spiritual root, leading to diverse manifestations of the same essence. The author contrasts the mixed nature of the locusts in the time of Joel, which came from various lands, with the singularity of the locusts in Moses' time, highlighting the idea of unity versus multiplicity in divine creation. Ultimately, this underscores the belief that true unity in diversity is a reflection of God's design in the world.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מה שהגלות אצל הערב רב קשה יותר מהגלות של אומה"ע, כי בגלות של האומות משתעבדין ישראל תחת יד אומה אחת במקום שדרים שם, משא"כ גלות הערב רב שהם משורש כל האומות כמבואר בדרז"ל, סובלים ישראל תחתיהם מבחי' כל האומות, וכל אומה יש לה מידה רעה אחרת, ואצלם נקבצים כל המידות רעות יחד משורש כל האומות והבן.
translation: And with this, it will be understood why the exile under the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) is more difficult than the exile of the nations of the world. For in the exile of the nations, Israel is subjugated under one nation in the place where they dwell, whereas in the exile of the Erev Rav, who are rooted in all the nations as explained by our Sages, Israel suffers under them from the aspect of all the nations. Each nation has its own negative trait, and among them, all the negative traits are gathered together from the root of all the nations, and understand this.
summary: The passage explains that the exile under the "Erev Rav" (mixed multitude) is more difficult for the Jewish people than the exile under the nations. In the exile of the nations, Jews are subjugated under one specific nation, whereas the Erev Rav embodies the negative traits of all nations combined. This results in a unique suffering, as the Jewish people endure the collective negative attributes of all nations simultaneously, highlighting the profound spiritual challenges posed by the Erev Rav.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יתבאר דברי הזוה"ק דדחיל משה מן המקטריגים בעת מכת הארבה (עיין לעיל העתק לשונו) שנתעוררו בעת ההוא דייקא ע"י גזירת הארבה שהוא משרשם, ואף שלא הוסיפו על הארבה להרע למצרים, אבל קטרגו על ישראל ע"י שעוררו אותם בשמותם וע"ד דאיתא במד"ר ר"פ וישלח (פר' ע"ה סי' ג') שמואל בר נחמן אמר משל לארכילסטים (פרש"י שר לסטים) שהי' ישן בפרשת דרכים, עבר חד ושרי מעיר לי' (התחיל לעורר אותו משינתו) קם ושרי מקפח בי' וכו', א"ל ניער בישא, א"ל דמיך הו' ועוררתני כך א"ל הקב"ה לדרכו הי' מהלך ואתה משלח אצלו וכו' עיי"ש, ועד"ז לעניננו כי ע"י הזכרת שמות שרי האומות שלמעלה ע"י גזירת הארבה והילק וכו', נתעוררו גם הם ובאו לקטרג על ישראל, וע"כ דחיל משרע"ה מקטרוגם בעת ההוא, ועייל לי' קוב"ה בחדרי חדרים גם יובנו דברי המהרוו"ח ז"ל כי משה צפה שהשטן מקטרג על יציאת ישראל ממצרים, ומסיבת זה לא הי' משה רוצה ליכנס לפרעה, ואמר השם אל משה בא אל פרעה ואל תפחד מקטרוג השטן כי כפרך נתתי בר"ה ואיהו איוב עכ"ל, ומקושר כל זה לפ' הארבה כי זה הי' סיבה על שנתעוררו בקטרוגם כנ"ל.
translation: And according to this, the words of the Zohar will be clarified, that Moses was afraid of the accusers at the time of the plague of locusts (see above for the text) who arose at that time specifically due to the decree of the locusts, which is from their root. And even though they did not add to the locusts to harm the Egyptians, they accused Israel by awakening them with their names. And as it is stated in the Midrash, Parashat Vayishlach (Parashat 45, Section 3), Shmuel bar Nachman said a parable about robbers who were sleeping at a crossroads. One passed by and began to awaken him from his sleep, he got up and began to rob him, etc. He said to him, "Shake off the bad," he replied, "You have awakened me like this," so said the Holy One, blessed be He, to him, "You were walking on your way, and you are sending to him," etc. See there. And similarly, in our matter, that through the mention of the names of the ministers of the nations above, due to the decree of the locusts and the like, they were also aroused and came to accuse Israel. Therefore, Moses was afraid of their accusations at that time, and the Holy One, blessed be He, entered with him into the innermost chambers. This also explains the words of the Maharal, may his memory be blessed, that Moses foresaw that the Satan was accusing regarding the departure of Israel from Egypt, and because of this, Moses did not want to go to Pharaoh. And the Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and do not be afraid of the accusations of the Satan, for I have given you a counter in Rosh Hashanah, and he is Job." Thus, all this is connected to the plague of locusts, for this was the reason that they were aroused in their accusations as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual opposition during the plague of locusts, highlighting how the mention of the names of the nations' angels provoked them to accuse Israel. It illustrates that Moses, aware of this spiritual contention, hesitated to confront Pharaoh due to the fear of these accusations. God reassured Moses, emphasizing that He had already granted him authority over such challenges. This reflects the Hasidic understanding of the interplay between divine will, human action, and the spiritual forces that influence earthly events.

passage_content: ולזה דייק הכתוב לומר למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, דהנה שורש שם הארבה נאמר על שרי אומה"ע וכנ"ל, ומין הארבה למטה בארץ נקרא ע"ד השאלה באותן האותיות עצמם שנקראים שרי מעלה המקטריגים, וז"ש הקב"ה למשרע"ה מה שאני שולח הארבה למצרים, לא תחשוב שאף שרי המקטריגים יבואו שהם שורש השם זה בעצם, לא כן הוא רק אותן הנקראים באותיות של הארבה בדרך שאלה הם יבואו על פרעה ועל מצרים, ועפי"ז יובן מה שהסמיכו בזוה"ק הפסוק אשרי העם יודעי תרועה לפ' הארבה, עפימ"ש בנבואת יואל אחר מכת הארבה (יואל ב' א') תקעו שופר בציון. קדשו צום קראו עצרה וגו', מבואר דמסגולת השופר לבטל גזירה זו דארבה, ואף שהוצרכו גם לצירוף התשובה כמבואר בפסוקים שם, מ"מ גם כח השופר סייע לבטל הגזירה, וסגולה זו לא הי' לפרעה והוכרח לבקש ממשרע"ה שיעתיר בעדו להסיר ממנו את המות הזה, ואפשר דע"כ הסמיכו בזוה"ק לפ' הארבה ר"י פתח אשרי העם יודעי תרועה שרק ישראל יש להם סגולת השופר המבטל גזירות רעות ומערבב המקטריגים משא"כ האומה"ע.
translation: And for this, the verse is precise in saying, "for the sake of these two signs within him," for behold, the root of the name of the locust is said about the ministers of the nations of the world, as mentioned above, and the kind of locust below on the earth is called according to the question in those very letters that are called the ministers above who are the accusers. And this is what the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe: "What I am sending the locust to Egypt, do not think that even the ministers of the accusers will come, for they are the root of this name in essence; rather, those who are called by the letters of the locust in the form of a question will come upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt." And according to this, it will be understood why the Zohar connects the verse "Happy is the people that know the sound of the shofar" to the locust plague, as it is stated in the prophecy of Yoel after the plague of locusts (Yoel 2:1), "Blow the shofar in Zion, sanctify a fast, call for an assembly," it is explained that it is the merit of the shofar to annul this decree of locusts, and although they also needed the combination of repentance as explained in the verses there, nevertheless, the power of the shofar also helped to annul the decree. And this merit was not for Pharaoh, and he was compelled to ask Moshe to pray for him to remove this death from him. And it is possible that this is why they connected in the Zohar to the verse about the locusts, "Happy is the people that know the sound of the shofar," for only Israel has the merit of the shofar that annuls bad decrees and confuses the accusers, unlike the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the locust plague in the context of divine judgment and intercession. It emphasizes that while the locusts are associated with the celestial accusers, their impact is specifically directed at Pharaoh and Egypt, highlighting the unique spiritual status of the Jewish people. The text underscores the power of the shofar to annul negative decrees, a privilege exclusive to Israel, contrasting it with the inability of the nations to invoke such spiritual protection. Ultimately, it illustrates the relationship between repentance, divine mercy, and the efficacy of the shofar in averting calamities.

passage_content: עוד יתבאר בענין הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי הגמ' (ב"ק קט"ז ע"ב) במתני' שם הגוזל שדה מחבירו ונטלוה מסיקין, (פרש"י אנסין גזלוה מן הגזלן) אם מכת מדינה היא אומר לו הרי שלך לפניך אם מחמת הגזלן חייב להעמיד לו שדה אחר, ופירשו בגמ' אמר רנב"י מאן דתני מסיקין לא משתבש, ומאן דתני מציקין לא משתבש, מאן דתני מציקין וכו' דכתיב במצור ובמצוק (דברים כ"ח), ומאן דתני מסיקין לא משתבש דכתיב (דברים כ"ח) יירש הצלצל ומתרגמינן יחסניני' סקאה, פרש"י צלצל ארבה גזלן הוא שאוכל תבואות כל אדם עכ"ל, וכתבו התוס' יחסניני' סקאה פי' בקונטרס ארבה, כמו ומעלה את הסקאין (במס' תענית ו' ע"א) שהוא מין ארבה, ואין נראה לר"ת, דלשון ירושה ואחסנתא משמע דאבני אדם איירי, ונטלוה מסיקין נמי איירי בבנ"א, ונראה שהאויב קרי סקאה שעולין ומכסין את הארץ כדכתיב הנה כסה את עין הארץ וע"ש כך נקרא צלצל שמכסה כל הארץ כצל וכו' עכ"ד ר"ת, ולבסוף מסקו בתוס' ונראה דירושה שייכא שפיר בעופות וחיות כמו וירשוה קאת וקפוד (ישעי' ל"ד) ע"כ, ולמסקנת דבריהם יל"פ יירש הצלצל על הארבה כפרש"י, אלא דמסיקין דמתני' בעכ"ח בבנ"א איירי, וגם לפרש"י מסיקין דמתני' בגזלן בנ"א מיירי ולא בארבה כמ"ש הרא"ש ז"ל הובא בשטמק"צ וז"ל פרש"י סקאה ארבה וכו', וגזלן קורא מסיק במתני', אבל אינו גובאי ממש דא"כ מאי מחמת הגזלן, וכי אין הארבה אוכל אלא שדות של אדם אחד עכ"ד ז"ל.
translation: It will be further explained regarding the aforementioned matter, by prefacing the words of the Gemara (Baba Kamma 116b) in the Mishnah there about one who steals a field from his friend and they take it from him. (Rashi explains: they forcibly took it from the thief.) If it is a matter of state law, he says to him, "Here is yours before you," but if it is due to the thief, he is obligated to provide him with another field. The Gemara explains: Rabbi Natan ben Yochai said, "Whoever teaches 'they take' does not err," and "whoever teaches 'they trouble' does not err," and "whoever teaches 'they trouble' etc., as it is written, 'in siege and in distress' (Deuteronomy 28), and "whoever teaches 'they take' does not err, as it is written (Deuteronomy 28), 'the locust will inherit,' and we translate 'yachasnin' as 'the locust,' Rashi explains: 'the locust' is a thief that consumes the crops of everyone." Thus wrote the Tosafot: "Yachasnin" means 'locust,' like 'and raises the locusts' (in Taanit 6a), which is a type of locust, and it does not seem correct to R"T, for the term 'inheritance' and 'yachasanta' implies that it refers to human beings. And 'they take' also refers to human beings. It seems that the enemy is called 'skah' because they rise and cover the land, as it is written, 'behold, it covers the eye of the land,' and therefore it is called 'tzeltzel' which covers the entire land like a shadow, etc." Thus concluded R"T. And in the end, the Tosafot concluded that it seems that 'inheritance' applies well to birds and animals, like 'the kite and the raven will inherit' (Isaiah 34). Therefore, according to the conclusion of their words, it can be understood that 'the locust will inherit' refers to the locust as Rashi explained, except that 'they take' in the Mishnah refers to human beings, and also according to Rashi, 'they take' in the Mishnah refers to a thief who is a human being and not to locusts, as stated by the Rosh, may his memory be blessed, brought in the Shitah Mekubetzes, and Rashi's words are: 'skah' is locust, etc. A thief is called 'taking' in the Mishnah, but he is not a true collector, for if so, what does it mean 'due to the thief'? And does the locust only consume the fields of one person? Thus concluded his words, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the Talmudic interpretation of a case involving a thief who steals a field, emphasizing the distinction between different types of theft and the responsibilities of the thief. It highlights the concept of "Mikdash" (sanctuary) and the idea that the thief must compensate the victim, reflecting a deeper theological principle of justice and restoration in the community. The discussion also touches on the metaphor of locusts as a representation of destruction and the need for divine intervention to restore balance. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of ethical behavior and accountability within the framework of Jewish law.

passage_content: נמצא בין לדעת רש"י ז"ל ובין לדעת התוס' שם הארבה סקאה, וגזלן בנ"א נקרא ג"כ בלשון משנה סקאה כשם הארבה, ע"ש שאומנתו כמעשה הארבה גוזל בנ"א, עיין בדברינו (פ' שמות עמוד צ"ח) כי האומה"ע נמשלו לחיות הטורפות כמ"ש בזוה"ק שמות (ג' ע"א) ממעונות אריות אלין בני שעיר וכו' מהררי נמרים אלין בני ישמעאל וכו', עפ"י הנודע כי באדם בעל בחירה כלול בו כוחות של כל הנבראים, ובידו להטיב או להרע, ואם אוחז במידות חיות הטורפות הוא גרוע ומסוכן הרבה יותר מהם, כמ"ש בזוהר הקדוש פרשת וישב (קפ"ה ע"ב) זעירין אינון דיכלי לאשתזבא מינייהו עיין שם, ועל כן המתדמין ועושים כמעשיהם, יאות להם להקרא בשמותם, וכמו כן לעניננו בשמות הארבה שנקראים כן על שם גזלנותא, כמו שכתב הרד"ק ז"ל (יואל א' ד') נקרא גזם על שם שגוזז את התבואה, וילק לפי שהוא לוקק ולוחך את העשב, וחסיל לפי שהוא כורת את הכל, וע"כ האנס וגזלן בנ"א יקרא בשמם ע"ש שעושה כמעשיהם, ומפורש כן במתני' לפי' רש"י והתוס' ז"ל.
translation: It is found between the opinion of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, and the opinion of the Tosafists there, that a robber of people is also called in the language of the Mishnah "saka" like the locust, because his profession is like that of the locust which robs people. Refer to our words (Parashat Shemot, page 178) that the nations of the world are compared to predatory animals, as it is written in the Zohar, Shemot (3:1) from the dens of lions, these are the sons of Seir, etc., from the mountains of leopards, these are the sons of Ishmael, etc., according to the known principle that in a person with free will are included the powers of all created beings, and it is in his hands to do good or evil. And if he holds the traits of predatory animals, he is much worse and more dangerous than they are, as it is written in the holy Zohar, Parashat Vayeshev (135b), "They are small who are able to be removed from them," refer there. And therefore, those who imitate and act like them, it is fitting for them to be called by their names. Likewise, in our matter, the names of the locusts are called so because of their robbing nature, as the Radak, may his memory be blessed, wrote (Joel 1:4) that it is called "gizem" because it cuts the grain, and "yilek" because it licks and grazes the grass, and "chasid" because it cuts everything. Therefore, the rapist and robber of people will be called by their name because he acts like them, and this is explicitly stated in the Mishnah according to the explanation of Rashi and the Tosafists, may their memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the comparison between human behavior and the predatory nature of certain animals, particularly locusts, which are seen as symbols of theft and destruction. It emphasizes that humans, endowed with free will, possess the potential for both good and evil, and those who emulate the destructive traits of predatory creatures are deemed even more dangerous. The text highlights the idea that individuals who engage in harmful actions are rightfully associated with the names of these destructive beings, reflecting their moral and ethical choices. This connection underscores the Hasidic belief in the profound impact of one's actions and character on their spiritual identity.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל בכוונת דברי רש"י ז"ל, במ"ש לחלק בין ארבה שבימי יואל, דשם הי' ע"י מינין הרבה וכו' אבל של משה לא הי' אלא של מין אחד וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' עכ"ל, והקשו בעה"ת והרמב"ן ז"ל שהרי מפורש בס' תהלים שגם במצרים הי' ארבה ילק וחסיל, ולדרכנו אפ"ל כוונתו כי בשל יואל הי' ע"י מינין הרבה ארבה ילק חסיל וגזם, שבאו גם מאומה"ע לבוז ולשלול שדותיהם של ישראל, דכיון שיצאה גזירה על הארבה שיכלה שדותיהם של ישראל, מצאה מדת הדין מקום לחול, ובאו גם מאומה"ע הנקראים כן ע"ש מעשיהם, ונרמז כן בדברי התרגום יוב"ע (שהבאנו לעיל) שמפרש עה"פ ושלמתי לכם את השנים אשר אכל הארבה הילק והחסיל והגזם וגו', ואשלם לכון שניא טבתא חלף שניא דבזו יתכון פלחי כוכביא אומיא ולישניא ושלטוניא ומלכותא פורעניות חילי רבא דשלחות בכון עכ"ל, ואלמלי לא היו נועלין חלק בפורעניות א"כ תשלומין למ"ל ומאי עבידתי', אלא ודאי שגם הם היו כלולים במכת הארבה המפורש בקרא, ולזה כתב רש"י ז"ל לחלק דשם הי' ע"י מינין הרבה משא"כ ארבה שבימי משה לא הי' אלא של מין אחד בלבד, ר"ל שלא הי' ממין בעלי בחירה הנקראים ג"כ בשם הארבה ילק וכו' ע"ש מעשיהם, כי כך גזרה חכמתו ית' שלא יבואו על מצרים כ"א מין בע"ח בלבד וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' ריבוי עצום ממין בע"ח בלבד, משא"כ הפלגת הארבה שבימי יואל הי' לצד שהי' כלול ממינים הרבה כנ"ל ולז"א הכתוב כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם וא"ש.
translation: And similarly, one could say regarding the intention of the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, in what he wrote to distinguish between the locusts in the days of Joel, where there were many kinds, etc., but in the case of Moses, there was only one kind, and there was none like it, nor will there be. Thus, the Baal HaTurim and the Ramban, may their memories be blessed, questioned this, for it is explicitly stated in the Book of Psalms that there were also locusts, yelek, and chasil in Egypt. According to our path, one could say that his intention was that in the case of Joel, it was due to many kinds of locusts: yelek, chasil, and gazam, which also came from the nations of the world to plunder and destroy the fields of Israel. Since a decree was issued regarding the locusts that would consume the fields of Israel, the attribute of justice found a place to take effect, and they also came from the nations of the world, which are called so according to their deeds. This is hinted at in the words of the Targum Yonatan (which we brought above) that explains the verse, "And I will repay you the years that the locust, the yelek, and the chasil have eaten," etc., and I will repay you for the years that the plowers of the nations and the rulers and the kingdoms of great calamities have sent upon you. And if they had not locked a portion in calamities, then what would be the repayment for the labor? Rather, it is certain that they were also included in the plague of locusts explicitly mentioned in the verse. Therefore, Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote to distinguish that there it was due to many kinds, whereas the locusts in the days of Moses were only of one kind, meaning that there was none from the kind of creatures that are also called by the name locust, yelek, etc., according to their deeds. For thus did the wisdom of the Blessed One decree that only one kind of animal would come upon Egypt, and there would not be a great multitude of one kind of animal alone. In contrast, the multitude of locusts in the days of Joel was due to the fact that it included many kinds, as mentioned above, and thus the verse states, "None like it will be in the world," and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the locust plagues during the times of Joel and Moses, emphasizing that Joel's plague involved multiple species of locusts, which symbolized a broader divine judgment that included nations hostile to Israel. In contrast, the plague in Egypt was limited to a single species, reflecting God's specific decree. This differentiation highlights the theological concept of divine justice and the idea that the severity of punishment can vary based on the circumstances and the nature of the transgressors involved. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that God's wisdom governs the nature and extent of divine retribution.

passage_content: ועפי"ז אפ"ל במאמה"כ את אשר התעללתי במצרים פרש"י שחקתי וצ"ב ענין השחוק מהו, ומדוע קרא למכה זו שחוק, אמנם אמרז"ל במד"ר כיון שבא ארבה שמחו המצריים וכו', ולדרכנו אפ"ל כי כאשר שמע פרעה מגזירת הארבה, וידע כי נרמזו בשמותם גם האומה"ע הנקראים כן, וחשב כי יבואו גם הם בצירוף הארבה ויעשה עמהם שלו' ללחום בישראל, כדרך האומה"ע אף אם שונאים זא"ז משתווים בעצה אחת נגד ישראל, כדמצינו במדין ומואב, ולזה שמחו המצריים, אבל נהפכה שמחתם לתוגה כי הי' המכה רק לרעתם, ולא באו רק מין הארבה של בע"ח שהמית בהם ואכל כל אשר להם, ולא נצמח להם ממנו הנאה של כלום וז"ש התעללתי שחקתי.
translation: And according to this, one can say in the verse, "that which I have played with in Egypt," Rashi explains, "I have laughed," and it is unclear what the matter of laughter is, and why he called this plague "laughter." However, our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash that when the locust came, the Egyptians rejoiced, etc. And according to our path, one can say that when Pharaoh heard the decree of the locust, and knew that they were hinted at in their names, also the nations of the world that are called so, he thought that they would also come together with the locust and make peace with them to fight against Israel, as is the way of the nations, even if they hate each other, they unite in counsel against Israel, as we find with Midian and Moab. Therefore, the Egyptians rejoiced, but their joy turned to sorrow because the plague was only for their detriment, and they did not come except for the kind of locust that killed them and consumed all that they had, and they did not derive any benefit from it at all. And this is what is meant by "I have played, I have laughed."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine irony in the plagues of Egypt, particularly focusing on the plague of locusts. It highlights how the Egyptians initially rejoiced at the arrival of the locusts, believing they would use them to unite against Israel, reflecting a common theme of nations banding together against the Jewish people. However, their joy turned to sorrow as the locusts brought destruction rather than benefit, illustrating the idea that what seems advantageous to the oppressors ultimately leads to their downfall. This reflects a deeper theological insight into God's control over events and the ultimate futility of opposing His will.

passage_content: (מכתי"ק) ה' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי וגו' למען שיתי אותותי אלה בקרבו וגו', וצ"ב מה שאמר למען שתי אותותי אלה שלא אמר זה בשאר מכות, גם למה לא אמר מופתי כמו שאמר בשאר מקומות, גם הלשון אלה שאמר כאן אינו מובן. גם מה שאמר רש"י ז"ל שתי שימי שאשית אני צ"ב, דבוודאי ידעינן שהכל היא עשי' מהקב"ה ולמה פרט את זה במכת הארבה דייקא, גם מה שאמר אח"כ ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' וידעתם כי אני ה' צריך להבין למה דוקא במכת הארבה אמר כן ולא בשאר מכות. גם מה שאמר את אשר התעללתי ופירש"י ז"ל שחקתי אינו מובן האיך שייך ע"ז לשון שחוק הלא הוכה במכות מופלאות ואינו בגדר שחוק.
translation: (From the handwritten notes) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc., in order that I may place these signs of Mine in his midst, etc." It is puzzling why He said "in order that I may place these signs of Mine" and did not say this regarding the other plagues. Also, why did He not say "My wonders" as He did in other places? Furthermore, the term "these" that He used here is not clear. Additionally, what Rashi, of blessed memory, said about "two times that I will place" is puzzling, for we certainly know that everything is an act of the Holy One, Blessed be He, so why did He specify this regarding the plague of locusts specifically? Also, what He said afterward, "and in order that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc., and you shall know that I am the Lord," needs to be understood as to why He said this specifically regarding the plague of locusts and not regarding the other plagues. Moreover, what He said, "that which I have dealt harshly," and Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that it means "I have laughed," is not understood; how does the term "laughter" apply here when He was struck with wondrous plagues and it is not in the realm of laughter?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the significance of God's communication to Moses regarding the plagues, particularly the locust plague, emphasizing the unique mention of "signs" and the specific language used. The text raises questions about why certain phrases and concepts are highlighted in this context, suggesting a deeper theological insight into God's intention to demonstrate His power and instill faith in future generations. The reference to "laughter" in relation to the plagues is also examined, indicating a complex understanding of divine intervention and the nature of suffering. Overall, the passage reflects on the importance of recognizing God's actions and their implications for faith and memory within the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: וליישב כ"ז אקדים דברי המד"ר כאן (פ' י"ג סי' ה') מהו הנני מביא מחר ארבה בגבולך ולא בגבול בני חם, וע"ז נאמר (ישעי' כ"ו) כי כאשר משפטיך לארץ צדק למדו וגו' שבמכת הארבה הכירו עד היכן גבול מצרים, וצריך להבין שכעין זה כבר אמור במכת הצפרדעים במד"ר (וארא פ' י' סי' ב') וז"ל שם: רז"ל אמרו המכות שהביא הקב"ה על המצריים גרם להם שיעשו שלום ביניהם, כיצד הי' מחלוקת בין בני כוש ובין בני המצרים, המצרים אומרים עד כאן תחומינו והכושים אומרים עד כאן תחומינו, כיון שבאו הצפרדעים עשו שלו' ביניהם, הגבול שהיו נכנסות לתוכו הדבר ידוע שאין השדה של כוש, שנאמר את כל גבולך, גבולך ולא של אחרים עכ"ד המדרש, וא"כ קשה אמרם ז"ל שבמכת הארבה הכירו עד היכן גבול מצרים, הלא כבר הי' ניכר זה ממכת הצפרדעים, ומה יוסיף תת כח להכרה זו עדות הארבה יותר מעדות הצפרדעים, גם קשה שבמכת הארבה מקרא הוא דורש על ככה, שע"ז נאמר בישעי' כי כאשר משפטיך לארץ צדק למדו וגו', ובמכת הצפרדעים שהוא מוקדם לא הזכירו דרשת הכתוב וטעמא בעי.
translation: To address this, I will first present the words of the Midrash here (Parashat Yitro, Section 5): "Behold, I will bring tomorrow a locust swarm into your borders, and not into the borders of the sons of Ham." And concerning this it is said (Isaiah 26), "For as your judgments are learned in the land, righteousness." In the plague of locusts, they recognized the extent of the borders of Egypt. It is necessary to understand that something similar was already mentioned in the plague of frogs in the Midrash (Va'era, Parashat 10, Section 2), where it is stated: "Our Sages said that the plagues which the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought upon the Egyptians caused them to make peace among themselves. How was there a dispute between the sons of Cush and the Egyptians? The Egyptians said, 'Up to here is our boundary,' and the Cushites said, 'Up to here is our boundary.' When the frogs came, they made peace among themselves, for the boundary into which they entered is known to be not the field of Cush, as it is said, 'All your borders, your borders and not those of others.'" Thus, the Midrash concludes. Therefore, it is difficult to understand their statement that in the plague of locusts they recognized the extent of the borders of Egypt, for this was already evident from the plague of frogs. What additional strength does the testimony of the locusts provide over the testimony of the frogs? It is also difficult that in the plague of locusts, the verse is interpreted in this manner, as it is said in Isaiah, "For as your judgments are learned in the land, righteousness," while in the plague of frogs, which is earlier, they did not mention the interpretation of the verse, and the reason is needed.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plagues in Egypt, particularly the plagues of frogs and locusts, as a means for the Egyptians to recognize their territorial boundaries. It highlights a Hasidic interpretation that the plagues not only served as divine punishment but also fostered a sense of unity among the Egyptians, who were previously in conflict over their borders. The text raises questions about the distinct lessons learned from each plague, emphasizing the deeper theological insight that God's justice and order are revealed through these events, ultimately leading to a recognition of divine authority and moral order in the world.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר בהקדם המסורה וינח הארבה וינח ביום השביעי, ופי' בבעה"ט ז"ל מלמד שנח הארבה בשבת, ונתקשו המפורשים מדוע דייקא הארבה נח בשבת ולא שאר המכות, ואפשר לומר לפענ"ד דהנה הא"ע כתב במכת דם שהי' גם בישראל, וכן בשאר המכות לא הי' הפרש בין מצרים לישראל, זולתי באותן המכות שמבואר בקרא שהפלא ה' בין מצרים לישראל, וחלקו עליו שהרי במכת דם מבואר בפי' בדברי חכז"ל (מד"ר פר' ט' סי' י') שאצל המצריים הי' דם ואצל ישראל הי' מים, ומשם נתעשרו ישראל שהיו מוכרין מים למצריים, וכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל במכת הערוב בפסוק והפלתי וגו' בעבור היות המכות הראשונות עומדות, איננו פלא שיהיו בארץ מצרים ולא בארץ גושן, אבל זו מכה משולחת וכאשר יעלו החיות ממעונות אריות ומהררי נמרים וישחיתו כל ארץ מצרים, ראוי הי' בטבעם שיבואו גם בארץ גושן אשר היא מכלל ארץ מצרים בתוכה, לכן הוצרך לומר והפלתי ארץ גשן, שתנצל כולה בעבור שעמי עומד עלי' עכ"ל, הרי שברור לדעתו ז"ל שגם כל המכות הראשונות לא הי' במקום מושבותם של ישראל, ולא הוצרך הכ' לפרט זה, אלא במכת ערוב טעמא אית בי' שהוצרך הכ' לפרש, אולם במכת הארבה כתב האבן עזרא (בפסוק שמות ז' כ"ד) טעם נכון שהי' גם במחנה ישראל ולא מצינו חולק על דבריו לא בדברי חכז"ל ולא בשאר מפורשים, והוא טעמא דמסתבר שהרי ישראל יצאו ממצרים טרם זמן הקציר, ובפרט לפי מ"ש הרמב"ן שמכת הארבה הי' בחודש ניסן אחר שצמחו החטה והכוסמת והתחילו העצים להוציא פרח וכו' ואז כבר ידעו ישראל שהגיע עת גאולתם כי בר"ח ניסן נאמר להם פ' קרבן פסח ונתבשרו שבליל ט"ו יתגלה להם הקדוש ברוך הוא ויגאלם, וא"כ כל הנצמח בשדה בניסן הי' נשאר הכל למצרים אחר שיצאו משם ישראל, וא"כ לא הי' שום טובה לישראל אילו לא אכל הארבה בשדותיהם, אלא למצרים בלבד הי' טובה, כי אך להם הי' נשאר מה שהי' בשדותיהם של ישראל, וא"כ אילו הי' הנס גם במכת הארבה להפליא בין מצרים לישראל, הוו זה ניסא למגנא אך לטובת מצרים, וע"כ מסתברין בזה דברי האבן עזרא, בפרט שלא מצינו ע"ז חולק בפירוש.
translation: And it can be said in advance of the tradition that the locusts rested and rested on the seventh day, and the Ba'al HaTurim, of blessed memory, explains that the locusts rested on Shabbat. The commentators were perplexed as to why specifically the locusts rested on Shabbat and not the other plagues. It can be said, in my humble opinion, that behold, the Abarbanel wrote regarding the plague of blood that it was also among the Israelites, and similarly, in the other plagues, there was no distinction between Egypt and Israel, except for those plagues that are explicitly stated in the verse that the Lord made a distinction between Egypt and Israel. They argued against him, for in the plague of blood it is explained in the words of our Sages (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat 9, Section 10) that among the Egyptians there was blood and among the Israelites there was water, and from there the Israelites became wealthy as they sold water to the Egyptians. The Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote regarding the plague of wild beasts in the verse "And I will make a distinction..." that since the first plagues were standing, it is not surprising that they were in the land of Egypt and not in the land of Goshen. However, this plague is unleashed, and when the beasts rise from the dens of lions and from the mountains of leopards and devastate all the land of Egypt, it was fitting by their nature that they would also come to the land of Goshen, which is part of the land of Egypt. Therefore, it was necessary to say "And I will make a distinction in the land of Goshen," so that it would be entirely spared because My people are standing upon it. Thus, it is clear according to his opinion, of blessed memory, that even all the first plagues were not in the dwelling places of the Israelites, and the verse did not need to specify this except in the plague of wild beasts, for there was a reason that required the verse to explain. However, regarding the plague of locusts, the Abarbanel wrote (in the verse Exodus 7:24) a correct reason that it was also in the camp of Israel, and we do not find anyone disputing his words, neither in the words of our Sages nor in other commentators. And it is reasonable, for the Israelites left Egypt before the time of the harvest, especially according to what the Ramban wrote that the plague of locusts occurred in the month of Nisan after the wheat and the barley had sprouted and the trees began to blossom, etc. Then the Israelites already knew that the time of their redemption had arrived, for on the first of Nisan they were told about the Paschal offering and were informed that on the night of the fifteenth the Holy One, blessed be He, would reveal Himself to them and redeem them. Therefore, everything that sprouted in the field in Nisan would remain for the Egyptians after the Israelites left there. Thus, there would be no benefit for the Israelites if the locusts did not eat in their fields, but only for the Egyptians would there be benefit, for only what remained in the fields of the Israelites would be for them. Therefore, if the miracle of making a distinction between Egypt and Israel had also occurred in the plague of locusts, it would have been a miracle only for the benefit of the Egyptians. Hence, the words of the Abarbanel are reasonable in this matter, especially since we do not find anyone disputing this in the commentary.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of locusts, which affected both Egypt and Israel, unlike the previous plagues that distinguished between the two. It emphasizes that the locusts' arrival during the month of Nisan, when the Israelites were anticipating their redemption, served a purpose for the Israelites by ensuring that the crops would not benefit the Egyptians after their departure. The text highlights the theological insight that God's intervention in the natural order was specifically aimed at protecting the Israelites and facilitating their eventual liberation, reinforcing the theme of divine providence in their redemption.

passage_content: נמצא לפי"ז שהי' הפרש בין שאר המכות למכת הארבה, שכולם לא היו בישראל כ"א אצל המצריים בלבד ומכת הארבה הי' גם ברשותם של ישראל, מעתה יש לנו טעם מספיק מה שכל המכות לא שבתו בשבת כ"א מכת הארבה בלבד, דכל המכות שהיו רק על המצרים בלבד אין להם שייכות לשמירת שבת כלל, ואף הגהינם אינו שובת בשבת אלא לשומרי שבת ולא לאותן שלא שמרוה בעוה"ז, משא"כ מכת הארבה שבא גם ברשות ישראל שהיו שומרי שבת גם במצרים כאמרז"ל לכן שבת ונח בשבת ולמדו ישראל מזה כחו של שבת כמו שאמרו חכז"ל נהר סמבטיון יוכיח שנח בשבת.
translation: It is found according to this that there was a distinction between the other plagues and the plague of locusts, that all the other plagues were only upon the Egyptians and not upon Israel, whereas the plague of locusts was also in the domain of Israel. From this, we have sufficient reason why all the plagues did not cease on Shabbat except for the plague of locusts, for all the plagues that were only upon the Egyptians have no connection to the observance of Shabbat at all, and even Gehenna does not rest on Shabbat except for those who observe Shabbat, and not for those who did not observe it in this world. In contrast, the plague of locusts came also in the domain of Israel, who were Shabbat observers even in Egypt, as our Sages of blessed memory said, therefore it rested and ceased on Shabbat, and Israel learned from this the power of Shabbat, as our Sages of blessed memory said, the river Sambatyon will testify that it rests on Shabbat.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the plagues of Egypt, particularly the plague of locusts, emphasizing that while other plagues affected only the Egyptians, the locusts also impacted the Israelites, who were observing the Sabbath. This connection allows for the understanding that the plague of locusts is significant in relation to the sanctity of the Sabbath, as it demonstrates the power of Sabbath observance even in a foreign land. The text highlights that the concept of rest on the Sabbath applies to those who uphold its sanctity, contrasting with the fate of those who do not. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological insight that the observance of the Sabbath transcends physical boundaries and affirms its importance in the lives of the faithful.

passage_content: ואפשר לפרש בזה מאמר הכתוב למען שיתי וגו' פירש"י ז"ל שיתי שימי שאשית אני, כי הקב"ה שומר משמרתו של תורה, ואמרו חז"ל שהקב"ה מקיים גם דברי חכמים, ולכן המכות ששמשו גם בשבת לא הי' שליחותם מהקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו, כ"א ע"י מערכת השמים שאינם שומרי תורה כנודע כי תורה לא בשמים הוא. משא"כ מכת הארבה ששבת ונח בשבת כדת של תורה, בא בשליחותו של הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו, ולכן אמר במכת הארבה שיתי שימי שאשית אני, ובחי' זו לא הי' בשארי המכות, ולכן עדות של הארבה מכוונת יותר ללמוד ממנו דין ומשפט, לפי שבא בשליחותו של הקב"ה כדת של תורה בשמירת שבת, משא"כ הצפרדעים שעשו מלאכתן גם בשבת אין במעשיהם סמיכה כ"כ כנז"ל, ובזה יובן מה שבמכת הארבה אמר שע"ז נאמר כאשר משפטיך לארץ צדק למדו, כי ממכת הארבה אפשר ללמוד משפט צדק כהלכה, אבל במכת הצפרדעים לא הביאו רז"ל דרשת הקרא ללמוד מהם צדק אלא שהמצריים והכושיים שאינם מרגישים ולא איכפת להו אם הוא מסטרא דקדושה או לא, כי המה וכל עניניהם כולם רק מסט"א, לכן עשו שלו' ע"י מכת הצפרדעים בלבד ולא הוצרכו יותר.
translation: And it is possible to interpret the statement in the verse "for I will set" etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "set" means "I will set," because the Holy One, blessed be He, guards the watch of the Torah. And our Sages have said that the Holy One, blessed be He, also fulfills the words of the sages. Therefore, the plagues that also served on Shabbat did not have their mission from the Holy One, blessed be He, in His honor and essence, but rather through the celestial system, which are not guardians of the Torah, as it is known that the Torah is not in the heavens. In contrast, the plague of locusts, which rested and ceased on Shabbat according to the law of the Torah, came by the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, in His honor and essence. Therefore, regarding the plague of locusts, it is said, "I will set," meaning "I will set," and in this aspect, it was not so with the other plagues. Thus, the testimony of the locusts is more directed towards learning law and justice, since it came by the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, according to the law of the Torah in the observance of Shabbat. In contrast, the frogs, which performed their work even on Shabbat, do not have their actions as firmly established, as mentioned. And in this, it can be understood what was said regarding the plague of locusts, that for this it was said, "When Your judgments are upon the earth, righteousness will be learned," for from the plague of locusts one can learn righteous judgment according to the law. However, regarding the plague of frogs, our Sages did not bring a homiletical interpretation to learn righteousness from them, but rather that the Egyptians and the Cushites, who do not feel and do not care whether it is from the side of holiness or not, for they and all their matters are only from the side of the other side, therefore they made peace only through the plague of frogs and did not need more.
summary: The passage discusses the divine nature of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that while God oversees the Torah and its observance, certain plagues, like the frogs, were executed through celestial forces that do not uphold the Torah. In contrast, the plague of locusts was directly commanded by God, reflecting a higher level of divine authority and adherence to the principles of justice and law. This distinction highlights that the locust plague serves as a model for understanding justice, as it aligns with the Torah's teachings, whereas the frogs represent a lesser spiritual significance. Ultimately, the text illustrates the importance of divine involvement in upholding justice and the Torah's authority in the world.

passage_content: וי"ל עוד עפ"י פשוטו דמה שאמר גבולך ולא גבול אחרים אפשר לפרשו בשני פנים, די"ל גבולך קאי על גבול המדינה שזה גורם לגזירת המכה, גם אפשר לפרש בלשון גבולך דהגזירה הי' על גבול היחידים שבאותו האומה וכמ"ש בתוה"ק (שמות י"ג ז') ולא יראה לך שאור בכל גבולך דקאי על גבול פרטי של כאו"א מישראל, ואין נ"מ באיזה מדינה הוא אלא רשותו וגבולו של ישראל גורם האיסור, ולכן במכת הצפרדעים דחזינן שלא הי' אצל ישראל אף שהיו דרים בתוך הגבול של מדינת מצרים, וא"כ ע"כ שאין הפי' גבולך האמור שם על גבול המדינה, אלא על גבול פרטי של אנשי אומה מצרים בכל מקום שהם דרים, וא"כ אין ראי' גם בהיפוך דבכל מקום שהיו הצפרדעים דהוי' בתוך גבול המדינה, שהרי אינו תלוי בגבול המדינה אלא בגבול דירת אנשי האומה, ובכל מקום שדרו אנשי האומה הוי זה בגבולם אף שהיא מחוץ למדינה, משא"כ במכת הארבה שהי' גם אצל ישראל, א"כ לא הי' הגזירה דווקא על האומה, שהרי ישראל אינם בכלל האומה של מצרים, וע"כ שרק המקום גורם, ומה שהוא בגבול מדינת מצרים הי' בכלל הגזירה, וא"כ שפיר הוי ראי' דבכ"מ שהי' מכת הארבה הוי בכלל מדינת מצרים ולא מדינת כוש, ולכן לא הביאו במדרש דרשת הקרא ללמוד מזה אלא במכת הארבה לא במכת הצפרדעים.
translation: It can also be explained according to its simple meaning that what is said "your border" and not "the border of others" can be interpreted in two ways. One could say that "your border" refers to the border of the state, which causes the decree of the plague. It can also be interpreted in the sense of "your border" that the decree was on the border of the individuals of that nation, as it is written in the Torah (Exodus 13:7) "and you shall not see leaven in all your borders," which refers to the private border of each individual of Israel. There is no difference in which state it is, but rather the authority and border of Israel causes the prohibition. Therefore, in the plague of frogs, we see that it was not upon Israel even though they were dwelling within the border of the land of Egypt. Thus, it follows that the meaning of "your border" mentioned there is not on the border of the state, but rather on the private border of the people of the nation of Egypt wherever they dwell. Therefore, there is no proof even in the opposite case that wherever the frogs were, they were within the border of the state, for it does not depend on the border of the state but on the dwelling border of the people of the nation. In every place where the people of the nation dwelled, it is considered within their border even if it is outside the state. This is unlike the plague of locusts, which was also upon Israel, thus the decree was not specifically on the nation, since Israel is not included in the nation of Egypt. Therefore, only the place causes it, and what is within the border of the land of Egypt was included in the decree. Hence, it is indeed a proof that wherever the plague of locusts was, it was within the land of Egypt and not the land of Cush. Therefore, they did not bring in the Midrash a homiletical interpretation from this except in the plague of locusts, not in the plague of frogs.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of boundaries in relation to divine decrees, emphasizing that the term "your boundary" refers not only to national borders but also to the individual spiritual boundaries of the people. It suggests that the plagues, such as the frogs, affected only the Egyptians and not the Israelites, highlighting that divine judgment is based on the spiritual state of individuals rather than their geographical location. In contrast, the plague of locusts impacted both Egyptians and Israelites, indicating that the decree was tied to the broader context of the Egyptian nation. This distinction underscores the idea that spiritual boundaries and individual righteousness play a crucial role in the experience of divine judgment.

passage_content: ומה שאמרו רז"ל במדרש שעוד במכת הצפרדעים עשו המצריים שלו' עם הכושים י"ל דאף דפרעה ידע מהנעשה במדינתו שאצל ישראל לא היו הצפרדעים, אבל הכושים שהם מחוץ למדינה י"ל שלא ידעו מזה, ופרעה הטעה אותם ולא הודיעם שלא היו הצפרדעים אצל ישראל, כדי להביא ראי' על הגבולים שבכ"מ שנכנסו הצפרדעים הוי מדינת מצרים ולא של כושים, והכושים בטעות עשו עי"ז שלו' ביניהם, אבל במכת הארבה הי' העדות אמת וראי' וודאית, וע"כ הביאו רז"ל דרשת הקרא כאשר משפטיך לארץ צדק למדו אצל מכת הארבה דייקא.
translation: And what our Sages said in the Midrash, that even during the plague of frogs, the Egyptians made peace with the Cushites, can be understood that although Pharaoh knew what was happening in his land, that there were no frogs among the Israelites, the Cushites, who were outside the land, may not have known this. Pharaoh deceived them and did not inform them that there were no frogs among the Israelites, in order to bring proof that wherever the frogs entered, it was the land of Egypt and not that of the Cushites. The Cushites mistakenly made peace among themselves because of this. However, during the plague of locusts, the testimony was true and the proof was certain. Therefore, our Sages brought the interpretation of the verse "as Your judgments are for the land, righteousness" specifically in connection with the plague of locusts.
summary: The passage discusses the plagues of Egypt, particularly the plague of frogs and the subsequent plague of locusts, highlighting the deception of Pharaoh towards the Egyptians and the Cushites. It suggests that while Pharaoh was aware that frogs did not afflict the Israelites, he misled the Cushites, who were unaware of this fact, leading them to mistakenly believe they were in a state of peace. In contrast, the plague of locusts served as a clear and undeniable testimony of God's judgment, reinforcing the idea that divine justice is evident in the natural order. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of recognizing God's presence and justice in the unfolding events of the world.

passage_content: א"י גם באופן אחר דהנה במכת הצפרדעים כתיב ויעשו כן החרטומים בלהטיהם ויעלו הצפרדעים על ארץ מצרים, א"כ הי' מעורב בין הצפרדעים גם מאותן שהעלו חרטומי מצרים. א"כ לכאורה אין ראי' ברורה ממ"ש במדרש הגבול שהיו נכנסות לתוכו הדבר ידוע שאין השדה של כוש שנאמר את כל גבולך גבולך ולא של אחרים, שהרי הציווי את כל גבולך נאמר רק על הצפרדעים שבאו ע"י משה ואהרן בשליחותו של הקב"ה, אבל לא על הצפרדעים שהעלו החרטומים בלהטיהם, ויוכל להיות שכן עשו החרטומים בכוונה, שהצפרדעים שהעלו בלהטיהם יכנסו גם לתוך אותו הגבול שלקחו מהכושים, וצ"ל שלא גילו זאת להכושים שיש בין אותן הצפרדעים גם מה שהעלו בלהטיהם ולא נכללו במאמר ד' את כל גבולך, כי מה שעשו החרטומים בלהטיהם הי' לגבי משה ואהרן להקטין כח הנס, שיוכלו להגיד על מעשה משה ואהרן שהוא כשפים ואינו אצבע אלקים אבל להכושים הוצרכו לומר שדברי משה ואהרן אמת מה שאומרים בשם ה' את כל גבולך, שאילו ח"ו לא הי' אמת אלא מעשה כשפים בעלמא אין להביא משם ראי' לעשות דין שאין מביאין ראי' מדברי שקרים, ובלא"ה אין דברי הקוסמים מדוקדקים כ"כ להביא ראיות מדקדוק לשונם וכמ"ש הרמב"ם (בפ' ו' מהלכות יסודי התורה) שהמעוננים והקוסמים וכיוצא בהם מקצת דבריהם מתקיימים ומקצתן אין מתקיימים אך הנביא כל דבריו קיימים שנאמר כי לא יפול מדבר ה' ארצה יעיי"ש, וצ"ל שיען שרצו להחזיק באותו הגבול שלקחו מהכושים שהי' ע"ז מחלוקת מהכושים, והביאו אז ראי' מלשונם הקדוש של משה ואהרן שאמרו בשם ה' גבולך, הוצרכו לומר להכושים שכל דברי משה ואהרן אמיתים בשם ה', ועכ"ח שהעלימו מהכושים מה שהכחישו במקומם את משה ואהרן ואמרו עליהם שאין דבריהם אלא דברי קוסמים בלבד, וממילא שהעלימו ג"כ מה שעשו להעלות עוד צפרדעים בלהטיהם, לכן יכלו להביא ראי' משם ונעשה שלו' בין הרשעים, אבל באמת הי' בטעות ע"י שהעלימו מן הכושים שמעורב כח אחר באותן הצפרדעים מה שבא מהחרטומים בעצמם בכח טומאתם, משא"כ אחר מכת הכנים שהוכרחו להודות גם לפני משה ואהרן ואמרו אצבע אלקים הוא וכמ"ש חז"ל שלא יכלו להוציא את הכנים מפני שאין השד שולט על פחות מכשעורה, ומבואר שם במד"ר (פ' י' סי' ז') שאז הכירו שהיו כל המעשים מעשה אלקים ולא מעשה שדים ומאז לא ניסו עוד לדמות עצמן למשה להוציא המכות, וכן כתב הרמב"ן ז"ל בפסוק אצבע אלקים הוא וז"ל כי בראות החרטומים שלא יכלו להוציא את הכנים הודו במעשה משה ואהרן שהי' מאת האלקים ולכן לא קרא אותם פרעה מן העת הזאת והלאה עכ"ל, נמצא דבמכת הארבה שהי' אח"כ לא עשו עוד החרטומים מאומה ולא הי' מעורב בתוכה שום כח אחר, אלא כל הארבה הי' מה שבא ע"י משה ואהרן בשם ה' שע"ז נאמר גבולך ולא גבול אחרים והוי ראי' וודאית שבכ"מ שנכנס הארבה לתוכו הוא גבול מצרים, ולכן לא הביא המדרש דרשת הקרא דצדק למדו אלא במכת הארבה בלבד לא במכת הצפרדעים שהי' מעורב בתוכו כח הטומאה ואינו אלא ראי' מוטעת.
translation: The Land of Israel also in another way, for behold, in the plague of frogs it is written, "And the magicians did so with their enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt." Therefore, it was mixed among the frogs also those that the Egyptian magicians brought up. Thus, seemingly, there is no clear proof from what is said in the Midrash regarding the boundary that they entered into it; it is known that the field of Cush is said to be "your entire boundary," and not that of others, since the command "your entire boundary" was only said regarding the frogs that came through Moses and Aaron by the agency of the Holy One, Blessed be He, but not regarding the frogs that the magicians brought up with their enchantments. It could be that the magicians intentionally caused the frogs they brought up with their enchantments to also enter into that boundary that they took from the Cushites, and it must be that they did not reveal this to the Cushites, that among those frogs were also those that they brought up with their enchantments, and they were not included in the statement of the Holy One, "your entire boundary," because what the magicians did with their enchantments was, in relation to Moses and Aaron, to diminish the power of the miracle, so that they could say about the act of Moses and Aaron that it was sorcery and not the finger of God. However, to the Cushites, they needed to say that the words of Moses and Aaron were true in the name of the Lord, "your entire boundary," for if, Heaven forbid, it were not true but merely an act of sorcery, one cannot bring proof from there to make a judgment, as one does not bring proof from false words. Moreover, the words of the sorcerers are not so precise as to bring proofs from the exactness of their language, as the Rambam wrote (in chapter 6 of the Laws of the Foundations of the Torah) that the astrologers and sorcerers, and the like, some of their words are fulfilled and some are not fulfilled, but the prophet's words are all fulfilled, as it is said, "For the word of the Lord will not fall to the ground." It must be that since they wanted to hold on to that boundary that they took from the Cushites, which was a matter of dispute with the Cushites, they brought a proof from the holy language of Moses and Aaron, who said in the name of the Lord, "your boundary," they needed to tell the Cushites that all the words of Moses and Aaron were true in the name of the Lord. And thus, they concealed from the Cushites that they denied Moses and Aaron in their place and said about them that their words were merely the words of sorcerers. Consequently, they also concealed what they did to bring up more frogs with their enchantments. Therefore, they could bring proof from there, and there was peace among the wicked. But in truth, it was a mistake due to their concealment from the Cushites that another power was mixed in with those frogs, which came from the magicians themselves through their impurity. This is unlike after the plague of lice, when they were forced to admit even before Moses and Aaron and said, "It is the finger of God," as our Sages have said that they could not bring forth the lice because the demon does not have power over less than a barley grain. It is explained there in the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, section 7) that then they recognized that all the acts were acts of God and not acts of demons, and since then they did not try to liken themselves to Moses to bring forth the plagues. Thus, the Ramban wrote in the verse "It is the finger of God," and he said that when the magicians saw that they could not bring forth the lice, they admitted to the act of Moses and Aaron that it was from God, and therefore Pharaoh did not call them from that time onward. It follows that in the plague of locusts that came afterward, the magicians did nothing further, and no other power was mixed in it, but all the locusts were what came through Moses and Aaron in the name of the Lord, for which it was said, "your boundary," and not the boundary of others, and it is a certain proof that wherever the locusts entered, it is the boundary of Egypt. Therefore, the Midrash did not bring the interpretation of the verse "righteousness they learned" except in the plague of locusts alone, not in the plague of frogs, which was mixed in it with the power of impurity and is nothing but a mistaken proof.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the frogs brought by Moses and Aaron through divine command and those conjured by the Egyptian magicians, emphasizing that the latter lacked true divine authority. It highlights that the magicians attempted to diminish the significance of Moses and Aaron's miracles by attributing them to sorcery, while the true power of God was only recognized after the plague of lice, which the magicians could not replicate. Consequently, the subsequent plague of locusts was solely attributed to the divine intervention of Moses and Aaron, reinforcing the idea that God's miracles are unequivocal and distinct from the illusions of sorcery. This underscores the theological concept that true divine acts cannot be conflated with human deception or magic.

passage_content: וי"ל עוד באופן אחר דהנה באותן הלאווין שאסרה התוה"ק לשוב מצרימה כמ"ש חז"ל (פתיחתא דאסתר רבתי סי' ג') בג' מקומות הזהירה התורה ע"ז, איכא פלוגתא בין הראשונים ז"ל די"א שהטעם הוא בשביל האומה של מצרים שדרין שם, וממילא אחר שבא סנחרב ובלבל את כל העולם כולו וכל דפריש מרובא פריש, ואין שם אותו האומה נתבטל האיסור, אבל רוב ראשונים לא ס"ל כן אלא גם עכשיו האיסור במקומו עומד, וכן נראה דעת הרמב"ם והרא"ה גם הסמ"ג והרא"ם והריטב"א והגהות מיימוני ועוד כמה ראשונים שכולם טרחו לבקש טעם על מה סמכו כמה גדולים שהיו דרים במצרים ע"כ ס"ל שאינו תלוי בהאומה אלא גם עכשיו אסור. ועי' מנ"ח (מצוה ת"ק) שהביא פלוגתא זו בקצרה, ולפי דעת רוב הראשונים שאינו תלוי בהאומה אלא במדינת מצרים, צ"ל שהמקום גורם שכל מה שהוא בגבול מצרים אסרה התוה"ק, ולפי"ז אותו הפלוגתא שהי' בין מצרים והכושים עד היכן הוא גבול מצרים גם לנו נ"מ גדולה לדינא, שכל מה שהוא בכלל גבול מצרים אסור לדור שמה ומוזהרין בלאווין דאורייתא ומה שהוא מגבול כושים אינו בכלל האיסור כלל.
translation: It can also be explained in another way: behold, regarding those prohibitions that the Torah has forbidden to return to Egypt, as our Sages have said (in the opening of Esther Rabbah, chapter 3), the Torah warns against this in three places. There is a dispute among the early authorities, some say that the reason is because of the nation of Egypt that dwells there, and consequently, after Sanheriv came and confused the entire world, and whoever separates from the majority separates, and since that nation is no longer there, the prohibition is nullified. However, the majority of the early authorities do not hold this view, but rather that even now the prohibition remains in its place. This is also the opinion of the Rambam, the Ra'ah, as well as the Semag, the Ra'am, the Ritva, and the Maimonides' glosses, and several other early authorities who all labored to seek a reason for why some great ones who lived in Egypt relied on this. Therefore, they hold that it is not dependent on the nation but that it is also forbidden now. And see the Minchat Chinuch (mitzvah 640) who briefly brought this dispute. According to the opinion of the majority of the early authorities, which is not dependent on the nation but on the land of Egypt, it must be that the place causes that everything within the borders of Egypt is forbidden by the Torah. According to this, the dispute that existed between Egypt and the Cushites regarding where the borders of Egypt extend is also significant for us in law, as everything that is within the borders of Egypt is forbidden to dwell there and is warned against with Torah prohibitions, while that which is from the borders of the Cushites is not included in the prohibition at all.
summary: The passage discusses the prohibition against returning to Egypt as outlined in the Torah, highlighting a debate among early authorities regarding its applicability. Some argue that the prohibition is tied to the presence of the Egyptian nation, while the majority maintain that it is inherently linked to the geographical location of Egypt itself. This distinction emphasizes that the sanctity of the land and its borders carries theological significance, suggesting that the Torah's commandments are not solely dependent on the people residing there but also on the inherent nature of the land. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of understanding the boundaries of prohibitions in relation to divine commandments.

passage_content: והנה בגבולי א"י טרחה התוה"ק בפ' מסעי לכתוב פרשה גדולה בכמה פסוקים להודיע מצרני גבולי רוחותי' סביב, וכתב הרמב"ן בס' המצות דלכן כתבה התוה"ק כל מצרני גבולי' סביב, יען שיש מ"ע בישוב א"י לכן הוצרך להודיע מהיכן מתחיל המקום לקיום המצוה ורש"י לשיטתו שסובר שאין מ"ע בישיבת הארץ כאשר הביא הרמב"ן עצמו שכן דעת רש"י ז"ל, לכן פי' שם (בפ' מסעי) עה"כ זאת הארץ לפי שהרבה מצות נוהגות בארץ ואין נוהגות בחו"ל הוצרך לכתוב מצרני גבולי רוחותי' סביב, לומר לך מן הגבולים הללו ולפנים המצות נוהגות עכ"ל הרי שכיון שיש נפק"מ במצות דאורייתא הוצרכה התוה"ק להאריך לכתוב כל גבולי הארץ, שא"א לסמוך על מדת הגבול שחושבין בנ"א מעצמם במידי דאורייתא אם אין לזה ראי' מהתוה"ק, וא"כ גם במצרים שיש איסור לאוין דאורייתא בגבול אותה המדינה, ע"כ צורך גדול להודיע לנו מצרני גבולי רוחותי' סביב לידע מהיכן מתחיל האיסור, ולא נמצא בזה שום רמז ורמיזא לא בקראי ולא בגמ' ולא בפוסקים, ואיך נוכל לידע מהיכן מתחיל האיסור, גם אותה הפלוגתא שבין מצרים לכושים אשר נתברר ע"י הצפרדעים והארבה, אין אתנו יודע עד מה, איפוה גבול המקום שלמדו צדק מהצפרדעים והארבה, ומה שאפשר לידע באיזה השערה מספרי האומות זה וודאי אינו מוסמך כלל להלכה במידי דאורייתא, ולא ראיתי מי שיתעורר בזה והוא לפלא בעיני
translation: And behold, in the borders of the Land of Israel, the Holy Torah took the trouble in Parashat Masei to write a large section with several verses to inform us of the boundaries of its borders all around. The Ramban wrote in the Book of Commandments that therefore the Holy Torah wrote all the boundaries surrounding it, because there is a positive commandment in settling the Land of Israel; thus, it was necessary to inform us from where the place begins for the fulfillment of the commandment. And Rashi, according to his opinion, who holds that there is no positive commandment in residing in the land, as the Ramban himself brought, so Rashi explained there (in Parashat Masei) on the verse "This is the land" that since many commandments are applicable in the land and not applicable outside of it, it was necessary to write the boundaries surrounding it, to tell you that from these boundaries and inward, the commandments are applicable. Thus, since there is a practical difference in the commandments of the Torah, the Holy Torah needed to elaborate and write all the borders of the land, for one cannot rely on the measure of the boundary that people consider for themselves in matters of the Torah if there is no proof from the Holy Torah. And therefore, even in Egypt, where there is a prohibition of negative commandments of the Torah regarding the boundary of that country, there is a great need to inform us of the boundaries surrounding it to know from where the prohibition begins. And there is no hint or indication found in the verses, nor in the Gemara, nor in the Poskim, and how can we know from where the prohibition begins? Also, the dispute between Egypt and the Cushites, which was clarified by the frogs and the locusts, we do not know until what point the boundary of the place is that learned justice from the frogs and the locusts. And what can be known in any estimation from the books of the nations is certainly not authoritative at all for halacha in matters of the Torah, and I have not seen anyone who has been aroused about this, and it is a wonder in my eyes.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of clearly defining the boundaries of the Land of Israel as outlined in the Torah, emphasizing that the commandments associated with the land are significant and cannot be based solely on human estimations. It highlights the differing opinions of the Ramban and Rashi regarding the obligation of residing in the land, underscoring the necessity of divine guidance in understanding the boundaries and the implications for observance of commandments. The text also raises concerns about the lack of clarity regarding prohibitions in neighboring regions, illustrating the need for precise knowledge rooted in Torah to navigate these complexities.

passage_content: אמנם יתבאר עפי"ד הרמב"ן (בפ' זו) בפסוק ואחריו לא יהי' כן שכתב ר"ח שמעת עתירת משה רבינו עד עכשיו אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים ואם יפול בא"י ויבוא ויכנס בגבול מצרים, אינו אוכל מכל יבול הארץ כלום עד עכשיו, ואמר כי זה כבר דבר ידוע הוא לכל וכו' וע"ז נאמר שיחו בכל נפלאותיו עכ"ל יעיי"ש, והכלי יקר פי' בזה מה שאמר הכתוב במכת הארבה ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולא אמר כן בשאר מכות, כי בשאר המכות ארכו הימים והכל נשכח, אבל במכת הארבה נשאר רושם לדורות גם אחר הסרת המכה, כי ברוב הימים ימצאו הדורות דבר חידוש, ויראו כי יבוא ארבה ולא יאכל כלום מכל יבול מצרים יעיי"ש שהאריך.
translation: Indeed, it will be explained according to the words of the Ramban (in this chapter) regarding the verse "And afterward it shall not be so," as R' Chaim wrote that since the time of Moshe Rabbeinu until now, locusts do not cause loss in all the borders of Egypt, and if they fall into Eretz Yisrael and come and enter the borders of Egypt, they do not eat anything from the produce of the land until now. And he said that this is already a well-known matter to all, etc. And concerning this, it is said, "Speak of His wonders" (Tehillim 105:2). The Kli Yakar explains this regarding what the scripture says about the plague of locusts, "And in order that you may tell in the ears of your son," etc., and it does not say so regarding the other plagues, for in the other plagues the days were prolonged and everything was forgotten. But in the plague of locusts, a mark remained for generations even after the plague was removed, for in most days the generations will find something new, and they will see that locusts come and do not eat anything from the produce of Egypt, as he elaborated.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of locusts in Egypt, emphasizing that it serves as a lasting reminder of God's wonders. Unlike other plagues, which may fade from memory over time, the locusts left a distinct mark, demonstrating that even when they invade, they do not consume the produce of the land. This phenomenon is presented as a divine sign, reinforcing the idea that God's power and intervention in the world are evident and should be recounted to future generations. The text highlights the importance of remembering and teaching these miraculous events as a means of connecting with the divine.

passage_content: ולפי"ז נשאר לנו ידיעה והבחנה לידע ולהבחין עד היכן המה גבולי מצרים, שבכל מקום שאנו רואים שאף אם בא יבא הארבה לא יאכל משם כלום, בוודאי זה גבול מצרים וכמ"ש הר"ח שזה דבר ידוע לכל, וכמו שנתברר אז המחלוקת שבין מצרים לכושים ע"י מכת הארבה, כמו כן נשאר בירור זה לדורות ממכת הארבה על כל גבולי מצרים. אלא שבדורות האחרונים אין לנו ידיעה גם מזה, כי בדורות האחרונים גדול כח ההסתרה בכל הפרטים, ואמרו חכז"ל (בב"ר פר' מ"ב סי' ג') אין לך שעה קשה מזה שנאמר ואנכי הסתר אסתיר.
translation: According to this, we have knowledge and discernment to know and distinguish until where the borders of Egypt are, that in every place we see that even if the locusts come, they will not eat anything from there, certainly this is the border of Egypt, as the Rach explains, this is a well-known matter to all. And just as the dispute between Egypt and the Cushites was clarified through the plague of locusts, so too this clarification remains for generations from the plague of locusts on all the borders of Egypt. However, in recent generations, we have no knowledge even of this, for in recent generations the power of concealment is great in all details, and our sages of blessed memory said (in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 42, Section 3) that there is no more difficult hour than this, as it is said, "And I will surely hide My face."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of boundaries, specifically the limits of Egypt, as symbolized by the plague of locusts that did not consume anything beyond these borders. It highlights the clarity of this distinction in earlier generations, contrasting it with the current era where the concealment of divine presence is more profound, making it difficult to discern these boundaries. The text references a teaching from the sages about the severity of this concealment, emphasizing the theological insight that in times of great obscurity, understanding and recognition of spiritual truths become challenging.

passage_content: ובזה מיושב היטב מה שהביא במדרש רק במכת הארבה הקרא דכאשר משפטיך לארץ צדק למדו יושבי תבל, כי ממכת הארבה נשאר לנו לימוד קבוע לדורות, לידע גבול מצרים היכן מתחיל האיסור, אבל במכת הצפרדעים שלא נשאר לנו משם שום זכר לדורות, אלא אז בעת ההוא הי' מזה בירור לעשות שלו' בין הרשעים מצרים וכושים, ומאי איכפת לנו בזה, הלא כינוס לרשעים רע להם ורע לעולם וכמו שפי' רש"י ז"ל שיכולים עי"ז להתיעץ יחד להרע, ואין שלו' אמר ה' לרשעים, ועכ"פ מאי דהוי הוי ולא נשאר אח"כ שום זכר אי' המקום ההוא, לכן לא הביא ע"ז הקרא שאמר ישעי' צדק למדו, אבל במכת הארבה יש מזה לימוד לכלל ישראל לדורות כמו שנתבאר.
translation: And with this, it is well understood what is brought in the Midrash only regarding the plague of locusts, the verse "For as Your judgments are upon the earth, the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness," for from the plague of locusts we have a fixed lesson for generations, to know the boundary of Egypt where the prohibition begins. However, regarding the plague of frogs, we have no remembrance from there for generations, except at that time there was a clarification to create peace between the wicked Egyptians and the Cushites, and what does it matter to us? After all, the gathering of the wicked is bad for them and bad for the world, as Rashi explains that they can thereby consult together to do evil, and there is no peace, says the Lord, for the wicked. And in any case, whatever was, was, and there remains no remembrance of that place afterwards; therefore, the verse that says "righteousness they learned" was not brought for this. But regarding the plague of locusts, there is a lesson from it for all of Israel for generations, as has been explained.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plagues in Egypt, particularly contrasting the plague of locusts with that of frogs. It emphasizes that the plague of locusts left a lasting lesson for future generations, specifically regarding the boundaries of Egypt and the prohibition associated with it. In contrast, the plague of frogs did not leave any enduring memory or teaching, as it served only to clarify the distinction between the wicked Egyptians and the Israelites at that time. This reflects a broader theological insight that God's judgments are purposeful, providing lessons for the righteous while the wicked ultimately face consequences without lasting impact.

passage_content: ומעתה נחזור לענינינו לפרש משאה"כ למען שתי אותותי אלה וגו' עפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה בישמח משה (פ' תשא) לפרש הפסוק כי אות היא ביני וביניכם וגו' עפי"ד השלה"ק כי ס"ר נשמות לישראל וס"ר שבתות, שי"ן אלפים בשית אלפי שני, וש' אלפים ביום שכולו שבת דהוא אלף השביעי, וכל נשמה נחצבה משבת אחד וכו', והיינו כי אות היא, דידוע דס"ר אותיות לתורה וכל נשמה יש לה אות אחת, ויובן מזה שכל שבת נחצב ג"כ מאות אחת, וא"כ כל שבת ושבת הוא ממש איזה אות בתורה, כל שבת אות אחר וזה שאמר כי אות היא עכ"ל, ולהלן בפסוק אות הוא לעולם האריך עוד יותר להסביר הדברים, דמיום שנברא העולם כל שבת ושבת מתייחס לאות אחר מהתוה"ק ולנשמה אחרת המתייחסת לאותו השבת ולאותו האות מהתוה"ק יעיי"ש, וכתב באוהחה"ק (פ' בראשית) עה"כ כי בו שבת וגו' שמיום ברא אלקים אדם על הארץ לא חסר מעולם דבר המעמיד צדיק יסוד עולם שהוא שומר שבת, ולולא זאת לא הי' אפשרות לעולם לעמוד ואפי' במצרים היו שומרי שבתות יעיי"ש.
translation: And from now on, let us return to our matter to explain the verse "for the sake of these two signs" etc., as it is explained in Psalm 107, "May Moses rejoice" (Parashat Tisa) to interpret the verse "for it is a sign between Me and you" etc., according to the words of the Shelah HaKadosh that there are 600,000 souls for Israel and 600,000 Shabbatot, which are 1,000 in six thousand years, and 1,000 in the day that is entirely Shabbat, which is the seventh millennium, and each soul is hewn from one Shabbat, etc. This means that it is a sign, for it is known that there are 600,000 letters in the Torah and each soul has one letter, and it can be understood from this that each Shabbat is also hewn from one letter, and thus each Shabbat is indeed a specific letter in the Torah, each Shabbat a different letter, and this is what is meant by "for it is a sign." Furthermore, in the verse "a sign is forever," it elaborates even more to explain the matters, that from the day the world was created, each Shabbat is related to a different letter from the Holy Torah and to a different soul that is connected to that Shabbat and to that letter from the Holy Torah, as you can see there. And it is written in the Ohev Yisrael (Parashat Bereishit) on the verse "for in it He rested" etc., that from the day God created man on the earth, there has never been a lack of something that upholds the righteous, the foundation of the world, which is the one who observes the Shabbat, and without this, it would not be possible for the world to stand, and even in Egypt there were Shabbat observers, as you can see there.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Jewish soul, the Sabbath, and the Torah, emphasizing that each soul is linked to a specific letter of the Torah, with each Sabbath representing a unique letter as well. It highlights that there are 600,000 souls corresponding to the 600,000 letters of the Torah, and each Sabbath is a manifestation of a different letter, reinforcing the idea that the observance of the Sabbath is essential for the world's existence. The text also notes that since the creation of the world, the observance of the Sabbath has been crucial for maintaining the stability of the universe, with even the Israelites in Egypt upholding this practice.
