passage_content: ולז"א ועתה אם שמע תשמעו בקולי ושמרתם את בריתי והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים, כפרש"י אוצר חביב, שיתירה חבתכם וחשיבות עבודתכם לפני, ונתברר כן לכל ממה שראיתם אשר עשיתי למצרים, נמצא שהי' צורך להכבדת לב, שעי"ז נתגדל כבוד שמים וכבוד התורה, ולז"א בא אל פרעה בשליחותי, כי אני הכבדתי את לבו, ואף שאין הקב"ה מייחד שמו ית' על הרעה, אבל זה הי' טובה גם להם, שנעשו כלים שעל ידם נתפרסם כבוד שמים וכבוד התורה, וז"ש למען שיתי אותותי אלה בקרבו ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו', שיכירו שאך בשביל ישראל עשיתי כל זה ויהי' זה להם להתחזקות בכל דורות הגלות, כי בעוה"ר ההסתרה גדולה והרשעים מתפארים לומר כל עושי רע טוב בעיני ד', נמצא שהי' הכבדת הלב טובה לדור ההוא ולכל דורות ישראל ונתרבה כבו"ש על ידו.
translation: And to explain, now if you will truly listen to My voice and keep My covenant, you will be a treasured people for Me from all the nations, as Rashi explains, a cherished treasure, which emphasizes your love and the importance of your service before Me. And it has been clarified from all that you have seen that I did to Egypt, that there was a need for the hardening of the heart, through which the honor of Heaven and the honor of the Torah were magnified. And to explain, come to Pharaoh in My name, for I have hardened his heart. And even though the Holy One, blessed be He, does not specifically attribute His name to evil, this was also a benefit for them, as they became vessels through which the honor of Heaven and the honor of the Torah were made known. And this is what is meant by "in order that I may place these signs of Mine in his midst and in order that you may tell in the ears of your son," etc., so that they recognize that it was only for the sake of Israel that I did all this, and this will serve as a source of strength for them in all generations of exile, for in our times the concealment is great and the wicked boast to say that all who do evil are good in the eyes of the Lord. Thus, the hardening of the heart was a benefit for that generation and for all generations of Israel, and the honor of the Holy One, blessed be He, was increased through it.
summary: The passage emphasizes the special relationship between God and the Jewish people, highlighting their unique status as a treasured possession among nations. It discusses the hardening of Pharaoh's heart as a means to elevate the honor of God and the Torah, demonstrating that even seemingly negative actions can serve a greater purpose. This serves as a reminder for future generations of Israel, reinforcing their faith amidst challenges and the apparent concealment of divine justice in the world. Ultimately, the hardening of the heart is portrayed as beneficial for both the immediate context and for all of Israel throughout history.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בענין הכבדת הלב, בהקדם לבאר פסוקי (הפטורת וארא יחזקאל כ"ט) שניבא יחזקאל על מצרים ונתתי את ארץ מצרים לחרבות חורב שממה וגו', לא תעבר בה רגל אדם ורגל בהמה לא תעבר בה ולא תשב ארבעים שנה וגו' ואמר עוד ונטשתיך המדברה וגו' על פני השדה תפול לא תאסף ולא תקבץ לחית הארץ ולעוף השמים נתתיך לאכלה, וידעו כל יושבי מצרים כי אני ד' יען היותם משענת קנה לבית ישראל, (פרש"י והמפרשים ז"ל שכל העונש הזה יבא עליהם יען היותם משענת קנה לבית ישראל, כי היו מבטיחים את ישראל להצילם מיד הכשדים ומפני בטחונם בהם מרדו במלך בבל ולא שמעו בקול הנביא ירמי' שהתרה בהם על החורבן כדאיתא בס' ירמי'), מן הממלכות תהי' שפלה וגו' ולא יהי' עוד לבית ישראל למבטח מזכיר עון בפנותם אחריהם וידעו כי אני ד' וגו'. ביום ההוא אצמיח קרן לבית ישראל ולך אתן פתחון פה בתוכם וידעו כי אני ד', וכתב רש"י ז"ל לא שמעתי ולא מצאתי פי' מקרא זה, מה הוא צמח קרנם של ישראל במפלת מצרים, שהרי ישראל גלו ח' שנים לפני מפלת מצרים והיו בגלות בבל ע' שנה, ואומר אני ביום ההוא מוסב על פרשה של מעלה מקץ מ' שנה אקבץ את מצרים, ואותו חשבון כלה בשנה שמלך בלשאצר, ומצינו בדניאל שבאותו שנה התחילו מלכי פרס להתחזק וכו', וזהו צמיחת קרן לישראל שנא' בכורש הוא יבנה עירי וגו' עכ"ל, אמנם לפירשו צ"ב סיומא דקרא ולך אתן פתחון פה וגו' דקאי על יחזקאל הנביא ולא הי' קיים עוד בזמן ההוא שנסתלק בימי נבוכדנצר.
translation: And I will say further regarding the matter of the hardening of the heart, to preface the explanation of the verses (from the Haftorah of Vaeira, Ezekiel 29) that Ezekiel prophesied about Egypt: "And I gave the land of Egypt to desolation and waste, etc., no foot of man shall pass through it, and no foot of beast shall pass through it, and it shall not be inhabited for forty years, etc." And he also said, "And I will leave you in the wilderness, etc., upon the field you shall fall, you shall not be gathered nor collected for the beasts of the earth and for the fowl of the heavens I have given you to eat," and they shall know all the inhabitants of Egypt that I am the Lord, because they were a broken reed for the house of Israel. (Rashi and the commentators explain that all this punishment will come upon them because they were a broken reed for the house of Israel, as they promised Israel to save them from the hands of the Chaldeans, and because of their trust in them, they rebelled against the king of Babylon and did not listen to the voice of the prophet Jeremiah who warned them about the destruction, as it is stated in the book of Jeremiah.) "From the kingdoms it shall be lowly, etc., and it shall no longer be a stronghold for the house of Israel, a reminder of sin when they turn after them, and they shall know that I am the Lord, etc." "On that day I will cause a horn to sprout for the house of Israel, and to you I will give a mouth to speak among them, and they shall know that I am the Lord." And Rashi wrote, "I have not heard nor found an explanation for this verse, what is the sprouting of the horn of Israel in the downfall of Egypt, since Israel was exiled eight years before the downfall of Egypt and was in exile in Babylon for seventy years." And I say that "on that day" refers to the section above, at the end of forty years I will gather Egypt, and that calculation concludes in the year that Belshazzar reigned, and we find in Daniel that in that year the kings of Persia began to strengthen, etc., and this is the sprouting of the horn for Israel, as it is said, "Cyrus, he will build my city," etc. However, regarding the explanation, the conclusion of the verse "and to you I will give a mouth to speak," etc., refers to the prophet Ezekiel, who was no longer alive at that time, as he was taken away in the days of Nebuchadnezzar.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic words of Ezekiel regarding the destruction of Egypt and its consequences for the Israelites, emphasizing that Egypt's downfall serves as a lesson for Israel, who relied on them for support against Babylon. The text highlights the idea that Israel's reliance on foreign powers leads to their own downfall, while God's promise of redemption and restoration is affirmed through the metaphor of a "horn" that signifies strength and renewal for Israel. The mention of Cyrus rebuilding Jerusalem illustrates the eventual divine intervention and the restoration of Israel after their exile. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the themes of faith, reliance on God, and the consequences of turning away from divine guidance.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה המצריים הרעו לישראל מאוד בהיותם בגולה בארצם, והשליכו זכוריהם ליאור והרגום ורמסום בטיט, ואעפ"כ לא נגזר עליהם עונש קשה כ"כ כמו בימי נבוכדנצר, שאף שלקו במכות ונטבעו בים, אבל ממלכת מצרים נשאר מלוכה גדולה וארצם לא הי' לשממה, ומדוע בימי נבוכדנצר נגזר עליהם עונש קשה הימנו לזה מפרש הכתוב יען היותם משענת קנה לבית ישראל, כי חלוק גדול יש בין כובד חטאם מאז לשל עכשיו, כי בימי משה גילו המצריים רשעתם וכובד לבם, וידעו ישראל שאין לצפות מהם טובה וחסד. ותלו עיניהם למרום ויצעקו בנ"י אל ד' ובטחו בישועתו ית' וידעו כי רק הוא ית' יכול להושיע ואין זולתו, ע"כ הספיק למדת עונשם שהוכו ונטבעו החוטאים לבדם, אבל ארצם ומלכותם לא נחרבה לשממה, משא"כ בימי נבוכדנצר היו למשענת קנה לבית ישראל, והסירו את לב ישראל מאחרי ד', שלא ישימו אל לבם נבואת החורבן, כי הם יעזורו להם להצילם מיד הכשדים, ובטחו ישראל בזרוע מלכותם, ע"כ נגזר עליהם מן הממלכות תהי' שפלה וגו' והמעטתים לבלתי רדות בגוים, ולא יהי' עוד לבית ישראל למבטח מזכיר עון בפנותם אחריהם וידעו כי אני ד' אלקים, דזהו הטעם לאיבוד ארצם ושפלות מלכותם, שלא יהיו עוד לישראל למבטח מזכיר עון בפנותם אחריהם, וידעו כי אני ד"א המושיע ואין זולתי, ולזה א"ש סיום הנבואה ביום ההוא אצמיח קרן לבית ישראל, דע"י מפלת מצרים יהי' צמיחת קרן לישראל שישיגו ישראל ממדת העונש המגיע עליהם, שאין לבטוח כ"א בהקב"ה לבדו ושוא תשועת אדם לבטוח בגבורת האומות, ועי"כ מזה יהי' צמיחת קרן לבית ישראל כי יזכו עי"ז לישועה, ולך אתן פתחון פה בתוכה, כי יתאמת בעיניהם דברי הנביא המוכיחם, ולא יבטחו עוד לדחות הפורעניות ע"י עזרת האומות.
translation: And it appears that the Egyptians greatly harmed Israel while they were in exile in their land, casting their males into the river, killing them, and trampling them in the mud. Nevertheless, a harsh punishment was not decreed upon them as it was in the days of Nebuchadnezzar, for although they were struck with plagues and drowned in the sea, the kingdom of Egypt remained a great monarchy, and their land was not laid waste. And why, in the days of Nebuchadnezzar, was a harsh punishment decreed upon them? The verse explains, due to their being a reed staff for the House of Israel, for there is a great difference between the weight of their sin then and now. In the days of Moses, the Egyptians revealed their wickedness and hard-heartedness, and Israel knew that they could not expect good and kindness from them. They lifted their eyes to the heavens and cried out, "The children of Israel to God," and trusted in His salvation, knowing that only He could save, and no one else. Therefore, the measure of their punishment sufficed, as the sinners were struck and drowned alone, but their land and kingdom were not destroyed to desolation. In contrast, in the days of Nebuchadnezzar, they were a reed staff for the House of Israel, and they turned the hearts of Israel away from God, so that they would not pay attention to the prophecy of destruction, believing that they would help them save themselves from the hands of the Chaldeans, and Israel trusted in the strength of their monarchy. Therefore, it was decreed upon them that from the kingdoms there would be lowliness, and they would be diminished so that they would not dominate the nations, and they would no longer be a reminder of sin for the House of Israel when they turned after them, and they would know that I am the Lord their God. This is the reason for the loss of their land and the lowliness of their kingdom, that they would no longer be a reminder of sin for Israel when they turned after them, and they would know that I am the Lord, the Savior, and there is no one else. And thus, the conclusion of the prophecy on that day, "I will raise up a horn for the House of Israel," signifies that through the downfall of Egypt, there will be a growth of a horn for Israel, as Israel will attain from the measure of the punishment that is due to them, that they should trust only in the Holy One, blessed be He, and that the salvation of man is in vain to trust in the might of the nations. And through this, there will be a growth of a horn for the House of Israel, for they will merit salvation through this, and to you I will give an opening of the mouth within it, for the words of the prophet will be confirmed in their eyes, and they will no longer trust to avert calamities through the help of the nations.
summary: The passage discusses the differing fates of the Israelites under Egyptian oppression and during the Babylonian exile, emphasizing that the Egyptians' cruelty led to a reliance on God for salvation, while the Israelites' trust in Babylonian power resulted in severe punishment. It highlights the importance of recognizing that true salvation comes solely from God, not from reliance on foreign nations. The text suggests that the downfall of Egypt will ultimately lead to the rise of Israel, reinforcing the idea that faith in God is the only true source of hope and redemption. This shift in reliance is seen as essential for the Israelites to understand their relationship with God and to avoid the pitfalls of misplaced trust.

passage_content: ולזה הי' צורך והכרח להכבדת לב פרעה, כי אלמלי הסכים פרעה מרצונו לשלחם, הי' זה למשענת קנה לבית ישראל, לבטוח בתשועת האומות, והי' ניגרם מזה הירוס וחורבן אף לדורות, שיעמדו מסיתים לישראל בדורות הגלות להסיר בטחונם של ישראל מהקב"ה, ושאפשר לגאולה ע"י חסד האומה"ע כמו שהי' במצרים. ולזה הי' משרע"ה נתיירא עכשיו לבוא אל פרעה, כי אחרי כל המכות כבר נתרכך לבבו, ופן יאבה לשלחם ברצונו, וזה יגרום ח"ו הריסה וחורבן לדורות, לז"א לו הקב"ה בא אל פרעה ואל תחוש שירצה לשלחם, כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותתי אלה בקרבו שיבואו עליו כל המכות וישלחם בעכ"ח מפני כובד המכות ולא מרצונו, והצורך לכל זה למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך את אשר התעללתי במצרים ואת אתתי אשר שמתי בם, כי לא אבו לשלוח עד אשר תמו ונשלמו כל המכות, ועי"ז וידעתם כי אני ד' המושיע ואין זולתי, ולא תבטחו בזרוע בשר ובעזרת האומה"ע.
translation: And for this, it was necessary and imperative to harden Pharaoh's heart, for had Pharaoh willingly agreed to send them away, it would have been a crutch for the House of Israel, to trust in the salvation of the nations, and this would have led to destruction and ruin even for future generations, as there would be instigators against Israel in the generations of exile to remove their trust in the Holy One, Blessed be He, and to suggest that redemption could come through the kindness of the nations, as it was in Egypt. Therefore, Moshe was now afraid to go to Pharaoh, for after all the plagues, his heart had already softened, and he might agree to send them away willingly, and this would cause, Heaven forbid, destruction and ruin for generations. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Go to Pharaoh and do not be concerned that he will want to send them away, for I have hardened his heart, etc., in order that these signs of Mine may come upon him, that all the plagues will come upon him, and he will send them away reluctantly due to the severity of the plagues and not of his own will. The necessity for all this is so that you may tell in the ears of your son and your son's son about what I did in Egypt and My signs that I placed upon them, for they did not want to send them away until all the plagues were completed, and through this you will know that I am the Lord, the Savior, and there is none besides Me, and you shall not trust in the strength of flesh and blood or in the assistance of the nations."
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity of hardening Pharaoh's heart to prevent him from willingly releasing the Israelites, which would lead to a reliance on human nations for salvation rather than on God. This divine strategy ensures that the Israelites recognize God's singular role as their savior, as they would only be freed after enduring all the plagues. The ultimate goal is to instill a lasting faith in future generations, teaching them to trust solely in God's power rather than in the might of nations.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר קישור המסורה ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולמען יאריכון ימיך וגו', שבזכות שתתחזק בטחונכם בישועת השי"ת ושאין זולתו שיגאלנו, עי"ז יצמיח קרן בית ישראל כהבטחת הנביא, ויזכו ישראל לירושת הארץ במהרה, וז"ש ולמען יאריכון ימיך על האדמה וגו', עוד אפ"ל עפ"י אמרם ז"ל (ב"ר פ' מ"ט סי' ד') כל המניח בן צדיק כאלו לא מת, וז"א למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו' וידעתם כי אני ד', ועי"ז למען יאריכון ימיך לעולם, אם תזכה להשריש בהם אמונת אומן שרק לד' הישועה ואין זולתו להושיע.
translation: And this will clarify the connection of the tradition, and in order that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc., and in order that your days may be prolonged, etc. For through the merit of strengthening your trust in the salvation of the Holy One, blessed be He, and that there is no other who will redeem us, through this the horn of the House of Israel will sprout, as promised by the prophet, and Israel will merit to inherit the land speedily. And this is what is meant by "and in order that your days may be prolonged upon the land," etc. Furthermore, it can be said according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 49, Section 4) that anyone who leaves a righteous son is as if he has not died. And this is the meaning of "in order that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson," etc., and you shall know that I am the Lord. And through this, "in order that your days may be prolonged forever," if you merit to instill in them a faith of truth that salvation is only from the Lord and there is no other to save.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of instilling unwavering faith in God's salvation within future generations, as this belief is linked to the continuity and longevity of life on earth. It suggests that by strengthening trust in God's unique ability to redeem, the Jewish people will witness the fulfillment of prophetic promises, including the inheritance of the land. Additionally, it highlights the significance of teaching children about God's presence and power, reinforcing the idea that a righteous lineage ensures spiritual immortality. Ultimately, the text underscores the centrality of faith in God's singular role as the source of salvation.

passage_content: ונל"פ עוד במאמה"כ כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותתי אלה וגו', דהנה משפט מצרים נמשך י"ב חודש כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, וכבר הקשה האוהחה"ק בפ' שמות עה"פ וארד להצילו וגו' כי למה האריך ד' י"ב חודש במכות מצרים וכו' והי' לו להביא המכות זו אחר זו ויגאלם מיד עיי"ש שפי' לדרכו. ואפ"ל עפימ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' בא) עה"פ ומושב בנ"י וגו' וז"ל ואם יהי' חשבון של אותיות רד"ו מסורת בישראל, יתכן שירמוז ליורדים עצמם, שאחרי מות יעקב יעמדו הם שם רד"ו שנים, עכ"ל. ולטעם זה הי' צורך להכבדת הלב שלא יאבה פרעה לשלחם עד כי יושלם זמן רד"ו, ולטעם זה נתארכו זמן המכות עד י"ב חודש כי אז הי' זמנם לצאת לא קודם לכן, וז"א כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, וקאי על ישראל שיתאמת אצלם האותיות רד"ו שהי' מסורת בישראל לקץ גאולתם.
translation: And we can further explain in the manner of our holy teachers that I have hardened his heart, etc., in order to perform these two signs of Mine, etc. Behold, the judgment of Egypt lasted twelve months, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, writes. The holy teacher has already asked in Parashat Shemot on the verse "And I have come down to save him," etc., why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, prolong the plagues of Egypt for twelve months, etc., and He could have brought the plagues one after the other and redeemed them immediately, as is explained there according to his approach. And it can be said according to what the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, writes (in Parashat Bo) on the verse "And the dwelling of the children of Israel," etc., that if there is a calculation of the letters of 216, it is a tradition in Israel, it is possible that it hints at the very descendents, that after the death of Jacob they would remain there for 216 years. Therefore, it was necessary for the hardening of the heart so that Pharaoh would not wish to send them until the time of 216 was completed, and for this reason the duration of the plagues was extended to twelve months, for then was their time to leave, not before. And this is what is meant by "I have hardened his heart," etc., in order that these two signs of Mine be established within him, and it refers to Israel that the letters of 216 would be confirmed for them, which was a tradition in Israel regarding the end of their redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the prolonged suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that God hardened Pharaoh's heart to ensure the completion of a predetermined period of 216 years before their redemption. This delay in the plagues, lasting twelve months, was necessary for the fulfillment of the prophetic tradition regarding the Israelites' suffering. The text highlights the importance of divine timing in the process of redemption, reinforcing the belief that God's plans unfold according to a specific, sacred timeline. Ultimately, this serves to strengthen the faith of the Israelites in the prophetic signs of their eventual liberation.

passage_content: או אפ"ל דאותתי רמז על אותות הדם דם פסח ודם מילה, שקראן הכתוב אות שנא' והי' הדם לכם לאות וגו', והי' צורך לגאולתן של ישראל שיקיימו ישראל ב' מצות אלו, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בשם מדרש ר' מתיא בן חרש שלא הי' בידם מצות וכו' כדי שיגאלו שנא' ואת ערום וערי' ונתן להם ב' מצות דם פסח ודם מילה וכו' ואומר (זכרי' ט') גם את בדם בריתך שלחתי אסיריך מבור אין מים בו וכו' עיי"ש, ולזה הי' צורך להכבדת הלב לעכב יציאתם עד ליל פסח שיקיימו ישראל ב' האותות שהי' הכרח לגאולתם, וז"א כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותתי אלה בקרבו של ישראל, וע"ד שכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה דמלת בקרבו קאי על ישראל עיי"ש.
translation: Or perhaps I hinted at the signs of the blood, the blood of the Passover and the blood of circumcision, which the scripture calls a sign, as it is said, "And the blood shall be to you for a sign," etc. It was necessary for the redemption of Israel that they fulfill these two commandments, as Rashi, of blessed memory, states in the name of the Midrash of Rabbi Mattiyah ben Charash, that they did not have the commandments, etc., in order to be redeemed, as it is said, "And He gave them two commandments, the blood of the Passover and the blood of circumcision," etc. And it says (Zechariah 9:11), "Also by the blood of your covenant I have sent forth your prisoners out of the pit wherein is no water," etc. Therefore, it was necessary to harden the heart to delay their departure until the night of Passover, so that Israel would fulfill the two signs that were essential for their redemption. And this is what is meant by "For I have hardened his heart," etc., for the sake of these two signs within Israel, and according to what is written, "Let Moses rejoice," may his memory be blessed, that the word "within" refers to Israel, as noted there.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the blood of the Passover lamb and the blood of circumcision as essential signs for the redemption of the Israelites. It emphasizes that these two commandments were necessary for their salvation, as indicated by the verse stating that the blood would serve as a sign for them. The text also highlights that God hardened Pharaoh's heart to ensure that the Israelites would fulfill these commandments, which were crucial for their liberation. Ultimately, it reflects on the deep connection between these rituals and the spiritual readiness of the Jewish people for redemption.

translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh," etc. In the Holy Zohar, Rabbi Yitzchak opened and said, "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar; O Lord, in the light of Your countenance they walk." And it requires clarification how this verse connects here.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the connection between God's command to Moses and the Zohar's teaching highlights the significance of spiritual awareness and joy in divine service. The phrase "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar" emphasizes the importance of recognizing and responding to God's presence, which illuminates their path. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the transformative power of joy and awareness in one's relationship with the Divine. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true connection with God leads to enlightenment and guidance in life.

passage_content: ג) ה' אל משה ואל אהרן זאת חקת הפסח, במד"ר (פ' י"ט סי' א') זש"ה (משלי י"ד) לב יודע מרת נפשו אלו ישראל שהיו נתונים במצרים בשעבוד, וכיון שבאו לצאת וגזר עליהן הקב"ה לעשות פסח, באו המצרים לאכול עמהם, א"ל הקב"ה ח"ו כל בן נכר לא יאכל בו הוי לב יודע מרת נפשו ובשמחתו לא יתערב זר עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב כוונת דרשתם ז"ל הכי הי' שעבוד מצרים רק בסתרי הלב, הרי מפורש בכתוב ויעבידו מצרים את בנ"י בפרך ודרשו רז"ל בעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוף ומשברתו, וכל גופן הי' בצרה ומה לב יודע מרת נפשו, גם מ"ש באו המצריים לאכול עמהן צ"ב, ממ"ש הן יזבחו תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלנו, ואמרו רז"ל שהיו המצרים שיניהם קהות ולא יכלו לעשות דבר, ואיך יתכן שגם הם בעצמן באו לאכול ממנו אתמהה, גם מ"ש ובשמחתו לא יתערב זר צ"ב מדוע נפסלו מטעם השמחה דייקא, הלא קרבן פסח ממצות התורה ולא ניתנו המצות כ"א לישראל, ואף בישראל מילת בניו ועבדיו מעכבתו מלאכול הפסח ומכ"ש לעכו"ם.
translation: 3) The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses and Aaron, "This is the statute of the Passover." In the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, Section 1), it is stated: "The heart knows the bitterness of its soul" (Proverbs 14), referring to Israel who were enslaved in Egypt. When they came to leave, the Holy One, blessed be He, decreed upon them to perform the Passover, and the Egyptians came to eat with them. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Heaven forbid! No foreigner shall eat of it." This is the meaning of "the heart knows the bitterness of its soul," and a stranger shall not mix in his joy. Thus far the Midrash. It is necessary to understand their intention: Was the slavery in Egypt only in the hidden recesses of the heart? For it is explicitly written, "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor," and our sages have interpreted it as "with hard work that breaks the body and crushes it." All of their bodies were in distress, so what does "the heart knows the bitterness of its soul" mean? Also, what is meant by "the Egyptians came to eat with them"? Regarding what is written, "Behold, they will sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, and they will not be stoned," our sages have said that the Egyptians had dull teeth and could not do anything. How could it be that they themselves came to eat from it? I am perplexed. Furthermore, what is meant by "a stranger shall not mix in his joy"? It is necessary to understand why they were disqualified specifically due to joy. After all, the Passover offering is one of the commandments of the Torah, and the commandments were not given except to Israel. And even among Israel, the matter of his sons and servants prevents him from eating the Passover, how much more so for a non-Jew.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice and the exclusion of non-Jews from participating in it, emphasizing that true understanding and joy in the observance of mitzvot are rooted in the inner spiritual state of the Jewish people. It highlights that the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt was not only physical but also deeply emotional, as their hearts were burdened. The text questions the apparent contradiction of Egyptians wanting to partake in the sacrifice, underscoring that the essence of the Passover is tied to the unique spiritual connection of the Jewish people to their traditions and divine commandments. Ultimately, it conveys that joy in fulfilling mitzvot must be pure and untainted by outside influences.

translation: In the Midrash (Parashat 19, Section 6), it states: "No foreigner shall eat of it," to fulfill what is said (Psalms 147): "He declares His words to Jacob, His statutes and judgments to Israel; He has not done so with any nation," etc. And this requires further investigation.
summary: The passage emphasizes the distinction between the Jewish people and other nations, highlighting that certain spiritual and divine laws are uniquely given to Israel. It references the idea that God's teachings and statutes are specifically for the descendants of Jacob, underscoring a special covenantal relationship. This exclusivity reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the unique spiritual mission of the Jewish people in the world. The text invites contemplation on the implications of this divine selection and the responsibilities it entails.

passage_content: ה) משה זכור את היום הזה אשר יצאתם ממצרים מבית עבדים וגו', היום אתם יוצאים בחודש האביב: ראוי להבין דמתחיל בלשון עבר אשר יצאתם, וסיים בלשון הוה היום אתם יוצאים, גם למ"ל להזכיר חודש האביב, וידוע דניסן חודש האביב הוא.
translation: 5) Moses, remember this day when you went out of Egypt from the house of bondage, etc., today you are going out in the month of Aviv: It is fitting to understand that it begins in the past tense "when you went out," and concludes in the present tense "today you are going out," also why it is necessary to mention the month of Aviv, and it is known that Nisan is the month of Aviv.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the Exodus from Egypt, highlighting the transition from past to present by using both past and present tense. It reflects on the importance of remembering the historical event while also recognizing its ongoing relevance in the current month of Nisan, which symbolizes renewal and redemption. This duality illustrates the Hasidic concept of living in the moment while being rooted in historical spiritual experiences, emphasizing the continuous nature of liberation and divine intervention in the lives of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ונתחיל בביאור דברי המדרש לב יודע מרת נפשו, דהנה הגלות היותר קשה במצרים הי' גלות הנפש ועד"ז בשאר גליות, ובאמת הי' להם לישראל במצרים מדות ומעלות נשגבים, כאמרז"ל שהיו גדורים מעריות ומאיסור נדה ומבת אל נכר. וכל ישראל נשמרו מכל אלה כאמרז"ל אחת היתה ופרסמה הכתוב, אולם אם מידי עבירה יצאו מידי הרהור לא יצאו והוצרכו לתקן פגם זה טרם גאולתם, ואיתא במד"ר פ' שמות (פר' א' סי' ל"ו) וירא אלקים שעשו תשובה הבינונים וגם הרשעים הרהרו לעשות תשובה, וידע אלקים שאפי' אחד בחבירו לא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו, וזה מכוון את לבו וזה מכוון את לבו ועושה תשובה, ולפי שפגם ההרהור הי' בלב ע"כ בחי' התקון והתשובה היתה צריכה להיות ג"כ בפנימית הלב, ואין אדם יודע מה בלב חבירו רק הבוכ"ע בוחן כליות ולב, ע"כ אמרז"ל אחד בחבירו לא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו, וז"ש לב יודע מרת נפשו כי שורש פגם זה הוא בלב, כמ"ש ולא תתורו אחרי לבבכם ואחרי עיניכם, ודרשו ז"ל עה"כ ונשמרת מכל דבר רע שלא יהרהר אדם ביום ויבוא לידי טומאה בלילה.
translation: And we will begin with the explanation of the words of the Midrash, "The heart knows the bitterness of its soul." Behold, the most difficult exile was in Egypt, which was an exile of the soul, and similarly in other exiles. In truth, the Israelites in Egypt had lofty virtues and qualities, as our Sages have said that they were guarded from immorality, from the prohibition of nida, and from the daughter of a foreign god. All of Israel kept themselves from these, as our Sages have said, "One was [the level of their observance], and the Scripture made it known." However, although they were free from sin, they were not free from improper thoughts, and they needed to rectify this flaw before their redemption. It is stated in the Midrash, Parashat Shemot (Parashat 1, Section 36), "And God saw that the intermediates had repented, and even the wicked contemplated repenting, and God knew that even one among his fellow would not know, only the Holy One, blessed be He, alone." This one directs his heart, and that one directs his heart and repents. And because the flaw of improper thoughts was in the heart, therefore the aspect of rectification and repentance also needed to be in the inner heart. And no person knows what is in the heart of his fellow, only the Holy One, blessed be He, who examines the kidneys and the heart. Therefore, our Sages have said, "One among his fellow would not know, only the Holy One, blessed be He, alone." And this is what is meant by "The heart knows the bitterness of its soul," for the root of this flaw is in the heart, as it is written, "And you shall not stray after your heart and after your eyes." And our Sages expounded on the verse, "And you shall guard yourself from any evil thing," that a person should not contemplate during the day and come to impurity at night.
summary: The passage discusses the profound spiritual exile experienced by the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that their greatest struggle was the exile of the soul rather than physical oppression. Despite their high moral standards, they needed to rectify their inner thoughts and intentions, as true repentance required a transformation of the heart. The text highlights that only God knows the depths of one's heart, underscoring the importance of internal purity and vigilance against negative thoughts, which can lead to spiritual impurity. Ultimately, it conveys that the root of spiritual flaws lies within the heart, necessitating sincere introspection and repentance.

passage_content: והנה כל עוד שהאדם משוקע ר"ל בעבירות, לא ירגיש לבו בצרת נפשו ואינו יודע באיזה מצב הוא עומד, ועד היכן הוא משוקע בעבירות כאמרז"ל (שבת דף י"ג ע"ב) אין בשר המת מרגיש באיזמל ופירשתי במאמה"כ (תהלים כ"ה) טוב וישר ה' על כן יורה חטאים בדרך, דלכאורה הול"ל יורה חוטאים, וע"ד שהקשו (ברכות י' ע"א) מי כתיב חוטאים חטאים כתיב, דחטאים לאו היינו חוטאים, אמנם אמרז"ל בזוה"ק (ויקרא כ"ג ע"ב) או הודע אליו חטאתו אשר חטא. הודע אליו מסטרא דמאן, או ידע חטאתו מבעי' לי' מהו הודע אליו, אלא קב"ה פקיד לכנסת ישראל לאודעה לי' לבר נש ההוא חובא דהוא חב וכו', ומאן דקאים בלילא למלעי באורייתא. אורייתא קא מודעא לי' חובי', ולא באורח דינא אלא כאמא דאודעא לברה במלה רכיך וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק, ובספה"ק נועם אלימלך בהנהגת האדם כתב דחטאת הנעורים ר"ל מסמין עיני האדם ר"ל, ועי"כ נאבד ונשכח ממנו הרגשת החטא, ואי' איפא ימצא תקנה להתחרט ולשוב על חטאיו, אלא שהקב"ה בטובו וחסדו לרחם על בריותיו מודיע לי' חטאי' ומורה לו דרך תשובה, וז"ש טוב וישר ה' על כן יורה חטאים בדרך.
translation: And behold, as long as a person is immersed, so to speak, in sins, his heart will not feel the distress of his soul, and he does not know in what state he stands, and how deeply he is immersed in sins, as our Sages have said (Shabbat 13b), "The flesh of the dead does not feel the scalpel." I have explained in my commentary (Psalms 25) "Good and upright is the Lord; therefore He instructs sinners in the way." It could have said "He instructs the sinners," and in the manner that they asked (Berakhot 10a), "Who wrote 'sinners'? It is written 'sinners'." For "sinners" is not the same as "sinners." However, our Sages have said in the Zohar (Vayikra 23b), "Or let him be made aware of his sin which he has sinned." Let him be made aware from whose side? Or does he need to know his sin? What does "let him be made aware" mean? Rather, the Holy One, blessed be He, has appointed the congregation of Israel to inform him of that burden which he carries, etc. And whoever stands at night to engage in the Torah, the Torah informs him of his debts, and not in a legal manner, but like a mother who informs her son with gentle words, etc. Thus said the Zohar. And in the holy book Noam Elimelech on the conduct of man, it is written that the sins of youth, so to speak, blind a person's eyes, so to speak, and as a result, he loses and forgets the feeling of sin. And where then can he find a remedy to regret and return from his sins? Except that the Holy One, blessed be He, in His goodness and kindness, has mercy on His creatures and informs him of his sins and shows him the way of repentance. And this is what is meant by "Good and upright is the Lord; therefore He instructs sinners in the way."
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual state of a person immersed in sins, who remains unaware of their plight, akin to a dead body not feeling a knife. It emphasizes that God, in His goodness, guides sinners towards repentance by revealing their transgressions, as indicated in the verse "Good and upright is the Lord; therefore He instructs sinners in the way." The text highlights the importance of divine mercy in helping individuals recognize their faults and return to the path of righteousness, illustrating a key Hasidic belief in God's compassionate guidance.

passage_content: וכמו"כ בני ישראל היו משוקעים בטומאת מצרים כ"כ, עד שנאבד מהם הרגשת החטא לגמרי, אלא שריחם הבוית"ש עליהם ושלח אליהם את משה ואהרן והפרישום מע"ז לפני גאולתם, כמ"ש רז"ל משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן למצוה, ואכלו הפסח בלילה ההוא בהתעוררות קדושה נפלאה, ועשו תשובה שלימה מאהבת הנס, ונתעלו למדריגה עליונה ונתקרבו להשי"ת, ואז נודע להם למפרע באיזה מצב היו ועד היכן היו משוקעים עד הנה.
translation: And likewise, the children of Israel were so deeply immersed in the impurity of Egypt that they completely lost the feeling of sin. However, the Blessed One had mercy on them and sent to them Moses and Aaron, and separated them from idolatry before their redemption, as our Sages have said, "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for the mitzvah," and they ate the Passover on that night with a wondrous awakening of holiness, and they made complete repentance out of love for the miracle, and they were elevated to a high level and drew close to the Holy One, Blessed be He. Then it was revealed to them retrospectively in what state they had been and how deeply they had been immersed until then.
summary: The passage discusses the deep spiritual state of the Israelites, who were so immersed in the impurity of Egypt that they lost their awareness of sin. In divine compassion, God sent Moses and Aaron to separate them from idolatry before their redemption. Through a profound awakening during the Passover, they experienced a complete repentance motivated by love for the miracle, which elevated them to a higher spiritual level and allowed them to recognize their previous dire condition.

passage_content: וז"ש במדרש עה"פ זאת חקת הפסח זש"ה לב יודע מרת נפשו, דבשעת אכילת הקרבן פסח נודע לכל לב מרת נפשו, ועד היכן מגיע פגם העבירה, ובעוה"ר עכשיו השפלות גדול יותר מכמו שהי' במצרים, וכמ"ש באוה"ח הק' דאז היו ישראל משוקעים במ"ט שערי טומאה, ועכשיו הגענו לשער הנו"ן וע"י כח התוה"ק ננצל גם מזה, וכשיעזור השי"ת שנזכה להגאולה שלימה אז נדע ונשיג באיזה מצב היינו, ולעת עתה בעוה"ר הלבבות סתומים ואין אנו משיגין כלל באיזה מצב אנו נמצאין, והשי"ת ירחם על עמו שנזכה לראות ולספר כ"ז מתוך נחת ושמחה והתרוממות.
translation: And this is what is said in the Midrash on the verse "This is the statute of the Passover," as it is written, "A heart knows the bitterness of its soul." For at the time of eating the Passover offering, every heart knows the bitterness of its soul, and to what extent the blemish of sin reaches. And in our current times, the degradation is even greater than it was in Egypt, as the holy Ohr HaChaim writes, that then the Israelites were sunk in the forty-nine gates of impurity, and now we have reached the fiftieth gate. And through the power of the Torah, we will be saved from this as well. When the Holy One, blessed be He, helps us and we merit the complete redemption, then we will know and understand in what state we were. But for now, in our current times, the hearts are sealed, and we do not comprehend at all in what state we find ourselves. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on His people, that we merit to see and recount all this with tranquility, joy, and elevation.
summary: The passage discusses the profound spiritual awareness that arises during the Passover sacrifice, highlighting that each heart recognizes its own suffering and the extent of sin's blemish. It contrasts the current state of spiritual degradation, which is even lower than that experienced in Egypt, with the hope of redemption through the power of the Torah. The author expresses a longing for a future revelation of understanding regarding their current condition, while acknowledging the present obscurity of hearts. Ultimately, it is a plea for divine mercy, hoping for a joyful and elevated experience of redemption.

passage_content: ופירשתי מה דאיתא במד"ר (פ' י"ח סי' י"ב) עה"כ ליל שמורים הוא לה' לדורותם, משל לאשה שהיתה מצפה לבעלה שפירש למדינת הים, אמר לה יהא סימן הזה בידך, בעת שתראי אותו סימן, דעי שאני בא וכו', כך ישראל מצפין משעמדה אדום, אמר הקב"ה הסימן הזה יהי' בידכם ביום שעשיתי לכם תשועה ובאותו לילה היו יודעים שאני גואלכם ואם לאו אל תאמינו, שלא קרבה העת שנא' (ישעי' ס') אני ה' בעתה אחישנה עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאו' קשה הלא מעיקרי האמונה להאמין ולחכות בכל יום שיבוא, והיום אם בקולו תשמעו אמר המלך המשיח (סנהדרין צ"ח ע"א), וא"כ בכל יומא ויומא זמנו הוא ואיך אמרו רז"ל שצ"ל בלילה הזה דייקא, וכעי"ז הקשה הטורי אבן במס' ר"ה עמ"ד (עירובין מ"ג ע"א) הריני נזיר ביום שבן דוד בא אסור לשתות יין כל ימות החול, ובמקו"א אמרינן בניסן עתידין להגאל וא"כ מדוע נאסר בכל ימות השנה, והוא ז"ל תירץ דבעתה צ"ל דוקא בניסן, משא"כ בחי' אחישנה יכול להיות בכל יום ע"כ תירוצו, ואפ"ל עוד עפימ"ש הנזה"ק (פ' ויחי) עה"פ אני ה' בעתה אחישנה, דיש זמן המוכן לגאולה וזהו בעתה, אמנם הבוי"ת ברצונו משנה עיתים ומחליף הזמנים ומקדים הזמן של הגאולה ומעתיקו ממקומו לקבעו כפי אשר יעלה ברצונו ית"ש, וזהו אני ה' בעתה אחישנה, היינו את הזמן של בעתה יחיש להקדימו ברצונו, נמצא שיהי' הגאולה בעתה וגם אחישנה יעיי"ש באריכות, ולפי"ז אה"נ דהזמן של בעתה הוא בניסן ובליל יצי"מ דייקא, אבל הקב"ה ברצונו ית' מעתיק הזמן הזה והמזל וכוכב המאיר בו לקבעו בכל יום שיהי' רצונו ית'.
translation:
And I explained what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, Section 12) regarding the verse "It is a night of watching for the Lord to bring them out of the land of Egypt," as a parable of a woman who was waiting for her husband who had gone to a distant land. He said to her, "This sign shall be in your hand; when you see this sign, know that I am coming," etc. So too, Israel waits for the time when Edom stands against them. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "This sign shall be in your hand on the day I bring you salvation, and on that night you will know that I am your Redeemer, and if not, do not believe, for the time has not yet come," as it is stated (Isaiah 60:22), "I am the Lord; in its time, I will hasten it." This is the end of the Midrash. 

However, it seems difficult, for it is one of the fundamentals of faith to believe and wait every day for the coming of the Messiah, and today, if you will listen to His voice, said the King Messiah (Sanhedrin 98a). Therefore, every day is its time, and how could our sages say that it must be specifically on this night? Similarly, the Turim Aven asked in Tractate Rosh Hashanah (page 4) that I will be a Nazirite on the day that the son of David comes; it is forbidden to drink wine all the days of the week. And in another place, we say that in Nissan, they will be redeemed, so why is it forbidden all year round? He, may his memory be blessed, answered that it must be in its time specifically in Nissan, whereas in the aspect of "I will hasten it," it can be any day. 

And it can also be said according to what is mentioned in the Zohar (Parashat Vayechi) regarding the verse "I am the Lord; in its time, I will hasten it," that there is a time prepared for redemption, and that is "in its time." However, the Blessed One, in His will, changes times and alters the seasons, and brings forward the time of redemption and moves it from its place to establish it according to what He desires, blessed be He. This is "I am the Lord; in its time, I will hasten it," meaning that the time of "in its time" He will hasten according to His will. Thus, the redemption will be both in its time and hastened. 

According to this, it is indeed true that the time of "in its time" is in Nissan and specifically on the night of the Exodus from Egypt, but the Holy One, blessed be He, in His will, moves this time and the constellation and star that shines in it to establish it every day according to His will.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of waiting for redemption, likening it to a woman awaiting her husband's return, with a sign indicating his arrival. It emphasizes that while the belief in the imminent coming of the Messiah is a fundamental tenet of faith, there are specific times, particularly Passover, that are traditionally associated with redemption. The text highlights the idea that God can alter the timing of redemption according to His will, allowing for the possibility of an earlier arrival than expected. Ultimately, it conveys a deep theological insight into the interplay between divine timing and human anticipation in the context of salvation.

passage_content: ומעתה לא קשה קושית הטורי אבן וא"ש דברי המדרש הנ"ל דסימן זה יהא מסור בידך כשתראי אותו סימן וכו' ואם לאו אל תאמינו שלא קרבה העת שנא' אני ה' בעתה אחישנה, שתהי' הגאולה בליל יצ"מ דייקא ע"י החלפת והקדמת הזמנים כנ"ל, ורק הבוכ"ע בעצמו יכול לעשות זאת, וא"א שתהי' גאולה זולתו ית"ש, ומכ"ש ע"י סיבה של כפירה ומינות ר"ל, בוודאי שאין זה גאולה רק אסון נורא להכלל ישראל, ובעוה"ר בימינו אלה הגיעני הרעה הזה. וחזינן בדברי חכז"ל ובספה"ק כמה התרו בנו שלא נטעה עצמינו במשיחי שקר, כי ראו ברוה"ק שיעמדו על ישראל נסיונות כאלו וכמו שכבר הי' בכמה דורות, והרמב"ם ז"ל העיד שהי' כן בימיו ואח"כ הכת ש"ץ שר"י, אולם כמו שהוא בזמנינו לא הי' עוד משעת בריאת העולם, שהאפיקורסים ומעבירי הדת תפסו להם מדינה וממשלה ומעבירין על הדת והאמונה בכפי' ר"ל, ויהודים שרוצין להאמין בהשי"ת ובתוה"ק נמשכין אחריהן, אוי לנו שכך עלתה בימינו, השי"ת ירחם שיתעקר מלכות הזדון במהרה ע"י אליהו ומלך המשיח, ולא ע"י האומות ח"ו דאם ניתן רשות למשחית אינו מבחין, והשי"ת יעזור שתתקיים במהרה להעביר ממשלת זדון מן הארץ והי' ה' למלך על כל הארץ
translation: And from now on, the question of the stone towers is not difficult, and I understand the words of the aforementioned Midrash that this sign shall be entrusted to you when you see that sign, etc. And if not, do not believe that the time has not drawn near, as it is said, "I am the Lord; in its time, I will hasten it." The redemption will specifically be on the night of Passover through the exchange and advancement of times, as mentioned above, and only the Holy One, blessed be He, can do this. It is impossible for there to be redemption without Him, may He be blessed, and certainly not through the cause of heresy and apostasy, God forbid. This is certainly not redemption but a terrible disaster for the entire Jewish people. And in our days, this evil has reached me. We see in the words of our sages and in the holy books how they warned us not to deceive ourselves with false messiahs, for they saw in the Holy Spirit that such trials would arise against Israel, as has already happened in several generations. And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, testified that it was so in his days, and afterwards the sect of Shabbetai Tzvi, may his name be blotted out. However, as it is in our time, it has not been since the creation of the world that the heretics and those who lead the faith astray have taken for themselves a state and government and are forcing the religion and faith upon us, God forbid. And Jews who wish to believe in the Holy One, blessed be He, and in the Torah and commandments are drawn after them. Woe to us that this has arisen in our days. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy and uproot the kingdom of wickedness quickly through Elijah and the King Messiah, and not through the nations, God forbid, for if permission is given to the destroyer, he does not discern. And may the Holy One, blessed be He, help that it be fulfilled quickly to remove the government of wickedness from the earth, and the Lord shall be King over all the earth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the belief that true redemption can only come from God and cannot be achieved through false messiahs or heretical movements. It warns against the dangers of skepticism and the influence of those who undermine faith, highlighting that the current challenges faced by the Jewish people are unprecedented. The text expresses a deep yearning for divine intervention to remove the oppressive forces and establish God's sovereignty over the earth, particularly through the coming of Elijah and the Messiah. Ultimately, it reflects a profound trust in God's timing for redemption, as articulated in the teachings of Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ונחזור לבאר מאמה"כ זכור את היום הזה אשר יצאתם ממצרים וגו' היום אתם יוצאים בחודש האביב, ואפ"ל עפימ"ש בייטב פנים (לחנוכה סי' כ"ט) בשם הה"ק ר' אורי מסטרעליסק זי"ע לפרש הכתוב (בפ' עקב) כי תאמר בלבבך רבים הגוים האלה וגו' זכור תזכור את אשר עשה ה' אלקיך לפרעה ולכל מצרים וגו', דע"י זכירת יציאת מצרים יתעורר נס ההצלה והשפעת הגאולה, ועי"ז זוכין להנצל מהם בכל פעם. וזה שאה"כ כי תאמר בלבבך רבים הגוים האלה ממני איכה אוכל להורישם, לזה אמר זכור תזכור את אשר עשה ה' לפרעה ולכל מצרים, ובכח זכירת יצי"מ תגרום עשות גם היום כן להכרית הגוים ההם יעיי"ש, וז"ש זכור את היום הזה אשר יצאתם ממצרים, ובזכות הזכירה נזכה שיהי' היום אתם יוצאים מגלות המר הזה ויהי' בחודש האביב, דהרי הגאולה צ"ל בניסן, ואעפ"כ כל יומא זמני' וכנ"ל בנזר הקודש, ובזכות זכירת יצי"מ יזכו ישראל שהיום יהי' חודש האביב ע"י החלפת הזמנים, והיום אתם יוצאים ובחודש האביב, וז"ש ושמרת את החקה הזאת למועדה מימים ימימה, דע"י שמירת חקה הזאת מצות הפסח וזכירת יצי"מ, תזכו למועדה מימים ימימה מועד הגאולה שהוא ניסן. תקבע באחד מימות השנה כפי שיעלה ברצונו ית"ש, כי ימים רמז על ימי השנה כמ"ש ימים תהי' גאולתו.
translation: And we will return to explain the verse: "Remember this day in which you went out of Egypt..." Today you are going out in the month of Aviv. And I can say, as mentioned in the writings of the holy Rabbi Uri of Stryj, may his memory be a blessing, to explain the verse (in Parshat Eikev) "When you say in your heart, 'These nations are more numerous than I, how can I drive them out?'" Remember, you must remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and all of Egypt... For through the remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt, the miracle of salvation and the influence of redemption is awakened, and through this, we merit to be saved from them at all times. This is what is meant when it says, "When you say in your heart, 'These nations are more numerous than I, how can I drive them out?'" Therefore, it says, "Remember, you must remember what the Lord did to Pharaoh and all of Egypt," and through the power of remembering the Exodus from Egypt, you will cause that even today He will act similarly to eradicate those nations, as explained there. This is what is meant by "Remember this day in which you went out of Egypt," and through the merit of this remembrance, we will be worthy that today you will go out from this bitter exile, and it will be in the month of Aviv, for the redemption must be in Nissan. And yet, every day is a time for it, as mentioned in the crown of holiness. And through the merit of remembering the Exodus from Egypt, the Jewish people will merit that today will be the month of Aviv through the changing of times, and "Today you are going out in the month of Aviv." This is what is meant by "And you shall observe this statute at its appointed time from year to year," for through the observance of this statute, the commandment of Passover and the remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt, you will merit the appointed time from year to year, the time of redemption which is Nissan. It will be established on one of the days of the year as it will arise in His will, blessed be He, for days hint at the days of the year, as it is said, "Days will be His redemption."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of remembering the Exodus from Egypt as a means to invoke divine salvation and redemption. It suggests that by recalling God's miracles against Pharaoh and Egypt, one can inspire similar acts of deliverance in the present. The text connects the act of remembrance with the timing of redemption, indicating that true liberation is linked to the month of Nissan, and that through the observance of Passover and the remembrance of the Exodus, the Jewish people can attain ongoing redemption throughout the year. Ultimately, it highlights the cyclical nature of time and the potential for spiritual renewal through remembrance and observance.

passage_content: והנה גם במצרים זכו ישראל אל הגאולה ולנס ההצלה בזכות זכירת יצי"מ ומצות הקרבן פסח כמ"ש וראיתי את הדם ופסחתי עליכם וגו', וע"כ כשהגיעו ישראל לקיים מצות קרבן פסח הי' להם שמחה גדולה שיזכו להגאולה, שהרי רוב גדול מישראל מתו בג' ימי אפילה, כאמרז"ל (במדרש ילקוט רמז רכ"ז) שלא נשארו מהם רק אחד מחמשה, ולחד מ"ד במדרש א' מס' רבוא. וגם אחר מכת החושך לא ידעו עדיין מי יזכה להגאולה, כי קשה מאוד הבירור וצריכין רחמים גדולים לעבור את הבירור ולהנצל, וכמו שראינו שגם אותן שיצאו ממצרים וזכו להגאולה ולקריעת ים סוף ולמעמד הנבחר, אעפ"כ לביאת הארץ לא זכו רק יהושע וכלב, ובזמנינו אלה אין אתנו יודע מי יזכה להגאולה ויעבור את הבירור הקשה, דאף במצרים לא היו משוקעים בשפלות גדול כ"כ כמו בדורנו היום, ואיתא בזוה"ק (שמות דף ז' ע"ב) ר' שמעון זקף ידוי ובכה, ואמר ווי מאן דיזדמן בההוא זמנא, וזכאה חולקי' מאן דיזדמן וישתכח בההוא זמנא, ולכאו' נראה כסותר דברי עצמו, אמנם הדר מפרש בזוה"ק ווי מאן דיזדמן בההוא זמנא וכו' ולא ישתכח זכאי, זכאה מאן דיזדמן וישתכח בההוא זמנא, בגין דההוא דיתקיים וכו' לההוא נהירו דחדוה דמלכא עכ"ד הזוה"ק, לכן בנ"י במצרים כשהגיעו לאכילת קרבן פסח הי' להם עבודה זו לשמחה גדולה, על שזכו בהבירור ויזכו להגאל ממצרים: והמצרים לא היו יכולין לראות בשמחתם ויפג לבם, לכן באו אף הם להצטרף לאכול עמהם, והי' כוונתם בזה לבטלם ממצותם ועי"ז יתבטל נס הגאולה ח"ו, לזה אמר הבוכ"ע ח"ו בשמחתו לא יתערב זר, וכמו שמצינו בבנין בית שני שרצו הכותים לבטל הבנין ובעלילה זו באו לעזור ולהשתתף והשיבו להם ראשי אבות ישראל לא לנו ולכם לבנות בית לאלקינו, וז"ש ובשמחתו לא יתערב זר.
translation: And behold, even in Egypt, the Israelites merited redemption and the miracle of salvation due to the remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt and the commandment of the Passover offering, as it is said, "And I saw the blood, and I passed over you," etc. Therefore, when the Israelites came to fulfill the commandment of the Passover offering, they had great joy that they would merit redemption, for a great majority of Israel died during the three days of darkness, as our sages of blessed memory said (in the Midrash Yalkut, Remez 267) that only one out of five remained, and according to one opinion in the Midrash, one out of a hundred thousand. And even after the plague of darkness, they still did not know who would merit redemption, for the clarification was very difficult, and they needed great mercy to pass through the clarification and be saved. As we see, even those who left Egypt and merited redemption and the splitting of the sea and the chosen standing at Sinai, nevertheless, for entering the land, only Joshua and Caleb merited it. And in our times, no one knows who will merit redemption and pass through the difficult clarification, for even in Egypt, they were not sunk in such great lowliness as in our generation today. And it is stated in the Zohar (Exodus, page 7b) that Rabbi Shimon raised his hands and wept, saying, "Woe to whoever is present at that time, and blessed is whoever is present and is remembered at that time," for that which will be fulfilled, etc., for that is the light of the joy of the King. Therefore, when the Children of Israel in Egypt came to eat the Passover offering, this work was for them a great joy, for they merited in the clarification and would be redeemed from Egypt. And the Egyptians could not bear to see their joy, and their hearts were troubled; therefore, they also came to join them in eating, and their intention in this was to nullify their commandments, and thereby the miracle of redemption would be nullified, Heaven forbid. This is why it is said, "In his joy, a stranger shall not be mixed in," for as we find regarding the building of the Second Temple, the Samaritans wanted to nullify the building, and under this pretext, they came to help and participate, and the heads of the fathers of Israel replied to them, "It is not for us and you to build a house for our God." And this is what is meant by "In his joy, a stranger shall not be mixed in."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the significance of the Passover sacrifice and the remembrance of the Exodus as crucial elements for the Jewish people's redemption from Egypt. Despite the overwhelming challenges and the uncertainty of who would merit salvation, the Israelites found great joy in fulfilling the commandment of the Passover sacrifice, which symbolized their hope for liberation. The text warns against external influences that could undermine their spiritual mission, drawing parallels to past attempts to disrupt the rebuilding of the Second Temple. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of maintaining purity and focus in the pursuit of divine redemption.

passage_content: ואיתא בזוה"ק (בראשית דף כ"ז) וימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה בקושיא, בחומר בקל וחומר, ובלבנים בלבון הלכתא, בשדה דא משנה, את כל עבודתם וגו' דא ברייתא עכ"ד הזוה"ק, ובספה"ק מאור עינים (פ' שמות) מבאר עה"פ ויעבידו מצרים את בנ"י בפרך, דהנה התורה אף שלא ניתנה קודם המבול, מ"מ היתה גם בזה העולם, כי כח הפועל בנפעל, רק שלא ניתנה בלבושין כמו אחר מת"ת שנתלבשה בלבושים כמו זה העולם, והיו יחידי סגולה שהיו מקיימין התורה כמו שהיא במרום מחמת שהיו משיגין וכו' את פנימיותי' האמיתי וכו', ובדור המבול היו רשעים גדולים עד שהפסיקו את העולם עם הפועל שהוא התורה מן הבוב"ה, ע"כ כשנפסק התורה והעולם משרשם ע"כ חרב העולם באותו זמן והי' מבול, ולהיכן הפילו את התורה בקליפת מצרים וכו', ע"כ הוצרכו ישראל לירד למצרים להעלות את התורה שנפלה בקליפת מצרים, וכמ"ש בזוה"ק ויעבידו מצרים את בנ"י בפרך בחומר דא ק"ו ובלבנים דא ליבון הלכתא בפרך דא פירכא וכו', וזהו ממש התורה שהיתה ביניהן, הוציאו ישראל עם כל בחינותי', כי כל זה הוא בחינת התורה וכו', עד שהעלו את אותיות התורה מעומק קליפת מצרים, ואז כשיצאו יכלו לקבל התורה בג' חדשים וזהו וינצלו את מצרים
translation: And it is stated in the Zohar (Genesis, page 27) that they embittered their lives with hard work, with difficulty, with clay and with bricks, in the field of this Mishnah, all their work, etc., as the Zohar concludes. And in the holy book Maor Einayim (Parashat Shemot) it explains the verse "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor," that behold, the Torah, although it was not given before the Flood, nevertheless existed in this world as well, for the power of the doer is in the deed, only that it was not given in garments like after the giving of the Torah, which was clothed in garments like in this world. And there were select individuals who upheld the Torah as it is in the heights because they attained, etc., its true inner essence, etc. In the generation of the Flood, there were great wicked ones who interrupted the world with the action that is the Torah from the Blessed Holy One. Therefore, when the Torah and the world were severed from their root, the world was destroyed at that time and there was a Flood. And where did they cast the Torah? Into the shell of Egypt, etc. Therefore, the Israelites needed to descend to Egypt to elevate the Torah that had fallen into the shell of Egypt, as it is written in the Zohar, "And the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor," with clay, which is a difficulty, and with bricks, which is the clarification of the law, with rigor, which is a challenge, etc. And this is truly the Torah that was among them; the Israelites extracted it with all its aspects, for all this is the aspect of the Torah, etc., until they elevated the letters of the Torah from the depths of the shell of Egypt. And then, when they left, they were able to receive the Torah in three months, and this is "And they plundered the Egyptians."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the Torah existed even before its formal revelation at Sinai, as it was present in a hidden form during the time of the Flood. It emphasizes that the Israelites' suffering in Egypt was necessary to elevate the Torah, which had fallen into the "klipah" (shell) of Egypt. Through their hardships, the Israelites were able to extract the essence of the Torah from this spiritual impurity, enabling them to receive the Torah fully three months later. This process illustrates the deep connection between suffering, redemption, and the divine wisdom of the Torah.

passage_content: וכתב עוד שם דאחר יצי"מ שהוציאו הדעת מהגלות אף שיש גלות, מ"מ אין הדעת בגלות כ"א לתועים גמורים הכופרים במציאות וכו' עכת"ד יעיי"ש באריכות, ורואין זאת בזמנינו אלה שבאין בטענות מן התורה, ובעוה"ר רבים חללים הפילה ועצומים כל הרוגי, וכמו"כ המצרים הציקו להם בכח התורה, וע"י הקרבן פסח שהבדילם הבוכ"ע כמ"ש ובשמחתו לא יתערב זר, עי"כ ניצולו מהם על כל האופנים, ובזה מובן מה שהסמיכו במדרש לכאן הפסוק מגיד דבריו ליעקב חקיו ומשפטיו לישראל לא עשה כן לכל גוי ומשפטים בל ידעום.
translation: And he wrote further there that after the Exodus from Egypt, they removed the intellect from the exile, even though there is exile; nevertheless, the intellect is not in exile except for those who are completely lost, the deniers of existence, etc. Thus far, see there at length. And we see this in our times, where they come with claims from the Torah, and woe to us, many have fallen and great are all the slain. Likewise, the oppressors have troubled them with the power of the Torah, and through the Passover offering, which distinguished them from the nations, as it is said, "And in His joy, no foreigner shall mix in," thereby they were saved from them in all ways. And in this, it is understood why the Midrash connects here the verse, "He declares His words to Jacob, His statutes and judgments to Israel; He has not done so with any nation, and His judgments they do not know."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that, following the Exodus from Egypt, the understanding of God and the Torah was liberated from exile, although some still remain in spiritual exile due to their disbelief. It highlights the challenges faced by the Jewish people, who are often attacked using the very teachings of the Torah, yet emphasizes that through the observance of Passover, they are distinguished and protected from such adversities. The text also references a Midrash that underscores the unique relationship between God and Israel, indicating that His laws and judgments are not given to other nations, reinforcing the special covenantal bond.

passage_content: ונחזור לבאר ענין הארבה שהתחלנו בו, עפימ"ש האלשיך הק' לפרש הפסוק את אשר התעללתי במצרים ופרש"י ז"ל שחקתי, דהנה ממכת ברד לא נשאר כ"א החטה והכוסמת שלא נכו כי אפילות הנה, ודרשו ז"ל פלאי פלאות נעשו להם שלא נכו, ובאמת הי' ההצלה הזו כדי להוסיף עליהם מכת הארבה, וזהו התעללתי שחקתו שהם חשבו שנעשו הנסים להם להצלתם ולטובתם ובאמת היו הנסים אלו רק להוסיף עליהן מכה על מכתם וזהו השחוק עייש"ד, ואמרתי במקהלות עם כשניצלנו עפ"י נס (בשנת תרח"ץ במדינת רומעניע מגזירת גאגא ימ"ש) עפי"ד החת"ס זלה"ה בס' הזכרון מעצם כתי"ק עה"כ נתת ליראיך נס להתנוסס מפני קושט סלה, ותוכן דבה"ק שבשנת תקס"ט לפ"ק באו הצרפתים במצור על עיר פרעסבורג, ויורו חצים ובליסטראות אל תוך העיר והי' פחד ובהלה וסכנה עצומה, וע"י נס פתאום יצאו האויבים משם, ואמר אז החת"ס ז"ל כי אין מנס הזה עדיין ראי' שנצלנו כבר, כי לפעמים עושה הקב"ה כן כעין התראה, להודיע שנגזרה גזירה וצריכין לשוב ולהקדים תפלה לצרה ואז יהיו ראויין באמת להצלה, ואם ח"ו תקשו ערפכם הכינו למה שהוא קשה מן הראשונים, וזהו נתת ליראיך נס כדי להתנוסס היינו שיהיו ראויין לנס השני, מפני קושט סלה שהנס הזה יהי' נצחי ולא יבוא אחריו פורעניות עוד יעייש"ד (הועתק הענין בקו' עהגועה"ת סי' ל"ו).
translation: And let us return to explain the matter of the locusts that we began with, according to what the holy Alshich explained regarding the verse "that which I have played with in Egypt," and Rashi, of blessed memory, explained "I have mocked." Behold, from the plague of hail, only the wheat and the spelt remained unharmed, for they are late crops, and our sages of blessed memory have interpreted that wondrous wonders were done for them that they were not struck. And indeed, this salvation was in order to add upon them the plague of locusts, and this is what is meant by "I have played," that they thought that these miracles were done for their salvation and for their good, but in truth, these miracles were only to add upon them a blow to their plague, and this is the mockery, as it is written. And I said in the gatherings when we were saved by a miracle (in the year 5688 in the land of Romania from the decree of Gagah, may his name be blotted out) according to the words of the Chasam Sofer, of blessed memory, in the book of remembrance from his own handwriting on the verse "You have given a miracle to those who fear You to be raised up because of the truth of Selah," and the content of the holy words is that in the year 5690 from the creation of the world, the French came to besiege the city of Pressburg, and they shot arrows and catapults into the city, and there was fear and panic and a tremendous danger, and by a miracle, suddenly the enemies left there. And then the Chasam Sofer, of blessed memory, said that this miracle is not yet a proof that we have already been saved, for sometimes the Holy One, blessed be He, does so as a kind of warning, to inform that a decree has been issued and that we need to return and hasten prayer for the trouble, and then they will truly be worthy of salvation. And if, Heaven forbid, you harden your neck, prepare for what is harder than the first ones. And this is "You have given a miracle to those who fear You to be raised up," meaning that they should be worthy of the second miracle, because of the truth of Selah, that this miracle will be eternal and no calamity will come upon them afterward, as it is written. (The matter was copied in the collection of the holy teachings, section 36).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine intervention and the nature of miracles, particularly in the context of the plagues in Egypt. It highlights that the miraculous events, such as the survival of certain crops during the plague of hail, were not merely for the benefit of the Israelites but served to intensify their suffering with the subsequent plague of locusts. The author references a historical event where a miraculous deliverance occurred, emphasizing that such miracles can serve as warnings or tests, urging the faithful to repent and pray for true salvation. Ultimately, the text conveys that genuine readiness for divine assistance is essential for experiencing lasting redemption.

passage_content: וכן אמרתי אז כי אף שניצלנו מן הצרה לע"ע ונהייתה לנו ישועה גדולה, אבל הראו לנו מן השמים בזה התראה לשוב להשי"ת שלא יחזור וישנה פרשת הפורעניות, ובעוה"ר לא ארכו הימים ובא עלינו גזירה קשה הימנה, ונאבדו בעוה"ר מסלתה ומשמנה של בית ישראל ונשארנו מיעוטא דמיעוטא בשפל המצב באין גודר גדר ועומד בפרץ וגם אנו שניצלנו בניסי נסים מי יודע אם לא הי' ח"ו זה הנס כדי להתנוסס, וכמה וכמה מאחב"י שניצולו בשנות השואה עפ"י נס, והם עתה עוה"פ באותה צרה עצמה ואשרי אדם מפחד תמיד, השי"ת יודע מה יעבור עוד מהחבלי משיח הקשים, וכל עוד שלא שמענו שופרו של משיח צדקינו אין אנו יודעים אם לא הי' זה הנס כמו הנס דברד שהי' רק כדי להניח מקום למכת הארבה, השי"ת ירחם עלינו ויוציאנו מאפילה לאורה ונזכה לומר הנה אלקינו זה קוינו לו ויושיענו זה ה' קוינו לו נגילה ונשמחה בישועתו.
translation: And so I said then that even though we have been saved from the trouble for now and a great salvation has come to us, they have shown us from the heavens a warning to return to the Blessed One, so that the portion of calamities does not return and repeat. And woe to us, the days did not prolong, and a harsh decree came upon us, and we have lost, woe to us, the cream of the crop of the House of Israel, and we remain a small minority in a lowly state without a fence to protect us, standing in the breach. And even we who were saved by miraculous miracles, who knows if this miracle was not, Heaven forbid, just to be a banner, and how many of our brethren who were saved during the years of the Holocaust by a miracle, and they are now, alas, in that very same trouble. Blessed is the person who is always afraid; the Blessed One knows what further pains of the Messiah we will endure. As long as we have not heard the shofar of our righteous Messiah, we do not know if this miracle was like the miracle of the hail, which was only to make way for the plague of locusts. May the Blessed One have mercy on us and take us out of darkness to light, and may we merit to say, "Behold, our God, this is what we hoped for, and He will save us; this is the Lord, we hoped for Him, we will rejoice and be glad in His salvation."
summary: The passage reflects on the transient nature of salvation and the need for repentance to avoid future calamities. It emphasizes that despite experiencing miraculous deliverance, the Jewish people must remain vigilant and aware of the potential for renewed suffering. The author draws parallels between past and present hardships, suggesting that even miraculous escapes may serve as a precursor to further trials. Ultimately, it expresses a deep yearning for redemption and the hope that divine mercy will lead to a brighter future.

passage_content: ולזה אמה"כ ולמען תספר באזני בנך וב"ב וגו' (עי' לעיל קושיא ב') דהנה כתב המהר"ל מפראג הטעם שפותחין הדלת בשפוך חמתך, להודיע לבנינו ולפרסם מה שקבלה בידינו מן הנביאים, שטרם שיבוא הגואל צדק יקדים אלי' הנביא לבוא, ולהשריש בלבות הקטנים שהגאולה שלימה תלוי' בביאת אליהו הנביא, ועד שלא הקדים אליהו לבוא לא נטעה בגאולה של שקר, וכמו"כ אנו יכולים ללמוד ממכת הארבה ע"ד שכתב האלשיך הק' דמכת הארבה הי' רק ע"י הנס שהי' במכת ברד, ונשכיל מזה שלא להתפעל מנס הנעשה לרשעים, שהנס הוא אך לרעתם ולייסרם בסופם, ולז"א במכת הארבה ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך, כדי להשריש בהם אמונת אומן שלא להתפעל אף מנסים בענין הגאולה, וא"א שתהי' גאולה אמיתית כ"א שיקדים אלי' הנביא לבוא כנ"ל, ולזה הסמיכו בזוה"ק לכאן הפסוק אשרי העם יודעי תרועה, דעד שלא שמענו שופר של משיח אין זה גאולה אמיתית ולא נטעה עצמינו בגאולה כוזבת, רק נצפה לישועת השי"ת ולביאת אליהו המבשר טוב, ונזכה לזה במהרה בנחת ובשמחה בלי צרה ועקתא בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And for this, as it is written, "And in order that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson" (see above question 2), behold, the Maharal of Prague wrote the reason why we open the door during "Pour out Your wrath," to inform our children and to publicize what we have received from the prophets, that before the righteous Redeemer comes, the prophet Elijah will come first, and to instill in the hearts of the young ones that the complete redemption depends on the coming of Elijah the prophet. Until Elijah comes first, we should not be misled by a false redemption. Likewise, we can learn from the plague of locusts, as written by the holy Alshich, that the plague of locusts was only through the miracle that occurred with the plague of hail, and we should understand from this not to be swayed by miracles that happen to the wicked, for the miracle is only for their detriment and to punish them in the end. Therefore, it is said in the plague of locusts, "And in order that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson," to instill in them a firm belief not to be swayed even by miracles regarding the redemption. True redemption cannot occur unless the prophet Elijah comes first, as mentioned above. For this reason, the Zohar connects here the verse "Blessed is the people that knows the sound of the shofar," that until we hear the shofar of the Messiah, this is not true redemption, and we should not deceive ourselves with a false redemption. Rather, we await the salvation of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the coming of Elijah who announces good tidings, and may we merit this speedily, peacefully, and joyfully, without trouble or distress, with the uplifting of the horn of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of teaching future generations about the true nature of redemption, which is contingent upon the coming of the prophet Elijah before the arrival of the Messiah. It warns against being misled by false redemptions and stresses that genuine salvation cannot occur without Elijah's announcement. The text draws on historical events, such as the plagues in Egypt, to illustrate that miraculous occurrences should not distract from the true path of faith. Ultimately, it expresses a hopeful anticipation for the authentic redemption and the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו ואת לב עבדיו למען שיתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, צ"ב הכוונה באומרו "אלה" ולא ביארם, גם מלת בקרבו צ"ב.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants, in order that I may place these signs of Mine within him." It is necessary to understand the meaning of His saying "these" and not explaining them, and also the word "within him" is also in need of clarification.
summary: In this passage, God instructs Moses to approach Pharaoh, emphasizing that He has hardened Pharaoh's heart and that of his servants to demonstrate His signs within them. The use of the term "these" without specifying the signs suggests a deeper, intrinsic connection to the divine will and the unfolding of God's plan. The phrase "within him" indicates that the signs are not merely external manifestations but are meant to penetrate the inner essence of Pharaoh and his people, highlighting the transformative power of divine revelation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the interplay between divine sovereignty and human agency, illustrating how spiritual truths can be revealed through challenging circumstances.

passage_content: ב) תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך את אשר התעללתי במצרים, לכאורה עיקר הסיפור ראוי להיות שהקב"ה הציל את ישראל מתחת יד מצרים. כי אלו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים הרי אנו ובנינו ובני בנינו משועבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, ובחסדי השי"ת ניצולו ישראל ונאבדו המצריים, אבל מדוע חייבה אותנו תוה"ק לספר פרעי המכות ובכמה מכות הכו המצריים ואיך שהתעולל הקב"ה בהם כמ"ש למען תספר וגו' את אשר התעללתי במצרים.
translation: B) You shall tell your son and your grandson about what I did to the Egyptians. It seems that the main point of the story should be that the Holy One, Blessed be He, saved Israel from the hand of Egypt. For if the Holy One, Blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out of Egypt, we and our children and our children's children would have been enslaved to Pharaoh in Egypt. And by the grace of the Holy One, Blessed be He, Israel was saved and the Egyptians were lost. But why does the Torah obligate us to recount the plagues and how many plagues the Egyptians were struck with, and how the Holy One, Blessed be He, dealt with them, as it is written, "so that you may tell..." about what I did to the Egyptians?
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of recounting the story of the Exodus from Egypt, highlighting that while God's salvation of the Israelites is central, the Torah also instructs us to detail the plagues and the suffering inflicted upon the Egyptians. This serves to illustrate God's power and justice, demonstrating that the narrative is not solely about liberation but also about divine retribution. The act of storytelling is a means to instill faith and awareness of God's involvement in history, ensuring that future generations recognize the significance of these events. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine mercy and justice.

passage_content: ג) ר"פ זו ר' יהודה פתח ואמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ה' באור פניך יהלכון וכו' צ"ב קישור פסוק זה לכאן. ובהגהות מהרח"ו פי' סמיכות פסוק זה כאן, יראה כי משה צפה שהשטן הי' מקטרג על יציאת ישראל ממצרים, וזה הי' בר"ה וכו' עכ"ד, וקשה הרי מכת ארבה לא הי' בר"ה כ"א בר"ח ניסן סמוך ליציאתם.
translation: 3) In this section, Rabbi Yehuda opened and said, "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar; they shall walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance," etc. It is necessary to connect this verse here. And in the glosses of the Maharal, it is explained that the proximity of this verse here indicates that Moses foresaw that the Satan would accuse regarding the departure of Israel from Egypt, and this was on Rosh Hashanah, etc. However, it is difficult, for the plague of locusts did not occur on Rosh Hashanah, but rather on the first of Nissan, close to their departure.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, Rabbi Yehuda reflects on the verse "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar," linking it to the spiritual significance of Rosh Hashanah. The commentary by the Maharcho suggests that Moses foresaw the Satan's accusations against the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, which occurred during this time. Despite the plague of locusts not happening on Rosh Hashanah but rather on the 1st of Nissan, the text emphasizes the importance of divine protection and the role of repentance and awareness in overcoming spiritual adversities. This highlights key Hasidic themes of faith, divine providence, and the transformative power of awareness in the face of challenges.

passage_content: ד) פרעה אל משה ויאמר לכו עבדו את ה' רק צאנכם ובקרכם יצג גם טפכם ילך עמכם, הקשה הכלי יקר ז"ל דאם צאנם ובקרם יצג א"כ מה יזבחו, ואיך אמר לכו עבדו את ה' והוא עצמו מעכב בידם, גם צ"ב מדוע נתהפך דעתו אחר מכת החושך, ומתחלה אמר לכו נא הגברים וגו' ורצה למנוע ולעכב הליכת הטף, ולא הזכיר מניעת הצאן והבקר, ואח"כ הסכים על הטף ורצה למנוע הצאן ובקר.
translation: 4) Pharaoh said to Moses, "Go, serve the Lord; only your flocks and your herds shall be left behind; even your little ones may go with you." The כלי יקר (Kli Yakar) asks, if their flocks and herds are to remain, then what will they sacrifice? And how could he say, "Go, serve the Lord," while he himself is preventing them? It is also puzzling why his mind changed after the plague of darkness. Initially, he said, "Go, now, you men," and wanted to prevent and hold back the little ones, and he did not mention preventing the flocks and herds. Later, he agreed to let the little ones go but wanted to prevent the flocks and herds.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Pharaoh's contradictory commands to Moses regarding the Israelites' worship of God, highlighting the theological tension between Pharaoh's acknowledgment of God's authority and his refusal to let the people go fully. The question arises about the significance of Pharaoh allowing the livestock to remain behind, which raises concerns about the nature of true worship and sacrifice. Additionally, the shift in Pharaoh's stance after the plague of darkness reflects the struggle between spiritual liberation and material attachment, emphasizing the complexity of human resistance to divine will. This illustrates key Hasidic themes of the inner conflict between the soul's desire for connection with God and the distractions of worldly concerns.
