passage_content: ומ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים במדבר ונזבחה לד' אלקינו והאוחה"ק נדחק בזה וכתב כי ה' לא אמר פרט זה אלא ישראל והי' צורך לזה להטעות לב פרעה שירדוף אחריהם עיי"ש, ול"נ שאמת יהגה חכו של משרע"ה, כי לא אמר שאחר ג' ימים יחזרו, רק שאחר הליכת ג' ימים יעבדו את ד', ובאמת כן הי' שאז נתעלו ישראל וזכו לעבדות ה' בבחי' יותר מעולה וגבוה, דכל זמן שהיו במצרים אף שנתעלו בעשור לחדש שמשכו ידיהם מע"ז וקבלו עליהם עול מלכותו ית', מ"מ עדיין היו משוקעים עד רגע אחרונה ליציאתם כמאמה"כ ולא יכלו להתמהמה, ורק כשיצאו התחילו בעבודה האמיתית ונקי' מכל זוהמת טומאת מצרים, וידוע שעבודת יום השבת מקודשת יותר, ואינו דומה עבודת יום חול לעבודת יום השבת, וישראל יצאו ממצרים בחמישי בשבת, נמצא יום שלישי להליכתם הי' שבת ולז"א נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה לד' אלקינו, כי אז יזכו ישראל לשלימות העבודה מה שא"א להשיג להם בעודם במצרים ואף אחר שיצאו כ"א ליום השלישי מיציאתם והבן.
translation: And regarding the statement, "Let us go three days' journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God," the holy one, blessed be He, was troubled by this and wrote that the Holy One did not mention this detail except for Israel, and it was necessary to mislead the heart of Pharaoh so that he would pursue them, as explained there. And I believe that the truth is that Moshe Rabbeinu was hinting, for he did not say that after three days they would return, but rather that after walking three days they would serve the Lord. And indeed, it was so that then Israel ascended and merited to serve the Lord in a more elevated and higher manner, for as long as they were in Egypt, even though they ascended on the tenth of the month when they withdrew their hands from idolatry and accepted upon themselves the yoke of His kingdom, nevertheless, they were still immersed until the very last moment of their departure, as it is written, and they could not delay. Only when they left did they begin the true service, cleansed from all the impurity of Egypt. And it is known that the service of the Sabbath day is more sanctified, and the service of a weekday is not comparable to the service of the Sabbath day. And Israel left Egypt on the fifth of the Sabbath, thus the third day of their journey was a Sabbath. Therefore, it is said, "Let us go three days' journey and sacrifice to the Lord our God," for then Israel would merit the completeness of the service that they could not achieve while still in Egypt, and even after they left, except on the third day of their departure. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' request to journey three days into the desert to worship God, emphasizing that this was a strategic move to mislead Pharaoh into pursuing them. It highlights that the true elevation of the Israelites' service to God began only after their departure from Egypt, as they were still tainted by its impurities. The text notes that their journey coincided with the Sabbath, a day of heightened sanctity, allowing them to achieve a more profound level of divine service that was unattainable while in Egypt. Thus, the three-day journey symbolizes a transition to a purer and more elevated form of worship.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפ"י דרכנו הראשון דברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל ר"י פתח אשרי העם יודעי תרועה וגו', עפי"מ שפי' הנוע"מ זלה"ה בספה"ק אמרות טהורות (תהלים פ"ט) אשרי העם יודעי תרועה, שיודעים וזוכרים הדין, בעת שבאור פניך יהלכון בעת טובתם, ומקדימין רצון לצרה ועושין תשובה בזמן הטובה עכ"ל, והנה כבר ביארנו לעיל דהכבדת לב פרעה הי' ע"י שנעשה לו נס בהשארת החטה והכוסמת, גם כתבו התוס' (בכורות מ"א ע"א) דשחין מצרים יבש מבפנים הי' ולא מתסי, ואם נתרפאו ממנו המצריים שמא מעשה נס הי' עכ"ל, ובראותם הצלתם בדרך נס נתחזק לבם יותר, והוא ית' משחק בהם מראה להם הרוחה, כדי לתת מקום שיחולו עליו יתר המכות כולן, דאלמלא נשארו החטה והכוסמת בברד, במה תחול מכת הארבה וכן כולן עד"ז, אמנם פרעה הרשע נתגדל בלבבו והתפאר שהקב"ה עושה לו נסים ומגין עליו להצילו מן הפורעניות ועי"ז נתוסף לו טומאה על טומאתו, לכן הסמיכו בזוה"ק לכאן אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון, שאיש ישראל צריך שיהי' לבו נשבר בקרבו בכגון דא, ואף אם יש רגלים לדבר שנעשו לו נסים מצד הקדושה, מ"מ מפחד מחרדת הדין אף בעת שבאור פניך יהלכון ועושים תשובה בזמן הטובה ועי"ז זוכים להיות טובתן נצחית.
translation: And even according to our first approach, the words of the Zohar mentioned above, Rabbi Yoel opened with "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," etc. According to what the Noda B'Yehuda, may his memory be blessed, explained in the holy book "Amarot Tahorot" (Psalms 89), "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," that they know and remember the judgment, at the time when they walk in the light of Your countenance during their good times, and they prioritize desire over trouble and repent in times of goodness, thus it is written. And behold, we have already explained above that the hardening of Pharaoh's heart was due to the miracle of the preservation of the wheat and the spelt. The Tosafot also wrote (Baba Kamma 41a) that the boils of Egypt were dry from within and not from the outside, and if the Egyptians were healed from it, perhaps it was a miraculous act. And upon seeing their salvation through a miracle, their hearts were strengthened even more, and He, blessed be He, played with them, showing them relief, in order to give room for all the other plagues to befall them, for if the wheat and the spelt had remained intact in the hail, how would the plague of locusts come upon them, and so on. However, the wicked Pharaoh grew proud in his heart and boasted that the Holy One, blessed be He, was performing miracles for him and protecting him from calamities, and thereby he added impurity to his impurity. Therefore, it is connected in the Zohar to here, "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," that "in the light of Your countenance they walk," for a Jew needs to have a broken heart within him in such matters, and even if there are grounds to say that miracles were done for him from the side of holiness, nevertheless, out of fear of the dread of judgment, even at the time when "in the light of Your countenance they walk," they repent in times of goodness, and thereby merit to have their goodness be eternal.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of recognizing divine intervention and the need for humility in the face of God's blessings. It emphasizes that true understanding and remembrance of God's judgments should lead individuals to repentance, especially during times of goodness. The text contrasts the hardened heart of Pharaoh, who became arrogant due to miraculous events, with the ideal behavior of the Jewish people, who should maintain a broken spirit and fear of divine judgment, ensuring their eternal goodness. Ultimately, it highlights the necessity of balancing gratitude for divine favor with a profound awareness of one's spiritual state.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר במאה"כ כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רופאך שהקשו במכילתא אם אין בהם מחלה מפני מה צריכים רפואה, גם מדוע שלל הכתוב מחלה אשר שמתי במצרים דייקא, וכמו"כ יצילנו הקב"ה מכל המחלות, אולם לפי דרכנו הנ"ל המחלה אשר שם ד' במצרים הי' בסיבת הרפואה שקדמה לה, דע"י שנתרפאו משחין בדרך נס הי' באפשרותם לקבל עוד מחלות וכן כולם עד"ז, אמנם אם הבוי"ת מרפא, רפואתו נצחית ולא יוסיף עצב עמה לגרום עוד מחלה, רק רפואתו של פרעה והמצרים הי' בשליחות השטן להוסיף טומאה על טומאתו ולהכביד לבו וסופו לגרום להם אבדון, ולז"א אם שמוע תשמע לקול ד' אלקיך והישר בעיניו תעשה וגו' כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך, שהי' המחלה ע"י סיבת הרפואה שקדמה לה כי אני ד' רופאך ויהי' רפואתך נצחי ולא יגרום אחרי' מחלה.
translation: And similarly, it will be explained in the verse, "All the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer." The Mechilta questions why, if there are no sicknesses among them, they need healing. It also asks why the verse specifically excludes the sickness that I placed in Egypt. Likewise, may the Holy One, blessed be He, save us from all sicknesses. However, according to our aforementioned approach, the sickness that the Lord placed in Egypt was due to the healing that preceded it. For by being healed from boils in a miraculous way, it was possible for them to receive further sicknesses, and so on. However, if the Blessed One heals, His healing is eternal and does not bring sorrow with it to cause further sickness. Rather, the healing of Pharaoh and the Egyptians was through the agency of the Satan to add impurity to their impurity and to harden his heart, ultimately leading to their destruction. Therefore, it is said, "If you will listen to the voice of the Lord your God and do what is right in His eyes... all the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you," for the sickness was due to the healing that preceded it, because I am the Lord your Healer, and your healing will be eternal and will not cause further sickness afterward.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine healing, emphasizing that the illnesses inflicted in Egypt were ultimately for the purpose of healing, as God is the eternal healer. It contrasts God's healing, which is permanent and does not lead to further suffering, with the temporary remedies of Pharaoh and the Egyptians, which were influenced by evil and resulted in greater affliction. The text underscores that true healing from God is free from the pain of subsequent illness, highlighting the transformative power of divine intervention.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה שאיש ישראל צריך להיות תמיד לבו נשבר בקרבו, אף בעת שזוכה להיות באור פניך יהלכון כבחי' שכתב בספה"ק נוע"מ הנ"ל, ובעוה"ר רחוקים אנו מבחי' זו של באור פניך יהלכון וההסתרת פנים גדולה מאוד, השי"ת ירחם על עמו וישפיע בלבבות בנ"י קדושה וטהרה ויאיר עינינו שנזכה לראות האמת, ונזכה לעשות תשובה שלימה וכל אחד ישתדל להשריש האמונה בלב בניו וב"ב ועי"ז יתחזק גם הוא באמונתו והשגתו בידיעת ה', וז"פ הסמיכות ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו' ועי"ז וידעתם כי אני ד' וחלילה להיפך גם בעצמו לא ידע ויסוג אחור ר"ל, הבוכ"ע יעזור שנזכה לקבל אור פניו ית"ש, בהתרוממת קרן התורה וישראל ובישועה שלימה ואמיתית בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: The conclusion we draw from this is that a Jew must always have a broken heart within him, even at times when he is privileged to walk in the light of Your countenance, as written in the holy book Nefesh HaChaim mentioned above. And, alas, we are far from this state of walking in the light of Your countenance, and the concealment of the face is very great. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on His people and instill in the hearts of the Jewish people holiness and purity, and may He illuminate our eyes so that we merit to see the truth, and may we merit to make complete repentance. Each one should strive to instill faith in the hearts of his children and household, and through this, he will also strengthen himself in his faith and understanding of the knowledge of God. And this is the meaning of the proximity to "and you shall tell your son and your son's son, etc." and through this "and you shall know that I am the Lord," and God forbid the opposite, for if one does not know himself, he will turn away, Heaven forbid. May the Blessed One help us to merit to receive the light of His countenance, with the elevation of the crown of the Torah and Israel, and with complete and true salvation through the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, speedily and in our days.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of a broken heart in the spiritual life of a Jew, even when experiencing divine light. It reflects on the current distance from this divine illumination and the significant concealment of God's presence. The author prays for mercy and the awakening of holiness within the hearts of the Jewish people, encouraging the transmission of faith to future generations. Ultimately, it expresses a longing for redemption and the revelation of God's glory.

passage_content: ויאמר ד' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אתתי אלה בקרבו, יל"ד דכבר הודיע השי"ת למשה כ"פ בפרשיות הקודמת שיחזק את לב פרעה, כמ"ש (בפ' שמות) ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו' והכיתי את מצרים בכל נפלאתי ואח"כ ישלח אתכם, ועוד א"ל השם ואני אחזק את לבו ולא ישלח את העם, ובפ' וארא ואני אקשה את לב פרעה והרבתי את אתתי וגו', ולמה הי' הצורך לכפול עוד ולהודיעו במכת הארבה בפרטיות כי אני הכבדתי את לבו, והרי כבר ידע משה רבינו בזה.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc., in order to place these signs of Mine in his midst." It is known that the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses multiple times in the previous sections that He would strengthen Pharaoh's heart, as it is written (in Parashat Shemot), "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, etc., and I will strike Egypt with all My wonders, and afterwards he will send you." Furthermore, the Lord said to him, "And I will strengthen his heart, and he will not send the people," and in Parashat Va'era, "And I will harden Pharaoh's heart and increase My signs, etc." So why was there a need to repeat and inform him specifically regarding the plague of locusts that "I have hardened his heart," when Moses already knew this?
summary: In this passage, the Divine communication to Moses emphasizes the intentional hardening of Pharaoh's heart to demonstrate God's power through the plagues. The repetition of this theme serves to reinforce the idea that God's sovereignty is paramount, and that the unfolding events are part of a divine plan to reveal His might. This highlights the theological concept of divine intervention in human affairs, illustrating that even the obstinacy of Pharaoh is under God's control to fulfill His purpose. Ultimately, it underscores the relationship between divine will and human agency within the context of redemption.

passage_content: ב) יש לשאול דהול"ל למען שתי מכותי או מופתי, ולמה אמר הכתוב אתתי, וכתב רש"י ז"ל (בפ' ואתחנן) באותות הם סימנין להאמין שהוא שלוחו של מקום כגון מה זה בידך, במופתים הם נפלאות שהביא עליהם מכות מופלאות, וא"כ יצדק על המכות לומר מופתי ולא אותתי, וכן הקשה האריז"ל בס' הלקוטים עיי"ש.
translation: B) One should ask why it should say "for the sake of two signs" or "for the sake of wonders," and why the scripture says "I have given signs." And Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote (in Parashat Va'etchanan) that "signs" are indications to believe that it is the messenger of the Holy One, Blessed be He, such as "What is this in your hand?" In contrast, "wonders" are the miraculous plagues that He brought upon them. Therefore, it would be more appropriate to refer to the plagues as "wonders" rather than "signs." And thus, the Arizal also posed this question in the book of Lekutim; see there.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between "signs" (אותות) and "wonders" (מופתים) in the context of divine intervention. It references Rashi's interpretation that signs serve as indicators of God's messenger, while wonders refer to miraculous plagues. The text raises a theological question about why the term "signs" is used instead of "wonders" when describing the plagues, suggesting a deeper understanding of God's communication and the nature of His miracles. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of faith and the recognition of divine presence in the world.

translation: 3) Regarding "I have come to these," it is known that wherever it says "these" it disqualifies the earlier ones, and what does the verse come to exclude in saying "I have come to these and not others."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "these" in the context of divine communication, emphasizing that it serves to exclude previous interpretations or teachings. This highlights a Hasidic concept of renewal and the importance of direct, personal revelation from the Divine. The text suggests that the specific mention of "these" indicates a unique and current understanding that supersedes earlier ones, reflecting a dynamic relationship between the Divine and humanity. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that spiritual insights are continually evolving and must be approached with fresh perspectives.

passage_content: ד) תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו', הקשה הכלי יקר למה נאמר במכת הארבה למען תספר יותר מבשאר המכות, והרי כמו"כ נצטווינו לספר בכל הנסים שעשה ד' בהוציאנו ממצרים שנא' והגדת לבנך וגו', ותירץ הכלי יקר עפימ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בש"ר חננאל עה"פ לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים, כי מעת עתרת תפלת משה רבינו שיוסר הארבה מאמ"צ ועד היום הזה, אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים, ואם יפול בא"י ויכנס בגבול מצרים אין אוכל מן יבול מצרים כלום וזה ידוע לכל, וע"ז נאמר שיחו בכל נפלאותיו עכ"ל ר"ח ז"ל, וכתב הכלי יקר ז"ל כי בזה יובן הפסוק למען תספר באזני בנך וגו', כי יראו הדורות דבר חידוש כזה, כי יבא הארבה ולא יאכל כלום מכל גבול מצרים וישאלו הבנים על נס זה, ויצטרכו להשיב להם סיפור כל הקורות באמ"צ, וזהו שמסיים ר"ח בדבריו פסוק שיחו בכל נפלאותיו, כי בלי ספק לכך השאיר הקב"ה רושם זה לדורות, שעל ידו יזכרו יצ"מ, וז"ש למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך ופי' זה יקר ונכון מאוד. עכת"ד הכלי יקר ז"ל. אמנם לכאורה עדיין אין הדעת מתיישבת בזה, כי איך יסובב נס זה לידי סיפור בני ישראל, ונס זה יהי' ידוע רק למצריים הגרים שם, אבל לא לבנ"י שהזהירם הכתוב בלא תשוב מצרימה והכתוב אומר למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך והוא ציווי על דורות ישראל, ולא מצינו שיספרו ישראל בנס זה ואינו מפורסם כלל, ואלולי הר"ח גילה לנו דבר זה, לא היינו יודעין בו כלל, ואיך יובן שע"ז אמה"כ למען תספר באזני בנך וצ"ב.
translation: 4) "You shall tell your son and your grandson," the Kli Yakar asks why it is stated regarding the plague of locusts "so that you may tell" more than regarding the other plagues, and indeed we are also commanded to recount all the miracles that God performed in taking us out of Egypt, as it is said, "and you shall tell your son," etc. The Kli Yakar answers according to what the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, said in the name of Chananiel on the verse "There remained not one locust in all the border of Egypt," that from the time of the fervent prayer of our teacher Moses that the locusts be removed from Egypt until this day, locusts do not destroy anything in all the borders of Egypt, and if they fall in the Land of Israel and enter the borders of Egypt, they do not eat anything from the produce of Egypt, and this is known to all. And for this it is said, "Speak of all His wonders," thus far the words of R' Chaim, may his memory be blessed. The Kli Yakar, may his memory be blessed, wrote that this explains the verse "so that you may tell your son and your grandson," for the generations will see such a novelty, that locusts will come and eat nothing from all the borders of Egypt, and the children will ask about this miracle, and they will need to respond to them recounting all the events in Egypt, and this is what R' Chaim concludes in his words with the verse "Speak of all His wonders," for without a doubt, this is why the Holy One, blessed be He, left this mark for the generations, by which they will remember the Exodus from Egypt. Therefore, it is said "so that you may tell your son and your grandson," and this explanation is precious and very correct. Thus far the Kli Yakar, may his memory be blessed. However, at first glance, the mind does not settle with this, for how will this miracle lead to the recounting by the children of Israel, and this miracle will only be known to the Egyptians living there, but not to the children of Israel, who were warned by the scripture not to return to Egypt, and the scripture says "so that you may tell your son and your grandson," and this is a command for the generations of Israel, and we do not find that Israel recounts this miracle, and it is not publicized at all, and were it not for R' Chaim revealing this matter to us, we would not know of it at all, and how can it be understood that for this the scripture says "so that you may tell your son," and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of recounting the miracles of the plagues, particularly the plague of locusts, as a means to instill faith and memory in future generations. The "Kli Yakar" explains that the unique nature of the locust plague, which did not harm the crops of Egypt due to Moses' prayers, serves as a lasting reminder of God's wonders. This miraculous event is intended to prompt questions from children, leading to discussions about the Exodus and God's interventions. The text emphasizes the importance of storytelling in preserving the memory of divine acts across generations, even if the specific miracle may not be widely known among the Israelites.

passage_content: ה) הענין צ"ב, דלמה זכו מצרים לברכה זו שיוסר מהם עונש הארבה לדורות עולם, הלא הסרת הארבה מהם הי' ע"צ העונש ולרעתם, כמ"ש במדרש ששמחו המצרים במכת הארבה, אמרו נקבוץ ונמלא מהם חביות, אמר הקב"ה במכה שהבאתי עליכם בה אתם שמחים, מיד ויהפוך ד' רוח ים וגו' לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים. אף המלוחים פרחו והלכו להם ע"כ המדרש. והנה לטעם זה יספיק הסרת הארבה הנמצא בגבולם באותה שעה כדי שלא יהנו מהם, אבל מדוע זכו שיוסר מהם עונש הארבה לדורות וטעמא בעי. והגם שבודאי תפלת משרע"ה כוחו נצחי ועומדת לעד, אבל הי"ל למשה רבינו להתפלל באופן שיוסר מהם עתה ויחזור עליהם לאח"ז ע"צ העונש. ולפי"ז השתכרו עוד ממכת הארבה, ולמה הגיע עליהם ככה.
translation: The matter is difficult to understand, why did Egypt merit this blessing that the punishment of the locusts would be removed from them for all generations? After all, the removal of the locusts from them was a punishment and for their detriment, as it is said in the Midrash that the Egyptians rejoiced in the plague of locusts, saying, "Let us gather and fill barrels with them." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "In the plague that I brought upon you, you rejoice," and immediately the Lord turned the wind of the sea, and there was not a single locust left in all the borders of Egypt. Even the salted ones flew away and left, thus says the Midrash. Now, for this reason, the removal of the locusts that were in their borders at that time would suffice so that they would not benefit from them, but why did they merit that the punishment of the locusts be removed from them for generations, and the reason is needed. And although certainly the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu has eternal power and stands forever, he could have prayed in such a way that the locusts would be removed from them now and return upon them later as a punishment. According to this, they would have still profited from the plague of locusts, so why did this happen to them?
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of why the Egyptians were spared from the lasting punishment of locusts, despite their initial joy in the plague. It highlights that while Moses' prayer had eternal power, it raises the question of why he did not pray for a temporary removal of the locusts, allowing for their eventual return as a punishment. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine justice and mercy, suggesting that the Egyptians' enjoyment of the plague led to a more profound consequence than mere immediate suffering. Ultimately, it emphasizes the complexity of divine retribution and the interplay between human actions and divine will.

translation: "And I have mocked, as Rashi explains, I have played; the holy Alshich questions why the blow is called 'laughter'."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the concept of divine playfulness, as indicated by the term "שחוק" (laughter) used to describe God's actions. The question posed by the Alshich highlights the paradox of calling a painful experience a form of laughter, suggesting that even in suffering, there is a deeper, joyful purpose orchestrated by the Divine. This illustrates a key Hasidic idea that challenges believers to find meaning and joy within their trials, emphasizing the belief that God's intentions are ultimately benevolent, even when they are not immediately apparent. Thus, the passage invites a perspective that sees divine wisdom and joy interwoven with human experience, encouraging faith in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ז) את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ. פרש"י לשון קצרה דבר, שהול"ל ולא יוכל הרואה לראות את הארץ: לכאורה כל המאמר ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ מיותר, דכבר אמר שיהי' הארץ מכוסה, ומה לו להכתוב להודיע עוד שלא יוכל לראות את הארץ, ומובן מאליו.
translation: 7) The eye of the land, and he will not be able to see the land. Rashi explains that it is a brief expression, as it could have said, "and the seer will not be able to see the land." At first glance, the entire statement "and he will not be able to see the land" seems superfluous, for it has already been stated that the land will be covered, and what need is there to write that he will not be able to see the land, which is self-evident.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual perception and the limitations of human understanding in relation to the divine. It highlights that even when the land is concealed, the inability to see it signifies a deeper spiritual blindness. This reflects the Hasidic idea that true insight requires more than mere physical sight; it necessitates a profound connection to the divine. The redundancy in the statement emphasizes the importance of recognizing the barriers to spiritual awareness.

passage_content: ח) צ"ב משפרש"י וכסה את עין הארץ את מראה הארץ, ובתרגום אונקלס עין שמשא דארעא, וכוונת הכתוב לפי"ז דמראה הארץ יהי' מכוסה, וגם ניצוץ וזריחת השמש הנופל על הארץ יהי' מכוסה מרוב הארבה, וקשה דהול"ל וכסה את הארץ ומלת עין מיותר לגמרי, דמה נפק"מ אם מראה הארץ ומראה זריחת השמש מכוסה, או הארץ עצמה מכוסה מרוב הארבה, ואדרבה זו קללה גרוע יותר שכל הארץ יהי' מכוסה בארבה, ולהלן הוא אומר ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ, וכן ותחשך הארץ ולא אמר עין הארץ ומשמע דהארץ עצמה יהי' מכוסה, ולמה יאמר כאן עין הארץ ויותר יצדק לומר עין הרואה, כמשפרש"י ז"ל ולא יוכל לראות הרואה וכו', הרי שהכתוב מדבר בעין הרואה, ועין הארץ אין לו ענין לכאן וצ"ב.
translation: (8) It is difficult to understand the explanation of Rashi, "and He covered the eye of the land, the appearance of the land," and in the translation of Onkelos, "the eye of the sun that shines upon the land." The intent of the verse, according to this, is that the appearance of the land will be covered, and also the spark and the rising of the sun that falls upon the land will be covered due to the abundance of the locusts. It is difficult, for it could have simply said, "and He covered the land," and the word "eye" is entirely superfluous. What difference does it make if the appearance of the land and the appearance of the rising sun are covered, or if the land itself is covered due to the locusts? On the contrary, this is a worse curse, that the entire land will be covered with locusts. Later, it says, "and he will not be able to see the land," and similarly, "and the land was darkened," and it does not say "the eye of the land," implying that the land itself will be covered. Why then does it say here "the eye of the land," and it would be more fitting to say "the eye that sees," as Rashi explains, "and the seer will not be able to see," etc.? Thus, the verse speaks of the eye that sees, and "the eye of the land" has no relevance here, and it is difficult to understand.
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "and cover the eye of the land" from the Torah, questioning its significance and the use of the term "eye." It suggests that the "eye of the land" symbolizes the perception of the land's beauty and the sunlight, which will be obscured by the locust plague. The text emphasizes the deeper theological insight that this covering represents not just a physical obstruction but a spiritual blindness, where the divine light and beauty of creation are hidden from view, reflecting a more profound curse than mere physical coverage.

passage_content: ט) (פרשה זו רמז קפ"ו) והוא במד"ר קהלת, (פ' א' סי' ט') אמר ר"ל כל מה שברא הקב"ה באדם ברא בארץ. אדם יש לו ראש והארץ יש לה ראש שנא' וראש עפרות תבל, אדם יש לו עינים והארץ יש לה עינים שנא' ויכס את עין כל הארץ וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה לא שמעינן מהא מידי דהארץ יש לה עינים, דא"א לומר כוונת הכתוב על עין הארץ ממש, דא"כ מה דסמיך לי' ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ קאי ג"כ על עין הארץ, ואדרבה עין הארץ יראה הארבה שהרי מונח עליו, אלא ע"כ ולא יוכל לראות קאי על עין הרואה כמו שפי' ז"ל, וע"כ עין הארץ פירושו מראה הארץ או עין שמשא דארעא ולא עין הארץ ממש, ואיך נלמד מכאן דרשתם דהארץ יש לה עינים.
translation: This section hints at 116 (Kaf-Vav). It is found in the Midrash Kohelet (Chapter 1, Section 9), where Rabbi Levi said: "Everything that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created in man, He created in the earth. Man has a head, and the earth has a head, as it is said, 'And the head of the dust of the earth.' Man has eyes, and the earth has eyes, as it is said, 'And He covered the eye of all the earth,' etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. At first glance, we do not hear anything from this regarding the earth having eyes, for it is impossible to say that the intent of the verse refers to the eye of the earth itself, for if so, what is meant by 'and He will not be able to see the earth' also referring to the eye of the earth? On the contrary, the eye of the earth will see the locust, as it is laid upon it. Rather, 'and He will not be able to see' refers to the eye that sees, as explained by our sages. Therefore, the eye of the earth means the appearance of the earth or the eye that bears the earth, and not the eye of the earth itself. And how do we learn from here that the earth has eyes?"
summary: The passage discusses the connection between humanity and the earth, highlighting that just as a person has a head and eyes, so too does the earth possess analogous features, symbolically referred to as its "head" and "eyes." The text emphasizes that the "eyes" of the earth do not refer to literal eyes but rather to the earth's ability to perceive and reflect the state of the world. This interpretation underscores a Hasidic understanding of the interconnectedness of creation, suggesting that both man and earth share a divine purpose and awareness. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological insight that the physical and spiritual realms are intertwined, with each reflecting the other.

passage_content: י) לא הי' כן ארבה כמוהו ואחריו לא יהי' כן, הקשה רש"י ז"ל דהרי בארבה שהי' בימי יואל כתיב כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם, למדנו שהי' כבד משל משה, ותירץ דאותו של יואל הי' של מינים הרבה ארבה וילק וחסיל וגזם, אבל הארבה שבימי משה לא הי' אלא של מין א', וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' רבוי ארבה ממין א', והרמב"ן ז"ל הקשה על פירושו שהרי כתיב ויתן לחסיל יבולם ויגיעם לארבה, ועוד כתיב אמר ויבא ארבה וילק ואין מספר, הרי דגם אותו שבימי משה הי' של מינים הרבה, והדרא קושיא לדוכתי' למה נאמר ואחריו לא יהי' כן. ותירץ הרמב"ן ז"ל עפ"י דברי ר"ח הנ"ל דמעת תפלת משרע"ה לא יהי' ארבה עוד בגבול מצרים, ומ"ש הכתוב ואחריו לא יהי' קאי על גבול מצרים אבל יהי' בכל העולם, אולם לפי"ד יקשה למה אמה"כ ואחריו לא יהי' כן הרי לא יהי' בכלל מכה זו לא כיו"ב ולא שלא כיו"ב, והול"ל ואחריו לא יהי' וכבר פירשנו בזה אופנים שונים ועוד לאלקי מילין.
translation: 1) There will not be such a locust as this, nor will there be such after it. Rashi, of blessed memory, asked that since it is written regarding the locust in the days of Joel, "like it will not be in the world," we learn that it was heavier than that of Moses. He answered that the locust of Joel was of many species: locust, grasshopper, and beetle, but the locust in the days of Moses was only of one species, and there will not be nor will there be an abundance of locusts of one species. Nachmanides, of blessed memory, challenged this explanation, for it is written, "And He gave to the grasshopper its yield and He brought them to the locust," and it is also written, "He said, and the locust came and the grasshopper, and there is no number," thus indicating that even that of the days of Moses was of many species. The question returns to its place: why is it said, "and after it there will not be such"? Nachmanides answered, based on the words of R' Chaim mentioned above, that from the prayer of Moses, there will not be locusts again in the borders of Egypt, and what the verse means by "and after it there will not be" refers to the borders of Egypt, but there will be throughout the world. However, according to this explanation, it is difficult to understand why it says, "and after it there will not be such," since there will not be at all in this plague, neither similar nor dissimilar, and it should have said, "and after it there will not be," and we have already explained this in various ways and still to the God of words.
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of the locust plague during the time of Joel, emphasizing that it was unprecedented and more severe than any previous plague, including that of Moses. It highlights the diversity of the locust species involved in Joel's plague compared to the singular type during Moses' time. Theological insights suggest that while the plague in Egypt was limited to that region, Joel's locusts would affect the entire world, indicating a broader divine judgment. The text reflects on the complexities of interpreting scriptural prophecies and the nature of divine intervention in history.

translation: 11) "Only from this death," it is known that the "Achin" and "Rakin" are few, and what does it come to exclude by saying "only from this death"? Also, that there are two exclusions here: "only" and "this." It requires clarification for what purpose it comes.

Ultimately, it encourages a deeper exploration of the meaning of life and death within the context of divine purpose.

passage_content: יב) זש"ה אמרו לאלקים מה נורא מעשיך ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך, ישקרו ויעשו כחשים בדבריהם וכו', פרעה אמר לא ידעתי את ד', נעשה כחשן והודה ואמר ה' הצדיק, הוא אמר גם את בנ"י לא אשלח, א"ל הקב"ה למשה בא אל פרעה ועל ידך ישלח, שנא' שלח משה עבדו וגו' ויוצא עמו בששון עכ"ל, ובמד"ר (פ' כ' סי' י') איתא מאמר זה עה"פ ויהי בשלח פרעה עיי"ש, ולכאורה צ"ב דאין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, דבשעה שאמר לא ידעתי את ד' נתכוין כן באמת בדבריו, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דפרעה הי' חכם גדול ויודע את האלקים ומודה בו אבל לא הי' יודע את השם המיוחד וכעי"ז איתא בזוה"ק, ואח"כ נתוודע לו ע"י המכות כמשה"כ וידעו מצרים כי אני ד' בנטותי את ידי על מצרים וגו'. וכן מ"ש את ישראל לא אשלח, באותה שעה הי' פיו ולבו שוין ולא רצה לשלחם ברצונו, ואח"כ שלחם מחמת ההכרח ע"י שנלקה במכות גדולות ואין זה בגדר כחש וכזב אלא בגדר רשעות, וצ"ב דרשתם ז"ל.
translation: 11) As it is said, "They said to God, 'How awesome are Your deeds! In the abundance of Your might, Your enemies will lie to You, they will deceive and speak falsehoods in their words,' etc. Pharaoh said, 'I do not know the Lord,' he became a liar and acknowledged, saying, 'The Lord is righteous.' He also said, 'I will not send the Children of Israel.' The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, 'Go to Pharaoh, and through you he will send them,' as it is stated, 'Moses, His servant, was sent out with joy,' etc. And in the Midrash (Parashat Bo, Section 10) this saying is found on the verse, 'And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people,' etc. At first glance, it is difficult to understand why this is considered lying and falsehood, for at the time he said, 'I do not know the Lord,' he truly meant it in his words, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, writes that Pharaoh was a great wise man who knew God and acknowledged Him, but he did not know the special Name. Similarly, it is stated in the Zohar. And afterwards, he was made aware through the plagues, as it is written, 'And Egypt will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out My hand over Egypt,' etc. Likewise, when he said, 'I will not send Israel,' at that moment his mouth and heart were in agreement, and he did not want to send them willingly. Later, he sent them out due to necessity, after being struck by great plagues, and this is not considered lying and falsehood but rather wickedness, and the interpretation of our sages is difficult.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's denial of God's existence and his eventual acknowledgment of God's power through the plagues. It highlights the distinction between Pharaoh's initial claim of ignorance, which was not entirely false as he recognized a higher power but did not know God's true name, and his later refusal to release the Israelites willingly. The text emphasizes that Pharaoh's actions stemmed from wickedness rather than mere deceit, illustrating the complexity of human acknowledgment of divine authority and the struggle between free will and divine intervention.

passage_content: יג) את משה ואת אהרן אל פרעה ויאמר אלהם לכו עבדו את ד' וגו' מי ומי ההולכים, אבא מארי זלה"ה בקדושת יו"ט הביא מדרש בשם ס' עיר דוד וז"ל, אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, עתידים אתם אומרים מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו וזה מי ומי ההולכים, וצ"ב דמה ענין הך קרא להכא.
translation: 13) To Moses and Aaron to Pharaoh, and he said to them, "Go, serve the Lord," etc. "Who are the ones going?" My father, may his memory be a blessing, in the sanctity of the festival brought a Midrash in the name of the Book of the City of David, and it is said: Pharaoh asked, "Who are the ones going?" You are destined to say, "Who may ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who may stand in His holy place?" And this is "Who are the ones going?" And it is to be wondered what the connection of this verse is to here.
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between Moses, Aaron, and Pharaoh highlights the spiritual journey of the Israelites as they seek to serve God. Pharaoh's question, "Who is going?" reflects a deeper theological inquiry about the nature of those who ascend to holiness and engage in divine service. The reference to the Midrash from the Book of City of David suggests that the quest for spiritual elevation is a collective endeavor, emphasizing the importance of community in achieving sanctity. This interaction underscores the tension between worldly authority and the divine calling to worship, illustrating the profound significance of spiritual liberation.

passage_content: יד) ראוי להבין בתשובת משרע"ה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, דלמה כפל לומר בנערינו בבנינו והיינו הך, וגם נלך נלך ב' זימני למה ויספיק בחדא, והאברבנאל הקשה דהול"ל לשון קצרה כולנו נלך, ולמה הי' הצורך לפרוט כל סוג לבדו. ובבעה"ט כתב אמר פרעה למשה וכי סבורים אתם ליכנס לארץ והלא כולם ימותו במדבר, ולא יכנסו לארץ כ"א שנים בלבד יהושע וכלב, ועליהם אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, והאברבנאל הביא מאמר זה בשם מדרש, ומשה השיבו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ולא על יותר מבן ס' עיי"ש. ולפי"ז מ"ש בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך הכוונה על הפחותים מבן כ' בשעת הגזירה, אולם אלו הרי כבר נכללו במ"ש בנערינו, והכפל בדבריו למה.
translation: It is fitting to understand in the response of Moshe Rabbeinu, "With our young and with our old we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go," why it is repeated to say "with our young" and "with our sons," as they are essentially the same. Also, why does it say "we will go" twice, when one would suffice? The Abarbanel questioned why it wasn't stated in a shorter form, "We will all go," and what was the need to specify each category separately. In the Be'er HaTev, it is written that Pharaoh said to Moshe, "Do you think you will enter the land? But they will all die in the desert, and only Yehoshua and Kalev will enter the land." And concerning them, Pharaoh asked, "Who are the ones going?" The Abarbanel brought this saying in the name of a Midrash, and Moshe replied, "With our young and with our old we will go," for there was no decree against those under twenty or over sixty, as mentioned there. According to this, when it says "with our sons and with our daughters we will go," it refers to those under twenty at the time of the decree; however, they are already included in the mention of "with our young," so why the repetition in his words?
summary: The passage discusses Moses' response to Pharaoh regarding the Israelites' intention to leave Egypt, emphasizing the inclusion of both the young and the old. The repetition of "in our youth and in our old age" and the distinction between "our sons and our daughters" highlights the comprehensive nature of the Jewish community's journey, suggesting that all generations are vital to the collective spiritual mission. The text reflects on the theological concept that divine decrees do not apply uniformly across all ages, indicating a nuanced understanding of God's mercy and the importance of every individual in the covenantal relationship. Ultimately, it underscores the unity and continuity of the Jewish people in their quest for redemption.

passage_content: טו) בפ' קרבן פסח דברו אל כל עדת ישראל לאמר בעשור לחדש הזה ויקחו להם איש שה לבית אבות וגו', ובמכילתא לאמר צא ואמור אליהם מיד דברי ר' ישמעאל, שנא' ויצא ודבר אל בנ"י את אשר יצוה, וצ"ב דלמה צריך לימוד ע"ז, ומהיכי תיתי ימנע משה רבינו הדיבור, ובודאי שיודיע לישראל מצות השי"ת בלי איחור.
translation: 15) In the section of the Paschal Offering, it speaks to the entire congregation of Israel, saying, "On the tenth of this month, they shall take for themselves a lamb, each man according to his father's house," etc. And in the Mekhilta, it says to go and tell them immediately, as stated by Rabbi Yishmael, since it is written, "And he went out and spoke to the children of Israel that which he was commanded." And it is questioned why there is a need for this teaching, and how could Moshe Rabbeinu possibly refrain from speaking, when surely he would inform Israel of the commandments of the Holy One, blessed be He, without delay.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the commandment given to the Israelites regarding the Paschal lamb, emphasizing the importance of communication in fulfilling divine commandments. The reference to Rabbi Yishmael highlights the necessity of Moses conveying God's instructions to the people without delay, suggesting that the act of teaching and sharing divine will is crucial for spiritual connection. This underscores a key Hasidic concept that emphasizes the role of leadership and guidance in the observance of mitzvot, reflecting the relationship between the divine and the community. The passage illustrates the theological insight that timely communication of God's commandments is essential for the collective spiritual journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: טז) במכילתא (הובא ברש"י ז"ל) מפני מה הקדים הכתוב לקיחתו של פסח לשחיטתו ד' ימים, מה שלא צו' כן בפסח דורות, הי' ר' מתיא בן חרש אומר, ה"ה אומר ואעבור עליך ואראך והנה עתך עת דודים (יחזקאל ט"ז), הגיע שבועתו שנשבע הקב"ה לאברהם שיגאל את בניו, ולא הי' בידם מצות כדי שיגאלו כמ"ש ואת ערום וערי' וכו', ולפי שהיו שטופים בע"ז במצרים, וע"ז שקולה כנגד כל המצות וכו', אמר להם משכו ידיכם מע"ז והדבקו במצות עכ"ד המכילתא, ובמד"ר (פ' ט"ז סי' ג') איתא א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך אין ישראל יוצאין מכאן, עד שישחטו את אלהי מצרים לעיניהם, שאודיע להם שאין אלהיהם כלום. עכ"ד המדרש. ולכאורה קשה הרי בר"ח נצטוו ישראל במצו' זו, כמ"ש ז"ל הראהו הלבנה בחידושה וכו' והצווי הי' שיקיימו המצו' בעשור לחדש, ולפי טעם המכילתא דהקדים לקיחתו ד' ימים כדי לפרוש מע"ז, למה לא נצטוו ישראל לקיים מצו' זו מיד בר"ח, ולמה ימתינו לפרוש מע"ז עד בעשור לחדש, וכל רגע ורגע הוי פסידא דלא הדר וצ"ב.
translation:
16) In the Mechilta (brought by Rashi, may his memory be blessed), it is asked why the Torah preceded the taking of the Paschal lamb by four days before its slaughter, which is not commanded in the Paschal observance for future generations. Rabbi Mattia ben Charash would say, "He (God) says, 'And I passed over you and saw you, and behold, your time is the time of love' (Ezekiel 16)." The time of His oath, which the Holy One, blessed be He, swore to Abraham to redeem his children, had arrived, and they did not have the commandments to be redeemed, as it is said, "And you were naked and bare," etc. Since they were immersed in idolatry in Egypt, and idolatry is equivalent to all the commandments, He said to them, "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and cling to the commandments," thus concludes the Mechilta. And in the Midrash (Parashat 16, section 3), it is stated that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes, so that I will make known to them that their gods are nothing." Thus concludes the Midrash. 

At first glance, it is difficult, for on Rosh Chodesh, Israel was commanded in this commandment, as it is said, "He showed him the moon in its renewal," etc., and the command was that they should fulfill the commandment on the tenth of the month. According to the reasoning of the Mechilta, that the taking was preceded by four days in order to distance themselves from idolatry, why were the Israelites not commanded to fulfill this commandment immediately on Rosh Chodesh? And why did they wait to distance themselves from idolatry until the tenth of the month? Every moment that passes is a loss that cannot be recovered, and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' preparation for the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing the need to distance themselves from idolatry before performing the commandment. It highlights God's promise to Abraham regarding the redemption of his descendants and the necessity for the Israelites to renounce their worship of Egyptian gods. The text raises a question about the timing of the commandment, noting that although the Israelites were instructed to take the lamb on the first of the month, they were not to sacrifice it until the tenth, suggesting a deliberate process of spiritual purification. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine intervention, the importance of faithfulness to God's commandments, and the transformative journey from idolatry to holiness.

passage_content: יז) משה לכל זקני ישראל ויאמר אלהם משכו וקחו לכם צאן וגו', ולכאורה הרי היתה מצות השם אליו דברו אל כל עדת ישראל לאמר, ומדוע אמר לזקני ישראל, ובמכילתא איכא פלוגתא בזה, ר' יאשי' ס"ל הדבר יצא מפי משה לישראל אלא שעשאן להזקנים בית דין, ור' יונתן ס"ל הדבר יצא מפי משה לזקנים והזקנים לכל ישראל, ובמדרש רבה (פ' ט"ז סי' א') ויקרא משה לכל זקני ישראל הה"ד בישישים חכמה ואורך ימים תבונה, למה זכו הזקנים שיגאלו ישראל על ידיהן, בשעה שבא משה למצרים וא"ל אלקי אבותיכם שלחני אליכם, אילו לא קבלו הזקנים את דבריו של משה, אף כל ישראל לא היו מקבלים אותה, אלא הזקנים קבלו תחלה ומשכו כל ישראל אחריהם, אמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים ויהי' גאולת מצרים על ידיהן. שיהיו ישראל שוחטין פסחיהן על ידם של זקנים שנאמר ויקרא משה לכל זקני ישראל ויאמר אליהם משכו וקחו וגו' עכ"ד המדרש, ועדיין צ"ב כי למה הוצרכו להיות נעשית מצוה זו ע"י הזקנים, ולא סגי שיצוה משה לבני ישראל, כאשר א"ל השי"ת דברו אל כל עדת ישראל וגו' ומה הוסיפו כח הזקנים בעשייתן.
translation: 17) Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," etc. At first glance, it seems that the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was to speak to the entire congregation of Israel, so why did he speak to the elders of Israel? And in the Mekhilta, there is a dispute about this: Rabbi Yashiyah holds that the matter came from Moses to Israel, but he made the elders a court. Rabbi Jonathan holds that the matter came from Moses to the elders, and the elders to all of Israel. And in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat 16, Section 1), it states, "Moses called all the elders of Israel," as it is written, "In the aged is wisdom, and length of days understanding." Why did the elders merit that Israel be redeemed through them? When Moses came to Egypt and said to them, "The God of your fathers has sent me to you," if the elders had not accepted Moses' words, then all of Israel would not have accepted them either. Rather, the elders accepted first and drew all of Israel after them. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will repay the elders, and the redemption from Egypt will be through them," so that Israel would slaughter their Passover offerings through the hands of the elders, as it is said, "And Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, 'Draw out and take...'" Thus far the Midrash. And it still needs to be understood why this commandment needed to be performed by the elders, and it would not have sufficed for Moses to command the children of Israel, as the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Speak to the entire congregation of Israel," etc. What additional power did the elders contribute to its performance?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses addressing the elders of Israel when instructing them to take a lamb for the Passover, highlighting a debate among scholars about the role of the elders in this command. It emphasizes that the elders' acceptance of Moses' message was crucial for the collective acceptance of the Israelites, suggesting that their leadership and wisdom were necessary for the redemption process. The text reflects on the theological idea that divine redemption is facilitated through established leadership, underscoring the importance of communal authority in fulfilling God's commandments. Ultimately, it raises questions about the necessity of the elders' involvement in the mitzvah, suggesting a deeper connection between leadership and spiritual responsibility.

passage_content: יח) והובא ברש"י ז"ל וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, וכי כבר עשו והלא מראש חודש נאמר להם מצוה זו ולא עשו עד בעשור לחודש, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם כאילו עשו, ומהו כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, וצ"ב דמאי למימרא, וכי ס"ד שמשה ואהרן לא קיימו ח"ו מצות השי"ת ולא עשו הפסח אשר צוה השי"ת לכל ישראל, ולמה צריך יתור קרא להורות על זה.
translation: 18) And it is brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." But did they already do it? Wasn't this command given to them from the beginning of the month, and they did not do it until the tenth of the month? Rather, since they accepted upon themselves, it is as if they had done it. And what does "so they did" mean? Even Moses and Aaron did so. And it is difficult to understand what this is coming to teach us. Is it possible that Moses and Aaron did not fulfill, Heaven forbid, the commandments of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and did not perform the Passover as commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to all of Israel? And why is an extra verse needed to indicate this?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention and spiritual elevation in fulfilling commandments, highlighting that the Israelites, despite not performing the Passover sacrifice until the 10th of the month, are considered as if they had done so because they accepted the commandment upon themselves. It emphasizes that even Moses and Aaron, who are seen as exemplary figures, are included in this understanding, suggesting that their spiritual commitment is paramount. The text raises questions about the necessity of reiterating that Moses and Aaron fulfilled God's command, indicating a deeper theological insight into the nature of obedience and the significance of intention in religious practice.

passage_content: טרם שנבוא אל הביאור נקדים לפרש מאמר פלא בדברי חז"ל בסנהדרין (קי"א ע"א) עה"פ (זכרי' י"ג) והי' בכל הארץ נאם ד' פי שנים בה יכרתו יגועו והשלישית יותר בה, והבאתי את השלישית באש וצרפתים כצרוף את הכסף ובחנתים כבחון את הזהב וגו' (והוא נבואה על גאולה העתידה וחבלי משיח), אמר ריש לקיש שלישי של שם, פרש"י ששני חלקים של כל העולם יהיו נכרתים, וחלק שלישי יוותר בה, ואיזהו חלק שלישי, כל שלישיות שיש לשלש אנו משלשין, שמנח נפרדו כל העולם וג' בנים היו לו, הרי שליש בניו הוא שם, ושלישי של שם הוא ארפכשד, ושלישי של ארפכשד שהי' אברהם מבני בניו יוותר וכל העולם יכרת, ולדברי ר"ל נמצאו ישראל מתמעטין ביותר ושמא יהיו נכללין בפי שנים אשר יכרתו, א"ל ר' יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, פרש"י לא ניחא להקב"ה שאתה ממעט אותם כ"כ, אלא אפי' שלישית של נח דהיינו מכל ב"נ ומכל העולם כולו יוותר השליש, וכל ישראל ישארו ואם אין ישראל מרובין כ"כ, להיות אחד משליש העולם, יהיו הגרים וחסידי עובד כוכבים משלימין לשליש עיי"ש.
translation: Before we come to the explanation, we will precede with a wondrous statement from the words of our Sages in Sanhedrin (91a) regarding the verse (Zechariah 13:8) "And it shall be in all the land, says the Lord, two parts therein shall be cut off and die, but the third part shall be left therein. And I will bring the third part through the fire and will refine them as silver is refined and will test them as gold is tested," etc. (and this is a prophecy about the future redemption and the birth pangs of the Messiah). Rish Lakish said, "the third part is that of Shem." Rashi explains that two parts of the entire world will be cut off, and a third part will remain. And what is the third part? All thirds that we have, we divide. Since Noah separated the entire world and had three sons, a third of his sons is Shem, and the third of Shem is Arpachshad, and the third of Arpachshad, who was Abraham from his grandchildren, will remain, while the entire world will be cut off. According to Rish Lakish, it turns out that Israel is diminishing greatly, and perhaps they will be included in the two parts that will be cut off. Rabbi Yochanan said to him, "It is not pleasing to the Master that you say this to them." Rashi explains that it is not pleasing to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that you diminish them so much, but even the third of Noah, meaning from all the children of man and from the entire world, the third will remain, and all of Israel will remain. And if Israel is not so numerous, to be one of the third of the world, the converts and the pious among the idol worshippers will complete the third, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses a prophetic interpretation of Zechariah 13:8, which speaks of a future redemption and the trials preceding the Messiah's arrival. It highlights the concept that while two-thirds of the world may be cut off, a third will remain, symbolizing the survival of the Jewish people. Rish Lakish suggests that this third includes the descendants of Shem, specifically through Arpachshad and Abraham, while Rabbi Yochanan emphasizes that even if the Jewish population is small, they will be preserved alongside righteous gentiles, ensuring the fulfillment of God's promise. This reflects a deep theological insight into divine mercy and the enduring nature of Israel amidst global challenges.

passage_content: עוד פליגי ר"י ור"ל על משה"כ (בנבואת ירמי' ג') שובו בנים שובבים נאם ד' כי אנכי בעלתי אתכם, ולקחתי אתכם אחד מעיר ושנים ממשפחה, והבאתי אתכם ציון ונתתי לכם רועים כלבי ורעו אתכם דעה והשכל, אמר ר"ל דברים ככתבן, פרש"י שלא ימלטו אלא אחד מעיר וב' ממשפחה ח"ו, א"ל ר"י לא ניחא לי' למרייהו דאמרת עלייהו הכי, אלא א' מעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, ושנים ממשפחה מזכין כל המשפחה כולה, פרש"י בשביל חסיד א' שיש בעיר אקח את כל העיר כולה, ובסוף הסוגיא שם, תניא ר' סימאי אומר נאמר ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם ונאמר והבאתי אתכם, מקיש יציאתן ממצרים לביאתן לארץ, מה ביאתן לארץ שנים מס' רבוא, פרש"י שלא נשתיירו אלא יהושע וכלב מכל דור המדבר, אף יציאתן ממצרים שנים מס' רבוא, (פרש"י שהשאר מתו כולן בג' ימי אפילה) אמר רבא וכן לימות המשיח שנאמר וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מארץ מצרים, פרש"י ז"ל וכן לימות המשיח שלא ישארו מכל ס' רבוא אלא שנים עכ"ד ז"ל
translation: Rav Yochanan and Reish Lakish further argue about the verse (in the prophecy of Jeremiah 3): "Return, wayward children, says the Lord, for I am married to you, and I took you one from a city and two from a family, and I brought you to Zion, and I gave you shepherds according to My heart, and they will feed you with knowledge and understanding." Reish Lakish interprets the words literally, explaining that they will not escape except for one from a city and two from a family, Heaven forbid. Rav Yochanan responds that it is not pleasing to him that you say this about them, but rather that one from a city merits the entire city, and two from a family merit the entire family. Rashi explains that because of one righteous person in the city, I will take the entire city. At the end of the section there, it is taught: Rabbi Simai says it is stated, "And I took you to be My people," and it is stated, "And I brought you," linking their exodus from Egypt to their entry into the land. Just as their entry into the land involved two from six hundred thousand, Rashi explains that only Joshua and Caleb remained from the entire generation of the desert, so too their exodus from Egypt involved two from six hundred thousand (Rashi explains that the rest all died during the three days of darkness). Rava said, and so it will be in the days of the Messiah, as it is said, "And it will answer there as in the days of your youth and as in the day you came up from the land of Egypt." Rashi, blessed be his memory, explains that in the days of the Messiah, there will not remain from the six hundred thousand except for two. Thus concludes his words, blessed be he.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic message from Jeremiah about the return of the exiled Israelites, emphasizing that even a single righteous individual can merit redemption for an entire city or family. Rabbi Yochanan argues that the presence of one righteous person can uplift the whole community, contrasting with Rabbi Elazar's more literal interpretation. The text further connects the exodus from Egypt to the future redemption, suggesting that just as only a few individuals (Joshua and Caleb) survived the desert, so too will only a small remnant remain in the messianic era. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of righteousness and the communal implications of individual piety.

passage_content: והנה המאמר הזה מרפסן איגרא, וכל השומע תצלנה אזניו, והיתכן שלא ישארו ח"ו לימות המשיח אלא ב' מס' רבוא, וא"א להעלות על הדעת שיהיו דברי רבא הנ"ל ככתבן וכפשוטן, ויותר תמיה על מ"ש המהרש"א וז"ל ואולי שאלו השנים שנשארו שהם כלב מיהודה ויהושע מאפרים, הוא רמז על הב' דלעתיד משיח בן דוד מיהודה ומשיח בן יוסף מאפרים עכ"ל, ואיך יעלה על הדעת שלא ישארו לעתיד מישראל כ"א תרין משיחין, ובודאי לא ניחא לי' למרייהו למימר הכי.
translation: And behold, this statement is a great wonder, and all who hear it will have their ears tingle. Is it possible that there will only remain, Heaven forbid, two hundred thousand for the days of the Messiah? It is inconceivable to think that the words of Rava mentioned above should be taken literally and simply. It is even more astonishing regarding what the Maharsha wrote, and I quote: "And perhaps the two that remain, which are Caleb from Judah and Joshua from Ephraim, hint at the two in the future: Messiah son of David from Judah and Messiah son of Joseph from Ephraim." How can it be conceived that there will remain for the future from Israel only two Messiahs? Certainly, it would not be pleasing to them to say such a thing.
summary: The passage discusses the implications of a teaching that suggests only two individuals will remain for the Messianic era, raising concerns about the interpretation of Rabba's words. It questions the validity of the Maharsha's suggestion that these two figures symbolize the future Messiahs, one from Judah and one from Ephraim. The author expresses disbelief that such a limited number of individuals could represent the entirety of Israel in the future, emphasizing the importance of a broader understanding of redemption and the Messianic promise.

passage_content: עוד קשה דכמו דפליג ר' יוחנן בב' פלוגתות הנ"ל, ואמר דלא ניחא לי' למרייהו למימר הכי, מכ"ש דהו"ל לאפלוגי הכא, ומדוע אין כאן חולק על דברי רבא שלא ישארו כ"א שנים מס' רבוא, שהוא פחות הרבה מחשבון השלישית שאמר ר"ל, ואף מחשבון א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ואיך יתכן שכ"ע יודו לדברי רבא ואין חולק על דבריו כלל.
translation: It is also difficult, for just as Rabbi Yochanan argues in the two aforementioned disputes, and says that it is not pleasing to him to say such a thing, how much more so would it be that he should argue here. And why is there no one disputing the words of Rava, that they should not remain less than a hundred years, which is much less than the calculation of the third that R' Elazar said, and even less than the calculation of one in a city and two from a family? And how can it be that everyone would agree with the words of Rava and there is no one disputing his words at all?
summary: The passage discusses a disagreement among scholars, particularly Rabbi Yochanan, regarding the interpretation of certain teachings. It emphasizes the importance of unity in understanding Rabbi Aba's assertion that there should not be a division of years among the Jewish people, which is significantly less than the third calculation mentioned by Rabbi Elazar. The text highlights the consensus on Rabbi Aba's views, suggesting a deeper theological principle of collective agreement and harmony in the interpretation of sacred teachings. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of unity in thought and belief within the community.

passage_content: עוד קשה עמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל דדברי ר"ל א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה דברים ככתבן. לשיטתו אזיל דס"ל שלישית של שם ויתמעטו ישראל ח"ו, ור' יוחנן אזיל לשיטתו שלא יתמעטו עיי"ש, ואינו מובן דבריו דלפי האמת אין זה לשיטתו, ואדרבה דבריו סותרין דברי עצמו, דאיך שיהי' חשבון של שלישית הוא הרבה יותר מא' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ומ"ש ר"ל א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה אינו בסוג חשבון שלישית לד"ה, ולפעמים לא יעלה אפי' לא' מני אלף, ואיך אפשר שיחלוק ר"ל על דברי עצמו.
translation: It is still difficult regarding what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, said that the words of R' Eliezer are one from a city and two from a family, as they are written. According to his reasoning, he holds that a third of the name will diminish Israel, Heaven forbid, while R' Yochanan follows his reasoning that they will not be diminished, as stated there. His words are not understood, for in truth this is not according to his reasoning; on the contrary, his words contradict themselves. How could the calculation of a third be much more than one from a city and two from a family? And what R' Eliezer says, one from a city and two from a family, is not in the category of the calculation of a third according to the law, and at times it may not even reach one in a thousand. How is it possible that R' Eliezer would argue against his own words?
summary: The passage discusses a theological debate regarding the population of Israel, referencing the views of the Maharsha and Rabbi Yochanan. It highlights a contradiction in the Maharsha's reasoning about the diminishing numbers of Israel, suggesting that his interpretation of the population count is inconsistent. The text emphasizes the complexity of the calculations involved, indicating that the notion of a third of the population is significantly different from the simpler counts of one from a city and two from a family. Ultimately, it raises questions about the coherence of the Maharsha's arguments in light of the broader implications for the Jewish people.

passage_content: וע"ק דאין החשבון מכוון ומדוקדק משה"כ א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, דהרי בעיר ימצא עפ"י רוב הרבה משפחות, ויספיק לדברי ר' יוחנן הגנת צדיק א' על כל העיר ועל הרבה משפחות שבתוכה, ואיך משפחה שעפ"י הרוב אנשי' מועטין מעיר, יצטרכו ב' צדיקים להגין עליהם שימלטו בזכותם, ואינו מובן עפ"י פשוטו והסברא יורה ההיפך, וראיתי שהרי"ף בעין יעקב הקשה כן, ותירץ דהכי קאמר דא' מגין על כל העיר ועל כל המשפחות אשר בתוכה, אבל אם חלק ממשפחתו בעיר אחרת אין כח זכותו מגין על אלו שהם בעיר אחרת, ע"כ צ"ל להיות שנים, דזכות הצדיק השני מגין על אלו שהם בעיר האחרת עכ"ד. אבל תירוצו דחוק קצת דלפי"ז עיקר חסר מן הספר, דהו"ל לר' יוחנן למימר דא' ממשפחה מזכה כל המשפחה כולה לאותם שהם בתוך העיר, אבל לאותם שהם מחוץ לעיר צריך להגנתם זכות עוד צדיק, ואינו מוזכר כלל תוך העיר וחוץ לעיר במימרא דר' יוחנן וצ"ב.
translation: And regarding this, the calculation is not precise and exact as it is stated: one in the city and two from the family. For in the city, there will be, according to the majority, many families, and it suffices for the words of Rabbi Yochanan that the merit of one righteous person protects the entire city and many families within it. And how can it be that a family, which according to the majority has few people compared to the city, would need two righteous individuals to protect them so that they may be saved through their merit? This is not understood according to its simple meaning, and reason would indicate the opposite. I have seen that the Rif in Ein Yaakov posed this question and answered that this is what is meant: that one protects the entire city and all the families within it. However, if part of his family is in another city, his merit does not have the power to protect those who are in another city. Therefore, it must be that there are two, for the merit of the second righteous person protects those who are in the other city. Thus far his words. But his answer is somewhat forced, for according to this, a fundamental point is missing from the text. Rabbi Yochanan should have said that one from the family merits for the entire family as a whole for those who are within the city, but for those who are outside the city, another righteous person's merit is needed for their protection, and the distinction between within the city and outside the city is not mentioned at all in Rabbi Yochanan's statement, and this requires further investigation.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the protection offered by righteous individuals (tzaddikim) to communities and families, highlighting a tension between the sufficiency of one tzaddik for an entire city versus the need for multiple tzaddikim for families located outside the city. It references Rabbi Yochanan's assertion that one tzaddik can defend an entire city, yet raises questions about the necessity of additional tzaddikim for families in different locations. The text critiques the explanation provided by the Rif, suggesting that it lacks clarity and depth, particularly regarding the implications of tzaddikim's protective powers across different geographical boundaries. Ultimately, it emphasizes the complexity of divine protection and the interconnectedness of community and righteousness.

passage_content: ועוד דאפי' לפי תירוצו של הרי"ף לא יונח אלא לדברי ר' יוחנן, אבל לפי דברי ר"ל ורב כהנא דס"ל דברים ככתבן, וכפרש"י שלא ימלטו ח"ו אלא א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, הרי אין חשבון זה צודק, דאיך יתכן דמעיר שאנשי' מרובים לא ימלט אלא א', וממשפחה ימלטו שנים, ואינו מובן המאמר כפשוטו כלל, ובודאי שאין פירוש המאמר הזה כפי פשטות המשמעות.
translation: And furthermore, even according to the explanation of the Rif, it will only be understood according to the words of Rabbi Yochanan. However, according to the words of Rabbi Levi and Rav Kahana, who hold that things are as they are written, and as Rashi explains that they will not be saved, Heaven forbid, except for one from a city and two from a family, this calculation is not correct. How is it possible that from a city with many people, only one will be saved, while from a family, two will be saved? The statement is not understood literally at all, and certainly, the interpretation of this statement is not according to the simple meaning of the text.
summary: The passage discusses a theological interpretation of a Talmudic statement regarding the survival of individuals from a city and a family during a catastrophic event. It critiques the understanding that only one person from a populous city could be saved while two could be saved from a family, suggesting that this interpretation lacks logical consistency. The author emphasizes that the straightforward reading of the text does not align with the deeper theological implications, indicating a need for a more nuanced understanding of divine justice and mercy in the context of communal and familial relationships.

passage_content: ועוד דאיך אפשר דכללא כייל ר"ל, לחשוב כל העיירות בדרגא חדא, וכל המשפחות בדרגא חדא. והחוש והמציאות יכחיש דבר זה, דישנם הרבה עיירות שאין בהם אפי' א' שומר תומ"צ בעו"ה, וישנם עיירות שנמצא בהם לאלפים שומרי תומ"צ, וכן לא כל המשפחות שוות, ואיך אפ"ל שמכל עיר ימלט רק א' ומכל משפחה ב'. גם לא הגביל ר"ל מדת העיר כמה יהי' בה וישאר ממנה א', וכמה יהי' המשפחה שישאר ממנה ב' וצ"ב.
translation: And furthermore, how is it possible that a general rule is established, to consider all the towns as one level, and all the families as one level? The senses and reality contradict this, as there are many towns that do not have even one individual who observes the Torah and commandments, while there are towns that have thousands of those who observe the Torah and commandments. Likewise, not all families are equal, and how can it be said that from each town only one will be saved and from each family two? Also, it is not specified, G-d forbid, what the measure of the town will be for there to remain one from it, and how many will be from the family for there to remain two, and so on.
summary: The passage questions the idea of categorizing all towns and families into a single level of spiritual merit, highlighting the stark differences in observance and righteousness among them. It emphasizes that some towns may lack even a single individual who upholds the Torah, while others may have thousands of observant individuals. This disparity challenges the notion that a uniform standard can apply to all communities and families, suggesting a more nuanced understanding of divine judgment and the varied spiritual landscapes within the Jewish people. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexity of faith and the individual paths of righteousness that exist within the broader community.

passage_content: וראיתי שהרד"ק ז"ל יש לו פי' אחר בפסוק הנ"ל, וכתב שקאי על עיירות הגוים ועל משפחות הגוים, וז"ל א' מעיר אפי' יהודי א' יהי' לבדו בעיר מערי הגוים משם אקחנו, וכן אם יהיו אפי' שנים לבדם באומה אחת של גוים משם אקחם, ואומה נקרא משפחה כמשה"כ ואם משפחת מצרים לא תעלה, וכמ"ש לכל משפחות ממלכות צפונה עכ"ד, אולם גם על פירושו קשה דלמה הגביל בעיר סכום הא' ובמשפחה אמר שנים, ובודאי שלא יודח ממנו ית' נידח, ואפי' א' מישראל שיהי' באומה של גוים יקבצהו השי"ת משם, ועוד דאין סוגית הגמ' סובל פירושו כלל, דא"כ למה אמר ר' יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו וכו', וע"כ שאין סוגית הגמ' אזלא כפירושו.
translation: And I saw that the Radak, may his memory be blessed, has another interpretation of the above verse, and he wrote that it refers to the cities of the nations and to the families of the nations. He said that if there is even one Jew alone in a city among the cities of the nations, from there I will take him, and likewise if there are even two alone in one nation of the nations, from there I will take them. And a nation is called a family, as it is written, "And if the family of Egypt does not ascend," and as it is said, "to all the families of the kingdoms of the north," thus far his words. However, his interpretation is also difficult, for why did he limit it to one in a city and say two in a family? And certainly, no one will be cast away from Him, and even if there is one from Israel who is in a nation of the nations, the Holy One, blessed be He, will gather him from there. Furthermore, the topic of the Gemara does not support his interpretation at all, for if so, why did Rabbi Yochanan say, "It is not pleasant for them," etc.? Therefore, the topic of the Gemara does not follow his interpretation.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a biblical verse by the commentator Radak, who suggests it refers to the gathering of Jews from among the nations, even if they are alone or in small numbers. The author questions this interpretation, noting inconsistencies regarding the limitations placed on the number of Jews in a city versus a family, and emphasizes that God will not abandon even a single Jew in exile. Furthermore, the author argues that the Talmudic context does not support Radak's explanation, highlighting the theological belief in God's unwavering commitment to gather His people from all corners of the earth.

passage_content: ורש"י ז"ל פי' בזכרי' פסוק הנ"ל והבאתי את השלישית באש, דקאי על גירי האומות, שיסבלו בצרת חבלי משיח ובמלחמות גוג ומגוג עם ישראל, ומשם יבחנו אם גרי אמת הם, והרבה מן המתיהדים תחלה ישובו לסורם ויתחברו עם גוג, ולפי"ז לא קאי השלישית על ישראל, ואפשר דישראל ישארו כולם חיים וקיימים, אבל הצירוף יהי' בגירי האומות. אמנם שיטת הגמ' לא אזלא כפי פירושו, ועדיין דברי הגמ' הנ"ל צ"ב.
translation: And Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained in Zechariah the above verse, "and I will bring the third part through the fire," which refers to the converts from the nations, who will suffer during the birth pangs of the Messiah and in the wars of Gog and Magog with Israel. From there, it will be tested whether they are true converts, and many of those who initially became Jewish will return to their former ways and join Gog. According to this, the third part does not refer to Israel, and it is possible that all of Israel will remain alive and enduring, but the mixture will be among the converts from the nations. However, the approach of the Gemara does not align with his interpretation, and the words of the aforementioned Gemara still require clarification.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a verse from Zechariah, focusing on the concept of the "third" group that will be tested during the trials of the Messianic era and the wars of Gog and Magog. It suggests that this group refers to the converts from the nations who will face suffering and may ultimately reveal their true allegiance, with many initially drawn to Judaism potentially returning to their former ways and aligning with Gog. In contrast, it posits that the Jewish people may remain intact and survive these tribulations, indicating a distinction between the fate of Israel and that of the nations. The text also notes a divergence between this interpretation and the teachings of the Gemara, leaving some questions unresolved.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר הערה בדרך רמז על משה"כ א' בעיר ושנים במשפחה, עפימ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל (ירמי' ה') עה"פ שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים וראו נא ודעו ובקשו ברחובותי' אם תמצאו איש, אם יש עושה משפט מבקש אמונה וגו' והקשה הרד"ק ז"ל כי הנה היו בירושלים חסידים ועבדי ד' כמבואר בפסוקים בכ"מ, ואיך אמר ירמי' אם תמצאו איש עושה משפע מבקש אמונה, ופי' אדוני אבי ז"ל כי ירמי' אמר בחוצות ירושלים ואמר ברחובותי', כי החסידים שהיו בירושלים היו מתחבאים בבתיהם, ולא היו יכולים להתראות ברחובות ובחוצות מפני הרשעים עיי"ש, וכן פי' השלה"ק שלכן אמר הכתוב בחוצות וברחובות, כי אלמלי לא היו יראים מן העם לעשות משפט ולבקש אמונה ברחובה של עיר, אז היו בכוחם להגין עליהם וז"ש ירמי' שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים ובקשו ברחובותי' אם תמצאו שם איש עושה משפט מבקש אמונה ואסלח לכל העיר בזכותם. וכעי"ז פירש האבן עזרא בפ' וירא עה"פ אם אמצא בסדום חמשים צדיקים בתוך העיר ונשאתי לכל המקום בעבורם, וז"ל וטעם בתוך העיר, שהם יראים את השם בפרהסיא, וכן שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים עכ"ל, (והארכתי בזה בהקדמת ספרי ויואל משה עמוד ט"ו) ולזה לא התפלל אברהם אלא על אותן הצדיקים שהן בצדקתן בתוך העיר, אבל באלו שיראים להגיד האמת ולהוכיח בשער בת רבים, ידע אברהם שאין בהם כח הגנה להיות העיר נמלט בזכותם, ולא ניסה להתפלל בזכותם, ומילתא דמסתבר הוא, כי אם אין מתקשר עמהם להטיב דרכיהם אין זכותו מצטרף להגין עליהם ג"כ. ולפי"ז אפשר לומר בכוונת חז"ל דא' מהעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, היינו בצדיק שהוא בתוך העיר ומוכיח בשער בת רבים, אז יש לו כח הגנה להציל את כל העיר כמ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל, ושנים ממשפחה מיירי בצדיקים שמוכיחים רק לבני משפחתם, ואין להם התקשרות עם בני העיר להטיב מעשיהם, ע"כ אין בהם כח הגנה להציל את כל העיר רק את בני משפחתם, גם כח זכותם מועטת משל הראשונים, וצריך זכות שני צדיקים להגין על בני המשפחה, ואם גם בני משפחתם לא יוכיחו, אין להם כח הגנה כלל שיצילו אחרים בזכותם, כ"ז אפשר לומר בדרך רמז בגמרא הנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible to say a note in a hint regarding the verse "one in the city and two in the family," according to what the Radak, may his memory be blessed, said (Jeremiah 5) on the verse "Roam the streets of Jerusalem and see now and know and seek in its squares if you can find a man, if there is one who does justice, who seeks faith," and the Radak asked, may his memory be blessed, that there were indeed pious ones and servants of God in Jerusalem, as is explained in the verses everywhere, and how could Jeremiah say if you can find a man who does justice, who seeks faith? My father, may his memory be blessed, explained that Jeremiah spoke of the streets of Jerusalem and said in its squares, because the pious ones who were in Jerusalem were hiding in their homes, and they could not be seen in the streets and squares because of the wicked, as noted there. Similarly, the Shlah HaKadosh explained that is why the verse said in the streets and in the squares, for if they were not afraid of the people to do justice and seek faith in the public square, then they would have the power to defend them, and that is what Jeremiah meant when he said "Roam the streets of Jerusalem and seek in its squares if you can find there a man who does justice, who seeks faith, and I will forgive the entire city for their sake." And similarly, the Ibn Ezra explained in Parashat Vayera on the verse "If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, I will spare the whole place for their sake," and he said the reason for "within the city" is that they fear the Name in public, and thus "Roam the streets of Jerusalem." I have elaborated on this in the introduction to my book "Yoel Moshe," page 15. Therefore, Abraham did not pray except for those righteous ones who are righteous within the city, but for those who are afraid to proclaim the truth and to reprove in the public square, Abraham knew that they do not have the power to defend for the city to be saved for their sake, and he did not attempt to pray for their sake. This is a reasonable matter, for if they do not connect with them to improve their ways, their merit does not combine to defend them either. According to this, it is possible to say in the intention of our Sages that "one from the city merits the entire city," meaning a righteous person who is within the city and reproves in the public square, then he has the power to defend to save the entire city, as the Radak, may his memory be blessed, said. And "two from the family" refers to the righteous who only reprove their family members, and they do not have a connection with the people of the city to improve their deeds; therefore, they do not have the power to defend to save the entire city, only their family members. Also, their merit is lesser than that of the former, and two righteous ones are needed to defend the family members. And if even their family members do not reprove, they have no power to defend at all to save others for their sake. All this can be said as a hint in the above Gemara.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of righteous individuals and their ability to protect their communities through their actions. It emphasizes that true righteousness requires public acknowledgment and advocacy for justice, as exemplified by the prophet Jeremiah's call to find those who seek truth in the streets of Jerusalem. The text contrasts the effectiveness of a single righteous person in the city, who can safeguard the entire community, with the limited influence of those who only advocate for their immediate family. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of communal responsibility and the need for visible righteousness to effect change and provide protection.
