passage_content: ובזה יבואר המדרש הנ"ל זש"ה ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו', מתחלה אמר לא ידעתי את ד' וגם את ישראל לא אשלח נעשה כחשן והודה ואמר ד' הצדיק ואמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וכו' (עיין לעיל קושיא י"ב), כי באמת היו כל דבריו מתחלה כחש ושקר, ומ"ש לא ידעתי את ד' הי' שקר בפיו, כי הי"ל לירא מפחד ה' אחרי שידע שם אלקים, וגם מ"ש את ישראל לא אשלח הי' מתחלה כחש וכזב, כי הי"ל לידע במושג שכל אנושי כי לא יעלה בידו ולא יצליח נגד רצונו ית', אלא שהנגיעה מדמה ומכחש ונדמה לו שלא ידע את ד', ולולי הנגיעה הי"ל ידיעה, אלא שנעלמה ידיעתו מחמת הנגיעה, ואחרי שהוכרח לשלח ראה למפרע שהי' שטות וכחש ושקר כל מה שאמר, וז"ש יכחשו לך אויביך שע"י גודל השנאה באים לידי כחש ושקר ע"י סמיות עינים, וברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך, שע"י המכות שהוכה הודה אח"כ בעצמו על כחשותו ואמר ד' הצדיק.
translation: And this will clarify the aforementioned Midrash, as it is written: "By the greatness of Your might, Your enemies will feign to You," etc. At first, he said, "I do not know the Lord," and "I will not send Israel," he was a liar and acknowledged and said, "The Lord is righteous," and "Arise, go out from among My people," etc. (see above, question 12). For indeed, all his words at first were lies and falsehoods, and when he said, "I do not know the Lord," it was a lie in his mouth, for he should have feared the fear of the Lord after he knew the name of God. And also when he said, "I will not send Israel," it was initially a lie and deception, for he should have known, by human understanding, that he would not prevail nor succeed against His will, blessed be He. Rather, the personal interest blinded him and deceived him, leading him to think that he did not know the Lord. Had it not been for the personal interest, he would have had knowledge, but his knowledge was hidden due to the personal interest. And after he was compelled to send, he saw retrospectively that all he had said was folly, falsehood, and lies. Therefore, it is said, "Your enemies will feign to You," for through the intensity of hatred, they come to lies and falsehoods through blindness of eyes. "By the greatness of Your might, Your enemies will feign to You," for through the plagues he was struck, he later acknowledged his weakness and said, "The Lord is righteous."
summary: The passage discusses the theme of denial and recognition of divine authority, illustrating how the enemies of God, driven by hatred, ultimately succumb to falsehood and deception. Initially, they claim ignorance of God and reject His people, but this denial is rooted in a lack of true understanding and fear of the divine. The text emphasizes that their eventual acknowledgment of God's power comes only after experiencing His might, leading them to confess the truth of God's righteousness. This reflects a broader Hasidic insight into the transformative power of divine revelation and the consequences of human arrogance.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל מאמה"כ וכסה את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות וגו', עפי"מ דאיתא במדרש (ילקוט רמז תתקמ"ב) האזינו השמים ואדברה ותשמע הארץ וגו', שקרא משה ליושבי השמים וליושבי הארץ, וא"ל הרי גזר הקב"ה עלי שאמות ואיני יודע להיכן נפשי הולכת וכו' תנו דעתכם שתהיו מקבלין אותי בכבוד ומסתכלין בי כאלו אני חי ומדבר את דברי תורה לעולם עכ"ד המדרש, וכמו"כ אפשר לפרש לעניננו וכסה את עון הארץ על עין יושבי הארץ, אלו שכל מחשבתם שקועים בעניני ארציות, ואינם חושבים מה למעלה ממך, ועינם מכוסה מלראות דרך האמת, וז"ש ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ, וה"ז מקרא קצר ולא פי' מי הרואה, דבדרך כלל כן הוא, דמי שמשוחד לתאוותיו וכל רצונו להשיג רק עניני גשמיות, אינו יכול לראות האמת ורואה ההיפך ומדמהו לאמת, וא"א לכוין האמת כ"א מי שכל רצונו לעשות רצון אבינו שבשמים ואין לו רצון אחר זולתו. וזה ירמוז הכתוב שגם אחר המכות לא ישמע פרעה ולבו לא יבין, והטעם דמכוסה עין הרואה את הארץ ולא יוכל לראות האמת, וע"כ יתחזק ברשעו.
translation: And similarly, one can say regarding the verse, "And He covered the eye of the land, and it could not see," according to what is stated in the Midrash (Yalkut, Remez 866), "Give ear, O heavens, and I will speak; and let the earth hear the words of my mouth," that Moses called to the inhabitants of the heavens and the inhabitants of the earth, and said to them, "Behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, has decreed upon me that I shall die, and I do not know where my soul is going, etc. Consider that you should receive me with honor and look at me as if I am alive and speaking the words of Torah to the world." Thus said the Midrash. Likewise, it is possible to interpret for our matter, "And He covered the sin of the land from the eyes of the inhabitants of the land," those whose thoughts are immersed in earthly matters and do not think about what is above you, and their eyes are covered from seeing the path of truth. Therefore, it says, "and it could not see the land," and this is a brief verse, and it does not explain who is the one seeing. Generally, it is so that one who is blinded by his desires and whose entire will is to attain only material matters cannot see the truth and sees the opposite, and he imagines it to be the truth. One can only align with the truth if his entire will is to do the will of our Father in heaven and he has no other desire besides that. This hints that even after the plagues, Pharaoh will not hear, and his heart will not understand, and the reason is that the eye that sees the land is covered and cannot see the truth, and therefore he will strengthen himself in his wickedness.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual blindness caused by an obsession with earthly desires, which prevents individuals from perceiving the truth. It references a Midrash where Moses calls upon the heavens and the earth, emphasizing the need for recognition and respect for divine teachings. The text suggests that those who are consumed by materialism cannot see the true reality and remain entrenched in their wickedness, as exemplified by Pharaoh's hardened heart despite witnessing miracles. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of aligning one's will with the divine in order to attain true understanding and insight.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר פרשת קרבן פסח והדקדוקים שבענין (עיין לעיל קושיות ט"ו י"ח) ולתרץ קושיתנו הנ"ל מדוע לא נצטוו ישראל לעשות הפסח מיד בר"ח, דלפי טעם המדרש והגמ' שתכלית וטעם המצו' הי' להפרישם מע"ז שהיו שטופים בה, א"כ בכל יומא ויומא זמני', וכל רגע ורגע הוי פסידא דלא הדר, והו"ל להתחיל במצו' זו בר"ח ומדוע נצטוו להמתין עד בעשור לחדש. ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי המדרש בפ' וארא (פ' ו' סי' ה') ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, והנה הסיבה לזה היתה מפני שהיו משוקעים ומורגלים בע"ז וטומאת מצרים, ולפרוש מעבירה שמורגל האדם בה גדול הנסיון וקשה מאוד להשיגו, גם מפני שהי' ביניהם רשעי ישראל מרובים, עד שאמרו חז"ל במס' סנהדרין לחד מ"ד שלא יצאו אלא א' מס' רבוא והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה מפני שלא רצו לצאת ממצרים, ואלו היו רשעים ודבוקים בע"ז, וכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל (בפ"ו מה' דיעות), דדרך ברייתו של אדם להיות נמשך בדיעותיו ובמעשיו אחר ריעיו וחביריו ונוהג כמנהג אנשי מדינתו וכו', לפיכך אם הוא דר במדינה שמנהגותי' רעים ואין אנשי' הולכים בדרך ישרה, יעזוב את המדינה וילך למקום שאנשי' צדיקים וכו' עכ"ל, ולטעם זה הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולעשות תשובה גמורה, כיון שהיו מסובבים ברוב רשעים ועוע"ז, ודרך האדם להיות נמשך אחר ריעיו ולנהוג מנהג בני מדינתו.
translation:
And now we will explain the section of the Passover offering and the nuances regarding the matter (see above questions 15 and 18) and to resolve our aforementioned question of why Israel was not commanded to bring the Passover immediately on the first of the month, for according to the reasoning of the Midrash and the Gemara, the purpose and reason for the commandment was to separate them from idolatry in which they were immersed. Therefore, every day and every moment would be a loss if they did not return, and they should have begun this commandment on the first of the month. Why then were they commanded to wait until the tenth of the month? 

One could say, in light of the words of the Midrash in Parashat Va'era (Parashat 6, section 5), that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit, etc., which was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. The reason for this was that they were sunk and accustomed to idolatry and the impurity of Egypt, and to separate from a transgression that a person is accustomed to is a great trial and very difficult to achieve. Also, because there were many wicked among them, as our Sages said in Tractate Sanhedrin, according to one opinion, that only one out of six hundred thousand left, and the rest died in three days of darkness because they did not want to leave Egypt. These were the wicked and clung to idolatry. And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in the sixth chapter of the Laws of Opinions) that it is the nature of a person to be drawn in his opinions and actions after his friends and companions and to act according to the customs of his community, etc. Therefore, if he lives in a place where the customs are bad and the people do not walk in a straight path, he should leave that place and go to a place where the people are righteous, etc. Thus, for this reason, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry and to make complete repentance, since they were surrounded by many wicked and idolaters, and it is the way of a person to be drawn after his friends and to follow the customs of his community.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice and the delay in its observance until the 10th of the month, rather than immediately on Rosh Chodesh. It emphasizes the challenge for the Israelites to separate from idolatry, as they were deeply entrenched in the corrupt practices of Egypt and influenced by their wicked peers. The text highlights the difficulty of repentance when surrounded by negative influences, illustrating the struggle between individual spiritual growth and societal pressures. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound trials faced by the Israelites in their journey towards redemption and holiness.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' הארבה, כי לפי החשבון הי' מכת ברד בחודש אדר לא קודם לכן, כי אז השעורה אביב והחטה אפילה, ואח"כ בחודש ימים עד ניסן צמחה החטה והכוסמת והתחילו העצים להוציא פרח, והארבה הי' בניסן, וזה טעם הכתוב ואכל את כל העץ הצומח לכם וגו' עכ"ל, נמצא לפי חשבונו דשלש המכות היו בניסן ארבה חושך ומכת בכורות, ומכת ארבה נמשך עד ז' בניסן, כי כל מכה היתה משמשת ז' ימים, ומכת חשך מפורש בקרא שהי' ו' ימים, ואפשר דבשבת לא הי' מכת החשך משמשת, לפי הטעם שנזכר במדרש שיהיו ישראל מקברים מתיהם, דטעם זה לא שייך בשבת, ולפי"ז נשלמה מכת חשך בערב פסח, ובלילה הי' מכת בכורות, נמצא דבעשור לחודש שהוא שבת הגדול הי' בתוך ימי החושך, ורבינו בחיי חולק על הרמב"ן ז"ל, וס"ל דמכת ארבה הי' באדר, ובר"ח ניסן התחילה מכת חשך והיתה משמשת ז' ימים, ואחריו ז' ימים היו ימי הרוחה שבין מכה למכה, ולפי"ד היתה עשור לחודש אחר תשלום ימי החשך עיי"ש.
translation: And we will also precede what the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Arbeh, that according to the calculation, the plague of hail occurred in the month of Adar, not before, for then the barley was in its spring and the wheat was in its dark stage, and afterwards, a month until Nisan, the wheat and buckwheat grew, and the trees began to blossom, and the locusts were in Nisan. This is the meaning of the verse, "And it ate all the tree that grows for you," etc. Thus, according to his calculation, the three plagues were in Nisan: locusts, darkness, and the plague of the firstborn. The plague of locusts lasted until the 7th of Nisan, for each plague lasted for 7 days, and the plague of darkness is explicitly stated in the verse to have lasted for 6 days. It is possible that on Shabbat, the plague of darkness did not serve, according to the reason mentioned in the Midrash that the Israelites would be burying their dead, for this reason does not apply on Shabbat. According to this, the plague of darkness was completed on the eve of Passover, and at night was the plague of the firstborn. Thus, on the tenth of the month, which is the Great Shabbat, it was within the days of darkness. And Rabbeinu Bachaye disagrees with the Ramban, of blessed memory, and holds that the plague of locusts was in Adar, and on Rosh Chodesh Nisan the plague of darkness began and lasted for 7 days, and after that, there were 7 days of rest between plague and plague. According to his opinion, the tenth of the month was after the completion of the days of darkness, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the plagues in Egypt, particularly focusing on the plague of locusts, which the Ramban suggests occurred in Nissan, aligning with the growth cycles of crops. It emphasizes the significance of the plagues as a divine intervention, with each plague lasting seven days, and highlights the theological implications of darkness and death during the Passover period. The text contrasts the views of different scholars, illustrating the complexity of interpreting divine actions and their timing in relation to the Jewish calendar and agricultural cycles. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound connection between nature, divine will, and the Jewish experience of redemption.

passage_content: והנה נצטוו ישראל משכו וקחו לכם, ודרשו חז"ל במד"ר (פ' ט"ז סי' ב') משכו ידיכם מע"ז, והי' צורך לזכות גאולתם תשובה ופרישה מע"ז, בצירוף שמירת שבת כמ"ש (בדברנו פ' בשלח) מדברי הירושלמי (תענית פ"א) דע"י זכות שמירת שבת ותשובה ישראל נגאלין, ויליף לה מדכתיב בשובה ונחת תושעון, וע"כ הי' הצווי של משכו וקחו לקיימה בעשור לחדש שהי' שבת הגדול, כדי שיהי' להם זכות השבת וזכות התשובה, ופירשנו בזה דברי המדרש (שם) משכו וקחו הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון עיי"ש. וכתב הטו"ז (או"ח סי' רמ"ב) דמ"ש חז"ל כל המשמר שבת כהלכתה אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו, היינו שמירת שבת בצירוף התשובה, אלא דתשובה לחוד לא מהני כמ"ש ז"ל בד' חלוקי כפרה, עבר על כריתות ומיתות ב"ד תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, ע"כ קמ"ל כאן דתשובה עם שמירת שבת אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש שיש בה מיתת ב"ד, מ"מ נמחל לו חטאו לגמרי עכת"ד הטו"ז ז"ל, ומעתה ישראל במצרים שהיו עוע"ז הוצרכו לשני הזכותים גם יחד, דהיינו זכות שמירת שבת וגם זכות התשובה.
translation: And behold, Israel was commanded, "Take for yourselves," and our Sages expounded in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Tzav 16:2) that "Withdraw your hands from idolatry," and there was a need for them to merit their redemption through repentance and separation from idolatry, along with the observance of Shabbat, as it is stated (in our discussion on Parashat Beshalach) from the words of the Jerusalem Talmud (Ta'anit 1:1) that through the merit of observing Shabbat and repentance, Israel is redeemed. This is derived from the verse, "In repentance and rest you shall be saved." Therefore, the command of "Take for yourselves" was given on the tenth of the month, which was the Great Shabbat, so that they would have the merit of Shabbat and the merit of repentance. We explained this in the words of the Midrash (there) regarding "Take for yourselves," which corresponds to "In repentance and rest you shall be saved," as mentioned there. And the Taz (Orach Chaim 152) wrote that what our Sages said, "Anyone who observes Shabbat properly, even if he is an idolater like the generation of Enosh, his sins are forgiven," refers to the observance of Shabbat in conjunction with repentance. However, repentance alone is not sufficient, as our Sages stated regarding the four categories of atonement: one who transgresses the prohibitions of excision and the death penalty, repentance suspends [the punishment] and death atones. Therefore, it is taught here that repentance with the observance of Shabbat, even for an idolater like the generation of Enosh, which involves the death penalty, nonetheless, his sin is completely forgiven, as stated by the Taz. And from now on, the Israelites in Egypt, who were idolaters, needed both merits together, namely the merit of observing Shabbat and the merit of repentance.
summary: The passage discusses the commandment given to the Israelites to take a lamb for the Passover, interpreting it through a Hasidic lens that emphasizes the necessity of repentance and separation from idolatry for their redemption. It highlights the importance of observing the Sabbath as a merit that, combined with repentance, leads to salvation, referencing the Jerusalem Talmud. The text underscores that even those who have sinned, such as the Israelites in Egypt, can attain forgiveness through the dual merits of Sabbath observance and repentance, illustrating a profound theological insight into the power of these practices in achieving divine mercy.

passage_content: ומעתה אפשר לומר דע"כ לא נצטוו במצו' זו עד בעשור לחדש, כי עד שהיו מסובבים בעובדי ע"ז ורשעי ישראל, הי' קשה להם לעשות תשובה גמורה ולפרוש מע"ז לגמרי, ולהרחיק מלבם ומדעתם תאוות וטומאת מצרים, כי היו רשעי ישראל מרובים עליהם, ובלי ספק הי' ביניהם הרבה מן הצבועים, והי' החשש פן יעכבו עליהם מלפרוש מע"ז פרישה גמורה ע"י כח ההסתה, או ע"י שיכניסו דיעות נפסדות ופשטים שאינם אמת בצווי הבוי"ת ובאופן הפרישה מע"ז, וע"כ לא הי' אפשר לפרוש מע"ז פרישה גמורה עד בעשור לחודש, שהיו ימי החשך משמשים ולדעת רמב"ן ז"ל הי' בעשור לחודש אחר ג' ימים הראשונים של ימי החושך, ולדעת רבינו בחיי הי' אחר תשלום ימי החושך, עכ"פ אפשר שאז כבר מתו כל רשעי ישראל, ונשארו רק בני ישראל הכשרים, שהי' רצונם לפרוש מע"ז ולקיים צווי הבוי"ת באמת, ואז הי' מציאות שתתקיים צווי הבוי"ת משכו ידיכם מע"ז בשלימות גמור, ולא קודם לכן.
translation: And from now on, it is possible to say that they were not commanded in this mitzvah until the tenth of the month, because until they were surrounded by idol worshippers and the wicked of Israel, it was difficult for them to make a complete repentance and to completely separate themselves from idol worship, and to distance from their hearts and minds the desires and impurities of Egypt, for the wicked of Israel were numerous among them, and without a doubt there were many hypocrites among them. There was a concern that they would be hindered from completely separating from idol worship by the power of incitement, or by introducing false and superficial ideas that are not true regarding the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the manner of separating from idol worship. Therefore, it was not possible to completely separate from idol worship until the tenth of the month, which were the days of darkness, and according to Ramban, it was on the tenth of the month after the first three days of darkness, and according to Rabbeinu Bachaye, it was after the completion of the days of darkness. In any case, it is possible that by then all the wicked of Israel had already died, and only the righteous children of Israel remained, who desired to separate from idol worship and to fulfill the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in truth. Then there was a reality in which the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, would be fulfilled: "Withdraw your hands from idol worship" in complete perfection, and not before that.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the commandment to separate from idolatry, suggesting that it was only possible to achieve true repentance after the death of the wicked among Israel. The presence of these evildoers and their corrupting influences made it difficult for the righteous to fully detach from idolatry and the impurities of Egypt. It emphasizes that only after the darkness had passed and the righteous remained could the commandment to completely withdraw from idolatry be fulfilled, highlighting the importance of a pure community in achieving spiritual redemption.

passage_content: ועוד טעם בדבר דעד שלא נתקיים אצלם פרישה וביטול גמור בע"ז, לא הי' אפשר להם לקיים מצות ק"פ, עפימ"ש הפנים יפות ז"ל לפרש דברי המכילתא משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן של מצו', דלכאורה איך אפשר שיקחו מן המצרים שה לקרבן פסח, והרי יש בו איסור משום נעבד שמצריים היו עובדין לצאנם, אלא דאמרינן דע"ז שמכרו עכו"ם או משכנו מסתמא ביטלו, ודוקא שמכרו לישראל אבל מכרו לנכרי לא ביטלו, ע"כ היו צריכין ישראל למשוך ידיהם מע"ז תחלה, ואז נתבטל הע"ז ע"י מכירה עיי"ש, ומעתה א"ש מה שהיתה צווי השי"ת להיות מקחו בעשור דוקא ולא קודם לכן, כי הי' עליו חשש נעבד עד עתה, דלא אמרינן דעכו"ם בטולי' בטלי' אא"כ מכרה לישראל הפרוש מע"ז, ולא הי' הפרישה בשלימות אלא אחר ימי החשך כנ"ל. גם שהוצרכו ישראל לזכותא דשבת בצירוף התשובה ופרישה מע"ז כמ"ש לעיל, ובעשור לחדש הי' השבת היחידה ממכת חושך עד יצ"מ בין לדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל ובין לשיטת הרבינו בחיי ז"ל, ומעתה יובן הטעם שלא יכלו לקיים מצות פרישה זו מר"ח ניסן, והוצרכו להמתין עד בעשור לחדש.
translation: And another reason for this is that until they had a complete separation and total nullification of idolatry, it was not possible for them to fulfill the commandment of the Paschal lamb, as explained by the Pnei Yehoshua, who interprets the words of the Mechilta: "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves a lamb for the mitzvah." It seems, how could they take from the Egyptians for the Paschal sacrifice, when there is a prohibition because the Egyptians were worshipping their flocks? However, we say that idolatry sold by a non-Jew or mortgaged is certainly nullified, specifically when sold to a Jew, but if sold to a non-Jew, it is not nullified. Therefore, the Jews needed to withdraw their hands from idolatry first, and then the idolatry was nullified through the sale, as mentioned there. From this, it is clear why the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was to take it specifically on the tenth and not before, because there was a concern of it being worshipped until now, for we do not say that idolatry is nullified unless it is sold to a Jew who is separated from idolatry, and the separation was not complete until after the days of darkness, as mentioned above. Also, the Jews needed the merit of Shabbat combined with repentance and separation from idolatry, as stated above, and on the tenth of the month, there was the unique Shabbat from the plague of darkness until the Exodus, according to both the words of the Ramban and the opinion of Rabbeinu Bachaye. Therefore, it will be understood why they could not fulfill this command of separation from the first of Nissan, and they had to wait until the tenth of the month.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of complete separation from idolatry before the Israelites could fulfill the commandment of taking a Paschal lamb. It emphasizes that the prohibition against using animals from the Egyptians, who worshipped them, could only be lifted once the Israelites distanced themselves from idolatry. This separation was not fully realized until after the days of darkness, and thus they had to wait until the 10th of Nisan to properly observe this commandment, highlighting the importance of repentance and spiritual readiness in fulfilling divine commandments.

passage_content: ומעתה א"ש מה שהוצרך המצו' הזאת להיות נעשית ע"י הזקנים דוקא כמבואר בדברי המדרש לפי שהזקנים הכניסו האמונה בלב כל ישראל, בשעה שבא משה למצרים וא"ל אלקי אבותיכם שלחני אלכם, וקבלו הזקנים את דבריו של משה, ועי"ז הכניסו אמונת הגאולה בלב כל ישראל, ובזכות האמונה נגאלו ישראל ממצרים, אמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים ויהי' גאולת מצרים על ידן שנא' ויקרא משה לזקני ישראל ויאמר אלהם משכו וקחו וגו', וגם עכשיו הי' צורך לכח הזקנים, שיסייעו לישראל להפרישם מע"ז פרישה גמורה, כי הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז כמ"ש במדרש הנ"ל, נמצא כי היתה גאולת ישראל על ידיהן של הזקנים, כי אלולי הפרישה מע"ז לא היתה אפשר להן להגאל, וז"ש במדרש שאמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים מידה כנגד מידה על שהמשיכו את ישראל להאמין בבשורת הגאולה, ע"כ תהי' גאולת ישראל על ידיהן (ומתורץ קושיא י"ז הנ"ל).
translation: And from now on, I understand why this commandment had to be performed specifically by the elders, as explained in the words of the Midrash, for the elders instilled faith in the hearts of all Israel when Moses came to Egypt and said to them, "The God of your forefathers has sent me to you." The elders accepted Moses' words, and through this, they instilled the faith of redemption in the hearts of all Israel. And by virtue of this faith, Israel was redeemed from Egypt. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will reward the elders, and the redemption from Egypt will be through them," as it is said, "And Moses called for the elders of Israel and said to them, 'Draw out and take...'" And even now, there was a need for the strength of the elders to assist Israel in completely separating themselves from idolatry, for it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash. Thus, the redemption of Israel was through the elders, for without the separation from idolatry, it would not have been possible for them to be redeemed. Therefore, it is said in the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will reward the elders measure for measure for having encouraged Israel to believe in the tidings of redemption; thus, the redemption of Israel will be through them" (and this resolves the aforementioned question).
summary: The passage emphasizes the crucial role of the elders in instilling faith in the redemption among the Israelites during their time in Egypt. It highlights that their acceptance of Moses' message was instrumental in fostering a collective belief in the impending redemption, which ultimately led to their liberation. The text underscores the idea that the elders' efforts in guiding the people away from idolatry were essential for the redemption to occur, illustrating a reciprocal relationship between faith and divine intervention. Thus, the elders are recognized as pivotal figures in the process of redemption, receiving divine reward for their role in nurturing belief among the Israelites.

passage_content: וא"ש מ"ש במכילתא לאמר צא ואמור להם מיד דברי ר' ישמעאל, (עיין לעיל קושיא ע"ו) דהנה אע"פ שלא הי' אפשר לקיים מצות פרישה מע"ז אלא בעשור לחודש כנ"ל, ולטעם זה לא נצטוו לעשותה בר"ח, אעפ"כ היתה הצווי לאמר להם מיד. כדי שעכ"פ יקבלו עליהם קבלה אמיתית בלב שלם לפרוש מע"ז מיד בהקדם זמן שאפשר, ושלימות הפרישה לא הי' אפשר עד בעשור לחודש. אבל לפי שלא הי' החסרון מצידם, ע"כ דרשו חז"ל משקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם הכתוב כאלו כבר עשו. וא"ש מ"ש במכילתא הנ"ל אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, דבאמת משה ואהרן לא הוצרכו להמתין מלקיים המצו' עד בעשור לחדש, כי היו קדושים וטהורים ומוכנים אל המצו' מיד, ולא היו צריכים לטעם הפרישה מע"ז, וא"כ למה לא יקיימו מצות ד' תיכף בר"ח בשעת שנצטוו עלי' כי זריזים מקדימין למצות, ע"כ אמרו במכילתא אף משה ואהרן כן עשו והמתינו עד בעשור לחדש, לפי שהכלל ישראל היו צריכים להמתין עד בעשור לחדש והי' צווי הבוי"ת כן, אין להתחכם על גזירתו ית', ע"כ השמיענו הכתוב דאף משה ואהרן כן עשו והמתינו עד בעשור לחדש. וא"ש.
translation: And it is understood what is stated in the Mechilta, to say: "Go and tell them immediately," the words of Rabbi Yishmael (see above the question on 76). Behold, although it was not possible to fulfill the commandment of separation from idolatry except on the tenth of the month, as mentioned, and for this reason they were not commanded to do it on Rosh Chodesh, nevertheless, the command was to tell them immediately. This was so that they would at least accept upon themselves a true commitment in a complete heart to separate from idolatry as soon as the time allowed. The completeness of the separation was not possible until the tenth of the month. However, since there was no shortcoming on their part, therefore the Sages taught that once they accepted it upon themselves, the verse considers it as if they had already done it. And it is understood what is stated in the aforementioned Mechilta, that even Moshe and Aharon did so, for in truth, Moshe and Aharon did not need to wait to fulfill the commandments until the tenth of the month, because they were holy and pure and ready to fulfill the commandments immediately, and they did not need the reason for the separation from idolatry. So why did they not fulfill the commandment immediately on Rosh Chodesh at the time they were commanded? For the diligent are quick to perform commandments. Therefore, it was said in the Mechilta that even Moshe and Aharon did so and waited until the tenth of the month, because the entire Jewish people needed to wait until the tenth of the month, and the command of the Blessed One was so; one should not be clever against His decree. Therefore, the verse informs us that even Moshe and Aharon did so and waited until the tenth of the month. And it is understood.
summary: The passage discusses the commandment to separate from idolatry, emphasizing that although the full observance could only occur on the tenth of the month, the Israelites were instructed to accept this obligation immediately. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of sincere intention and readiness to fulfill commandments, even if the actual performance is delayed. The text highlights that Moses and Aaron, despite their purity and readiness, also waited to fulfill the commandment in alignment with the collective readiness of the people, illustrating the principle of communal responsibility in spiritual observance. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that accepting a commandment with a full heart is valued, and that adherence to divine timing is essential.

passage_content: נחזור במה שהתחלנו לבאר מקראי קודש בפרשת הארבה, והדקדוקים שבענין שנפרטו לעיל, בהקדם דברי הכלי יקר ז"ל בפ' וארא עה"פ הנה אנכי מכה במטך וגו' וז"ל בקיצור, בעשר מכות רבו בהם הדיעות, למה זה ועל מה זה היו המכות האלו לעונש על מצרים, וחז"ל נתנו טעם על כל המכות שהיו מידה כנגד מידה על המצריים, והוא ז"ל כתב ג"כ טעמים על כל המכות מדעתי' דנפשי', ובמכת הארבה נתן טעם, דארבה בא עליהם לפי שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך ואמרו פן ירבה, ע"כ שלח הקב"ה עליהם מכת הארבה, כי לשון ארבה משמש על הרבוי, כמו שמצינו כן בכמה פסוקים עכת"ד ז"ל, ומצאתי סעד וסמך לטעם זה בש"ך עה"ת, וז"ל מעולם לא הי' ארבה במצרים, ואם בא אינו מזיק ואינו נח, לפי שנתן פרעה את הגר בתו לשרה, ונאמר לה הרבה ארבה את זרעך עכת"ד ז"ל, ואפ"ל בצירוף דברי הכלי יקר ודברי הש"ך ז"ל, דמעולם לא הי' ארבה ע"צ העונש למצרים, מפני שהי' להם ברכת הרבה ארבה שאמר המלאך להגר, וכיון שהיו אותיות אלו מצטרפים להם לברכה, ברכת ד' לא יוסיף עצב עמה, ע"כ לא הצטרפו אותיות אלה להם לקללה ועונש. אבל עתה בא עליהם מכת הארבה ע"צ העונש לפי שרצו לבעל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה, ע"כ נצטרפו אותיות אלו להם לקללה וע"צ העונש, גם נפסק מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה מדה כנגד מדה, לפי שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכה זו ואמרו פן ירבה, ואחר שהתפלל משרע"ה להסיר מהם הארבה, הוסר מהם לגמרי צרופי אותיות של ארבה, ולא הי' להם עוד אחיזה באותיות אלו, ומעתה לא הי' עוד ארבה בכל גבול מצרים עד עולם, וגם ברכת הרבה ארבה הוסר מהם, וא"ש מ"ש רבינו חננאל עה"פ לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים, כי מעת תפלת משרע"ה ועד היום הזה אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים, והי' כ"ז ע"י כח תפלתו של משה שיוסר מהם הארבה עד עולם, אבל לא ע"צ הברכה הגיע להם ככה כ"א ע"צ העונש, כי לא רצה משרע"ה שיהי' להם עוד אחיזה בברכת הרבה ארבה, ולא יתרבו עוד רשעים בעולם, ע"כ הוסר מהם לגמרי הכח באותיות אלו של ארבה, ונתבטל מהם הארבה וגם ברכת הרבה ארבה (ומתורץ קושיא ה' הנ"ל).
translation: We will return to what we began to explain regarding the holy scriptures in the portion of the locust, and the nuances of the matter that were detailed above, prefacing the words of the Kli Yakar, may his memory be blessed, in Parashat Va'era on the verse "Behold, I am striking with my staff," etc. He writes briefly that in the ten plagues there were many opinions regarding why these plagues were a punishment for Egypt, and our sages provided reasons for each of the plagues, which were measure for measure against the Egyptians. He also wrote reasons for each of the plagues based on his own understanding. Regarding the plague of locusts, he gave a reason that the locust came upon them because they wanted to annul the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and they said, "Lest it multiply." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, sent upon them the plague of locusts, for the term "locust" is associated with abundance, as we find in several verses, as he stated. I found support for this reason in the Shach on the Torah, where he states that there was never locust in Egypt, and if it came, it did not harm and did not settle, because Pharaoh gave his daughter Hagar to Sarah, and it was said to her, "I will greatly multiply your seed," as he stated. And it can be said, combining the words of the Kli Yakar and the words of the Shach, that there was never locust as a punishment for Egypt, because they had the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" that the angel said to Hagar, and since these letters were joined to them for a blessing, the blessing of the Lord does not add sorrow with it. Therefore, these letters did not join to them for a curse and punishment. But now the plague of locusts came upon them as a punishment because they wanted to annul the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," therefore these letters joined to them for a curse and as a punishment. Also, the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" was taken from them measure for measure, because they wanted to annul this blessing for Israel and said, "Lest it multiply." And after Moses prayed to remove the locusts from them, the combinations of the letters of locust were completely removed from them, and they no longer had a hold on these letters. From then on, there was no more locust in all the borders of Egypt forever, and also the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" was removed from them. And it is clear what our teacher Chananel said on the verse that not a single locust remained in all the borders of Egypt, for from the time of Moses' prayer until this day, locusts do not destroy in all the borders of Egypt, and all this was through the power of Moses' prayer that the locusts would be removed from them forever. But it was not due to the blessing that they received this, rather due to the punishment, for Moses did not want them to have any hold on the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and that the wicked should not multiply in the world anymore. Therefore, the power in these letters of locust was completely removed from them, and both the locust and the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" were nullified from them (and the fifth question above is resolved).
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of the plague of locusts in Egypt, emphasizing the concept of divine retribution where each plague corresponds to the sins of the Egyptians. It highlights that the locusts were sent as punishment for the Egyptians' desire to negate the blessing of abundance promised to the Israelites. The text explains that, following Moses' prayer, the power of locusts was permanently removed from Egypt, symbolizing the eradication of both the curse and the blessing of abundance for the Egyptians, thus preventing further evil from proliferating. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the profound impact of prayer and the interconnectedness of blessings and curses in divine justice.

passage_content: והנה כל המכות היו מדה כנגד מדה לפי המעשים, ומכת הארבה הי' מדה כנגד מדה באותיות, לפי שרצו לבטל ברכת הרבה ארבה נענשו במכת הארבה, והוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה, ובזה יובן הכתוב למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, שהאותיות אשר בו הרעו לישראל, מדה כנגד מדה באותיות אלו יענשו ויבא אליהם הארבה ויוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה. וא"ש מ"ש אותותי אלה, דכ"מ שנא' אלה פוסל הראשונים, דנפסלו אותיות הראשונים אשר הי' משתמשים להם לברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך, ונתחלפו ונצטרפו האותיות לקללה ע"צ העונש, וז"ש אותותי אלה פוסל הראשונים (וסרו קושיות ב' וג').
translation: And behold, all the plagues were measure for measure according to their deeds, and the plague of locusts was measure for measure in letters, for they wished to nullify the blessing of "abundant increase," and they were punished with the plague of locusts, and the blessing of "abundant increase" was removed from them. And this explains the verse "for the sake of these two signs in his midst," that the letters which harmed Israel, measure for measure with these letters, they will be punished, and the locusts will come upon them, and the blessing of "abundant increase" will be removed from them. And it is clear what is meant by "these signs," for wherever it says "these," it disqualifies the first ones, for the letters of the first ones which they used for the blessing of "abundant increase" of your seed were disqualified, and the letters were exchanged and combined for a curse as a consequence of the punishment. Therefore, it is said "these signs disqualify the first ones" (and the questions of two and three are resolved).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine retribution, emphasizing that each plague in Egypt was a measure-for-measure punishment corresponding to the actions of the Egyptians. Specifically, the plague of locusts is seen as a direct consequence of their attempt to negate the blessing of abundance, resulting in the removal of that blessing. The text highlights the significance of letters and words, indicating that the very letters used to invoke blessings were transformed into instruments of curse as a form of punishment. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the power of language and the consequences of one's actions in relation to divine justice.

passage_content: והנה פרעה הי' חכם גדול כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, והי' חושש שכאשר יתפלל משה להסיר ממנו הארבה, יסיר מהם כח אותיות אלו ויתבטל מהם גם ברכת הרבה ארבה כאשר הי' באמת כן, ע"כ אמר פרעה העתירו אל ד' ויסר ממנו רק את המות הזה, כוונתו למעט במלת רק ותיבת הזה, שלא יוסר ממנו לגמרי אותיות של ארבה, אלא שלא ישמשו ע"צ העונש, וז"ש רק את המות הזה, אבל כח הברכה בתיבת ארבה ישאר לו. אבל משרע"ה לא עשה כן אלא התפלל שיוסר ממנו לגמרי אותיות אלו ולא נשאר ארבה בכל גבול מצרים עד עולם, וגם ברכת הארבה נתבטלה מהם עד עולם. (ומתורץ קושיא י"א).
translation: And behold, Pharaoh was a great wise man, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, writes, and he was concerned that when Moses would pray to remove the locusts from him, the power of these letters would be removed from them, and thus the blessing of the abundance of locusts would also be nullified, as it indeed was. Therefore, Pharaoh said, "Entreat the Lord for me, and let Him remove from me only this death," his intention being to minimize with the word "only" and the phrase "this death," so that the letters of locusts would not be completely removed from him, but rather that they would not serve as a punishment. This is what he meant by "only this death," but the power of the blessing in the word "locusts" would remain for him. However, Moses did not do this; rather, he prayed that these letters be completely removed from him, and there remained no locusts in all the borders of Egypt forever, and the blessing of the locusts was nullified from them forever. (And the question is resolved).
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's wisdom and his concern that if Moses prayed to remove the locusts, the power of the letters associated with them would also be diminished, thus affecting the blessing of abundance. Pharaoh's request to God was limited, seeking only the removal of "this death," implying he wanted to retain the potential for blessing. In contrast, Moses prayed for the complete removal of the locusts and their associated letters, resulting in their permanent absence in Egypt and the cancellation of the blessing of abundance. This highlights the Hasidic concept of the transformative power of prayer and the importance of seeking total redemption rather than partial relief.

passage_content: ובזה מתורץ משה"כ התעללתי במצרים ופרש"י שחקתי, דעד עכשיו הי"ל אותיות אלו של ארבה לברכה, ועכשיו שחקתי בהם ונהפכה לצרה ותוגה עליהם, או אפשר לפי שנשאר להם עכ"פ קצת ריוח ממכה זו, שלא והי' עוד ארבה בגבולם עד עולם, ע"כ קורא הכתוב למכה זו שחוק. ויבואר מה שאמר הכתוב למען תספר באזני בנך וגו' במכת הארבה דייקא, כי הכלל הוא דזה לעומת זה עשה אלקים, וכשזה נופל זה קם, כמו שלמדו חז"ל (פסחים דף מ"ב ע"ב) ממה שאמר הכתוב ולאום מלאום יאמץ, וממ"ש אמלאה החרבה, וע"כ מפני שע"י מכת הארבה הוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה, נתחזק אצל ישראל ברכה זו, וז"ש במדרש למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו' מכאן בשורה על הבנים, ר"ל שנתבשרו בברכת הרבה ארבה שיזכו לבנים ובני בנים ואפ"ל עוד כוונה בזה דלכאורה מה צורך לבשורה זו, וכי אפשר שאומה שלימה לא יהי' להם בנים, אמנם הבשורה הי' שיהי' להם בנים ובני בנים מאמינים בד' ובתורתו ויהי' בהם אמונת אומן בנסי ד', וז"ש למען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולא אמר והגדת לבנך כמ"ש במקו"א, דעצם הבשורה הי' כאן שיכנסו הדברים באזניהם, וזו הברכה האמיתיות של בשורת הבנים.
translation:
And with this, it is clarified what is meant by "I have played with Egypt," and Rashi explains "I have laughed." Until now, these letters of locusts were for blessing, and now I have laughed at them, and they have turned into trouble and sorrow for them. Or it is possible that since they at least had some relief from this plague, that there would no longer be locusts in their borders forever, therefore the scripture calls this plague "laughter." 

And it will be explained what the scripture says "so that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc." specifically regarding the plague of locusts, for the general principle is that "this corresponds to that" as God has made, and when this falls, that rises, as our Sages learned (Pesachim 42b) from what the scripture says "and nation shall be strengthened against nation," and from what is said "I will fill the desolate." Therefore, because through the plague of locusts the blessing of "many locusts" was removed from them, this blessing was strengthened among Israel. 

And this is what is said in the Midrash "so that you may tell in the ears of your son and your son's son, etc." from here is the good news for the children, meaning that they were informed of the blessing of "many locusts" that they would merit to have children and grandchildren. And it can also be said that there is another intention here, for seemingly what need is there for this good news, and is it possible that a whole nation would not have children? However, the good news was that they would have children and grandchildren who believe in God and His Torah, and they would have a faithful belief in God's miracles. And this is why it says "so that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc." and it does not say "and you shall tell your son" as stated elsewhere, for the essence of the good news here was that these words should enter their ears, and this is the true blessing of the good news of children.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the locust plague from a potential blessing to a source of suffering for Egypt, highlighting the Hasidic concept that divine actions often have dual outcomes. It emphasizes the idea that through suffering, the Jewish people are strengthened in their blessings, particularly in the promise of future generations. The text underscores the importance of passing down this message to children, ensuring that they inherit a faith in God and His miracles, which is seen as the true blessing of progeny. This reflects the belief that adversity can lead to spiritual growth and continuity of faith within the Jewish lineage.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בענין הנ"ל עפ"י המבואר בספה"ק דבכח הצדיקים לבטל גזירה רעה ולהפך הדין לרחמים ע"י שמהפכין צרופי אותיות של הגזירה לטובה, עד"מ צרה לרצה נגע לענג ופי' בזה והנה הנגע לא הפך את עינו, דאם נהפך העי"ן לבוא בראש התיבה נעשה מנגע לענג ונהפך לרחמים ולטובה, וכמו"כ פירשו (תהלים ל"ג י"ח) הנה עין ד' אל יריאיו למיחלים לחסדו להציל ממות נפשם, שאם נגזר ח"ו גזירת מות על המיחלים לחסדו, הבוי"ת מצרף אות עי"ן לתיבת מות ונעשה מעות, וזהו הנה עי"ן ד' אל יריאיו וגו' ועי"ז להציל ממות נפשם ולהחיותם ברעב ונתהפך הגזירה לטובה, ועד"ז מבואר בספה"ק שפרשת התוכחה רמוזים בה ברכות וטובות לישראל, ואם יזכו יתהפכו כולם לברכות ע"י התהפכות צירופי האותיות מקללה לברכה, ועד"ז בתיבה שיש לה ב' משמעות לטובה ולהיפך ח"ו, בכח הצדיקים וברצונו ית' מהפך המשמעות לטובה ומהדין עצמו נעשה רחמים גמורים לישראל ולהיפך לשונאי ישראל. ועד"ז יתבאר לענינו דהמצרים מפני שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך ואמרו פן ירבה, ע"כ נהפך להם משמעות ארבה לקללה במכת הארבה והוסר מהם ברכת הרבוי ולישראל נעשה ממכת הארבה ברכה ונתחזק אצלם ברכת הרבוי
translation: Furthermore, it can be said regarding the above matter according to what is explained in the holy books, that it is within the power of the righteous to annul a bad decree and to transform judgment into mercy by reversing the combinations of the letters of the decree for good. For example, the word "tzara" (trouble) can be transformed into "ratzon" (will) by changing the letter "ayin" to come at the beginning of the word, thus turning "nega" (plague) into "oneg" (delight), and it is explained that the plague did not turn his eye, for if the "ayin" is reversed to come at the beginning of the word, it becomes "oneg" and is transformed into mercy and goodness. Likewise, it is interpreted (Psalms 33:18) "Behold, the eye of the Lord is upon those who fear Him, upon those who hope for His kindness, to save their souls from death," that if a decree of death was, Heaven forbid, issued against those who hope for His kindness, the Blessed One combines the letter "ayin" with the word "mavet" (death) and it becomes "ma'ot" (money), and this is "the eye of the Lord is upon those who fear Him," and through this, He saves their souls from death and revives them in famine, and the decree is transformed for good. Similarly, it is explained in the holy books that the section of rebuke contains hints of blessings and goodness for Israel, and if they merit it, they will all be transformed into blessings through the reversal of the combinations of the letters from curse to blessing. Likewise, in a word that has two meanings, for good and the opposite, Heaven forbid, through the power of the righteous and His will, He transforms the meaning for good, and from the judgment itself, complete mercy is made for Israel and the opposite for the enemies of Israel. In the same way, it can be explained regarding the Egyptians, who wished to annul the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and said, "lest they multiply," therefore the meaning of "arbeh" (multiply) was turned into a curse in the plague of locusts, and the blessing of multiplication was removed from them, while for Israel, the plague of locusts became a blessing, and the blessing of multiplication was strengthened among them.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic belief in the power of the righteous to transform negative decrees into blessings through the manipulation of the letters and meanings of words. It illustrates this concept by explaining how the letter "ayin" can be altered to change the meaning of "negev" (plague) to "oneg" (delight), thereby turning a curse into a blessing. The text emphasizes that through faith and the intercession of the righteous, even harsh judgments can be transformed into mercy, as seen in the biblical context of God's protection over those who trust in Him. Additionally, it highlights the idea that the oppressors' intentions can backfire, as their attempts to diminish Israel's blessings ultimately lead to their own downfall.

passage_content: ובזה יל"פ דברי הזוה"ק בפתיחת פ' הארבה, ר"י פתח ואמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון ע"כ וצ"ב הקישור ויתבאר עפי"ד הגמ' (ר"ה ט"ז ע"ב) וא"ר יצחק כל שנה שאין תוקעין לה בתחילתה מריעין לה בסופה מ"ט דלא איערבב שטן עכ"ד הגמ' וכתב הטו"ז (ה' ר"ה סי' תקפ"ה) שנתגלה לו בחלום פי' הכתוב בחצוצרות וקול שופר הריעו לפני המלך ד', עפי"ד הגמ' הנ"ל, שיהיו נזהרים לקיים התרועה ע"י שופר, קודם שתהי' התרועה ח"ו בסוף השנה מאתו ית', ובזה אמר לפני המלך ד' כלומר קודם תרועת המלך ב"ה עכ"ל, וע"ד הרמז נל"פ עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל דהנה מלת תרועה יש לה ב' משמעות, כמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א (ר"ה ל"ב ע"ב) דמלת תרועה מורה על מדת הדין מלשון שבר עכ"ל, ובפ' בלק פרש"י ז"ל עה"פ ותרועת מלך בו לשון חבה וריעות וכו' וכן פי' הרשב"ם כמו איש רעים להתרועע וכן ת"א ושכינת מלכהון ביניהון, ומסגולת השופר להפך מדת הדין לרחמים ונעשה מתרועה שהוא לשון שבר תרועה של חבה ורעות, וז"פ הריעו לפני המלך ד' קודם תרועת המלך וכו', ר"ל שע"י סגולת השופר יתהפך הגזירה לטובה וימתק הדין בשרשו.
translation:
In this, the words of the Zohar are explained in the opening of Parshat Ha'arbeh. Rabbi Yochanan opened and said, "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar; they shall walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance." Therefore, the connection is questioned, and it will be clarified according to the words of the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 16b). Rabbi Yitzchak said, "Every year that we do not blow the shofar at its beginning, we will be troubled at its end. Why? Because the accuser does not become mixed in." Thus said the Gemara. The Taz (Orach Chaim 581:1) wrote that it was revealed to him in a dream the meaning of the verse, "With trumpets and the sound of the shofar, shout before the King, the Lord," according to the aforementioned Gemara, that we should be careful to fulfill the teruah with the shofar before the teruah, Heaven forbid, at the end of the year from Him. In this, it is said, "Before the King, the Lord," meaning before the teruah of the King, blessed be He. Thus far is his statement. 

And according to the hint, we can learn based on our previous path that the word "teruah" has two meanings, as stated by the Maharsha in his commentary (Rosh Hashanah 32b), that the word "teruah" indicates the attribute of judgment, from the language of breaking. Thus far is his statement. And in Parshat Balak, Rashi explained the verse, "And the teruah of the King is in it," as a language of affection and friendship, etc. Similarly, Rashi's son-in-law explained it as "a man of friends to befriend," and likewise the Targum, "And the Shechinah is among them." 

And it is the quality of the shofar to transform the attribute of judgment into mercy, and it is made from teruah, which is a language of breaking, into a teruah of affection and friendship. This is the meaning of "Shout before the King, the Lord," before the teruah of the King, etc., meaning that through the quality of the shofar, the decree will be turned to good, and the judgment will be sweetened at its root.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the shofar's sound, particularly in relation to the Jewish New Year and the concept of divine judgment. It emphasizes the importance of the shofar's teruah, which can transform the harshness of judgment (associated with the term "teruah" meaning "break") into mercy and love. By sounding the shofar before God's judgment, one can invoke a favorable decree, highlighting the shofar's power to alter the course of divine decisions. This reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between human actions, repentance, and divine mercy.

passage_content: ובזה יל"פ מאמה"כ אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון, ר"ל שישראל ניתן להם הכח להפוך התרועה לטובה, כמו שדרשו רז"ל (ויק"ר פ' כ"ט סי' ד') יודעי תרועה שיודעים לרצות את בוראם בתרועה, ומהפכים הדין לרחמים, ונתן טעם ד' באור פניך יהלכון שנשפעים מאורו ית', ובחי' האור משמשת ג"כ לב' פנים כמ"ש רז"ל ריש פסחים דאור משמעותי' יממא ומשמעותי' נגהי עיי"ש, והגה"ק מברדיטשוב זלה"ה פי' בזה כיתרון האור מן החשך כן יתרון לחכם מן הכסיל, כמו שהאור משמשת לב' פנים משא"כ החשך, כן יתרון לחכם מן הכסיל, כי החכם יכול לשנות את טעמו כמ"ש לדוד בשנותו וגו' משא"כ הכסיל עיי"ש וא"ש קישור דברי הזוה"ק לפ' הארבה, דגם בארבה הי' בחי' זו שע"י עתירת משרע"ה הוסר מכת הארבה ונתחלף לישראל לברכת הרבה ארבה ולמצרים להיפך, כן יעזור השי"ת בכל הדורות להמשיך השפעות טובות על ישראל רחמים וחסדים, ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And in this, it can be explained from our holy sources: "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar; O Lord, in the light of Your countenance shall they walk," meaning that Israel has been given the power to transform the sound of the shofar into goodness, as our sages have interpreted (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 29, Section 4) that those who know the sound of the shofar know how to appease their Creator with the shofar, and they transform judgment into mercy. And He gave the reason: "O Lord, in the light of Your countenance shall they walk," for they are infused with His light. And the aspect of light also serves two faces, as our sages have said at the beginning of Pesachim: "Light signifies day and signifies brightness," as mentioned there. And the holy one from Berdichev, may his memory be blessed, explained this as the advantage of light over darkness; so too is the advantage of the wise over the fool, for light serves two faces, whereas darkness does not. Thus, the wise can change their taste, as it is said of David, "When he changed his behavior," whereas the fool cannot, as mentioned there. And it is clear how this connects to the words of the Zohar regarding the locusts, that also in the case of the locusts, through the entreaty of Moshe Rabbeinu, the plague of locusts was removed and transformed into a blessing of much locusts for Israel and the opposite for Egypt. So may the Holy One, blessed be He, help in all generations to continue to bring forth good influences upon Israel, mercy and kindness, and may we soon merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the crown of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon, amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique ability of the Jewish people to transform their cries (teruah) into positive outcomes, turning judgment into mercy through their connection with God. It highlights the dual nature of divine light, which can illuminate both wisdom and folly, suggesting that the wise can adapt and change their perspectives, unlike the foolish. The text draws parallels to the biblical story of the locust plague, where Moses' intercession led to a reversal of fate for Israel and Egypt, symbolizing the hope for continued divine mercy and blessings for the Jewish people. Ultimately, it expresses a yearning for the redemption and elevation of Israel, culminating in the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: באופן אחר נל"פ דברי הזוהר הקדוש, בהקדם לבאר עוד בדברי הגמ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל, על פי המבואר בדבריהם ז"ל כי יש ששים רבוא אותיות לתורה, וכנגדן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל, ישראל נוטריקון יש ששים רבוא אותיות לתורה, וכל נשמה נאצל מאות א' שבתורה הקדושה, ובני ישראל שבכל דור ודור כולן שורשם וגזעם מאותן הששים רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שקבלו התוה"ק, נמצא כל א' מישראל מקושר באות א' בתורה, וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' תשא) הביא מ"ש השלה"ק בשם מגלת סתרים כי ס' רבוא נשמות לישראל וס' רבוא שבתות, שי"ן אלפים בשית אלפי שנין, וש' אלפים ביום שכולו שבת דהוא אלף השביעי, וכל נשמה נחצבה משבת א' עיי"ש, ופי' ק"ז זלה"ה בזה הפסוק כי אות היא ביני וביניכם, דס' רבוא אותיות לתורה וכל נשמה יש לה אות, וכמו"כ כל שבת ג"כ נחצב מאות א' שבתוה"ק, וא"כ כל שבת ושבת הוא ממש איזה אות בהתורה כל שבת אות אחר, וז"ש כי אות היא, ונמצא לפי"ז אותו האדם שהשבת מתייחס לו ביום השבת ההוא והבן, אם מחלל ח"ו השבת ההוא עונשו גדול מכל מחללי שבתות שהיו בעולם ושיהיו בעולם, דהרי הוא פוגם בעצם אותו השבת במקומו ובשעתו וכו', ופוגם בכל ישראל שסותם עצם האור שלא תוכל להאיר לישראל, וההיפך באם שמרו שכרו גדול יותר מכל שומרי שבתות שהיו ושיהיו, דהרי נותן הארה לשבת בהעצם ומאיר לכל ישראל בהארה יפה וברה, ומקבל הארה מכולם בסוד אור חוזר עכ"ל ק"ז זלל"ה, וכן הוא ממש באותיות התוה"ק אם ח"ו פוגם באות הזה המתייחס אליו ולשרשו גדול עונו מנשוא ר"ל וה"ה פוגם בכל ישראל למנוע הארת הקדושה ח"ו, להיפך באם שמרו מאיר לכל ישראל וכנ"ל, נמצא דע"י התוה"ק מתקשרין ומתאחדין כל נשמות ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, דכולם נכללים בס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שקבלו התוה"ק, וכל א' מהם נאצל מאות א' שבתוה"ק, וכל אותיות שבתוה"ק מתקשרין ומתאחדין כחדא, דס"ת שחסר ממנה אפי' אות א' פסולה, והמגיה בה אפי' אות א' כאילו כתבה כולה, ועד"ז כל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרים באותן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל ובתוה"ק,
translation:
In another way, we can explain the words of the holy Zohar, by first clarifying the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin mentioned above, according to what is explained in their words, that there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah, corresponding to the six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel. Israel is an acronym for "there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah," and each soul is derived from one letter of the holy Torah. The children of Israel in every generation are all rooted and stem from those six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel who received the Torah. Thus, each individual of Israel is connected to one letter in the Torah. And this is what Moshe, may his memory be blessed, brought in Parashat Tisa from what is said in the Shlah HaKadosh in the name of the Megillat Setarim, that there are six hundred thousand souls for Israel and six hundred thousand Shabbatot, which are six thousand years, and six thousand on the day that is entirely Shabbat, which is the seventh thousand. And every soul is hewn from one Shabbat, as stated there. The explanation of this, may his memory be blessed, regarding this verse is that "it is a sign between Me and you," for there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah, and each soul has a letter. Likewise, every Shabbat is also hewn from one letter of the holy Torah. Therefore, each Shabbat is indeed a specific letter in the Torah, each Shabbat a different letter. This is what is meant by "it is a sign." 

According to this, the person to whom the Shabbat relates on that particular Shabbat, if he, Heaven forbid, desecrates that Shabbat, his punishment is greater than all those who have desecrated Shabbat in the world and will do so in the future, for he is damaging the essence of that Shabbat in its place and at its time, etc., and he damages all of Israel by blocking the essence of the light so that it cannot shine for Israel. Conversely, if he observes it, his reward is greater than all those who have observed Shabbat in the past and will do so in the future, for he gives illumination to the Shabbat in its essence and shines for all of Israel with a beautiful and clear light, and he receives illumination from all in the secret of the returning light. Thus, it is indeed with the letters of the holy Torah; if, Heaven forbid, he damages this letter that relates to him and to his root, his sin is greater than can be borne, Heaven forbid, and the same applies to damaging all of Israel, preventing the illumination of holiness, Heaven forbid. Conversely, if he observes it, he brings light to all of Israel, as mentioned above. 

It follows that through the holy Torah, all the souls of Israel are connected and united until the end of all generations, for they are all included in the six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel who received the holy Torah, and each of them is derived from one letter of the holy Torah. All the letters of the holy Torah are connected and united as one, for a Torah scroll that is missing even one letter is invalid, and one who corrects it, even one letter, is as if he wrote the entire scroll. Similarly, all of Israel until the end of all generations are connected to those six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel and to the holy Torah.
summary: The passage discusses the profound connection between the letters of the Torah and the souls of the Jewish people, emphasizing that each soul is rooted in one of the 600,000 letters of the Torah. It highlights that the observance of Shabbat is intrinsically linked to these letters, with each Shabbat representing a unique letter that contributes to the spiritual illumination of all Israel. The text warns that violating Shabbat not only harms the individual but also diminishes the collective light available to the entire Jewish community. Conversely, observing Shabbat enhances the spiritual radiance for all, reinforcing the unity and interconnectedness of Jewish souls through the Torah.

passage_content: והנה מצינו דשורש נשמות ישראל שבדור המדבר היו כלולים כולם בס"ה משפחות, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בפ' פנחס עה"פ ואלה בני שותלח וז"ל צא וחשוב ותמצא בפרשה זו נ"ז משפחות ומבני לוי שמונה הרי ס"ה, וז"ש כי אתם המעט וגו' ה"א מעט, חמשה אתם חסרים ממשפחות כל העמים שהם שבעים, וכו' מיסודו של ר' משה הדרשן עכ"ל, נמצא דכל ישראל שבכל הדורות שרשם מאותן ס"ה משפחות, כל אחד משורש משפחה א' מהם אשר משם חוצבתו, ומקושרים כולם כאחד ע"י קדושת התוה"ק כנ"ל, וכענין הזה בעיירות של ארץ ישראל שנתחלקה הארץ בימי יהושע בגורל עפ"י ד', כל א' מישראל קבל חלקו המתייחס אליו ולשורש נשמתו, (ובספרי ויואל משה מאמר ישוב א"י סי' קכ"ח הארכתי בזה עיי"ש) היוצא לנו מזה דכל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרין באותן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שבדור המדבר ובאותן ס"ה משפחות ובאותן עיירות שמתייחסים לשורש נשמתם ונפל בגורלם עפ"י ד' וברוה"ק.
translation: And behold, we find that the root of the souls of Israel in the generation of the desert were all included in 65 families, as Rashi, of blessed memory, writes in Parashat Pinchas on the verse "And these are the sons of Shuthelach," and he says: "Go out and count, and you will find in this section 57 families, and from the children of Levi eight, making a total of 65." This is what is meant by "for you are the few," etc. The "few" refers to the five that you are lacking from the families of all the nations, which are seventy, etc., based on the foundation of Rabbi Moshe the preacher. Thus, it is found that all of Israel in all generations have their root from those 65 families, each one from the root of one family among them from which he is hewn, and they are all connected as one through the sanctity of the Holy Torah, as mentioned. And in a similar manner, in the towns of the Land of Israel, when the land was divided in the days of Joshua by lot according to the tribes, each one of Israel received his portion that relates to him and to the root of his soul (and in the book "Vayuel Moshe," in the essay on the settlement of the Land of Israel, section 128, I elaborated on this, see there). What emerges from this is that all of Israel until the end of all generations are connected to those 600,000 roots of the souls of Israel in the generation of the desert, and to those 65 families, and to those towns that relate to the root of their soul, and fell to their lot according to the tribes and through the Holy Spirit.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the souls of the Jewish people throughout all generations and the 65 families that existed during the time of the Exodus. It emphasizes that each individual's soul is rooted in one of these families, linking all Jews together through the sanctity of the Torah. Additionally, it highlights the idea that, similar to the division of the land in Israel by Joshua, each person receives a portion that corresponds to their spiritual lineage, reinforcing the unity and continuity of the Jewish people across time.

passage_content: ולפי"ז אפ"ל דמ"ש הכתוב ולקחתי א' מעיר ושנים ממשפחה מיירי באותן עיירות ובאותן ס"ה משפחות שהם מתייחסים לשרשי נשמות ישראל, והעיירות של עכשיו והמשפחות של עכשיו אינם בחשבון הזה, כי איך אפשר לכייל כולם בדרגא חדא וישנם עיירות גדולות ומרובים יושבי' המחזיקים בתורת ד' וכן להיפך ח"ו, ועד"ז במשפחות, ואיך יהי' מידתם שוה לדברי ר"י ולר"ל כקושיתנו לעיל, אמנם אותן העיירות והמשפחות כולם משורש א', וכל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרים בהם כל א' בשרשו כנ"ל, ובזה מיירי הכתוב ור"ל ס"ל דברים ככתבן, דפשוטו של מקרא כך הוא ועפ"י תוקף ודקדוק הדין לא ימצא זכאי בדינו כ"א א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, ור' יוחנן ורב פליגי עלי' וס"ל דא' מעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, ושנים ממשפחה מזכין כל המשפחה כולה שינצלו בזכותם שכלולים כולם בשורש א' כנ"ל.
translation: According to this, it can be said that what the verse states, "And I will take one from a city and two from a family," refers to those cities and those 65 families that are related to the roots of the souls of Israel. The cities of today and the families of today are not included in this calculation, for how can they all be measured on the same level? There are large and numerous cities inhabited by those who uphold the Torah of the Almighty, and conversely, Heaven forbid, there are also the opposite. Similarly, with families, how can their measure be equal according to the words of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer, as our question above? However, those cities and families are all from one root, and all of Israel, until the end of all generations, are connected to them, each one to its root, as mentioned. In this, the verse is referring, and Rabbi Eliezer holds that the words are as they are written. The simple meaning of the verse is indeed so, and according to the strength and precision of the law, one will not find a righteous person in his judgment except for one from a city and two from a family. Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi argue about this and hold that one from a city merits for the entire city, and two from a family merit for the entire family, for they are all included in one root, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the interconnectedness of Jewish souls, emphasizing that all individuals are rooted in a singular spiritual source, regardless of their current geographical or familial affiliations. It highlights the idea that the merit of one individual from a city or two from a family can potentially redeem the entire community or family, reflecting a deep theological belief in collective responsibility and unity among the Jewish people. The text contrasts different interpretations of this principle, illustrating the debate between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Lul on the extent of this redemptive power. Ultimately, it underscores the notion that all Jews, across generations, are linked through their shared spiritual roots.

passage_content: וא"ל ר' יוחנן לר"ל לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, פרש"י אין הקב"ה רוצה שתהא דן את ישראל כל כך לכף חובה, דהנה קיי"ל היכא דפליגי ר' יוחנן ור"ל הלכה כר' יוחנן וכן הלכתא כוותי' לגבי רב, ומכ"ש כאן דרב ור' יוחנן פליגי על ר"ל ושניהם ס"ל דא' מעיר מזכה כל העיר וכו', אך כבר כתב הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשניות פרק חלק אצל הפלוגתא אם עשרת השבטים עתידין לחזור וז"ל, כבר כתבתי לך פעמים רבות שכל מחלוקת שיהי' בין החכמים שאינו בא לידי מעשה, אלא שהוא אמונת דבר בלבד, אין צד לפסוק הלכה כא' מהם עכ"ל, והנה בכל פלוגתת חז"ל נמסרה כח ההכרעה לחכמי הדור כמ"ש הריטב"א (ערובין י"ג ע"ב) בביאור אמרם ז"ל אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים עיי"ש אבל בענין כזה שביד הקב"ה לעשות תליא ההכרעה במשקל ק"ל דעות ולכך א"ר יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, כלומר בודאי הקב"ה לא יכריע כדבריך, דרב חסד מטה כלפי חסד והבוי"ת יסכים על ידינו להכריע לכף זכות דאחד מעיר יציל כל בני העיר וב' ממשפחה יגינו על כולן, ובלבד שיהיו מקושרים בהשורש באותן ס"ה משפחות ובאותיות התוה"ק, כי אלו שנפסקו ונעתקו ח"ו משרשם בקדושה, עליהם אמר הכתוב וברותי מכם המורדים והפושעים וגו', אבל כל א' מישראל המקושר בתוה"ק ומצותי', ה"ה מקושר בשורש נשמות ישראל ולאותן ס"ה משפחות, ושנים מהם יגינו ויצילו כולם.
translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said to Rabbi Levi, "It is not pleasing to them that you said this to them." Rashi explains that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not want you to judge Israel so harshly. Behold, we hold that where Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Levi disagree, the halacha follows Rabbi Yochanan, and so too the halacha is with him regarding Rav. How much more so here, where Rav and Rabbi Yochanan disagree with Rabbi Levi, and both hold that one from a city can merit the entire city, etc. However, the Rambam has already written in his commentary on the Mishnah, in the chapter on the World to Come, regarding the dispute about whether the Ten Tribes will return, and he wrote: "I have written to you many times that any dispute among the sages that does not come to practical action, but is merely a matter of belief, there is no basis to rule halacha like one of them." Thus, in all disputes of the Sages, the power of decision is given to the sages of the generation, as the Ritva explains (Eruvin 13b) in his commentary on their saying, "These and those are the words of the Living God." However, in a matter like this, which is in the hands of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the decision depends on weighing a hundred and twenty opinions. Therefore, Rabbi Yochanan said, "It is not pleasing to them that you said this to them," meaning certainly the Holy One, Blessed be He, will not decide according to your words, for Rav leans towards kindness, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will agree through us to decide in favor of merit, that one from a city will save all the inhabitants, and two from a family will protect all of them, provided they are connected to the root of those thirty-five families and to the letters of the Torah. For those who have been severed and removed, Heaven forbid, from their root in holiness, concerning them the verse says, "And I will cut off from you the rebellious and the sinners," etc. But every Jew who is connected to the Torah and my commandments is indeed connected to the root of the souls of Israel and to those thirty-five families, and two of them will protect and save all.
summary: Rabbi Yochanan emphasizes that God does not wish to judge Israel harshly, highlighting the importance of mercy and the potential for redemption. He asserts that even one righteous individual can save an entire community, provided they are connected to the roots of holiness and the Torah. The passage underscores the belief that all Jews, when linked to the Torah and its commandments, are inherently connected to the collective soul of Israel, thus enabling mutual protection and salvation. Ultimately, the text reflects a deep commitment to the idea of communal responsibility and divine compassion in the face of sin.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בביאור הענין דהנה בגמ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל פליגי ג"כ ר' יוחנן ור"ל בפי' הכתוב (ישעי' ה') לכן הרחיבה שאול נפשה ופערה פיה לבלי חוק, אמר ר"ל למי שמשייר אפי' חוק אחד פרש"י שמשייר אפי' חוק א' מלשמרו נדון בגיהנם, א"ר יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, אלא אפי' לא למד אלא חוק א' עכ"ד הגמ' וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א לכאורה לפי משמעו קשה לדברי ר"ל, וכי משום עבירה א' נופל בגיהנם ולר"י נמי וכי מצוה אחת מצלת האדם מן הגיהנם עיי"ש תירוצו ועוד לאלקי מילין.
translation: And even further in explaining the matter, behold in the Gemara of Sanhedrin mentioned above, Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer also argue regarding the interpretation of the verse (Isaiah 5): "Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite and opened its mouth without measure." Rabbi Eliezer said that this refers to one who leaves even one law aside; Rashi explains that one who leaves even one law from observing it is judged in Gehenna. Rabbi Yochanan said that it is not pleasing to them that you say this, but even if one has only learned one law, so concludes the Gemara. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his first explanation that seemingly according to its meaning, it is difficult to the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Is it because of one transgression that one falls into Gehenna? And according to Rabbi Yochanan, is it true that one commandment saves a person from Gehenna? See there for his resolution and also for the divine matters.
summary: The passage discusses a debate between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer regarding the implications of a person's adherence to the commandments as reflected in Isaiah 5. Rabbi Eliezer argues that even neglecting one commandment can lead to punishment in Gehenna, while Rabbi Yochanan suggests that fulfilling even one commandment can save a person from such a fate. The text highlights the tension between strict adherence to the law and the potential for redemption through even minimal observance, emphasizing the importance of individual actions in the context of divine judgment. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the transformative power of mitzvot and the possibility of salvation through sincere effort.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה קיי"ל בכל פלוגתת חז"ל אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים כמ"ש רז"ל (ערובין י"ג ע"ב) והסביר רש"י ז"ל במס' כתובות (נ"ז ע"א) וז"ל כי פליגי תרי אמוראי בדין או באיסור והיתר, כל חד אמר הכי מסתבר טעמא וכו', מר יהיב טעמא להיתרא ומר יהיב טעמא לאיסורא וכו', ואיכא למימר אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים דזמנין דשייך האי טעמא וזמנין דשייך האי טעמא, שהטעם מתהפך לפי שנוי הדברים בשינוי מועט עכ"ל, והריטב"א כתב (ערובין י"ג) שאלו רבני צרפת האיך אפשר שיהיו שניהם דא"ח זה אוסר וזה מתיר, ותירצו כי כשעלה משה למרום לקבל תורה, הראו לו על כל דבר ודבר מ"ט פנים להיתר ומ'"ט פנים לאיסור, ושאל להקב"ה על זה, ואמר שיהא זה מסור לחכמי ישראל שבכל דור ודור ויהי' ההכרעה כמותן עכ"ל.
translation: And it can be understood that we hold in all the disputes of the Sages that these and those are the words of the living God, as our Sages have said (Eruvin 13b), and Rashi explained in Ketubot (57a) as follows: When two Amoraim argue about a law or about a prohibition and permission, each one says that his reasoning is more plausible, etc. One gives a reason for leniency and the other gives a reason for stringency, etc. And one can say that these and those are the words of the living God, for sometimes this reasoning applies and sometimes that reasoning applies, as the reasoning can change based on a slight alteration in the matter. Thus far the text. And the Ritva wrote (Eruvin 13) that the Rabbis of France asked how it is possible for both to be true, one prohibiting and the other permitting. They answered that when Moses ascended to the heavens to receive the Torah, he was shown for every matter forty-nine aspects for leniency and forty-nine aspects for stringency, and he asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, about this, and He said that this should be entrusted to the sages of Israel in every generation, and the decision should be according to them. Thus far the text.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that differing opinions among the sages of Israel are both considered "words of the living God," reflecting the complexity of divine law. It highlights that each argument has its own validity, as the reasoning can shift based on slight changes in circumstances. The text references the tradition that when Moses ascended to receive the Torah, he was shown multiple perspectives on each issue, emphasizing the dynamic nature of halachic interpretation. Ultimately, the authority to decide these matters is entrusted to the sages of each generation.

passage_content: אמנם בפלוגתת חז"ל שאינו בא לידי מעשה בנ"א לא נמסרה כח ההכרעה לחכמי הדורות, כמ"ש לעיל עפי"ד הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשניות, וכמו"כ בהך פלוגתא הנ"ל מי שמשייר חוק א' נדון בגיהנם ולר"י אפי' למד חוק א' ניצול מגיהנם, הכרעה זו תליא במשקל ק"ל דיעות, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (ה' תשובה פ"ג ה"ב) אדם שעונותיו מרובין על זכיותיו מיד הוא מת ברשעו וכו' וכן מדינה שעונותי' מרובין מיד הוא אובדת וכו', ושיקול זה אינו לפי מנין הזכיות והעונות אלא לפי גדלם, יש זכות שהיא כנגד כמה עונות וכו', ויש עון שהוא כנגד כמה זכיות וכו', ואין שוקלין אלא בדעתו של קל דיעות, והוא היודע האיך עורכין הזכיות כנגד העונות עכלה"ק.
translation: Indeed, in the dispute of our Sages that does not come to practical action for human beings, the power of decision was not given to the sages of the generations, as mentioned above according to the opinion of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in his commentary on the Mishnah. Likewise, in this aforementioned dispute, one who leaves out one law is judged in Gehenna, and according to Rabbi Yochanan, even one who learns one law is saved from Gehenna. This decision depends on weighing a hundred and twenty opinions, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, states (Hilchot Teshuvah 3:2) that a person whose sins are greater than his merits immediately dies in his wickedness, etc., and likewise a nation whose sins are greater is immediately lost, etc. This consideration is not based on the number of merits and sins but rather on their magnitude; there is a merit that is equivalent to many sins, etc., and there is a sin that is equivalent to many merits, etc. And one does not weigh except according to the opinion of the lighter opinions, and he is the one who knows how to arrange the merits against the sins, thus concludes the matter.
summary: The passage discusses the complexity of moral judgment in Jewish thought, emphasizing that the resolution of disputes regarding human actions is not solely in the hands of the sages. It highlights the idea that the weighing of merits and sins is not a simple tally but rather a nuanced evaluation of their significance, where certain merits can outweigh multiple sins and vice versa. This theological insight underscores the importance of understanding the qualitative aspects of one's actions rather than merely counting them, reflecting a deeper divine justice. Ultimately, it suggests that true discernment in these matters requires profound wisdom and insight.

passage_content: ומעתה דברי ר"י ור"ל אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים, ועפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל (במס' כתובות הנ"ל) דזמנין דשייך האי טעמא וזמנין דשייך האי טעמא, ותליא באיכות המצו' ואופן קיומה, דלפעמים אם יקיים האדם מצו' אחת במסנ"פ וברעותא דלבא ובכוונה אמיתית לש"ש, מצו' כזה מכריע את האדם לכף זכות אפי' אין בידו עוד זכיות, ובאופן זה יש מקום לשיטת ר' יוחנן שאפי' לא למד אלא חוק א' ניצול מגיהנם, ולעומת זה לפעמים עושה האדם ח"ו עבירה שהוא כנגד כמה זכיות ומכריעו לכף חובה ר"ל, ואז יש מקום לשיטת ר"ל למי שמשייר אפי' חוק א' מלשמרו נדון בגיהנם, ואו"א דברי אלקים חיים וזמנין שייך האי טעמא וכו' ותליא באיכות המעשים ובמשקל קל דיעות, וכמו"כ בפלוגתא דר"י ור"ל בפי' הפסוק ולקחתי אתכם א' מעיר ושנים ממשפחה, דר"ל ס"ל דברים ככתבן ור"י אמר א' מעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה וכו', אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים: שיש מקום לדברי שניהם ותליא באיכות הזכיות של אותו א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה המגינים בזכותם עליהם, ולפי שקול העונות של בני העיר או בני המשפחה, וההכרעה תליא במשקל ק"ל דעות ד', ולפי האמת אין כאן פלוגתא בעצם בין ר"י לר"ל, ותרווייהו מודים שתליא הכרעת פלוגתתם באיכות הזכיות ובמצב הדור ויש מקום כדברי כל או"א.
translation: And from now on, the words of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer are both words of the living God. And according to what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, said (in Tractate Ktubot mentioned above), that sometimes this reason applies and sometimes that reason applies, and it depends on the quality of the mitzvot and the manner of their fulfillment. For sometimes, if a person fulfills one mitzvah with a pure intention and a true desire for the sake of Heaven, such a mitzvah can tip the scales for the person to merit favor, even if they have no other merits. In this way, there is room for the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan, that even if one has only learned one law, they are saved from Gehenna. Conversely, sometimes a person, Heaven forbid, commits a transgression that is against several merits, tipping the scales to the side of liability, Heaven forbid. Then there is room for the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, that one who neglects even one law is judged in Gehenna. And these are both words of the living God, and sometimes this reason applies, etc., and it depends on the quality of the actions and the weight of the opinions. Likewise, in the dispute between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer regarding the interpretation of the verse, "And I took one from a city and two from a family," Rabbi Eliezer holds that the words are as they are written, while Rabbi Yochanan says that one from a city merits for the entire city, etc. These are both words of the living God: there is room for both of their opinions, and it depends on the quality of the merits of that one from the city and the two from the family who protect them with their merits, and according to the weight of the sins of the people of the city or the family. The decision depends on the weight of the four opinions, and in truth, there is no fundamental dispute between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer; both agree that the resolution of their dispute depends on the quality of the merits and the state of the generation, and there is room for the words of each one.
summary: The passage discusses the differing views of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer regarding the nature of divine judgment and the weight of individual merits and sins. It emphasizes that both perspectives are valid, as they depend on the quality of a person's actions and the collective merits of their community or family. The text highlights that a single good deed can tip the scales in favor of an individual, while a single transgression can lead to severe consequences, illustrating the dynamic interplay between righteousness and sin. Ultimately, it asserts that the resolution of their debate is contingent upon the specific circumstances and merits at play, affirming the complexity of divine justice.
