passage_content: ומ"ש ר"י לר"ל לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת הכי, נל"פ עפימ"ד בגמ' (יבמות קכ"א ע"ב) מעשה בבתו של ר' נחוניא חופר שיחין שנפלה לבור הגדול, ובאו והודיעו לרחב"ד, שעה ראשונה אמר להם שלו' וכו' שלישית אמר להם עלתה וכו', אמרו לו נביא אתה, אמר להם לא נביא אנכי ולא בן נביא, אלא דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו, א"ר אבא אעפ"כ מת בנו בצמא וכו', ובשיטה מקובצת (ב"ק דף נ') כתב ע"ז ולרבינו נל"פ אמרתי כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה, דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו, והסכים הקב"ה לדברי שכן דרכו של הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים, וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר' חנינא עכ"ד, וכעי"ז מצינו עוד בגמ' (חגיגה ט"ו ע"ב) אשכחי' רבה בר שילא לאלי' א"ל מאי קא עביד הקב"ה, א"ל קאמר שמעתא מפומייהו דכולהו רבנן ומפומי' דר"מ לא קאמר, א"ל אמאי משום דקא גמר שמעתא מפומי' דאחר, א"ל אמאי ר"מ רמון מצא תוכו אכל קליפתו זרק א"ל השתא קאמר מאיר בני אומר, הרי שהקב"ה מסכים לסברת הצדיקים אף בענין הכרעת זכותים דתליא במשקל קל דיעות.
translation: And what Rabbi Yochanan said to Rabbi Elazar, "It is not pleasing to them that you said this," it seems to me according to the explanation in the Gemara (Yevamot 121b) regarding the incident of the daughter of Rabbi Nechunya the digger of wells who fell into a large pit, and they came and informed Rabbi Chiya bar Abba. In the first hour, he said to them, "She is well," etc. In the third hour, he said to them, "She has risen," etc. They said to him, "You are a prophet." He said to them, "I am neither a prophet nor the son of a prophet, but a matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in it." Rabbi Abba said, "Nevertheless, his son died of thirst," etc. And in the Shita Mekubetzes (Baba Kamma 4b), it is written regarding this, "And according to our Rabbi, it seems to me that I said," meaning I presented this matter before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "A matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in it," and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with the words, for it is the way of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous. And when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chanina had already died. Thus far. And similarly, we find in the Gemara (Chagigah 15b) that Rabbi Bar Shila encountered Eliyahu and asked him, "What is the Holy One, Blessed be He, doing?" He said to him, "He is saying a teaching from the mouths of all the Rabbis, but from the mouth of Rabbi Meir, He did not say." He asked him, "Why? Because he is learning a teaching from the mouth of another?" He asked him, "Why? Rabbi Meir found a pomegranate, he ate its inside and threw away its peel." He said to him, "Now, Rabbi Meir says, 'My sons say,'" hence the Holy One, Blessed be He, agrees with the reasoning of the righteous even regarding the matter of the decision of merits that depends on the light weight of opinions.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that God aligns with the reasoning of the righteous, as illustrated by the story of Rabbi Nachuniah's daughter and the subsequent events surrounding Rabbi Chaninah's son. It emphasizes that even when a righteous person's efforts seem to fail, it is part of a divine plan, reflecting the belief that God supports the perspectives of the tzaddikim (righteous ones). The text also highlights the idea that the outcomes of righteous individuals' actions can be complex and may not always align with human expectations, yet they are ultimately part of a greater divine wisdom.

passage_content: ובזה יובן דברי ר"י לר"ל לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי וכפרש"י ז"ל אין הקב"ה רוצה שתהא דן את ישראל כל כך לכף חובה, דהאמנם שגם דרשת ר"ל בפירוש הפסוק אמיתית, ולפי מצב הדור יש מקום שמצד הדין הי' ראוי לפרש ח"ו כשיטת ר"ל, מ"מ אמירת הצדיק גורם השפעת רחמים וחסדים, ובכוחו להפך ולבטל שליטת הדין, והבוי"ת יסכים לסברת הצדיקים אם יכריעו לכף זכות אף אם אין זכותים בדור כמו שהי' ראוי להיות וז"ש לו ר"י לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת הכי, כי אמירת הצדיק עושה רושם, ולכן לא תאמר כן בפירוש הכתוב כמו שאמרת, כי אין הקב"ה רוצה שתהא דן את ישראל לכף חובה, רק תאמר הפי' להכרעת הזכות שאפי' א' מעיר מזכה כל בני העיר וכדברי ר"י, וכשתאמר כן תשפיע בדבריך רחמים וחסדים וידון הבוי"ת את ישראל לכף זכות, כי הבוי"ת מסכים לסברת הצדיקים.
translation: And with this, the words of Rabbi Yoel to Rabbi Lazer will be understood: It is not pleasing to the Master that you said this to them, as Rashi explains, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not want you to judge Israel so much to the side of guilt. Indeed, although Rabbi Lazer's interpretation of the verse is true, and according to the state of the generation there is a place where, according to strict judgment, it would have been appropriate to interpret it, Heaven forbid, in accordance with Rabbi Lazer's view, nevertheless, the words of the righteous cause the influence of mercy and kindness, and they have the power to reverse and nullify the dominion of judgment. The Blessed One will agree with the reasoning of the righteous if they decide in favor of merit, even if there are no merits in the generation as there ought to be. And this is what Rabbi Yoel said to him: It is not pleasing to the Master that you said this, for the words of the righteous make an impression. Therefore, do not say this in the interpretation of the verse as you said, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not want you to judge Israel to the side of guilt, but rather say the interpretation in favor of merit, that even if one from the city merits, all the inhabitants of the city are meritorious, as Rabbi Yoel said. And when you say this, you will influence in your words mercy and kindness, and the Blessed One will judge Israel to the side of merit, for the Blessed One agrees with the reasoning of the righteous.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of the words of a righteous person (tzaddik) in influencing divine judgment. It emphasizes that God does not desire to judge Israel harshly, and the tzaddik's interpretation can invoke mercy and kindness, even in a generation lacking merit. The text highlights that the tzaddik's perspective can sway divine judgment towards favor, suggesting that even a single individual's merit can uplift an entire community. Ultimately, the tzaddik's declarations carry significant weight in the heavenly court, leading to a more compassionate judgment for the people.

passage_content: ויל"פ עוד במאמר לא ניחא למרייהו וכו', עפימ"ד במד"ר (ר"פ דברים) אלה הדברים זש"ה (משלי כ"ח) מוכיח אדם אחרי חן ימצא וגו', אר"י בן סימון מהו אחרי, אמר הקב"ה כביכול משה הוכיחני אחר ישראל והוכיח לישראל אחרי, לישראל אמר אתם חטאתם חטאה גדולה, להקב"ה אמר למה ד' יחרה אפך בעמך עכ"ד המדרש, הרי שכן דרך הצדיקים להגדיל מדת החטא בתוכחתם לישראל, אבל בינם לבין קונם מלמדים זכות על ישראל וז"ש ר"י לר"ל לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת הכי, שאם תאמר דבריך לישראל לעוררם אל התשובה ולהודיעם שאפשר להיות פי' הפסוק דברים ככתבן, ואולי עי"ז ישימו על לבם להטיב מעשיהם מפחד העונש, אז שפיר עבדת, אבל בינך לבין קונך לא יאות לומר פירוש הזה, רק תכריע כפירוש האחר לכף זכות, וז"ש לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת הכי, שלפני מרייהו לא תימר הכי דלא ניחא לי' להבוי"ת בכך.
translation: And it is further explained in the saying "It is not pleasing to them," etc., according to the Midrash (Parashat Devarim) "These are the words," as it is written (Proverbs 28) "He who rebukes a man will find favor," etc. Rabbi Yochanan ben Simon said, what does "after" mean? The Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, said: Moses rebuked Me after Israel and rebuked Israel after. To Israel, he said: "You have sinned a great sin," and to the Holy One, blessed be He, he said: "Why, O Lord, does Your anger burn against Your people?" Thus is the Midrash. Behold, it is indeed the way of the righteous to magnify the measure of sin in their rebuke to Israel, but between them and their Creator, they teach merit for Israel. And this is what Rabbi Yochanan said to Rabbi Levi: "It is not pleasing to them that you said this," for if you say your words to Israel to awaken them to repentance and to inform them that it is possible to interpret the verse literally, and perhaps through this they will take to heart to improve their deeds out of fear of punishment, then you have done well. But between you and your Creator, it is not appropriate to say this interpretation; rather, you should lean towards the other interpretation for merit. And this is what is meant by "It is not pleasing to them that you said this," that before them, you should not say this, for it is not pleasing to them to be treated this way.
summary: The passage discusses the role of a righteous person (tzaddik) in addressing the sins of Israel, emphasizing that while they may highlight the severity of sin in their admonitions to the people, they simultaneously advocate for Israel before God. It illustrates the concept that a tzaddik's approach to rebuke is to elevate the merits of the people in their private discourse with God, contrasting this with the public call for repentance. The text underscores the importance of balancing truth and compassion, suggesting that the tzaddik must navigate between honest criticism and a protective stance for the community's spiritual welfare.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לפרש דברי רבא (בגמ' דסנהדרין שם) דבברייתא דר' סימאי אמרו מקיש יציאתן ממצרים לביאתן לארץ, מה ביאתן לארץ שנים מס' רבוא, אף יציאתן ממצרים שנים מס' רבוא, וע"ז אמר רבא וכן לימות המשיח שנא' וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מארץ מצרים, פרש"י וכן לימות המשיח שלא ישארו מכל ס' רבוא אלא ב', וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מארץ מצרים פרש"י עניים ושפלים יהיו כימי עלותה מארץ מצרים, ולכאורה אמאי לא אמרו בגמ' על דברי רבא לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת הכי, וכמ"ש ר' יוחנן על דרשת ר"ל, מכ"ש דהול"ל כן על דברי רבא שהוא ממעט המנין ח"ו יותר שלא ישארו ח"ו אלא ב' מששים רבוא, אמנם כבר פירשנו לעיל (בדרוש הקדום) דרבא מיקל יותר אף מדברי ר' יוחנן, וס"ל דיספיק הגנת ב' צדיקים לס' רבוא, ולמד כן ממשה"כ וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מארץ מצרים, הקיש הכתוב ימות המשיח לדור המדבר ולדור יוצאי מצרים, ומבואר בדברי האריז"ל דאותן שמתו במצרים לא ידחו עולמית, ועתידין לחזור בגלגול בדרא בתראה, וחלק גדול מהם יתוקנו במשך הדורות ויזכו לימות המשיח נמצא שע"י השנים מס' רבוא שיצאו יתוקנו כולם, שיתגלגלו בבניהם ויתבררו, וכמו"כ דור המדבר כולם יזכו לימות המשיח כמפורש במד"ר פ' ואתחנן (פ' ב' סי' ט') שלכך נקבר משרע"ה במדבר כדי שיבואו עמו כל דור המדבר עיי"ש, ואפשר שאותן השנים יהושע וכלב שנכנסו מיד לארץ הם סייעו בזכותם ופעולתם שכל דור המדבר יזכו לביאת הארץ בגאולה העתידה, כי ידוע שביאה הראשונה הי' הכנה לביאה הנצחי בגאולה העתידה, גם משה ואהרן שנקברו במדבר עמהם יבואו בגאולה העתידה ויביאו עמהם כל דור המדבר, הרי הגנת שנים מועלת לס' רבוא וכן ליוצאי מצרים, וע"ז אמר רבא וכן לימות המשיח, מדהקיש הכתוב ימות המשיח לדור המדבר ויוצאי מצרים, בעכ"ח שאף אז יגינו זכות השנים על כל ס' רבוא וכולם יזכו לימות המשיח דאין היקש למחצה דהרי אף דור המדבר ויוצאי מצרים יזכו לימות המשיח.
translation: And now we will explain the words of Rava (in the Gemara of Sanhedrin there) that in the Baraita of Rabbi Simai they said that the exodus from Egypt is compared to the entry into the Land, just as their entry into the Land was two hundred and ten years, so too their exodus from Egypt was two hundred and ten years. And regarding this, Rava said, "And so it is for the days of the Messiah," as it is written, "And it will answer there as in the days of your youth and as in the day of your ascent from the land of Egypt." Rashi explains that "and so it is for the days of the Messiah" means that there will not remain from the six hundred thousand except for two, and "And it will answer there as in the days of your youth and as in the day of your ascent from the land of Egypt" Rashi explains that the poor and lowly will be as in the day of your ascent from the land of Egypt. And at first glance, why did they not say in the Gemara regarding the words of Rava that it is not pleasing to them that you said this, and as Rabbi Yochanan said about the interpretation of Rabbi Levi, how much more so should it have been said regarding the words of Rava, who minimizes the count, Heaven forbid, that there will remain, Heaven forbid, only two out of sixty myriads. However, we have already explained above (in the ancient discourse) that Rava is more lenient even than the words of Rabbi Yochanan, and he holds that the merit of two righteous ones suffices for sixty myriads, and he learned this from the verse "And it will answer there as in the days of your youth and as in the day of your ascent from the land of Egypt." The verse compares the days of the Messiah to the generation of the wilderness and the generation that went out of Egypt. It is explained in the words of the Arizal that those who died in Egypt will not be pushed away forever, and they are destined to return in reincarnation in the last generation, and a large part of them will be rectified over the generations and will merit the days of the Messiah. Thus, through the two hundred and ten years that went out, they will all be rectified, as they will reincarnate in their children and will be clarified. Likewise, the entire generation of the wilderness will merit the days of the Messiah, as is explicit in the Midrash, Parashat Va'etchanan (Parashat 2, Section 9), that is why Moshe Rabbeinu was buried in the wilderness, so that all the generation of the wilderness would come with him, as you can see there. And it is possible that those years, Yehoshua and Kalev, who immediately entered the Land, assisted in their merit and action that the entire generation of the wilderness would merit the entry into the Land in the future redemption, for it is known that the first entry was a preparation for the eternal entry in the future redemption. Also, Moshe and Aharon, who were buried in the wilderness, will come with them in the future redemption and will bring with them the entire generation of the wilderness. Thus, the merit of the years is effective for sixty myriads and also for those who went out of Egypt. And regarding this, Rava said, "And so it is for the days of the Messiah," since the verse compares the days of the Messiah to the generation of the wilderness and those who went out of Egypt, it follows that even then the merit of the years will protect all sixty myriads, and they will all merit the days of the Messiah, for there is no comparison to half, for indeed both the generation of the wilderness and those who went out of Egypt will merit the days of the Messiah.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Exodus from Egypt and the future redemption in the Messianic era, emphasizing that just as the original Exodus involved a significant number of Israelites, so too will the future redemption. It highlights the belief that those who died in Egypt will eventually be reincarnated and will participate in the Messianic redemption, alongside the generation that wandered in the desert. The text underscores the idea that the merit of the past generations, particularly the righteous, will protect and ensure the inclusion of all in the future redemption, reflecting a deep theological understanding of continuity and divine mercy across generations.

passage_content: ואפשר שלזה דייק רש"י ז"ל לפרש הכתוב וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וגו', פי' עניים ושפלים יהיו כימי עלותה מארץ מצרים עכ"ל, ואלמלי הפי' בדברי רבא וכן לימות המשיח שלא ישארו ח"ו אלא ב' מס' רבוא. אמאי הוצרך לפרש עניים ושפלים יהיו, וכי יש עניות ושפלות יותר מזה. אלא ודאי ללמדנו בא שאין הפי' בדברי רבא שלא ישארו בחיים אלא ב' מס' רבוא כמו במצרים שמתו כולם בג' ימי אפילה, אלא היקש הכתוב הוא על מצב הדור לימות המשיח, שיהיו ישראל עניים בדעת ושפלים בכח התורה כימי עלותה מארץ מצרים, וישארו רק שנים הראויים בזכותם להגין על כולם, ובזכותם יזכו כל ישראל לימות המשיח, ועד"ז יתפרש הכוונה בדברי רש"י ז"ל שלא ישארו מכל ס' רבוא אלא שנים, ועכ"פ יש ללמוד מזה שלא להתפעל מדעת הרוב אף אם יהי' רק ב' נגד ס' רבוא, שאף במצרים הי' ב' כנגד ס' רבוא שלא היו ראויים לצאת, ואלמלי היו אותן השנים מושפעין ומשתווין לדעת הרוב, לא הי' ח"ו תקומה לשונאיהם של ישראל, ולא היו זוכין ליצ"מ וקבלת התורה והיו משתקעין שם לעולם ח"ו, והשי"ת יעזור לנו להתחזק ולהתגבר נגד זרם העולם ולא נזיז מדרך האמת לעולם.
translation: And it is possible that this is what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, intended when he explained the verse "And she answered there as in the days of her youth," meaning that the poor and lowly will be like the days of their ascent from the land of Egypt. And were it not for the explanation in the words of Rava, and similarly for the days of the Messiah, that there will not remain, Heaven forbid, but two out of six hundred thousand. Why did he need to explain that the poor and lowly will be? Is there any poverty and lowliness greater than this? Rather, it is certainly to teach us that the explanation in the words of Rava is not that there will remain alive but two out of six hundred thousand, as in Egypt where all died in three days of darkness, but the implication of the verse is regarding the state of the generation in the days of the Messiah, that the Jews will be poor in knowledge and lowly in the strength of the Torah like the days of their ascent from the land of Egypt, and only two will remain who are worthy, by their merit, to defend everyone, and by their merit all of Israel will merit the days of the Messiah. And similarly, the intention in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, should be understood that there will remain from the six hundred thousand but two. And in any case, we learn from this not to be swayed by the opinion of the majority, even if there are only two against six hundred thousand, for even in Egypt there were two against six hundred thousand who were not worthy to leave, and were it not for those two being influenced and aligning themselves with the opinion of the majority, there would have been, Heaven forbid, no redemption for the enemies of Israel, and they would not have merited the Exodus from Egypt and the acceptance of the Torah, and they would have been lost there forever, Heaven forbid. And may the Holy One, blessed be He, help us to strengthen and prevail against the current of the world, and may we never stray from the path of truth forever.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a biblical verse by Rashi, emphasizing that in the Messianic era, the Jewish people will be spiritually impoverished and weak in their understanding of Torah, akin to their state during the Exodus from Egypt. It highlights that only a small number, specifically two individuals, will be worthy enough to advocate for the entire nation, leading to their redemption. The text encourages not to be swayed by the majority opinion, as even in Egypt, two righteous individuals stood against a vast population, ultimately ensuring the survival and liberation of the Jewish people. The author calls for strength and perseverance in adhering to the truth amidst worldly pressures.

passage_content: וז"ש המהרש"א ז"ל שאלו השנים שנשארו כלב מיהודה ויהושע מאפרים, הוא רמז על השנים דלעתיד משיח בן דוד מיהודה ומשיח בן יוסף מאפרים עכ"ל, והכוונה לדרכנו כי בזכותם יגינו על כל הס' רבוא, וכל אלו הדבוקים בתוה"ק הרי הם מקושרים ומתאחדים אל הס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שבדור המדבר, והם ודאי יזכו לימות המשיח כמפורש בדרז"ל, וכל אלו הנכללים בשורשם יזכו עמהם, וכבר ביארנו בדברנו לעיל דע"י אותיות התוה"ק כל ישראל מתקשרין ומתאחדין כחדא, וע"כ בדין הוא שהחלק מצטרף עם כולו כי א"א להפרידם, וכמו אותיות התורה שאם חסר ממנו אות א' פסולה, והמגיה בו אות א' כאילו כתבה כולה, וע"כ יועיל הגנת זכות השנים על ס' רבוא, אך צריכים לסייעתא דשמיא שנתחזק נגד התגברות הנורא ונהי' מקושרים בתוה"ק, ובאמת אין אתנו יודע עד מה, באיזה בחי' צ"ל ההתקשרות בתוה"ק, ואם אינו ח"ו בכלל המנותקין מקדושת התוה"ק, דאף המקיים קצת ממצות התורה, הרי יכול להיות מלא עונות ופשעים ר"ל, וכל א' יודע נגעי לבבו, וחיל ורעדה יאחז בהתבונן במאמרי רז"ל הנ"ל, כמה קשה יהי' הבירור לפני ביאת המשיח, ולכל הפירושים איך שנאמר, צריכים עכ"פ לעבור לפני הגאולה צירוף אחר צירוף, מי שיהי' ראוי להצטרף בהגנת א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, דא"א זה כ"א ע"י ההתקשרות בתוה"ק כנ"ל, ואיך אפשר לשכוח אף רגע אחד הבירור הקשה שצריכין לעבור לפני הגאולה שלימה.
translation: And this is what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, said: The two who remained, Caleb from Judah and Joshua from Ephraim, hint at the future times of the Messiah, son of David from Judah, and the Messiah, son of Joseph from Ephraim. The intention is that through them, they will protect all the 600,000, and all those who are attached to the Torah and commandments are connected and united with the 600,000 root souls of Israel from the generation in the desert, and they will certainly merit the days of the Messiah, as is explicitly stated in the teachings of our Sages. All those included in their root will merit with them. And we have already explained in our previous words that through the letters of the Torah, all of Israel are connected and united as one. Therefore, it is just that the part joins with the whole, for it is impossible to separate them, just as the letters of the Torah, for if one letter is missing, it is invalid, and the one who corrects it with one letter is as if he wrote the entire Torah. Thus, the merit of the two will protect the 600,000, but we need divine assistance to strengthen against the terrible onslaught and to be connected to the Torah and commandments. And truly, no one knows to what extent the connection to the Torah and commandments must be, and if one is, God forbid, among those disconnected from the sanctity of the Torah and commandments, for even one who fulfills some of the commandments of the Torah can still be full of sins and transgressions, God forbid. And each one knows the afflictions of his heart, and trembling and fear will seize him when contemplating the words of our Sages mentioned above, how difficult the clarification will be before the coming of the Messiah. And for all the interpretations as stated, it is necessary, at the very least, to pass through before the redemption, one combination after another, for those who will be worthy to join in the protection of one from a city and two from a family, for this is only possible through the connection to the Torah and commandments, as mentioned. And how can one forget even for a moment the difficult clarification that we must go through before the complete redemption?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the figures of Caleb from Judah and Joshua from Ephraim as symbols of the future Messianic era, representing the connection between the two Messianic figures, Mashiach ben David and Mashiach ben Yosef. It emphasizes the importance of unity among the Jewish people through the Torah, suggesting that all souls are interconnected and that the merit of these two figures will protect the collective. The text warns of the challenges and judgments that will precede the coming of the Messiah, highlighting the necessity of a strong connection to the Torah to ensure one's inclusion in the redemption process. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound spiritual implications of maintaining this connection amidst the trials faced before the ultimate redemption.

passage_content: וע"כ ברישא דהאי קרא כתיב שובו בנים שובבים ולקחתי אתכם אחד מעיר וגו' שצריך לעשות הכנה לזה ע"י תשובה ומע"ט כדי שנהיו ראויים להצטרף בהגנת הצדיקים, וימים האלה ימי השובבי"ם מסוגלים לזה כידוע, והנה בקשתנו בתפלה נגילה ונשמחה בישועתך ולכאורה הכי יש הו"א שלא נשמח בישועתו ית' כשנזכה לראותה, אמנם לגודל שפלות מצבינו בעוה"ר שמלאים עונות ופשעים ומלוכלכים בחטאת נעורים ר"ל, והעינים סמויות והלב אטום ואין יודעין ואין מרגישים עד היכן משוקעים, וכשיבוא הישועה בגאולה הנצחית יהי' התגלות האמת, ובאיזה פנים נתראה לקבל ישועתו ית', ע"כ בקשתנו על ישועה כפולה, שנזכה אל הישועה הכללית ולא נדחה חלילה, גם שנזכה להיות נגילה ונשמחה בישועתו, ולא נבוש ולא נכלם ממעשינו, ואנו מקוים ומצפים שנזכה לזה, דהרי עכ"פ נמצאים בתוך הכלל ישראל יחידים שעושים נחת רוח להבוית"ש, והם יגינו בזכותם גם עלינו, ורק השי"ת יודע היכן הם, ובעוה"ר כולנו כצאן תעינו בשפלות וחשכות נורא הזה.
translation: And therefore, at the beginning of this verse it is written, "Return, O wayward children, and I will take you, one from a city," etc. This requires preparation through repentance and good deeds, so that we become worthy to join in the protection of the righteous. And these days, the days of Shovavim, are conducive to this, as is known. And behold, our request in prayer is that we will rejoice and be glad in Your salvation. And seemingly, there is a concern that we will not rejoice in His salvation when we merit to see it. However, due to the great lowliness of our state in this world, which is filled with sins and transgressions, and we are soiled with youthful sins, may it be said, and our eyes are blind and our hearts are sealed, and we do not know and do not feel how deep we are sunk. And when the salvation comes in the eternal redemption, there will be a revelation of the truth, and in what manner we will appear to receive His salvation. Therefore, our request is for a double salvation, that we merit the general salvation and not be rejected, heaven forbid, and also that we merit to rejoice and be glad in His salvation, and not be ashamed or embarrassed by our deeds. And we hope and expect to merit this, for there are, at least, individuals within the generality of Israel who bring satisfaction to the Blessed One, and they will protect us in their merit as well. And only the Holy One, blessed be He, knows where they are, and in this world, we are all like lost sheep in this terrible lowliness and darkness.
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity of repentance and good deeds to become worthy of joining the protection of the righteous, particularly during the spiritually significant days of "Shovavim." It reflects on the deep spiritual lowliness and unawareness of the Jewish people, who are burdened by sins and shortcomings. The author expresses a dual request for redemption: to attain both general salvation and the ability to rejoice in God's deliverance without shame for past actions. Ultimately, it highlights the hope that the righteous among the Jewish people will intercede on behalf of all, as they navigate through a time of spiritual darkness.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבארו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל (בדרוש הקדום) אמר פרעה וכי סבורים אתם ליכנס לארץ והלא כולם ימותו במדבר ולא יכנסו לארץ כי אם שנים יהושע וכלב ועליהם אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, ומשה השיבו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ולא על יותר מבן ס', עוד במדרש אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים עתידים אתם אומרים מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו וזה מי ומי ההולכים, עוד במדרש כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות וברבינו בחיי הביא מדרש כי חג ה' לנו זה חג השבועות וצ"ב.
translation: And according to our ways, the words of the aforementioned Midrashim will be clarified (in the ancient discourse). Pharaoh said, "Do you think you will enter the land? Behold, they will all die in the desert and will not enter the land except for two, Joshua and Caleb." And concerning them, Pharaoh said, "Who are the ones going?" Moses replied, "We will go with our young and with our old, for a decree was not made on less than twenty years old nor on more than fifty." Furthermore, in the Midrash, Pharaoh asked, "Who are the ones going?" You are destined to say, "Who will ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who will stand in His holy place?" And this is "Who are the ones going." Additionally, in the Midrash, it states that "The festival of the Lord for us" refers to the festival of Sukkot, and our Rabbi Bachaye brought a Midrash that "The festival of the Lord for us" refers to the festival of Shavuot, and this requires further investigation.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's skepticism about the Israelites' ability to enter the Promised Land, suggesting that only Joshua and Caleb would survive the wilderness. It highlights the idea that the divine decree does not apply to those under twenty or over sixty, emphasizing God's mercy and the potential for redemption. Additionally, it connects the concept of pilgrimage to the festivals, specifically Sukkot and Shavuot, reflecting on the spiritual journey and the significance of approaching holiness.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי המדרש (ילקוט תהלים רמז תרס"ד) מזמור לדוד ד' מי יגור באהליך, כתיב (ישעי' ל"א) נאם ד' אשר אור לו בציון ותנור לו בירושלים אמר דוד אם אור לו בציון ותנור לו בירושלים, ד' מי יגור באהליך, כתיב (זכרי' ב') ואני אהי' לה נאם ד' חומת אש סביב ולכבוד אהי' בתוכה אמר דוד אם חומת אש מבחוץ וכבוד מבפנים מי יכול לשרות בתוכה, דבר אחר מי ידור באהליך אין כתיב כאן אלא מי יגור, מאן יכיל לאיתותבא גבך ומאן יכיל למהוי תותבך וכו' משל לעירוני שנכנס למדינה וראה אותן מוכרין מיני כתיתין (פי' מיני מאכל תענוג) אמר מי יוכל לשבוע מאלו, אמרו לו חביריו מי שיש לו מעות, כך אמר דוד לפני הקב"ה ד' יגור באהליך, א"ל הקב"ה מי שיש לו מצות פרישות הולך תמים ופועל צדק עכ"ד המדרש. והמאמר הזה מבהיל ונורא מאוד, כי מבואר להדיא שא"א לדור בארץ ישראל אפי' דרך גרות כי אם מי שיש בו מדות הללו הולך תמים ופועל צדק וגו' וחומת אש בחוץ וכבוד השכינה בפנים לשמור על קדושתה.
translation: And we will precede the words of the Midrash (Yalkut Tehillim Remez 674) Psalm of David: "Hashem, who may dwell in Your tent?" It is written (Isaiah 31:4) "Thus says Hashem, as a lion roars, and a young lion over his prey, so will Hashem of Hosts come down to fight upon Mount Zion and upon its hill." David said, if there is light for Him in Zion and a furnace for Him in Jerusalem, "Hashem, who may dwell in Your tent?" It is written (Zechariah 2:5) "And I will be to her, says Hashem, a wall of fire all around, and for glory I will be in her midst." David said, if there is a wall of fire on the outside and glory on the inside, who can dwell within it? Another explanation: "Who may dwell in Your tent?" It does not say here "who will dwell," but rather "who may dwell." Who can bear Your greatness, and who can endure Your presence? It is like a city dweller who enters a state and sees them selling various delicacies (meaning types of delightful food) and says, "Who can be satisfied with these?" His friends said to him, "Whoever has money." Thus, David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Hashem, who may dwell in Your tent?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Whoever has the mitzvot of separation, walks uprightly, and practices righteousness." Thus concludes the Midrash. And this teaching is very frightening and awesome, for it is clearly stated that it is impossible to dwell in the Land of Israel, even as a convert, except for one who possesses these qualities: walking uprightly and practicing righteousness, etc., with a wall of fire on the outside and the glory of the Shechinah on the inside to guard its sanctity.
summary: The passage discusses the qualifications for dwelling in the presence of God, as articulated by King David. It emphasizes that only those who possess virtues such as integrity, righteousness, and adherence to commandments can truly reside in the sacred space of God's presence, symbolized by a protective wall of fire and divine glory. The text underscores the seriousness of these requirements, suggesting that merely being in the land of Israel is insufficient without the proper moral and spiritual attributes. Ultimately, it highlights the profound connection between ethical conduct and the sanctity of divine habitation.

passage_content: עוד יש מדרש כעי"ז (שוח"ט סי' כ"ה) מי ועלה בהר ד', א"ל הקב"ה אין אתה יודע, נקי כפים ובר לבב מי שיש בו ב' מדות הללו, מיד שמח ואמר יש בי עכ"ד המדרש, האמנם אין זה מדרך החסידים להיות בטוחים בנפשם שכבר הגיעו לשלימות המדות, ולבם נשבר בקרבם על שלא יצאו עדיין ידי חובתם לפי ערך השגתם, אמנם דוהמע"ה הובטח מהקב"ה על המלוכה לו ולזרעו כמ"ש (ש"ב ז') מי אנכי ד' אלקים ומי ביתי כי הביאתני עד הלום וגו' ותדבר גם אל בית עבדך למרחוק, פרש"י להמליך גם את בני אחרי, וכתיב לא בחרתי בעיר ואבחר בדוד, הרי שכסא דוד מקושר עם ירושלים, ולעתיד תחזור אליו המלוכה בבנין ירושלים, כמ"ש וכסא דוד לתוכה תכין בא"י בונה ירושלים, דצ"ל מעין החתימה סמוך לחתימה, וע"כ כששמע מהקב"ה שא"א שיעלה בהר ד' כ"א מי שיש בו ב' מדות הללו, מיד שמח ואמר יש בי, כי הבטחתו ית' לא ישוב ריקם, וכיון שהי' מובטח על זרעו עד סוף כל הדורות שישבו על כסא המלוכה בירושלים, ה"ז ג"כ הבטחה שימצא בזרעו תמיד מי שיש בו מדות הללו ולזה שמח. ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים עתידים אתם לומר מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו, ושאלה גדולה שאל שהרי צריך למדות הללו הולך תמים ופועל צדק נקי כפים ובר לבב וזולת זה א"א לגור בא"י ובירושלים, וכמ"ש דוד אם חומת אש מבחוץ וכו' מי יכול לשרות בתוכה, ומי יהי' ראוי לזה שיעלה בהר ד', ובא בטענה כפולה, הראשונה מכח ידיעת האצטגנינות שכולם ימותו במדבר ולא יכנסו כי אם שנים יהושע וכלב כדברי המדרש שבבעה"ט, וע"ז השיבו משרע"ה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך כי לא נגזרה גזירה על פחות מבן כ' ועל יותר מבן ס', בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך שאף אותם שימותו במדבר יתבררו ויתוקנו בהמשך הדורות ויתקיים אף בהם ההליכה ע"י שיתגלגלו עוה"פ בבניהם שיכנסו לעתיד בביאה הנצחי (עיין באריכות בדברנו לעיל), אמנם שאל עוד קושיא גדולה מהראשונה, כי עתידים אתם לומר מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו, ואף לעתיד מי יהי' ראוי לזה, כי לא ישארו רק ב' מס' רבוא ומפני מה אתם רוצים לצאת.
translation:
There is another Midrash similar to this (Shuchan Aruch, Siman 25): "Who may ascend the mountain of the Lord?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "You do not know; clean hands and a pure heart are required of one who possesses these two qualities." Immediately he rejoiced and said, "I have them." However, is it not the way of the pious to be secure in their souls that they have already attained the perfection of these qualities, while their hearts are broken within them for not having yet fulfilled their obligations according to their understanding? Nevertheless, David, peace be upon him, was assured by the Holy One, Blessed be He, regarding the kingship for him and his descendants, as it is written (II Samuel 7): "Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house that You have brought me this far?" And it also speaks to the house of Your servant from afar. Rashi explains that it refers to the kingship also for his sons after him, and it is written, "I did not choose the city, but I chose David." Thus, the throne of David is connected with Jerusalem, and in the future, the kingship will return to it with the rebuilding of Jerusalem, as it is written, "And prepare the throne of David therein in the land of Israel, building Jerusalem." This must be a kind of signature close to the signature. Therefore, when he heard from the Holy One, Blessed be He, that no one may ascend the mountain of the Lord except one who possesses these two qualities, he immediately rejoiced and said, "I have them," for His promise will not return empty. And since he was assured regarding his descendants until the end of all generations that they would sit on the throne of kingship in Jerusalem, this is also a promise that there will always be someone among his descendants who possesses these qualities, and for this, he rejoiced. 

In this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are clarified. Pharaoh said, "Who are the ones going? You will say, 'Who may ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who may stand in His holy place?'" And he asked a great question, for these qualities are necessary: "He who walks uprightly and works righteousness, who has clean hands and a pure heart." Without these, one cannot dwell in the land of Israel and in Jerusalem, as David said, "If a wall of fire is outside, who can dwell within it?" And who will be worthy to ascend the mountain of the Lord? He came with a double claim: the first, based on the knowledge of astrology that they would all die in the desert and only two would enter, Joshua and Caleb, according to the words of the Midrash in BaMidbar Rabbah. To this, Moshe Rabbeinu replied, "With our young and with our old we will go, for a decree was not made on those under twenty or over sixty. With our sons and with our daughters we will go," for even those who will die in the desert will be refined and corrected in the generations to come, and it will be fulfilled even for them the journey through their descendants who will enter in the future into the eternal coming (see in detail in our earlier discussion). However, he asked another great question beyond the first, for you will say, "Who may ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who may stand in His holy place?" And even in the future, who will be worthy of this, for only two will remain from the multitude, and why do you want to go out?
summary: The passage discusses the essential qualities required to ascend to God's mountain, emphasizing the importance of being "clean of hands and pure of heart." It highlights the assurance given to King David regarding his lineage and the eternal connection of his throne to Jerusalem, suggesting that there will always be individuals among his descendants who embody these virtues. The text also addresses the challenge posed by Pharaoh regarding who is worthy to enter the holy place, affirming that even those who may perish in the desert will ultimately be rectified through their descendants, ensuring a continuous path to spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ומשרע"ה השיבו בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, בגלגולי הדורות העתידים עד עת קץ, כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, ויתבאר עפימ"ד בגמ' (ע"ז דף ב' ע"א) לע"ל מביא הקב"ה ס"ת בחיקו, ואומר למי שעסק בה יבא ויטול שכרו מיד מתקבצין ובאין עובדי כוכבים בערבוביא שנא' כל הגוים נקבצו יחדיו וכו' ולבסוף יאמר להם הקב"ה שוטים שבעולם מי שטרח בערב שבת יאכל בשבת, מי שלא טרח בע"ש מהיכן יאכל בשבת, אלא אעפ"כ מצו' קלה יש לי וסוכה שמה לכו ועשו אותה וכו', וכאו"א מבעט בסוכתו ויוצא וכו', מיד הקב"ה יושב ומשחק עליהם שנא' (תהלים ב') יושב בשמים ישחק, א"ר יצחק אין שחוק לפני הקב"ה אלא אותו היום בלבד עכ"ד הגמ', ובספה"ק בנ"י (מאמר צלא דמהימנותא אות ח') כתב ע"ד הגמ' הנ"ל וז"ל הנלע"ד מהיכן שמעו רז"ל שהמבחן והנסיון לעתיד, מה בין ישראל לעכו"ם יהי' במצות סוכה, הגם שכל דרשותיהם היו מקובלות אצלם בתושבע"פ כל אחד כפי מה שקיבלה נשמתו בעמדה בסיני, עכ"ז כל דבר בתורה שבע"פ מיבע"ל סמיכות בתורה שבכתב, ונ"ל שהי' להם בקבלה זה ברמיזת המסורה, נמסר ב' פעמים ויד"ע, א' ויודע ד' את אשר לו, ב' וידע בהם את אנשי סוכות, רצ"ל ע"י אנשים המקיימים מצות סוכה ויודע ד' את אשר לו עיי"ש לדרכו.
translation: And Moshe Rabbeinu replied, "We will go with our sons and our daughters," through the cycles of future generations until the end of time, for the festival of the Holy One, blessed be He, is the festival of Sukkot. It will be explained according to the teachings of our sages in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 2a) that in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the Torah in His embrace and say to those who engaged with it, "Come and receive your reward." Immediately, the idol worshippers will gather and come, as it is said, "All the nations gathered together," etc. In the end, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say to them, "Fools of the world, whoever labored before the Sabbath will eat on the Sabbath; whoever did not labor on Friday, from where will he eat on the Sabbath?" Nevertheless, I have a light commandment for you, and it is called a Sukkah; go and make it, etc. And each one will kick at his Sukkah and go out, etc. Immediately, the Holy One, blessed be He, will sit and laugh at them, as it is said (Psalms 2), "He who sits in the heavens laughs." Rabbi Yitzchak said, "There is no laughter before the Holy One, blessed be He, except on that day alone," thus concludes the Gemara. And in the holy book Ben Yisrael (Maamar Tzila D'Meheimnusa, section 8), it is written regarding the aforementioned Gemara, "It seems to me that from where did our sages hear that the test and trial in the future, what will be the difference between Israel and the idol worshippers, will be in the commandment of Sukkah? Although all their interpretations were accepted by them in the Oral Torah, each according to what their soul received at the standing at Sinai, nevertheless, every matter in the Oral Torah must be connected to the Written Torah. And it seems to me that they had this in tradition hinted in the Masorah, which was given twice, and you shall know: once, 'And the Lord knows what is His,' and twice, 'And He will know them, the men of Sukkot,' meaning through the people who fulfill the commandment of Sukkah, and the Lord knows what is His."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Sukkah (the temporary dwelling used during the festival of Sukkot) as a symbol of divine providence and the distinction between Israel and the nations in the future. It highlights that in the Messianic era, God will reward those who engaged in the mitzvah of Sukkah, emphasizing the importance of fulfilling commandments. The text also reflects on the idea that the Torah's oral traditions are rooted in the written Torah, suggesting a deep connection between the two. Ultimately, it conveys that God's recognition of those who observe the mitzvah will be a key aspect of the future judgment.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפ"י דרכו ברמיזת המסורה, בהקדם מ"ש הבנ"י (שם אות ט"ו) בשם הרב החסיד מו"ה יהודא חאביליי ז"ל הביאו החיד"א זלה"ה, מדוע לא צוה השי"ת לעשות זכר למן ובאר כמו שצוה לעשות זכר לענני הכבוד במצות סוכה. להיות ענני הכבוד היו רק ישראל מיוחדים בטובה זו, כי הערב רב פלט אותם הענן, משא"כ מן ובאר גם הע"ר נהנו מהם עכ"ד, הראת לדעת כי שורש מצות סוכה שהוא זכר לענני הכבוד, מורה על הבדלה והפרשה, ויודע ד' את אשר לו ואת הקרוב והקריב אליו להקיפם בענן כבודו ית', והבדיל והרחיק הערב רב עוע"ז, ולכן לעתיד שיהי' רצון הבוי"ת להודיע לבאי העולם את אשר לו, המה בני ישראל אשר יבואו על שכרן ואין לאוה"ע חלק אתם, יעשה הבדלה ובירור זה ע"י מצות סוכה דייקא, כי שורש מצות סוכה הוא הבירור והבדלה בין ישראל לעמים, וז"פ המסורה ויודע ד' את אשר לו, וידע בהם את אנשי סוכות. ע"י אנשים המקיימים מצות סוכה כנ"ל.
translation: And even so, according to his way in hinting at the tradition, in light of what the Ben Ish Chai (there, letter 15) brought in the name of the pious Rabbi Moshe Yehuda Chavilah, may his memory be blessed, which the Chida, may his memory be blessed, brought forth: Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, not command to make a remembrance of the manna and the well, as He commanded to make a remembrance of the Clouds of Glory in the commandment of Sukkah? Because the Clouds of Glory were only for the special Israelites in this goodness, for the mixed multitude was expelled by the cloud, whereas the manna and the well were enjoyed even by the mixed multitude. Thus, you should know that the root of the commandment of Sukkah, which is a remembrance of the Clouds of Glory, indicates separation and distinction, and the Holy One knows what belongs to Him and who is close and brings them close to surround them with His glorious cloud, and He separated and distanced the mixed multitude, may their name be blotted out. Therefore, in the future, when it will be the will of the Creator to make known to the inhabitants of the world what belongs to Him, it will be the children of Israel who will come for their reward, and the nations of the world will have no share with them. This distinction and clarification will be made specifically through the commandment of Sukkah, for the root of the commandment of Sukkah is the clarification and distinction between Israel and the nations, as it is written in the tradition: "And the Lord knows what belongs to Him," and He will know them as the people of Sukkot, through the people who fulfill the commandment of Sukkah as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the mitzvah of Sukkah as a means of distinguishing between the Jewish people and the nations of the world. It highlights that while the Clouds of Glory were exclusive to the Israelites, both the mixed multitude and the Israelites benefited from the manna and the well. The mitzvah of Sukkah serves as a reminder of this separation, emphasizing God's knowledge of His chosen people and their unique relationship with Him. Ultimately, the observance of Sukkah symbolizes the future recognition of the Jewish people's distinct role in the world.

passage_content: והנה פרעה הרשע שאל ע"מ לקנטר מי ומי ההולכים עתידים אתם לומר מי יעלה בהר ד', ומי יהי' ראוי לכנוס בביאה ראשונה גם בביאה דלעתיד, כי לא יהיו אלא שנים, ובאמת יש תשובה ניצחת על שאלתו כי זכות השנים יגינו על ס' רבוא, גם משיח ואלי' יחזרו את כל ישראל למוטב, והבוי"ת יקרבנו אליו ויטהר לבבינו, אמנם לא רצה משרע"ה ליכנס עמו בטענות, כי א"א לברר אליו אמיתת טענותיו והמה צפונים ונעלמים עד עת קץ, ולא נתגלה אף לנביאים הרבה פרטיים בענין גאולה העתידה, והבוי"ת לבדו יודע איך שיהי' הבירור ומי יהי' ראוי, אבל השיבו בדרך כלל ואמר בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, שאף אותם שימותו במדבר יחזרו ויתקנו בגלגוליהם בבנינו וכו' וכולם ילכו ויכנסו לארץ ישראל, ואל תקנטרני לשאול מי יהי' הראוי לזה, כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, וע"י מצות סוכה יתברר מי ומי ההולכים, וישראל ינצחו במבחן ההוא ויצאו כולם זכאין משא"כ האומה"ע, ובזה נדחו כל טענותיו.
translation: And behold, the wicked Pharaoh asked in order to provoke, "Who are those who will ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who will be worthy to enter in the first coming and also in the coming of the future?" For there will only be two. And indeed, there is a decisive answer to his question, for the merit of the two will protect six hundred thousand, and the Messiah and Elijah will return all of Israel to goodness, and the Blessed One will draw us close to Him and purify our hearts. However, Moses did not want to enter into arguments with him, for it is impossible to clarify to him the truth of his claims, as they are hidden and concealed until the end of days, and it has not been revealed even to many specific prophets regarding the future redemption. Only the Blessed One knows how the clarification will be and who will be worthy. But he answered him in general and said, "We will go with our sons and our daughters," for even those who will die in the desert will return and rectify themselves in their reincarnations through our sons, etc., and all will go and enter the Land of Israel. And do not provoke me to ask who will be worthy of this, for the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Sukkot, and through the commandment of the Sukkah it will be clarified who are those who will go, and Israel will succeed in that test and all will emerge deserving, unlike the nations of the world. And with this, all his claims were dismissed.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's challenge regarding who will be worthy to ascend to God and enter the future redemption. It emphasizes that the merit of the generations will protect the multitude, and that through the coming of the Messiah and Elijah, all of Israel will ultimately be redeemed. Moses refrains from engaging in detailed arguments with Pharaoh, as the true criteria for worthiness are hidden until the end of days, but assures that through the observance of the Sukkot festival, the righteous will be revealed. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope and redemption for all of Israel, contrasting their fate with that of the nations.

passage_content: ועד"ז יל"פ המדרש רבינו בחיי כי חג ד' לנו זה חג השבועות, דכל נשמות ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות עמדו במעמד הנבחר, וכל או"א יש לו אחיזה באותיות התוה"ק ועי"ז המה מקושרים ומתאחדים בקדושת הבוית"ש כביכול, דאורייתא וקוב"ה וישראל חד הוא, חוץ ה' מינים שבערב רב והמינים ואפיקורסים שלא עמדו אבותיהם בהר סיני שאין להם התקשרות באותיות התוה"ק ובקדושתו ית', וא"כ גם חג השבועות יהי' בירור שיודיע השי"ת את אשר לו, ושניהם צדקו יחדיו, ועליהם רמז משרע"ה בתשובתו לפרעה.
translation: And similarly, the Midrash of Rabbeinu Bachaye explains that the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Shavuot, for all the souls of Israel, until the end of all generations, stood at the chosen standing, and each father has a connection to the letters of the Torah, and through this they are bound and united in the holiness of the Divine Presence, as it were, for the Torah, the Holy One, Blessed be He, and Israel are one. Except for the five species among the mixed multitude and the heretics and deniers who did not have their ancestors stand at Mount Sinai, for they have no connection to the letters of the Torah and to His holiness. Therefore, the festival of Shavuot will also be a clarification that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will make known what belongs to Him, and both sides were justified together, and this is hinted at by Moshe Rabbeinu in his response to Pharaoh.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel emphasizes that the festival of Shavuot represents the connection of all Jewish souls throughout history to the Torah, as each individual has a unique link to its letters. This connection signifies a unity between the Divine, the Torah, and Israel, highlighting the sanctity of this relationship. In contrast, those who do not share this connection, such as the mixed multitude and heretics who did not stand at Sinai, lack this bond with the holiness of the Torah. Ultimately, Shavuot serves as a time for God to reveal His chosen ones, affirming the duality of truth represented by both Moses and Pharaoh.

passage_content: ונל"פ במאמה"כ למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך ואת אשר התעללתי במצרים פרש"י שחקתי וצ"ב ענין השחוק מהו, ויתבאר עפי"ד הגמ' ע"ז הנ"ל, אין שחוק לפני הקב"ה אלא אותו היום בלבד, והקשו בגמ' והא"ר יהודה א"ר רב רביעיות יושב ומשחק עם לויתן שנא' לויתן זה יצרת לשחק בו, א"ר נחמן בן יצחק עם בריותיו משחק, ועל בריותיו אינו משחק אלא אותו היום בלבד, פרש"י על בריותיו על עבירות שעושין בריותיו אינו משחק אלא אותו היום עכ"ל, ובס' תורת חיים (מס' ע"ז) כתב לפרש ע"ד הגמ' הנ"ל, עם בריותיו משחק, שהוא שמחה לפניו ית' שברא בריות טובות, על בריותיו על עבירות שעושין בריותיו אינו משחק, שהוא ית' מצטער במפלתן של רשעים, כמ"ש חז"ל (מגילה י' ע"ב) מפני מה לא נאמר כי טוב בהודאה זו (ביהושפט שנלחם עם העמונים) לפי שאין הקב"ה שמח במפלתן של רשעים עכ"ד.
translation: And it is explained in the holy writings that you should tell in the ears of your son and your son's son about what I did in Egypt. Rashi explains that I played, and the question arises: what is the matter of play? It will be clarified according to the Gemara in Avodah Zarah mentioned above, that there is no play before the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for that day alone. The Gemara asks, but Rabbi Yehuda said in the name of Rabbi Rav that the Leviathan sits and plays, as it is said, "This Leviathan You created to play with." Rabbi Nachman ben Yitzchak said that He plays with His creations, and regarding His creations, He does not play except for that day alone. Rashi explains that regarding His creations, concerning the sins that His creations commit, He does not play except for that day. Thus far the text. And in the book Torat Chaim (from the tractate Avodah Zarah) it is written to explain according to the aforementioned Gemara, that He plays with His creations, which is joy before Him, Blessed be He, that He created good creations. Regarding His creations, concerning the sins that His creations commit, He does not play, for He, Blessed be He, is pained by the downfall of the wicked, as our Sages said (Megillah 10b) that the reason we do not say "it is good" in this praise (in reference to Jehoshaphat who fought against the Ammonites) is because the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not happy with the downfall of the wicked. Thus far the text.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of divine joy and sorrow, particularly in relation to human actions. It emphasizes that God only experiences joy on the day of redemption, while He does not take pleasure in the downfall of the wicked, reflecting His compassion for all creation. The text highlights that God's joy stems from the existence of righteous beings, contrasting with His sorrow over the sins committed by humanity. This duality illustrates the deep connection between divine emotion and human behavior in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ואפשר להסביר יותר עפי"ד הקדושת לוי זלה"ה בכללות הנסים (הו"ד לעיל) דלכן היתה מכת בכורות ע"י הבוב"ה בעצמו, כי היא היתה העיקר הגורם יציאת מצרים לבנ"י, ומחמת יצ"מ נתגדל שמו הגדול, וכו', והיתה טובה גדולה גם להאומות וכו', שהמצרים נעשים כלים שעל ידם נודע מציאות הבוב"ה ונתקדש ונתגדל שמו הגדול, משא"כ מכות הקודמין הי' ע"י שליח כי הם לא היו גורמים קדושת שמו הגדול כ"כ וכו' עיי"ש שהאריך, ועפי"ז יובן אמרם ז"ל בגמ' דע"ז הנ"ל מיום שחרב ביהמ"ק אין שחוק לפני הקב"ה אלא אותו היום בלבד, דמיום שחרב בית אלקינו ההסתרת פנים גדולה עד מאוד, לכן אין הקב"ה שמח במפלתן של רשעים, כי לא נצמח כבוד שמים מזה, ובנ"א תולים אותו במקרה וטבע, משא"כ בזמן שהביהמ"ק קיים הי' התגלות יותר והכירו בנסי ה' ונוראותיו, ונתקדש ש"ש ע"י הכאת הרשעים נמצא הי' טובה גם להם, ועד"ז לעתיד כשיבחן השי"ת האומה"ע במצות סוכה ולא יעמדו בנסיונם, מיד הקב"ה יושב ומשחק עליהם, כי אז יהי' התגלות כבוד שמים גדול ע"י מפלתן של רשעים, ולז"א אין שחוק לפני הקב"ה אלא אותו היום בלבד.
translation: And it is possible to explain further according to the words of the Kedushas Levi, may his merit protect us, regarding the generality of the miracles (as mentioned above), that therefore the plague of the firstborn was by the Blessed Holy One Himself, for it was the main cause of the Exodus from Egypt for the Children of Israel, and because of the Exodus from Egypt, His great name was magnified, etc., and it was also a great good for the nations, etc., that the Egyptians became vessels through which the existence of the Blessed Holy One was made known and His great name was sanctified and magnified. In contrast, the earlier plagues were through a messenger, for they did not cause the sanctification of His great name to such an extent, etc. As it is written there, he elaborated. And according to this, we can understand the statement of our Sages, of blessed memory, in the Gemara regarding the above-mentioned idol worship, that from the day the Holy Temple was destroyed, there is no laughter before the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for that day alone. For from the day the House of our God was destroyed, the concealment of the face is exceedingly great; therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not happy with the downfall of the wicked, for no honor for Heaven arises from this, and people attribute it to chance and nature. In contrast, at the time when the Holy Temple existed, there was greater revelation, and they recognized the miracles of the Lord and His wonders, and His name was sanctified through the smiting of the wicked, which was also good for them. And similarly, in the future, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, tests the nations of the world with the commandment of Sukkah and they do not stand in their trial, immediately the Holy One, Blessed be He, sits and laughs at them, for then there will be a great revelation of the honor of Heaven through the downfall of the wicked. And that is why it is said that there is no laughter before the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for that day alone.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Plague of the Firstborn as a direct act of God, emphasizing its role in the Exodus and the sanctification of God's name. It contrasts this with earlier plagues, which were carried out through intermediaries and did not achieve the same level of divine glory. The text also reflects on the absence of divine joy since the destruction of the Temple, highlighting that God's presence is less revealed in the world, and thus, He does not take pleasure in the downfall of the wicked. In the future, however, there will be a significant revelation of God's glory through the judgment of the nations, restoring the sanctity of His name.

passage_content: והנה כבר ביארנו לעיל דע"י הכבדת הלב שבמכת ארבה ג"כ נתקדש ש"ש, וראי' לזה מדכתיב כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותתי אלה פרש"י שאשית אני, דע"כ הי' באפשרי שיהי' נעשה ע"י הקב"ה כביכול, יען שנתקדש ש"ש והי' טובה גם להם (עייש"ד באריכות) ובזה יונח מ"ש אשר התעללתי במצרים שחקתי, כיון שיצמח מזה כבוד שמים לדורות, וכמ"ש למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך את אשר התעללתי במצרים, וכשנתגדל כ"ש ע"י מפלתן, הקב"ה משחק ושמח עליהם, וכמו שיהי' לעתיד.
translation: And behold, we have already explained above that through the hardening of the heart in the plague of locusts, the Holy Name was also sanctified, and the proof for this is that it is written, "For I have hardened his heart," etc., "in order to place these signs of Mine," as Rashi explains, "that I may place." Therefore, it was possible for it to be done by the Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, since the Holy Name was sanctified, and it was also good for them (as explained at length). And in this, we can understand what is meant by "I have played with Egypt," since from this will arise the glory of Heaven for generations, as it is said, "In order that you may tell in the ears of your son and your son's son what I have played with Egypt," and when it is magnified, certainly through their downfall, the Holy One, blessed be He, plays and rejoices over them, just as it will be in the future.
summary: The passage discusses how the hardening of Pharaoh's heart during the plague of locusts ultimately sanctified the Sabbath, as indicated by the divine intention behind it. It emphasizes that this hardening was a means for God to demonstrate His power and bring about a greater glory for future generations, as reflected in the command to recount the Exodus to one's children. The text suggests that God's actions, even in their severity, are ultimately aimed at achieving a higher purpose and joy, both for Himself and for the sanctification of His name.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר הכתוב כי אני הכבדתי את לבו למען שתי אותתי אלה וגו', (הדקדוקים כבר נפרטו לעיל) בהקדם מה שפירשתי דברי המדרש ילקוט (פ' במדבר רמז תרפ"ד) בשעה שקבלו ישראל את התורה, נתקנאו אומה"ע בהן מה ראו להתקרב יותר מן האומות, סתם פיהן הקב"ה אמר להן הביאו לי ספר יוחסין שלכם וכו' כשם שבני מביאין שנא' ויתילדו על משפחותם עכ"ד המדרש והקושיא מפורסמת דהרי רצה הקב"ה ליתן להם את התורה אף שאינם מיוחסים אלא שמיאנו לקבלו, וא"כ מה מקום לטענתם מה ראו להתקרב ישראל יותר מהם, ומדוע תלה הקב"ה סיבת מניעתם לטעם חסרון יחוסם וכבר פירשנוהו באופנים שונים, והנ"ל לעניננו עפימ"ש לעיל דס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שעמדו בהר סיני, כל נשמה נאצל מאות א' שבתוה"ק, נמצא יש להם התקשרות ואחיזה בעצם התורה, וע"כ זכו ישראל להשגת פנימיות התורה, משא"כ האומה"ע מעיקרא כשרצה הקב"ה ליתן התורה גם להם, הי' הכוונה רק בלבושים דיני התורה ומשפטי', כי אינם ראויים להיות להם חלק והשגה בעצמית התורה, אבל ישראל התוה"ק הוא חלקם וכחלק ממנה נחשבו, וישראל ואורייתא חד הוא, ועד"ז היתה טענת אומה"ע מה ראו ישראל להתקרב יותר מכל האומות שיש להם חלק עצמי בתוה"ק, ולא עשה כן לכל גוי, א"ל הקב"ה הביאו ספר יוחסין שלכם כשם שבני מביאין וכו', שישראל מקור מחצבתם קדוש מזרע אבוה"ק, ושורש נשמותיהם נאצל ממקום גבוה עליון, ע"כ זכו להיות להם אחיזה והתקשרות באותיות התוה"ק משא"כ אומה"ע שהם זרע פסול.
translation: And according to our path, the verse will be clarified: "For I have hardened his heart in order to show these signs of Mine," (the grammatical details have already been elaborated above). In advance of what I explained regarding the words of the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Bamidbar, Remez 784), at the time when Israel received the Torah, the nations of the world became envious of them. What did they see that they should draw closer than the other nations? The Holy One, blessed be He, silenced them and said, "Bring Me your genealogical records," etc. Just as My children bring, as it is stated, "And they were registered by their families." Thus concludes the Midrash. The question is well-known: The Holy One, blessed be He, desired to give them the Torah even though they are not of noble lineage, yet they refused to accept it. Therefore, what basis do they have for their claim of why Israel drew closer than them? And why did the Holy One, blessed be He, attribute their prevention to the lack of their lineage? We have already explained this in various ways. The above is relevant to our discussion, as I mentioned earlier, that six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel stood at Mount Sinai. Each soul is derived from one of the letters of the Holy Torah. Thus, they have a connection and attachment to the essence of the Torah. Therefore, Israel merited the attainment of the inner aspects of the Torah, whereas the nations of the world, initially, when the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to give the Torah to them as well, the intention was only for the garments of the laws and judgments of the Torah, for they are not worthy of having a share and understanding in the essence of the Torah. But for Israel, the Holy Torah is their portion, and as a part of it, they are considered. And Israel and the Torah are one. Similarly, the claim of the nations of the world was: What did Israel see to draw closer more than all the nations, who have a personal share in the Holy Torah? And He did not do so for any other nation. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "Bring Me your genealogical records, just as My children bring," etc., for Israel's source is holy, from the seed of our holy forefathers, and the root of their souls is derived from a high and exalted place. Therefore, they merited to have a connection and attachment to the letters of the Holy Torah, whereas the nations of the world are of a disqualified lineage.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual status of the Jewish people in relation to the Torah, emphasizing that their souls are rooted in a higher spiritual source, which grants them a direct connection to the essence of the Torah. It contrasts this with the nations of the world, who, despite God's initial intention to offer them the Torah, were deemed unworthy of its deeper spiritual insights and were only to receive its external laws. The text highlights that the Jewish people's lineage and spiritual heritage enable them to grasp the inner dimensions of the Torah, affirming their distinct role in the divine plan. Ultimately, it underscores the unity of Israel and the Torah, portraying them as inseparable.

passage_content: והנה איתא בזוה"ק (פ' שמות) שהעבודה והעינוי הי' טובה גדולה לישראל, דהמצריים חשיבו להון עבדין ומבזין להון לאתחתנא בהו ולאתערבא בהדייהו, גוברין געלן בהון נוקבתא געלן בהון, עד דאשתכלל כלא בזרעא קדישא, ועי"כ יצאו כולם זרע קדוש ולא נטמעו בהם עכת"ד, ובזה יתבאר מאמה"כ כי אני הכבדתי את לבו ואת לב עבדיו, כדי שיבדלו ישראל מהתחברותם כל עוד שמוכרחים להיות בארצם ולא הגיע עדיין עת יציאתם, למען שתי אותתי אלה בקרבם, שעי"ז זכו ישראל להיות להם אחיזה בס' רבוא אותיות התוה"ק, ומלת בקרבם קאי על ישראל ע"ד שפי' ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה, והביא ראי' מוכרחת ע"ז (הו"ד לעיל), ולז"א אותותי "אלה" ועפימ"ש האוהחה"ק (ר"פ דברים) אלה הדברים, אלה פסל כל הדברים חוץ מאלה, שאין דבר בעולם במדריגה שוה להם עיי"ש, וכמו"כ לענינינו אומרו אותותי אלה ירמוז על אותיות התוה"ק, לז"א אלה פוסל כל הדברים זולתו, כי אין בעולם דבר שישתוו' בערכם.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot) that the labor and suffering were a great good for Israel, for the Egyptians considered them as mere slaves and degraded them, causing them to be mixed among them, and they were able to redeem them through the daughters, until all were included in the holy seed. And thus, they all emerged as holy offspring and were not assimilated among them, as stated. And this will clarify the verse, "For I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants," so that Israel would be separated from their association as long as they were compelled to be in their land and the time of their departure had not yet arrived, in order to show these signs among them. Through this, Israel merited to have a connection with the 600,000 letters of the Torah, and the phrase "among them" refers to Israel, as explained by the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, who brought a compelling proof for this (as mentioned above). And thus, it is said "these signs," and according to the words of the holy Torah (Parashat Devarim), "These are the words," these exclude all other words, for there is nothing in the world that is on the same level as them, as stated there. Similarly, in our context, the phrase "these signs" alludes to the letters of the Torah, indicating that "these" exclude all other things, for there is nothing in the world that can be compared to their value.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the significance of the suffering endured by the Israelites in Egypt, which ultimately served to elevate their spiritual status and prevent their assimilation into Egyptian culture. It emphasizes that God hardened Pharaoh's heart to ensure the Israelites remained distinct until the appointed time for their redemption, allowing them to connect deeply with the Torah's letters. The text highlights that the unique status of the Israelites and their relationship with the Torah is unparalleled, as nothing else in the world can compare to their spiritual value.

passage_content: ונקדים לבאר במאמה"כ להלן ליל שמרים הוא לד' להוציאם מארץ מצרים הוא הלילה הזה לד' שמרים לכל בני ישראל לדורותם, פירש רש"י ז"ל ליל שמרים לה', שהיה הקדוש ברוך הוא שומר ומצפה לו, לקיים הבטחתו להוציאם מארץ מצרים, שמרים לכל בני ישראל לדורותם פרש"י משומר ובא מן המזיקין כענין שנאמר ולא יתן המשחית לבא אל בתיכם לנגוף עכ"ל, וראוי להבין מדוע לא פי' רש"י גם סיפא דקרא שמורים לכל בנ"י לדורותם כמו הרישא, שישראל שומרין ומצפין על קיום הבטחתו ית' שיגאלנו בלילה הזה, וע"ד אמרז"ל (ר"ה דף י"א ע"א) בניסן נגאלו ובניסן עתידין להיגאל.
translation: And we will begin to explain in the verse mentioned below that the night of watching is for the Lord to take them out of the land of Egypt; it is this night for the Lord, a night of watching for all the children of Israel throughout their generations. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that the night of watching is for the Lord, as the Holy One, blessed be He, was watching and waiting for it, to fulfill His promise to take them out of the land of Egypt. A night of watching for all the children of Israel throughout their generations, Rashi explained, is watched and comes from harm, as it is stated, "And the destroyer shall not come into your houses to smite you." It is fitting to understand why Rashi did not also explain the latter part of the verse, "watched for all the children of Israel throughout their generations," like the former part, that Israel watches and waits for the fulfillment of His promise, blessed be He, that He will redeem us on this night, in accordance with what our sages of blessed memory said (Rosh Hashanah 11a) that in Nissan they were redeemed, and in Nissan they will be redeemed in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the night of Passover, referred to as "Lail Shmurot," emphasizing that God watches over and anticipates the redemption of the Israelites from Egypt. Rashi explains that this night is safeguarded for the Jewish people throughout generations, highlighting God's promise of deliverance. The text raises a question about why Rashi does not elaborate on the latter part of the verse, suggesting that the Jewish people also have a role in safeguarding the promise of redemption, as indicated by the Talmudic teaching that they were redeemed in Nissan and will be redeemed again in the future.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר מאמה"כ (תהלים ק"ל) נפשי לד' משומרים לבקר שומרים לבוקר, פרש"י נפשי לד' משומרים לבוקר הריני מן המצפים לגאולה, שומרים לבוקר מצפין וחוזרין ומצפין עד עת קץ עכ"ל, ולפירושו עדיין צ"ב כפל הלשון, כי לשון ההוה מורה על התמידית, וכיון שאמר שומרים לבקר הריני מן המצפים לגאולה, מה צורך לכפול עוד, ויתבאר עפימ"ש האלשיך הק' (הו"ד בערבי נחל פ' נצבים) לפרש הפסוק (ישעי' ס"ב) על חומתיך ירושלים הפקדתי שומרים כל היום וכל הלילה תמיד לא יחשו המזכירים את ד' אל דמי לכם ואל תתנו דמי לו עד יכונן ועד ישים את ירושלים תהלה בארץ, וביאר הוא ז"ל כי בנין בית העתיד ב"ב יבוא מהשמים בנין של אש, וזה נעשה מרוחניות התורה ומע"ט שעושים ישראל מעת שנחרב ביהמ"ק, וכמו בנין גשמי שנעשה מאסיפת אבנים. שמשימין אבן על אבן עד שנגמר וכו', כך הוא בנין הרוחני חומת אש, כי המצות מאנשים פחותי הערך אשר אינם כ"כ חשובים, הם כענין אבנים הקטנים, והמצות מאנשים צדיקים הרמים הם כענין אבנים גדולות ומכולם נגמר הבנין, וכל ישראל יש להם חלק בו, ומי שאין לו חלק בו לא יראנו.
translation: And we will explain in advance the verse from Tehillim (120) "My soul waits for the Lord more than the watchmen for the morning, the watchmen for the morning." Rashi explains, "My soul waits for the Lord more than the watchmen for the morning, I am among those who await redemption; the watchmen for the morning are those who wait and return and wait again until the time of the end." However, according to his explanation, there is still a question regarding the repetition of the phrase, for the present tense indicates the continuous. Since he said "the watchmen for the morning," I am among those who await redemption, what is the need to repeat it? This will be clarified according to what the holy Alshich explains (quoted in Arvei Nachal, Parshat Nitzavim) in interpreting the verse (Isaiah 62) "Upon your walls, O Jerusalem, I have appointed watchmen all day and all night; they will never be silent, you who remind the Lord, do not be silent for yourselves and do not give Him rest until He establishes and makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth." He explained that the building of the future Holy Temple will come from the heavens, a structure of fire, and this is made from the spirituality of the Torah and the good deeds that the Jewish people perform since the destruction of the Holy Temple. Just as a physical building is made from the gathering of stones, placing one stone upon another until it is completed, so too is the spiritual building, a wall of fire, for the commandments from people of lesser value who are not so important are like small stones, and the commandments from righteous and elevated individuals are like large stones, and from all of them the building is completed. All of Israel has a share in it, and whoever does not have a share in it will not see it.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual vigilance and anticipation for redemption, as expressed in the verse from Psalms. It highlights the duality of waiting for the morning, symbolizing hope for the coming of the Messiah, and emphasizes the continuous effort of the Jewish people in building a spiritual edifice through their good deeds. The text compares this spiritual construction to the physical building of the Temple, where every mitzvah, regardless of the individual's status, contributes to the collective spiritual structure. Ultimately, it asserts that all of Israel has a share in this divine construction, and those who do not partake will not witness its fulfillment.

passage_content: ואמנם יקשה שבכל דור יש צדיקים הרבה אשר ממעשיהם הטובים כבר נגמר הבית ביתר שאת ויתר עז, ומה זה ככה עיכובא שעדיין לא נבנה ביהמ"ק, והתירוץ לזה כי אחד בונה ומאה סותרים, כי כל איש העושה עבירה מפיל קצת מחומת ביהמ"ק, ואם עושה ח"ו עבירה גדולה יצוייר שמפיל ח"ו כותל שלם אשר עמלו בוניו בו, ולזה צוה ד' הוכח תוכיח עד הכאה וקללה ולהתקוטט בחוטאים וכו', לזה מינה ד' שומרי החומות בלי יניחו לסותרה, והם המוכיחים את עם ד' וכו' המונעים את עוברי עבירה בל יפילו חומת ביהמ"ק, ולז"א על חומותיך ירושלים הפקדתי שומרים וגו', ומיסב הדיבור אל המוכיחים ואומר להם, אתם המזכירים את ד' אל דמי לכם וגו', לא ישיג אתכם עייפות למחות בעוברי עבירה ולהתקוטט עמהם עכ"ל הועתק בס' ערבי נחל בשמו.
translation: Indeed, it is difficult to understand that in every generation there are many righteous individuals whose good deeds have already strengthened the Temple even more, and yet there is still a delay in the rebuilding of the Holy Temple. The answer to this is that one builds while a hundred destroy, for every person who commits a transgression weakens a bit of the wall of the Holy Temple, and if one, Heaven forbid, commits a great sin, it can be imagined that they might, Heaven forbid, bring down an entire wall that its builders labored upon. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded to reprove, reprove until the blow and curse, and to contend with the sinners, etc. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, appointed guardians of the walls who will not allow them to be destroyed, and they are the reprovers of the people of the Holy One, blessed be He, etc., who prevent the transgressors from causing the wall of the Holy Temple to fall. And thus it is said, "Upon your walls, O Jerusalem, I have appointed watchmen," etc. And He turns the speech to the reprovers and says to them, "You who remind the Holy One, blessed be He, do not be silent for yourselves," etc. You shall not be weary in protesting against the transgressors and contending with them.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the presence of many righteous individuals in each generation alongside the continued destruction of the Holy Temple. It emphasizes that while some build through good deeds, others undermine this effort through their transgressions, likening sin to the tearing down of the Temple's walls. God appoints guardians to prevent the spiritual erosion caused by sinners, urging the righteous to persist in their efforts to rebuke wrongdoing and maintain the sanctity of the community. The text highlights the importance of vigilance and accountability in preserving spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ובזה פירשתי (בהקדמת ספרי ויואל משה) מאמרז"ל (ר"ה י"ז ע"א) המינין והאפיקורסין שכפרו בתורה ובתחה"מ וכו' יורדין לגיהנם ונידונין בה לדורי דורות וכו', וכל כך למה מפני שפשטו ידיהם בזבול, פרש"י שהחריבו ביהמ"ק בעוונם, והובא מאמר הזה ברמב"ם פ"ג מה' תשובה עיי"ש, ולכאורה ראוי להבין כי הטעם זה מפני שפשטו ידיהם בזבול יצדק לפי הפשטות על המינים ואפיקורסים שהיו קודם החורבן, אמנם מימרא זו נשנית בימי חכמי הש"ס אחר החורבן גם הביאו הרמב"ם ז"ל, א"כ בודאי שנאמרה על המינים ואפיקורסים שבכל הדורות, ואיך אפשר לומר שפשטו ידיהם בזבול שכבר נחרבה בעוונותינו, הרבים, ויתבאר על פי דברי קודש האלשיך הקדוש הנ"ל, כי הרשעים בעוונותם מהרסים ומחריבים הבנין של מעלה שנבנה ע"י מעשה הצדיקים, ושמעתי כי פ"א אמר מרן הקדוש בעל דברי חיים זלה"ה בשלחנו הטהור. שהביהמ"ק של מעלה נגמר אלא שחסר עדיין הפרוכת, ענה הרה"ק ר"י מטאמאשוב זלה"ה אנחנו מאמינים באמונה שלימה שרבינו הק' יוכל לעשות הפרוכת ולא השיב אז הד"ח זלה"ה דבר, אלא פ"א כשישב אל השולחן אמר מהיכן אתם יודעים שלא עשיתי את הפרוכת, אלא שרשע גדול במעשיו קרע אותו עכדה"ק, ובזה יובן אמרם ז"ל שהפליגו בעונש המינים והאפיקורסים על שפשטו ידיהם בזבול, כי הם הם המהרסים והמחריבים בנין ביהמ"ק וירושלים של מעלה, ובעוה"ר לבלבול המוחות וטשטוש הדעת שבזמנינו מכנין לאלו בוני ארץ וירושלים, ואינם אלא מחריבים ומהרסים, והם היו בעכרינו ולולי כן כבר היינו נגאלים, וכמ"ש בילקוט (פ' זו) שבזכות נטרונא יזכו ישראל להיגאל, והכתוב צווח ככרוכיא המזכירים את ד' אל דמי לכם, ובעוה"ר איך נמצא מרגוע לנפשנו שנמצאים גם שומרי תומ"צ המתחברים עם המהרסים ומחזיקים במעשיהם ונוטלים חלק עמהם, ד' ישמרנו מהם ומהמונם.
translation: And with this I have explained (in the introduction to my book Vayole Moshe) the saying of our Sages (Rosh Hashanah 17a) regarding the heretics and the apikorsim who denied the Torah and the teachings of the Sages, etc., that they descend to Gehenna and are judged there for generations upon generations, etc. And why is this? Because they stretched out their hands in the refuse. Rashi explains that they destroyed the Holy Temple because of their sins, and this saying is brought by the Rambam in chapter 3 of Hilchot Teshuvah, see there. At first glance, it is appropriate to understand that this reason, that they stretched out their hands in the refuse, would apply literally to the heretics and apikorsim who were before the destruction. However, this saying was repeated in the days of the Sages of the Talmud after the destruction, and the Rambam also brought it, so certainly it was said about the heretics and apikorsim of all generations. How can it be said that they stretched out their hands in the refuse when it has already been destroyed because of our many sins? This can be explained according to the words of the holy Alshich, as mentioned above, that the wicked, because of their sins, destroy and ruin the building above that was established by the deeds of the righteous. And I heard that once, the holy master, the Baal Divrei Chaim, may his merit protect us, at his pure table, said that the Holy Temple above is complete except that the curtain is still lacking. The holy Rabbi Yisrael of Tamatashov, may his merit protect us, responded that we believe with complete faith that our holy Rabbi can make the curtain. And then the holy Divrei Chaim did not respond anything, but once when he sat at the table, he said, "How do you know that I did not make the curtain? Rather, a great wicked one in his deeds tore it." And with this, we can understand what our Sages said regarding the severe punishment of the heretics and apikorsim for stretching out their hands in the refuse, for they are the ones who destroy and ruin the building of the Holy Temple and Jerusalem above. And in our times, due to the confusion of minds and the blurring of understanding, they are referred to as builders of the land and Jerusalem, and they are nothing but destroyers and ruiners. They were in our midst, and were it not for them, we would have already been redeemed, as it is stated in the Yalkut (Parashat Zu) that through the merit of Netronai, Israel will merit redemption. And the verse cries out like a raven, reminding us of the Lord, "Do not be silent for you." And in our times, how can we find rest for our souls when there are also those who observe the Torah and commandments who associate with the destroyers, support their deeds, and take part with them? May the Lord protect us from them and from their wealth.
summary: The passage discusses the severe consequences for heretics and those who deny the Torah, emphasizing that their actions contribute to the destruction of the spiritual Temple above, which is built through the righteous deeds of the tzaddikim. It highlights the belief that the spiritual structure of the Temple is incomplete due to the sins of the wicked, who are seen as the true destroyers of Jerusalem. The text warns against those who, while appearing to uphold the Torah, align themselves with these destructive forces, thus complicating the path to redemption. Ultimately, it calls for vigilance against such influences that hinder the Jewish people's salvation.
