passage_content: אולם המאמר נערים ילבינו פני זקנים ירמוז על בחי' אחרת, ויתבאר עפ"י דברי הנביא (ישעי' כ"ט) לכן כה אמר ה' אל בית יעקב אשר פדה את אברהם לא עתה יבוש יעקב ולא עתה פניו יחורו כי בראותו ילדיו מעשה ידי בקרבו יקדישו שמי והקדישו את קדוש יעקב וגו', מבואר מזה שאם אין ישראל מקדישין שם שמים וח"ו אין עושים רצונו של מקום מלבינים פניו של יע"א ישראל סבא, ומביישין השבטים הק' שהם נכללים ג"כ בשם יעקב כמ"ש היפ"ת בפירושא דהאי קרא יעקב אשר פדה את אברהם עייש"ד (הובא בדברינו במקו"א), וכן אמרז"ל בפתיחתא איכה רבתי (סימן כ"ד) ארשב"נ בשעה שחרב ביהמ"ק בא אברהם לפני הקב"ה בוכה וכו', אמר לפני הקב"ה מפני מה נשתניתי מכל אומה ולשון שבאתי לידי בושה וכלימה זאת וכו', ואולי זהו כוונת המאמר ונערים פני זקנים ילבינו שבעיקבא דמשיחא המנוערים מן המצות שאין בהם לא תורה ולא חכמה, ילבינו פני זקנים אבותינו ורבותינו הקדושים שהמה בעולם העליון שמתביישין ממעשינו.
translation: However, the statement "youths will make the faces of the elders white" hints at another aspect, and it can be explained according to the words of the prophet (Isaiah 29): "Therefore, thus says the Lord to the house of Jacob, who redeemed Abraham: Now Jacob shall not be ashamed, nor shall his face grow pale; for when he sees his children, the work of My hands, in his midst, they will sanctify My name and sanctify the Holy One of Jacob," etc. It is clear from this that if Israel does not sanctify the name of Heaven, G-d forbid, and does not fulfill the will of the Omnipresent, they will make the face of our forefather Jacob white, and they will bring shame upon the holy tribes, who are also included in the name Jacob, as explained by the Yefet in the commentary on this verse: "Jacob, who redeemed Abraham," as mentioned in our writings in other places. And so our sages said in the introduction to Eichah Rabbah (section 24): "When the Holy Temple was destroyed, Abraham came before the Holy One, Blessed be He, weeping, etc. He said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, 'Why have I been distinguished from all nations and languages, that I have come to this shame and disgrace?'" etc. And perhaps this is the intention of the statement "youths will make the faces of the elders white," that in the time of the Messiah, the youths who are removed from the commandments, who have neither Torah nor wisdom, will make the faces of the elders, our holy ancestors and teachers, who are in the upper world, white, as they are ashamed of our deeds.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the Jewish people's responsibility to sanctify God's name through their actions, emphasizing that failure to do so brings shame to their ancestors, particularly Jacob and the patriarchs. It references the prophetic words of Isaiah, highlighting that when Israel does not honor God, it results in the embarrassment of their forebears in the spiritual realm. The text also connects this idea to the Messianic era, suggesting that the neglect of commandments by the younger generation causes distress to the righteous ancestors who witness these actions. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining a strong connection to tradition and divine commandments to avoid bringing shame upon the Jewish legacy.

passage_content: והנה מבואר בדברי הראשונים ז"ל דתרי תחיות יש, והצדיקים הגדולים יעמדו בתחי' תיכף בביאת המשיח ויאכלו שני משיח, והשני הוא תחי' הכללי לכל העולם (הובא בדברינו בכ"מ), ואמרז"ל במד"ר (סוף פ' עקב) א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך כשם שנתת את נפשך עליהן בעוה"ז, כך לע"ל כשאביא להם את אלי' הנביא שניכן באין כאחת, מנין שכ"כ ה' ארך אפים וגדל כח וגו' ה' בסופה ובסערה דרכו וגו' בסופה זה משה וכו' ובסערה זה אלי' וכו', ועוד אמרז"ל במד"ר פ' חקת (פרשה י"ט אות ו') א"ל הקב"ה למשה שבחך הוא שהוצאת ס' רבוא וקברתם במדבר ואתה מכניס דור אחר, עכשיו יאמרו אין לדור המדבר חלק לעוה"ב, אלא תהא בצידן ותבא עמהן שנאמר ויתא ראשי עם צדקת ה' עשה, לכך כתיב לא תביאו את הקהל הזה אלא שיצאו עמך ע"כ, א"כ כשיבוא משה רבינו ע"ה עם אלי' יבואו עמו כל הדור ההוא ויעמדו צדיקי הדורות והם יסייעו לנו לעשות תשובה אמיתית, ובזכותם יעזור השי"ת שנוכל לעשות תשובה ולזכות אל הגאולה שלימה, כדי שלא יתביישו על ידינו שיהיו טוענין לפני השי"ת למה מגיע לנו בושה וכלימה הזו.
translation: And behold, it is explained in the words of the early authorities, may their memory be blessed, that there are two resurrections. The great righteous will rise immediately at the coming of the Messiah and will eat the two Messiahs, and the second is the general resurrection for the entire world (as we have mentioned elsewhere). And our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (at the end of Parashat Eikev) that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, just as you gave your soul for them in this world, so in the future, when I bring them Elijah the prophet, they will come as one." From where do we know this? As it is written, "The Lord is slow to anger and great in power," etc. "The Lord in the storm and in the tempest," etc. "In the storm" refers to Moses, etc., and "in the tempest" refers to Elijah, etc. Furthermore, our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Chukat (Section 19, Letter 6), that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "Your merit is that you brought out six hundred thousand and buried them in the desert, and you are bringing in another generation. Now they will say that the generation of the desert has no share in the World to Come, but you will be with them and come with them, as it is said, 'And the heads of the people of Israel came near, the righteousness of the Lord has done.'" Therefore, it is written, "You shall not bring this assembly, but that they go out with you." Thus, when our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, comes with Elijah, all that generation will come with him, and the righteous of the generations will stand and help us to make true repentance, and by their merit, may the Holy One, blessed be He, help us to repent and merit complete redemption, so that we will not be ashamed before Him, as they will claim before the Holy One, blessed be He, why we deserve this shame and disgrace.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of two resurrections, with the great righteous ones rising immediately upon the arrival of the Messiah, while the second resurrection is a general one for the entire world. It emphasizes the role of Moses and Elijah in this process, highlighting that they will lead the generation of the desert into the World to Come, ensuring that they are not left behind. The text underscores the importance of these righteous figures in helping the people achieve true repentance, which is essential for attaining complete redemption and avoiding shame before God.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל בכוונת התשובה שהשיב משה רבינו ע"ה על שאלת פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, ועפי"ד המדרש אמר מי יעלה בהר ה' ומי יקום במקום קדשו, ר"ל מי יזכה אל גאולה העתידה כנ"ל, והשיב לו משה רבינו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך שאף הנערים המנוערים מן המצות ילכו עם הזקנים שיעמדו בתחיית המתים בביאת אלי', ובזכותם שלא יתביישו ממעשיהם יזכו לעשות תשובה ויתקנו מעשיהם ויזכו אל הגאולה, ועוד אמר לו בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך היינו תינוקות של בית רבן שהבל פיהם אין בו חטא, ואם נזכה לגדלם על דרך התורה והיראה זה יעמוד לנו לזכות ויגן עלינו שנוכל לילך בנערינו ובזקנינו ביחד עם זקני הדורות וצדיקים הקודמים, ונזכה גם אנו אל הגאולה שלימה, ולזה כפל לומר ב"פ נלך שהם שני זכותים שעל ידיהם נזכה אל הגאולה, זכות הזקנים שלא יתביישו ממעשינו, וזכות תשב"ר, והבוכ"ע יעזור שבמהרה נזכה אל הגאולה שלימה האמיתית בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And similarly, one can say regarding the intention of the repentance that Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, answered Pharaoh's question of who are the ones going. According to the Midrash, it says, "Who shall ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who shall stand in His holy place," meaning who will merit the future redemption as mentioned above. Moshe Rabbeinu replied, "We will go with our young and with our old," for even the young ones, who are distanced from the commandments, will go with the elders who will stand in the resurrection of the dead at the coming of Eliyahu. And by virtue of them, that they will not be ashamed of their deeds, they will merit to repent, rectify their actions, and attain redemption. Furthermore, he said to him, "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," referring to the children of the house of study, whose innocent words contain no sin. If we merit to raise them in the ways of the Torah and fear of Heaven, this will stand for us as a merit and protect us so that we can go with our young and with our old together with the elders of the generations and the righteous ones of the past, and we too will merit the complete redemption. For this reason, he emphasized saying "we will go" twice, as they are two merits through which we will attain redemption: the merit of the elders, that they will not be ashamed of our deeds, and the merit of the children. May the Blessed One help that we may soon merit the true complete redemption with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the response of Moses to Pharaoh regarding who will go to worship, emphasizing the inclusion of both the young and the old in the journey towards redemption. It highlights the importance of the righteous elders, whose merit can inspire the younger generation to repent and improve their actions, thus facilitating their collective redemption. Additionally, it underscores the value of raising children in a Torah-observant environment, as their innocence can serve as a protective merit for the community. Ultimately, the text expresses a hope for a complete and imminent redemption, marked by the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: במסיבה את משה ואת אהרן אל פרעה ויאמר אליהם וגו' מי ומי ההולכים, ויאמר משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך וגו', הקשה הכלי יקר ההולכים לשון הוה אינו מתיישב, והי"ל לומר מי ילך משמע להבא, וכמו שהשיב לו משרע"ה בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, גם יל"ד בתשובת משרע"ה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, דהזכיר בתחלה דרך כלל בנערינו, וכבר נכלל בזה בבנינו ובבנותינו, ומה צורך לפורטם ולכפול עוד, גם מדוע הזכיר ב' פעמים נלך וחלקן לתרי בבא, וסגי שיאמר בנערינו ובזקנינו בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, גם יל"ד דמעיקרא צירף הליכת הנערים אל הזקנים, במ"ש בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, ואח"כ הזכירן עוה"פ לבדם בבנינו ובבנותינו בלי צירוף הזקנים וכ"ז טעמא בעי. ב) בתרגום יונתן (פ' בשלח) יש מאמר פלא עה"פ וחמשים עלו בנ"י מארץ מצרים, פי' יוב"ע וכל חד עם חמשא טפלין סליקו בני ישראל מארעא דמצרים, והוא פליאה נשגבה דאיך יצוייר דכל ישראל הי"ל במספר מכוון ומצומצם ה' טפלין לא פחות ולא יותר, גם הרי אמרז"ל (במד"ר פ' א' סי' ח') שהיו יולדות ששה בכרס א' והיו פרין ורבין שלא כדרך הטבע.
translation:
In the gathering, Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, and he said to them, etc., "Who are the ones going?" And Moses said, "We will go with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters," etc. The Kli Yakar questions why the term "the ones going" is in the present tense, which does not seem to fit, and he should have said "who will go," implying in the future. Just as Moshe Rabbeinu responded to him, "with our sons and with our daughters we will go," it is also necessary to understand Moshe Rabbeinu's response of "with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters we will go." He initially mentioned in general terms "with our young," which is already included in "with our sons and with our daughters." What is the need to specify and repeat them again? Also, why did he mention "we will go" twice and divide them into two statements? It would suffice to say, "with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters we will go." Additionally, it should be noted that initially he included the going of the young with the old when he said, "with our young and with our old we will go," and afterwards he mentioned them separately, "with our sons and with our daughters," without including the old. All of this requires explanation. 

In the translation of Jonathan (Parashat Beshalach), there is a wondrous statement regarding the verse "And fifty went up, the children of Israel, from the land of Egypt," meaning that each one with five children ascended from the land of Egypt. This is a remarkable wonder, how it could be imagined that all of Israel would have a specific and limited number of five children, no more and no less. Furthermore, it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Aleph, section 8) that they would give birth to six in one womb, and they were fruitful and multiplied contrary to the natural way.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh regarding the Israelites' departure, emphasizing the significance of the terms used to describe the people going to worship. The repetition of "we will go" and the specific mention of "our children and our elders" highlights the inclusivity of the entire community in the act of worship. Additionally, the reference to the miraculous nature of the Israelites' exodus, as noted in the Targum Jonathan, underscores the divine orchestration of their liberation, suggesting that their journey was both a physical and spiritual transformation, reflecting a profound theological insight into the nature of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפ"י דרשתם ז"ל וחמשים עלו בנ"י מארץ מצרים, אחד מחמשה יצאו וד' חלקים מתו בג' ימי אפילה, לפי שהיו רשעים ולא רצו לצאת ע"כ במדרש, אמנם יש לחקור דאותן הד' חלקים שנשארו במצרים מה נהי' עם בניהם הקטנים אשר אין עול בכפם, ובל"ס היו מספר רב, הכי נאמר שגם הם מתו ונשארו במצרים. זה דבר זר ורחוק מן השכל, דאם אבותיהם נטמעו והתחברו אל המצריים ולמדו ממעשיהם, וראתה חכמתו ית' שלא יאות התחברותם לכלל ישראל, ובעכ"ח נשארו שם ולעתיד יהי' תקון לנפשותם ויצטרפו ויתבררו כמבואר בדברי האריז"ל, אבל וודאי בניהם הקטנים לא חטאו ולא יעלה על הדעת שגם הם נתרחקו ונבדלו מכלל ישראל בעון אבותיהם, ויתכן שבניהם של אותן ד' חלקים שנשארו, נצטרפו אל הכלל ישראל ויצאו ממצרים עם חלק א' מחמשה אשר היו טהורים ונבדלים מהתחברותם של מצרים ודיעותוהם, והאמינו בדברי ה' ובמשה עבדו לצאת ממצרים והופרשו מע"ז, ועל ידיהם נתגדלו במדבר גם אלו הילדים לתורה ולמצות, ובזה יתבאר דברי יוב"ע וכל חד עם חמשה טפלין סליקו בנ"י מארעא דמצרים, ולא נחית למנינא שהיו במספר חמשה, אולם הכוונה ע"ד דרשתם ז"ל א' מחמשה יצאו וד' חלקים מתו וכו', ועד"ז הכוונה עם חמשה טפלין ר"ל ה' חלקים: שחוץ ממה שעלו עם טפלהון, הוליכו עמכם עוד הטפלים של אותן ד' חלקים שנשארו במצרים והוא פי' נכון בס"ד.
translation: And even though according to their interpretation, may their memory be blessed, fifty went up from the land of Egypt, one out of five went out, and four parts died in three days of darkness, because they were wicked and did not want to leave, thus it is stated in the Midrash. However, one must investigate what happened to those four parts that remained in Egypt regarding their small children who bore no sin, and certainly there were many of them. Shall we say that they also died and remained in Egypt? This is a strange and far-fetched idea, for if their fathers were absorbed and connected to the Egyptians and learned from their deeds, and the wisdom of the Blessed One saw that their connection would not be fitting for the community of Israel, therefore they remained there, and in the future there will be a rectification for their souls, and they will join and be clarified as explained in the words of the Arizal. But certainly, their small children did not sin, and it is inconceivable that they too were distanced and separated from the community of Israel due to the sins of their fathers. It is possible that the children of those four parts that remained joined the community of Israel and went out of Egypt with the one part out of five that were pure and separated from the connection to the Egyptians and their beliefs, and they believed in the words of Hashem and in Moses, His servant, to go out of Egypt and were separated from idolatry. Through them, these children were also raised in the wilderness to Torah and commandments. In this, the words of Yov"an will be clarified, and every one with five parts went up from the land of Egypt, and they did not descend to the count that was in the number five. However, the intention according to their interpretation, may their memory be blessed, is that one out of five went out, and four parts died, etc. Similarly, the intention with five parts means the five parts: that besides those who went up with the main part, they also brought with them the additional parts of those four parts that remained in Egypt, and this is a correct explanation, with the help of Heaven.
summary: The passage discusses the fate of the four-fifths of the Israelites who remained in Egypt during the Exodus, suggesting that their young children, who were innocent of sin, could not be condemned for their parents' actions. It posits that these children may have joined the one-fifth that left, as they believed in God and Moses, thus becoming part of the collective Israelite identity. The text emphasizes the idea of divine wisdom in separating the righteous from the wicked and hints at a future redemption for the souls of those who remained in Egypt. Ultimately, it reflects on the interconnectedness of the Jewish people and the potential for spiritual growth and purification.

passage_content: והנה כבר ביארנו (לעיל בדרוש הקדום) שהשיג פרעה דרוב גדול מישראל אינם רוצים לילך בעצתו והדרכתו של משה ואהרן, ע"י שהתחברו עם המצריים ולמדו ממעשיהם, ועד"ז הי' שאלתו מי ומי ההולכים בלשון הוה, ר"ל מי ומי ההולכים בדרכיכם ובדרך עבדות ה', וכמ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה עה"פ (תהלים א') אשרי האיש אשר לא הלך בעצת רשעים. דהליכה זו לאו הליכה ממש, אלא שלא הלך בדרכם ועצתם, וכעין שפירש"י ז"ל וילך איש מבית לוי שהלך בעצת בתו, הרי מבואר דהליכה בעצה יקרא הכתוב בשם הליכה סתם, ואף כאן טען פרעה אתם אומרים נלכה ונזבחה לה' אלקינו וגם את הטף רצונכם לצרף עמכם בהליכה זו, מי ומי ההולכים הלא מועטים הם אשר הולכים בעצתכם לעבודת הקב"ה ואיך תדברו בעד כללות האומה, והלא אחרי רבים להטות ורבים לא יצטרפו עמכם בהליכה זו, ובאמת לא הי' גם רצון הבוי"ת שיצטרפו ויתחברו עם ישראל לצאת עמהם, וע"כ מתו בג' ימי אפילה, כי הי' מזיק התחברותם לבנ"י הכשרים, אמנם טענת פרעה הי' כיון שאין כאן אלא מיעוטא דמיעוטא ההולכים בדרך זה, א"כ מה כח טענתכם לדבר בשם כלל ישראל, ובעיקר רצה לעכב הטף שלא יצאו, כמו שפירש דבריו מיד אח"כ ואמר לכו נא הגברים, שאם האבות אכלו בוסר שיני בנים תקהינה ולא נתגדלו עד"ז, ומה לכם להכריחם בעכ"ח על דעתכם.
translation: And behold, we have already explained (above in the ancient discourse) that Pharaoh realized that a large majority of Israel did not want to go by the counsel and guidance of Moses and Aaron, due to their association with the Egyptians and learning from their deeds. Similarly, his question was "who and who are going?" in the present tense, meaning who among you is going in your ways and in the way of the service of Hashem, as it is written (Psalms 1) "Blessed is the man who did not walk in the counsel of the wicked." This walking is not a literal walking, but rather that he did not walk in their ways and their counsel, as Rashi explains regarding "And a man from the house of Levi went" that he went by the counsel of his daughter; it is clear that walking by counsel is referred to in the text simply as walking. And here Pharaoh argued, you say "We will go and we will sacrifice to Hashem our God," and you also wish to include the children in this going, who are the few that are going according to your counsel to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He? How can you speak on behalf of the entire nation, when after all, it is known that "after the majority to incline" and many will not join you in this going? And indeed, it was not the will of the Creator that they should join and connect with Israel to go out with them, and therefore they died in the three days of darkness, for their association was harmful to the righteous children of Israel. However, Pharaoh's argument was that since there are only a minority of a minority going in this way, what power does your claim have to speak in the name of all of Israel? Primarily, he wanted to prevent the children from going out, as he explained his words immediately afterward and said, "Go now, you men," for if the fathers ate sour grapes, the children's teeth will be set on edge and they will not grow up in the same way. What right do you have to force them against their will according to your opinion?
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's realization that a significant portion of the Israelites are unwilling to follow the guidance of Moses and Aaron, having instead aligned themselves with Egyptian practices. Pharaoh questions the legitimacy of their claim to represent the entire nation, emphasizing that only a minority are truly committed to serving God. He argues that the connection between the Israelites and their children is weak, suggesting that forcing the next generation to follow their parents' faith is futile. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the importance of genuine commitment to divine service over mere adherence to tradition.

passage_content: ואפ"ל במאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, דיל"ד דהול"ל ולא שמעו אליו, שכבר נזכר שמשה הי' המדבר אליהם, ומה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה. ובמד"ר (פר' ו' סי' ה') מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, וג"ז תמוה דמעיקרא כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו' ומדוע עכשיו לא שמעו אל משה, ויתכן שהכשרים שבישראל שהאמינו בשליחותו מעיקרא, גם עכשיו לא נתהפך דעתם ורצונם, ומ"ש ולא שמעו אל משה הכוונה על אותן הד' חלקים אשר לא רצו לצאת, ואף אלו שמעו אליו בתחלה כמ"ש ויאמן העם וישמעו, אף שהיו אדוקים בתועבת מצרים ובע"ז, אבל חשבו לעשות פשרות ואחוז בזה וגם מזה אל תנח, אבל כאשר נוכחו לדעת שהדרך המבוקש ע"י משרע"ה בשליחות ה' להפריש מע"ז ותועבת מצרים פרישה גמורה בלי פשרות, לא אבו שמוע ולא רצו לקבל ממנו, וז"ש ולא שמעו אל משה, ר"ל לצד שמשה הי' המדבר אליהם וע"כ הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז על דעתו וכוונתו, ומה"ט לא יצאו אלא א' מחמשה, כי לא היו ראויים אלו שיתחברו עם ישראל, עד שיתבררו ויתוקנו לעתיד ויחזרו לשורשם, ופרעה השיג זאת ועד"ז הי' טענתו מי ומי ההולכים
translation: And even though it is written in the Torah that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, it could have been stated simply, "and they did not listen to him," since it was already mentioned that Moses was speaking to them. What then is the meaning of "and they did not listen to Moses"? In the Midrash (Parashat Va'eira, section 5), it is explained that due to shortness of spirit and hard work, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. This is also puzzling, for initially it is written, "And the people believed and listened," so why now did they not listen to Moses? It is possible that the righteous among Israel, who believed in his mission from the beginning, did not change their minds or desires even now. When it says "and they did not listen to Moses," it refers to those four parts who did not want to leave. Even those who initially listened to him, as it is written, "And the people believed and listened," although they were entrenched in the abominations of Egypt and idolatry, they thought to make compromises, holding on to both this and that, but when they realized that the path sought by Moshe Rabbeinu, by the command of Hashem, was a complete separation from idolatry and the abominations of Egypt without compromises, they did not want to listen and did not wish to accept from him. Therefore, it is said, "and they did not listen to Moses," meaning that since Moses was speaking to them, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry according to his opinion and intention. For this reason, only one out of five left, because these were not worthy to join with Israel until they would be clarified and rectified for the future and return to their root. Pharaoh understood this, and similarly was his claim, "Who are the ones going?"
summary: The passage discusses the reluctance of the Israelites to heed Moses' call to leave Egypt due to their spiritual bondage and attachment to idolatry. It highlights that while some initially believed in Moses' mission, they ultimately resisted a complete separation from their former ways, preferring compromise rather than total commitment to God's directive. This resistance is seen as a reflection of their unworthiness to join the Jewish people until they could be purified and return to their spiritual roots. The text emphasizes the challenge of true faith and the necessity of a complete break from past transgressions to fulfill divine purpose.

passage_content: אמנם משה רבינו השיב להכחיש טענתו, שלא כאשר תחשוב שהטף ישארו ברשותך, אבל בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, ועפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל שגם אותן הד' חלקים שלא יצאו אבל בניהם יצטרפו אל הכלל ישראל ויתגדלו ע"ד התורה, ואפשר דע"כ עשה מהן ב' חלוקות במ"ש בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, דהבנים מאותן ד' חלקים שנשארו במצרים, אף שהי' צורך גדול לחזור על תקנתם ולהצילם, אבל הרי נתגדלו בבית הורים אשר התחברו לדרכי המצריים, והי' סכנה גדולה בדבר שאלו הבנים יתחברו עם הבנים של הכשרים אשר נתגדלו בדרך הישן המסורה, ע"כ עשו מהם ב' חלוקות, ואלו הבנים שנשארו אבותיהם במצרים נצטרפו אל הזקנים שילמדום דרכי ה' איך לפרוש מדרכי האומות ותועבותם, והכשרים שבישראל הוליכו בניהם ובנותיהם עמהם ונתגדלו על ידיהם, וז"ש משרע"ה לפרעה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך היינו דגם אלו שישארו במצרים, נעריהם יצטרפו אל הזקנים וילכו עמהם בדרכיהם ועצתם, ואמר עוד בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך על בני הכשרים שיתגדלו אצל אבותיהם, ולזה הזכיר כפל הלשונות נלך נלך דלא סגי בחדא והצורך להפרידם ולגדלם כ"א בפ"ע עד שיתעלו להיות כולם אהובים וברורים בדרך המסורה.
translation: Indeed, Moshe Rabbeinu responded to deny his claim, that it is not as you think that the children will remain under your authority, but with our young and with our elders we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go. And according to the aforementioned principle, that even those four parts that did not leave, their children will join the congregation of Israel and will be raised according to the Torah. It is possible that this is why he made two distinctions in saying, "with our young and with our elders we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go," for the sons from those four parts that remained in Egypt, even though there was a great need to return to rectify them and save them, they were raised in a household of parents who connected to the ways of the Egyptians, and there was a great danger that these sons would connect with the sons of the righteous who were raised in the old, traditional way. Therefore, he made two distinctions, and those sons whose fathers remained in Egypt joined the elders who would teach them the ways of the Lord, how to separate from the ways of the nations and their abominations. And the righteous among Israel took their sons and daughters with them and raised them. This is what Moshe said to Pharaoh, "with our young and with our elders we will go," meaning that even those who will remain in Egypt, their young will join the elders and go with them in their ways and counsel. He also said, "with our sons and with our daughters we will go," regarding the sons of the righteous who will be raised by their fathers. And for this, he mentioned the repetition of the phrases "we will go, we will go," for it is not sufficient with one, and the need is to separate them and raise them only independently until they all elevate to be beloved and clear in the way of the tradition.
summary: Moses emphasizes the importance of separating the children of Israel from the influences of Egypt, highlighting that both the young and the old must journey together to ensure the proper education and spiritual growth of the next generation. He acknowledges the danger posed by the children who remained in Egypt, as they risked adopting the corrupt ways of their surroundings. By making a distinction between the children of the righteous and those influenced by Egyptian culture, Moses underscores the necessity of guiding all children towards the paths of holiness and tradition. This dual emphasis on unity and separation reflects a deep commitment to preserving the integrity of the Jewish identity and teachings.

passage_content: המורם מזה ללמוד עד כמה חיוב הזהירות בגידול הבנים ובנות בדרך הישן המסורה, וא"צ לפרט שהרבה מאוד פעלו להחזקת היהדות, הישיבות ובתי ת"ת שנתייסדו על טהרת הקודש באמעריקא לפני שנים הרבה, וניצולו על ידם ילדי ישראל במספר רב אשר לא ראו אצל הוריהם זיק של יהדות, אבל בכל זאת לאלו הילדים שנתגדלו בדרך הישן צריך הליכה מיוחדת, וא"א שיצטרפו אלו עם אלו כמו שפירשנו במאמה"כ בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, ועד"ז נקוה שיהיו כולם אהובים כולם ברורים ע"ד המקובל מאבותינו הקדושים, והאמת שהתוה"ק ודרך היהדות לא נשתנה כמ"ש החת"ס זלה"ה בצוואתו אל תאמר נשתנו העתים, יש לנו אב זקן הוא לא נשתנה ולא ישתנה, וכשנזכה אל הגאולה יחזור ויתוקן הכל אל מקומו ושרשו, וחיובא רמיא על כל א' מישראל, אף שלא הגיע עדיין לבחי' זו ואין בכח השגתו לשנות עצמו מדרכו הרגיל, וגם את בניו קשה לשנות בפ"א, עכ"ז חיובא רמיא לחזק חינוך כזה ע"ד הישן המסורה, שיהי' זה המציאות בעולם, ולהוי ידוע דאם יש במציאות חינוך כזה, ה"ה משפיע גם על אחרים אף על אותן שלא הגיעו עדיין להשגה זו, והבוכ"ע יעזור שהנלך הראשון יתעלה אל בחי' נלך השני, ונלך מעלה מעלה ולא נסוג אחור ח"ו, ונזכה לראות כל ישראל ברום המעלה ובשלימות האמיתי ומלכם בראשם, ולקבל פני משיח צדקנו בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: It is important to learn how essential it is to exercise caution in raising sons and daughters in the traditional way that has been passed down. There is no need to elaborate that many have worked to strengthen Judaism, the yeshivas, and the Torah schools that were established on the purity of holiness in America many years ago, and through them, many Jewish children were saved who had not seen a spark of Judaism in their parents. Nevertheless, for those children who were raised in the traditional way, there needs to be a special approach, and it is impossible for them to be grouped together as we explained in our holy writings, "In our sons and in our daughters we will go." In this way, we hope that all will be beloved and all will be clear according to the tradition received from our holy ancestors. The truth is that the Torah and the way of Judaism have not changed, as the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his will: "Do not say that the times have changed; we have an old father who has not changed and will not change." When we merit the redemption, everything will return and be restored to its place and root. There is an obligation upon every Jew, even if he has not yet reached this level and it is beyond his ability to change himself from his usual path, and it is also difficult to change his children in one go. Nevertheless, there is an obligation to strengthen such education in the traditional way that has been passed down, so that this will be the reality in the world. It should be known that if there is such an educational reality, it also influences others, even those who have not yet reached this understanding. May the Blessed One help that the first step we take will elevate us to the second level, and we will ascend higher and higher and not retreat backward, Heaven forbid. May we merit to see all of Israel at the height of greatness and in true completeness, with their King at their head, and to greet the Messiah, our righteous one, with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of adhering to traditional Jewish education and upbringing for children, highlighting the need for a distinct approach to ensure their spiritual development. It acknowledges the efforts made in America to preserve Judaism through institutions that have successfully reached many children who lacked Jewish exposure. The text asserts that despite the challenges of modernity, the essence of Torah and Jewish practice remains unchanged, and there is a collective responsibility to strengthen this traditional education. Ultimately, it expresses hope for a future redemption where all of Israel will attain spiritual elevation and welcome the Messiah.

passage_content: ויושב את משה ואת אהרן אל פרעה ויאמר אלהם לכו עבדו את ה' אלקיכם מי ומי ההולכים, ויאמר משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותנו בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך כי חג ה' לנו. הקשה בכלי יקר וז"ל יש בענין זה ספיקות, ההולכים לשון הוה אינו מתיישב, כי הול"ל מי ילך משמע להבא, כי ההולכים משמע שהולכים עכשיו והרי עדיין לא הלכו, ועוד שני פעמים נלך וודאי אחד מהם מיותר כי הול"ל בנערינו ובזקנינו בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך, ועוד כי חג ה' לנו והרי למעלה אמר בשם ה' ויחגו לי במדבר, משמע שיהי' חג ה' ולא לנו, והבדל זה ידוע כי חג לה' הוא בעבדות השי"ת, וחג לנו הוא בשמחת העובדים, כמ"ש עצרת לה' וכתיב עצרת תהי' לכם, ורז"ל אמרו (ביצה דף ט"ו ע"ב) דרך פשרה חציו לה' וחציו לכם, וכאן מי כהחכם ומי יודע פשר דבר עכ"ל הכלי יקר, עוד יל"ד מדוע חלקם הכתוב לתרי בבא בנערינו ובזקנינו בבנינו ובבנותנו, והרי הבנים ובנות כבר נכללו במאמר בנערינו.
translation: And he brought Moses and Aaron to Pharaoh, and he said to them, "Go, serve the Lord your God. Who are the ones going?" And Moses said, "We will go with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters, with our flocks and with our herds we will go, for it is a feast to the Lord for us." The Kli Yakar raises difficulties regarding this matter, and he says that there are uncertainties in this regard. The phrase "the ones going" in the present tense does not fit, for it should have said "who will go," which implies future action, while "the ones going" suggests they are going now, and they have not yet gone. Furthermore, the phrase "we will go" is mentioned twice, and certainly one of them is superfluous, as it should have said, "with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters we will go." Additionally, it states "for it is a feast to the Lord for us," while earlier it was said in the name of the Lord, "and they shall celebrate a feast to Me in the wilderness," implying that it will be a feast to the Lord and not to us. This distinction is known, for a feast to the Lord is in the service of the Blessed One, while a feast for us is in the joy of the servants, as it is written, "a feast to the Lord" and it is written, "a feast shall be for you." And our sages said (Beitzah 15b) that it is a compromise, half to the Lord and half to you. And here, who is as wise and who knows the interpretation of the matter? Thus concludes the Kli Yakar. It is also necessary to inquire why the verse divides them into two categories: with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters, when the sons and daughters are already included in the statement "with our young."
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between Moses, Aaron, and Pharaoh regarding the Israelites' intention to worship God, highlighting the distinction between serving God and the joy of the worshippers. It raises questions about the phrasing used, particularly the present tense "the ones going" and the redundancy in stating both "young and old" and "sons and daughters." The text emphasizes that the festival is for God in the context of servitude, while it is also a celebration for the people, reflecting the dual nature of worship as both a duty to God and a source of joy for the faithful. This duality is further illustrated by the concept of shared celebration, where part of the festival is dedicated to God and part to the community.

passage_content: ב) הטורים כתב אמר פרעה למשה מה אתם מבקשים כ"כ ללכת, וכי אתם סבורים ליכנס לארץ, מי ומי ההולכים ליכנס לארץ כי כולם ימותו במדבר חוץ יהושע וכלב. השיב משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ועל יתר מבן ס' עכ"ל, והאברבנאל מביא זה בשם מדרש רז"ל, וגם לפי"ד צ"ב המשך דברי הפסוק בבנינו ובבנותנו על מי קאי, אם על הפחותים מבן כ' כבר נכללו במלת בנערינו, ואם על היתרים מבן כ' הלא היו בכלל הגזירה למות במדבר וא"א לומר שעמהם יכנס לא"י.
translation: B) The Turim wrote that Pharaoh said to Moses, "What are you asking so much to go? Do you think you will enter the land? Who are those going to enter the land? For all will die in the desert, except for Joshua and Caleb." Moses replied, "With our young and with our old we will go, for a decree was not made on those under twenty and on those over sixty." Thus far the text. And the Abarbanel brings this in the name of the Midrash of our Sages. Also, according to the explanation, it is difficult to understand the continuation of the verse "with our sons and with our daughters" – on whom does it refer? If it refers to those under twenty, they are already included in the term "with our young." And if it refers to those over twenty, they are certainly included in the decree to die in the desert, and it cannot be said that they will enter the Land of Israel with them.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between Pharaoh and Moses highlights the tension between divine decree and human agency. Pharaoh questions the Israelites' desire to enter the Promised Land, noting that only Joshua and Caleb are exempt from the decree of death in the desert. Moses responds that they will go with their children and elders, suggesting that the decree does not apply to those under twenty and those over sixty. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interplay between faith, divine promise, and the importance of community in spiritual journeys.

passage_content: ג) אבא מארי זלה"ה בדרושים לסוכות הביא מדרש פליאה וזה תוארו ויאמר משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך וגו' כי חג ה' לנו, זה חג הסוכות והוא תמוה, וברבינו בחיי פי' כי חג ה' לנו זה חג שבועות עיי"ש, וג"ז צ"ב כי משרע"ה אמר דרך ג' ימים נלך ונזבחה וגומר, ועדיין היו ב' חדשים ויותר עד חג השבועות ומהו הכוונה במ"ש כי חג ה' לנו זה חג השבועות.
translation: 3) Our father, the Rebbe, may his memory be a blessing, in his discourses for Sukkot brought a wondrous Midrash, and this is its description: "And Moses said, 'We will go with our young and with our old... for it is a festival of the Lord for us.'" This refers to the festival of Sukkot, and it is puzzling. And our teacher, Bachya, explained that "for it is a festival of the Lord for us" refers to the festival of Shavuot, as you can see there. And this too is difficult, for Moshe said, "We will go three days' journey and we will sacrifice..." and there were still two months and more until the festival of Shavuot. What is the intention of saying, "for it is a festival of the Lord for us," referring to the festival of Shavuot?
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the perplexing statement by Moses regarding the celebration of a festival, specifically linking it to the holiday of Sukkot. The text highlights a commentary by Rabbeinu Bachaye, who interprets "this is a festival for the Lord" as referring to Shavuot, raising questions about the timing since Moses mentioned a journey of three days for sacrifices, while Shavuot occurs much later. This reflects a deeper theological exploration of the connection between the festivals and the spiritual significance of their observance in the context of divine service.

passage_content: ד) פרעה אל משה ויאמר לכו עבדו את ה' רק צאנכם ובקרכם יצג וגו', ויאמר משה גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות ועשינו לה' אלקינו, הקשה האוהחה"ק וז"ל איך שאול ישאל עבד ה' זבחי אלקים מאיש בזוי וטמא אשר הרים פיו בקדוש ישראל וכו' החפץ לה' בזבח רשעים.
translation: 4) Pharaoh said to Moses, "Go, serve the Lord; only your flocks and your herds shall be left behind," etc. And Moses said, "You must also give us sacrifices and burnt offerings, and we will make them for the Lord our God." The holy and exalted one asked, "How can Saul, the servant of the Lord, ask for the sacrifices of God from a despised and impure man who raised his mouth against the Holy One of Israel," etc. "Does the Lord desire the sacrifice of the wicked?"
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between Pharaoh and Moses highlights the tension between serving God and the moral integrity of the offeror. Moses insists that true worship requires sacrifices that are not tainted by the impurity of the oppressor, emphasizing that offerings from the wicked are not pleasing to God. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the intention and purity of the heart behind the act of worship are crucial for it to be accepted by the Divine. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of righteousness in one's relationship with God, suggesting that genuine devotion cannot coexist with moral corruption.

passage_content: ה) יל"ד דמאמר ועשינו לה' אלקינו מיותר, ומובן מאליו שהזבחים ועולות יקריבום לה' ולא לע"ז ח"ו, ומדוע הוצרך לפרט ולפרש ועשינו לה' אלקינו, ועוד דמאמר וגם מקננו ילך עמנו ג"כ מיותר ומובן מאליו. דאם פרעה יתן זבחים ועולות משלו, כ"ש שמקנה ישראל ילך עמהם, עוד יל"ד באומרו גם אתה וגו' וגם מקננו וגו', מ"ט כפל מלת גם ב"פ, והחיד"א זלה"ה מדייק באומרו גם אתה תתן בידנו דמלת בידינו מיותר, והול"ל גם אתה תתן זבחים וגו', ועוד היכן מצינו שנתקיים דיבור זה שאמר משה רבינו גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות, ולא יתכן שיכתב בתוה"ק דיבור שלא נתקיים.
translation: 5) It is asked regarding the statement "and we will make sacrifices to the Lord our God" that it is superfluous, and it is self-evident that the sacrifices and burnt offerings would be brought to the Lord and not to an idol, Heaven forbid. Why then was it necessary to specify and explain "and we will make sacrifices to the Lord our God"? Furthermore, the statement "and also our livestock will go with us" is also superfluous and self-evident. For if Pharaoh were to give sacrifices and burnt offerings from his own, certainly the livestock of Israel would go with them. Additionally, it is asked regarding the phrase "also you" and so on, and "and also our livestock" and so on, why the word "also" is repeated twice. The Chida, may his merit protect us, notes that the phrase "in our hand" is superfluous, and it could have simply stated "also you will give us sacrifices" and so on. Moreover, where do we find that this statement made by our teacher Moses, "also you will give us sacrifices and burnt offerings," was fulfilled? It is not fitting that the Holy Torah should record a statement that was not fulfilled.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of emphasizing that sacrifices and offerings are to be made to God, rather than to idols, highlighting the inherent understanding that offerings are meant for the Divine. It questions the redundancy of stating that the Israelites' livestock will accompany them, suggesting that if Pharaoh offers sacrifices, it is obvious that the Israelites' possessions would also go with them. The text also notes the repetition of the word "also" and the phrase "in our hands," indicating a deeper theological significance, as it implies a divine promise that must be fulfilled, raising the concern about the validity of statements made by Moses that did not come to pass.

passage_content: ו) בפרשה ויקרא למשה ולאהרן לילה ויאמר קומו צאו וגו' גם צאנכם גם בקרכם קחו כאשר דברתם ולכו, פירש"י מהו כאשר דברתם גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות, וצ"ב איך יתקשר זאת עם משמעות הכתוב, הלא בפירוש אמר צאנכם בקרכם דייקא קחו, ואם התכוין על מ"ש גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות, הול"ל גם צאני ובקרי אתן לכם.
translation: And in the portion, He called to Moses and to Aaron at night, and He said, "Arise, go out... also your sheep and also your cattle take as you have spoken, and go." Rashi explains what is meant by "as you have spoken" – "also you will give into our hands offerings and burnt offerings." It is puzzling how this connects with the meaning of the verse, for it explicitly states "your sheep and your cattle" to take. And if He intended to refer to what is said, "also you will give into our hands offerings and burnt offerings," it should have said, "also my sheep and my cattle I will give to you."
summary: In this passage, the call for Moses and Aaron to take their flocks and herds emphasizes the importance of physical offerings in the service of God. Rashi's commentary raises a question about the connection between the specific mention of their animals and the request for additional sacrifices, suggesting a deeper relationship between the material and spiritual realms. The text highlights the significance of both personal and communal offerings in achieving a connection with the divine, reflecting key Hasidic themes of integrating the physical with the spiritual in worship. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true devotion involves both the tangible and the intangible aspects of faith.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי אאמו"ר זלה"ה בקדויו"ט לפרש דברי המדרש (מובא בעיר דוד) אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, עתידים אתם אומרים מי יעלה בהר ה' ומי יקום במקום קדשו וזה מי ומי ההולכים, והוא תמוה מה ענין הך קרא לכאן ואאמו"ר ז"ל מפרשו בדרך הסוד עפ"י הנודע דמ"י נקרא מדת הבינה, (עיין בזוה"ק בהקדמת בראשית בדף הראשון ע"ב) ומ"י הוא"ו רומז למדת יסוד (עיין זוה"ק ויצא קס"ב), ובזה נזכה להבין מאמר דוהמע"ה, מ"י היינו מדת הבינה שהוא לשוב בתשובה כל ימיו יעלה בהר ה' ירצה שיעלה מעלה מעלה בהר ה' ע"י שירגיל עצמו במדת הבינה שהוא לשוב בתשובה כל ימיו. ורק תקומה לא יוכל להשלים זה הבנין אא"כ שיתקן קודם מדת היסוד, וזה שגמר אומר ומ"י הוא"ו רומז למדת יסוד יקום במקום קדשו, עי"ז יהי' תקומה לכל מדרגותיו, וז"ש פרעה אל משה ואהרן לכו עבדו את ה' וגו' מי ומי ההולכים, היינו אם אתם רוצים לילך לעבדות ה', צריכים אתם קודם לראות אם תקנתם את מדת הבינה התשובה בהקדמת מדת היסוד הנרמז בוא"ו של תיבת ומ"י, שבלא זה מה יתרון לכם במה שתלכו לעבודת השם, כי לא ירצה אם לא תקנתם מדת היסוד שהוא יסוד ושורש הכל, וע"ז השיב משה לאותו רשע בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כאמרם ז"ל (סוכה דף נ"ג ע"א) אשרי זקנותינו שכפרה על ילדותינו, דהיינו שבעת הזקנה עשו תשובה על מה שפגמו בחטאת נעורים ונתקנו אף ימי הנעורים, ובשניהם נלך לעבוד את ה', את"ד ומקצת לשון קדשו עייש"ד שהאריך.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin with the words of my revered father, may his memory be a blessing, in his holy discourse to explain the words of the Midrash (brought in the City of David). Pharaoh said, "Who are the ones going?" You are destined to say, "Who will ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who will stand in His holy place?" This refers to "who are the ones going," and it is puzzling what this verse has to do with here. My revered father, may his memory be a blessing, explains it in the way of the secret according to the known that "who" is called the attribute of understanding (see Zohar, Introduction to Genesis, page 1b), and "who" with a "vav" hints at the attribute of foundation (see Zohar, Vayetze, 162). With this, we merit to understand the saying of our sages, may their memory be a blessing: "Who" refers to the attribute of understanding, which is to return in repentance all his days. He will ascend the mountain of the Lord, meaning he wishes to rise higher and higher on the mountain of the Lord by habituating himself in the attribute of understanding, which is to return in repentance all his days. And only resurrection cannot complete this building unless he first rectifies the attribute of foundation. This is what he concludes, and "who" with a "vav" hints at the attribute of foundation, "he will stand in His holy place." Through this, there will be resurrection for all his levels. And this is what Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, "Go, serve the Lord," etc., "Who are the ones going?" This means if you want to go to serve the Lord, you must first see if you have rectified the attribute of understanding, repentance, in advance of the attribute of foundation, hinted at by the "vav" of the word "who." For without this, what advantage is it for you to go to serve the name of the Lord, for He will not desire it if you have not rectified the attribute of foundation, which is the foundation and root of everything. And to this, Moses replied to that wicked one, "We will go with our young and with our old," as our sages, may their memory be a blessing, said (Sukkah 53a), "Blessed are our elders for they atoned for our youth," meaning that in old age they repented for what they blemished in youthful sins, and they rectified even the days of youth, and with both we will go to serve the Lord, as you have written, and a portion of His holy language, may He be blessed, that he elaborated.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the question posed by Pharaoh regarding who will go to serve God, linking it to the concepts of repentance and spiritual elevation in Hasidic thought. It emphasizes that true ascent to God's presence requires the rectification of the attribute of understanding (bina) and the foundation (yesod), suggesting that one must engage in continuous repentance to achieve spiritual growth. The text highlights the importance of addressing past transgressions, particularly those of youth, and how maturity and repentance can lead to a holistic service of God. Ultimately, it underscores that without rectifying these foundational attributes, one's efforts in divine service may be in vain.

passage_content: ובדרכו אלך בתוס' נופך לפרש גם סיפא דקרא בבנינו ובבנותנו וגו', גם מה שהקשה בכלי יקר דההולכים לשון הוה אינו מתיישב והול"ל מי ילך, דהנה לפי חשבון הרמב"ן ז"ל מכת הארבה הי' בחודש ניסן לא קודם לכן (עייש"ד עה"פ הנני מביא מחר ארבה) ואמרז"ל במכילתא עה"פ וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ה' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, וכי כבר עשו והלא מר"ח נאמר להם מצוה זו ולא עשו עד בעשור לחדש, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם הכתוב כאילו עשו עכ"ד המכילתא, עכ"פ מבואר שבאותה שעה שהתרה משרע"ה בהם על מכת הארבה, כבר קבלו ישראל ע"ע מצות הפסח ועשו הכנה לקדושה נפלאה שהשיגו בליל יציאתם, ובאמת כן צריך להיות בכל מעשה המצות להקדים בחי' הרצון בחשוקה וחפיצה ודבוקה עוד טרם הגיע לידו לקיימנה, ואז הקב"ה מחשבה לו למעשה, וע"ד שפי' בספה"ק סידורו של שבת (ח"ב דרוש ד') מאמרם ז"ל (ויק"ר פ' כ"ז סי' ב') מי הקדמני ואשלם, מי עשה לו מזוזה עד שלא נתתי לו בית, מי עשה לי מעקה עד שלא נתתי לו גג, מי הפריש לי תרומה עד שלא נתתי לו גורן וכו', ולכאורה יפלא דבריהם והלא ידוע שאין הקב"ה בא בטרוניא עם בריותיו כמאמר רז"ל (ע"ז ג' ע"א) מה יש לו לעשות האם יעשה לו מזוזה בלא בית או מעקה בלא גג וכו' אתמהה, כי אם אין בית אנא יקבע המזוזה וכו' ופי' הוא ז"ל כי המשכיל וההולך בדרך אהבת אמת של הקב"ה ותורתו, כל מחשבתו ודעתו סובב על זה רק לקיים מצות ה' ולעסוק בתורתו ורוצה בקיומן באמת וכו', הנה בתחילת מחשבת בנין הבית עיקר ויקר בעיניו לקיים מצות ה', ובונה הבית לשם כך כדי שיקיים בו מצות מזוזה או מעקה וכדומה, וכל יגיעותיו וטרחותיו הכל יעשה בשביל המצוה כי היא אהובה לו, וכמו"כ בלישת העיסה משים תוכן כוונתו בתחילת הלישה כדי לקיים מצות בוראו להפריש ממנה חלה או ליתן ממנו לעניים, וע"ז אמה"כ מי הקדמני ואשלם, כלומר הנה אמת שבסוף הבנין אתה עושה מזוזה ומעקה, ובסוף הלישה אתה מפריש חלה, אבל נראה מה הי' העיקר והחשוב בעיניך, ואיזה הקדמת במחשבתך בתחילת הבנין והעשי', אם בנית מתחילה כדי שיהי' לך מקום לקבוע מזוזה וכו', ואז בודאי אשלם לך לראותי שמצותי יקר וחשוב בעיניך וכו' עיי"ש שהאריך.
translation: And in his way, I will walk with an added nuance to explain also the end of the verse regarding our sons and our daughters, etc. Also, regarding what the Kli Yakar questioned about the phrase "the ones who go" being in the present tense, it should have said "who will go." Behold, according to the calculation of the Ramban, the plague of locusts occurred in the month of Nisan, not before (as explained there on the verse "Behold, I bring tomorrow a locust"). And our sages said in the Mechilta on the verse "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did," that they had already done it, but it was said to them from the beginning of the month that they were commanded this mitzvah, and they did not do it until the tenth of the month. Rather, since they accepted upon themselves, the verse considers it as if they had done it. Thus, it is explained in the Mechilta. In any case, it is clear that at the moment when Moshe warned them about the plague of locusts, the Israelites had already accepted upon themselves the mitzvah of Passover and made preparations for the wonderful sanctity they achieved on the night of their departure. And indeed, it should be so in every act of the mitzvot, to precede with a desire, longing, and attachment even before it comes to their hands to fulfill it. Then the Holy One, blessed be He, considers their thought as an action, and as it is explained in the holy books, in the order of Shabbat (Part 2, Discourse 4), their saying (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 27, Section 2) "Who has preceded me that I should repay him? Who made a mezuzah for me before I gave him a house? Who made a railing for me before I gave him a roof? Who separated terumah for me before I gave him a granary?" etc. And at first glance, their words are puzzling, for it is known that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not come to argue with His creatures, as our sages said (Avodah Zarah 3a), what is there for Him to do? Will He make a mezuzah without a house or a railing without a roof? I wonder, for if there is no house, how can one affix the mezuzah, etc.? And he explained that the wise one and the one who walks in the path of the true love of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His Torah, all his thoughts and knowledge revolve around this, only to fulfill the commandments of the Lord and to engage in His Torah, and he truly desires their fulfillment, etc. Behold, at the beginning of the thought of building the house, it is primary and precious in his eyes to fulfill the command of the Lord, and he builds the house for this purpose so that he can fulfill the mitzvah of mezuzah or railing, and similar things. All his efforts and labors he does for the sake of the mitzvah because it is beloved to him. Likewise, in kneading the dough, he places the intention at the beginning of the kneading to fulfill the command of his Creator to separate challah from it or to give from it to the poor. And regarding this, the verse says, "Who has preceded me that I should repay him?" Meaning, it is true that at the end of the building you make a mezuzah and a railing, and at the end of the kneading you separate challah, but it is seen what was the main and important thing in your eyes, and what did you prioritize in your thought at the beginning of the building and the action? If you built initially so that you would have a place to affix the mezuzah, etc., then surely I will repay you for seeing that My commandments are precious and important in your eyes, etc. As it is explained there, he elaborated.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of intention and desire in fulfilling commandments, illustrating that the act of performing a mitzvah should be preceded by a heartfelt yearning to serve God. It discusses how the Israelites, even before the actual observance of Passover, accepted the commandment with a profound commitment, which elevated their spiritual state. The text highlights that true fulfillment of mitzvot is rooted in the initial intention to honor God, suggesting that the value of a commandment lies not only in its execution but in the love and dedication behind it. Ultimately, it conveys that God recognizes and rewards the sincere intentions of those who prioritize His commandments in their lives.

passage_content: ובאמת אף שיש לאיש הישראלי רצון לעבוד את ה' ב"ה, אבל אית רצון ואית רצון, כמ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה (בתפלה למשה מ"ב) עה"פ צמאה נפשי לאלקים וגו', כי יש ב' בחינות צמאון, יש צמאון בלא חשוקה ודבוקה וחפיצה ובלא דחילא ורחימא, רק רצון פשוט שרצונו הי' שיהי' טוב, אבל אינו רוצה לעמול זה מקרי צמאון מת ולא פרחת לעילא, וכדברי הצה"ק מו"ה ר' אלימלך ז"ל רצון דרצון שרוצה שיהי' רוצה, אבל אין זה התגלות הרצון, אבל התגלות הרצון בהתגלות הלב בחשוקה ודבוקה וחפיצה בהתלהבות רשפי אש שלהבת י"ה רוצה להדבק בדחילא ורחימא עכלה"ק, והתגלות הרצון האמיתי ניכר במעשה האדם בתנועותיו ובהתרגשותו.
translation: And indeed, although the Jewish person has a desire to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, there are desires and there are desires, as it is written in Tehillim 42:2 (in the prayer of Moshe, chapter 2) regarding the verse "My soul thirsts for God," etc. For there are two aspects of thirst: there is a thirst without yearning, attachment, and desire, and without fear and compassion, just a simple desire that his will is for things to be good, but he does not want to toil; this is a mere thirst that does not elevate him. And as the holy tzaddik, Rabbi Elimelech, of blessed memory, said, it is a desire of desire that wants to want, but this is not the revelation of the will. Rather, the revelation of the will is in the revelation of the heart with yearning, attachment, and desire, with the enthusiasm of fiery sparks of the flame of Yud-Heh, wanting to cling with fear and compassion, as is known. And the revelation of the true will is evident in a person's actions, in his movements and in his excitement.
summary: The passage discusses the different levels of desire within a Jewish person's yearning to serve God. It contrasts a simple, unrefined desire for goodness with a deeper, passionate longing characterized by fervor and attachment to the Divine. True expression of this desire is revealed through one's actions and emotional engagement, reflecting a profound connection to God. The text emphasizes that genuine spiritual yearning is marked by both fear and love, leading to a more elevated and authentic relationship with the Divine.

passage_content: והנה פרעה הרשע הי' גדול מאוד בחכמת מרכבה הטמאה, ומשם השיג בחי' מדריגתם של ישראל עד היכן הם משוקעים בטומאת ותועבת מצרים, ולזה שאל קושיא חזקה למשה ואהרן, אתם אומרים נלכה נזבחה לה' אלקינו, שרוצים אתם להתדבק בקדושתו ית' ולעבוד עבודתו, נראה מי ומי ההולכים, מי הם אשר הכינו עצמם בהכנת קדושה להיות נמנה בין ההולכים מיד ע"ד מי הקדימני וכו', וע"כ לא אמר מי ומי ילך בעתיד, כי לא שאל על פעולת ההליכה בעצם רק מי הם אשר כבר עשו הכנה לזה לתקן מדת היסוד ולהקדים רצון האמיתי להיות נחשב לו כמעשה מיד.
translation: And behold, the wicked Pharaoh was very great in the wisdom of the impure chariot, and from there he grasped the level of the Israelites and to what extent they were sunk in the impurity and abomination of Egypt. Therefore, he posed a strong question to Moses and Aaron: You say we will go and sacrifice to the Lord our God, for you wish to cleave to His holiness and to serve His work. Let us see who are the ones going, who are those who have prepared themselves with the preparation of holiness to be counted among the ones going, immediately in accordance with "who has preceded me," etc. And thus he did not ask who will go in the future, for he did not inquire about the act of going itself, but rather who are those who have already made preparations for this, to rectify the attribute of foundation and to precede the true will to be considered as an act immediately.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's profound understanding of the spiritual state of the Israelites, recognizing their entanglement in the impurities of Egypt. He challenges Moses and Aaron by questioning who among the Israelites has prepared themselves for the holiness required to serve God, emphasizing the importance of spiritual readiness and intention. Pharaoh's inquiry reflects a deeper Hasidic concept that true service to God necessitates prior preparation and alignment of one's will with divine purpose, rather than mere action. This highlights the significance of inner transformation and the readiness of the heart in the pursuit of holiness.

passage_content: או אפ"ל ששאל פרעה מי המה הראויים להיות בין ההולכים, כי באמת לא היו ישראל ראויים להגאל עד רגע אחרונה, שהפלא ה' חסדו להעלותם לרום המעלות ועשו תשובה שלימה מאהבה והודו ושבחו להשי"ת באמירת הלל בהתעוררות נפלאה ואהבה עזה, ואז נעשה בהם השתנות גדול לטובה והיו ראויים להגאל, אמנם פרעה לא ידע העתיד וראה רק מצבם הנוכחי, וע"כ שאל מי ומי ההולכים ר"ל הראויים להיות בין ההולכים, ולזה לא אמר מי ילך כי לא שאל על עצם ההליכה כ"א על זכות ההליכה והבן.
translation: Or perhaps Pharaoh asked who are worthy to be among those going, for in truth the Israelites were not worthy of redemption until the very last moment, as the Holy One, blessed be He, performed wonders of His kindness to elevate them to great heights, and they repented completely out of love and praised and glorified the Blessed One with the recitation of Hallel in a wondrous awakening and intense love. Then a great transformation occurred within them for the good, and they became worthy of redemption. However, Pharaoh did not know the future and only saw their current state, and therefore he asked who are the ones going, meaning who are worthy to be among those going. For this reason, he did not say who will go, as he was not asking about the act of going itself, but rather about the merit of the going, understand this.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's inquiry about who among the Israelites was worthy to leave Egypt, highlighting that they were not deserving of redemption until the last moment. It emphasizes that through sincere repentance and heartfelt praise to God, the Israelites experienced a profound transformation that made them worthy of liberation. Pharaoh, however, could only perceive their current state and did not recognize their potential for change, focusing on their merit rather than the act of leaving itself. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine grace, the power of repentance, and the transformative nature of sincere devotion.

passage_content: אמנם תלונתו הנ"ל מעיקרא ליתא, דבאמת באותה שעה כבר עשו ישראל הכנה להדבק בקדושתו ית', וקבלו עליהם לקיים מצות הפסח מר"ח כמבואר במכילתא הנ"ל, ונוסף לזה הגדיל השי"ת חסדו עמהם בגאולת מצרים להעלותם שלא על סדר המדריגות רק בדרך דילוג וקפיצה ונתעלו בפ"א מדיוטא התחתונה לרום המעלות, וכמ"ש בספה"ק ופסח ה' על הפתח, להיות שצריך להקדים לכל דבר שבקדושה אתערותא דלתתא, כמ"ש רז"ל (שהש"ר פ' ה' סי' ג') פתחו לי פתח כפתחו של מחט ואני אפתח לכם כפתחו של אולם. אבל בגאולת מצרים הפליא ה' חסדו להקדים אתערותא דלעילא, וז"ש ופסח ה' על הפתח להושיעם טרם שפתחו פתח באתערותא דלתתא עכ"ד ז"ל, וע"כ מה ששאל בענין ההכנה מי הם הראויים להיגאל אינה שאלה, אמנם מה שנרמז בתיבת מ"י ומ"י ההולכים על תשובה ותיקון היסוד כמ"ש אאמו"ר זלה"ה, וזולת זה לא ירצה העבודה, ע"ז השיבו לו משה ואהרן ב' תשובות, בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, ע"ד שאמרז"ל (סוכה דף נ"ג ע"א) אשרי זקנותינו שכפרה על ילדותינו, היינו אף אלו שפגמו ר"ל בנערותם בחטא הנורא, עשו תשובה בעת זקנתם והעלו ותקנו אף ימי הנעורים ובשניהם נלך לעבוד את ה', וע"ד שפי' אאמו"ר זלה"ה, ואמר עוד בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך שנשתדל ונזדרז להשגיח על בנינו ובנותנו הקטנים שיתנהגו בטהרה ולא יתלכלכו בפגם מדת היסוד, וזה יהי' תקון גם לנפשינו, וז"ש בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך, שעל ידם נזכה גם אנו לילך ולהדבק בעבודת השי"ת.
translation: Indeed, his aforementioned complaint is unfounded, for at that time the Israelites had already made preparations to attach themselves to His holiness, and they accepted upon themselves to fulfill the commandments of Passover from the beginning of the month, as explained in the aforementioned Mekilta. In addition to this, the Holy One, blessed be He, magnified His kindness with them in the redemption from Egypt, elevating them not in accordance with the order of the levels, but rather through a manner of leaping and jumping, and they ascended from the lowest level to the heights, as it is written in the holy books, "And the Lord passed over the entrance," for it is necessary to precede every matter of holiness with an awakening from below, as our sages of blessed memory said (Shir HaShirim Rabbah, Parashah 5, Section 3), "Open for Me a door the size of a needle's eye, and I will open for you a door the size of a hall." But in the redemption from Egypt, the Lord astonished His kindness by preceding an awakening from above, and this is what is meant by "And the Lord passed over the entrance" to save them before they opened a door with an awakening from below. Therefore, what he asked regarding the preparation of who is worthy to be redeemed is not a question. However, what is hinted at in the words "Who" and "Who" refers to those who are engaged in repentance and rectification of the foundation, as my revered father, may his memory be blessed, said. Aside from this, the work would not be desired. To this, Moses and Aaron answered him with two responses: "With our young and with our old we will go," in accordance with what our sages of blessed memory said (Sukkah 53a), "Blessed are our elders for atoning for our youth," meaning that even those who blemished themselves, God forbid, in their youth with the terrible sin, repented in their old age and rectified even the days of their youth, and with both we will go to serve the Lord. And as my revered father, may his memory be blessed, explained further, "And with our sons and with our daughters we will go," meaning that we should strive and hasten to ensure that our young sons and daughters conduct themselves with purity and do not become sullied by the blemish of the foundation, and this will also be a rectification for our souls. This is what is meant by "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," for through them we will merit to also go and attach ourselves to the service of the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the preparation of the Israelites for their redemption from Egypt, emphasizing that they had already begun to connect with God's holiness by committing to the Passover commandments. It highlights the unique divine grace in their redemption, where God initiated the process without waiting for their own efforts, illustrating the concept of "at'ataruta d'le'ela" (higher awakening). The text also addresses the importance of repentance and the role of both the young and the old in spiritual growth, suggesting that through the purity and guidance of their children, individuals can achieve personal redemption and a deeper connection to God.

passage_content: או אפ"ל דעל שאלת פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, ר"ל מי הם הראויים להיגאל ובאיזה זכות כנ"ל, ע"ז השיבו משרע"ה בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך, בזכות שנדריך בנינו ובנותנו על דרך ה' ודרך התוה"ק, וזה כחו יפה על הגאולה כמו שהפליגו רז"ל (שבת דף קי"ט ע"ב) בשבח תשב"ר הבל פיהם שאין בו חטא שאין ערוך אלי', ובזכותם משרה הקב"ה שכינתו בישראל, ועי"ז יהי' תקנה גם לנו, כי בהכח וזכות של בנינו ובנותנו נזכה עוד גם אנו לעשות תשובה ראוי' והגונה, והשי"ת יעזור לנו שיתקיים בנו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, לתקן בימי הזקנה ולהעלות גם ימי הנעורים, ואם לא השלמנו אף זה כדבעי, נזכה עכ"פ בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך לגדל דורות ישרים ועל ידם נבנה גם אנו.
translation: Or perhaps regarding Pharaoh's question of who are going, meaning who are worthy of redemption and by what merit, to this Moshe Rabbeinu responded, "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," by the merit that we will guide our sons and daughters in the ways of Hashem and the ways of the Holy Torah. This is a strong merit for redemption, as our Sages have extolled (Shabbat 119b) the praise of the righteous whose words are without sin and are incomparable to Hashem. And by their merit, the Holy One, Blessed be He, rests His Shechinah among Israel, and through this there will be a remedy for us as well, for through the strength and merit of our sons and daughters, we too will merit to do true and fitting repentance. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help us that it be fulfilled in us, "With our young and with our old we will go," to rectify in the days of old age and to elevate also the days of youth. And if we have not completed this as it should be, may we at least merit, "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," to raise up righteous generations, and through them we will also build.
summary: The passage discusses the question posed by Pharaoh regarding who is worthy of redemption, to which Moses responds that they will go with their children, emphasizing the importance of educating the next generation in the ways of God and the Torah. This commitment to guiding their children is seen as a powerful merit for redemption, as it aligns with the idea that the purity of children can invoke God's presence among the people. The text highlights the belief that through the righteous upbringing of future generations, individuals can also achieve personal repentance and spiritual elevation, ultimately leading to collective redemption. The hope is expressed that both the young and the old will be able to contribute to this process of spiritual growth and renewal.

passage_content: ומעתה נבוא לבאר עפ"י דברי המדרש הובא בבעה"ט שהשיב משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ועל יתר מבן ס', ולפירוש זה צ"ב המשך דברי הפסוק בבנינו ובבנותנו, דכבר נכלל במאמר בנערינו ובזקנינו (עיין לעיל קושיא ב'), ויובן עפימ"ש בש"ך עה"ת (פ' דברים) בהקדם קושית המפורשים וכן הקשה באור החיים הק' שמצינו שהוכיח משרע"ה את ישראל על מה שהמרו על ים בים סוף, ויאמר האומר והלא אותם שהמרו על ים סוף כבר מתו ונשלמו בט"ו באב של שנת המ' קודם מאמר זה של משה, וא"כ אלה הצאן מה עשו שמוכיחם עיי"ש תירוצו, ובש"ך עה"ת כתב לתרץ דשפיר הוכיחם דעכשיו כבר חזרו ונתגלגלו בהם אותם החוטאים וידעו בעצמן ולזה שתקו ע"כ, נמצא דאותו הדור שנכנסו לא"י הם בעצמן היו דור המדבר שנתגלגלו עוה"פ בבניהם.
translation: And from now on we will explain according to the words of the Midrash brought in the Be'er HaTev, that Moshe replied, "With our young and with our old we will go," for a decree was not issued on those less than twenty years old and on those more than fifty. According to this interpretation, the continuation of the verse regarding "our sons and our daughters" is puzzling, as it is already included in the statement "with our young and with our old" (see above the question in section B). This will be understood according to what is stated in the Shach on the Torah (Parashat Devarim) in advance of the question of the commentators, and so the Ohr HaChaim HaKadosh also asked, for we find that he reproached Yisrael for rebelling at the Sea of Reeds, and he said, "But those who rebelled at the Sea of Reeds have already died and were completed on the fifteenth of Av of the fortieth year before this statement of Moshe." Therefore, what did these sheep do that he reproached them? See there for his answer. And in the Shach on the Torah, he wrote to answer that he reproached them because now those sinners had returned and reincarnated in them, and they knew it themselves, and for this reason they were silent. Thus, it turns out that that generation that entered the Land of Israel were themselves the generation of the desert who had reincarnated in their children.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses' statement about leading the Israelites, emphasizing that the decree against the sinners was not applicable to those under twenty and over sixty. It raises a question about the inclusion of "our sons and daughters" in the context of the previous mention of "our young and old." The text suggests that the current generation entering the Promised Land is a reincarnation of the previous generation that sinned, indicating a belief in the cyclical nature of souls and the continuity of spiritual responsibility across generations. This reflects a deep theological insight into the connection between past and present, as well as the enduring consequences of actions.

passage_content: ולפי"ז אפ"ל דעל שאלת פרעה מי ומי ההולכים ליכנס לארץ כי כולם ימותו במדבר, השיבו משרע"ה ב' תשובות בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ולא על יתר מבן ס' כמ"ש בבעה"ט, ועוד השיבו בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך, שאף מתי מדבר יכנסו לא"י ע"י שיתגלגלו עוה"פ בבניהם כדברי הש"ך עה"ת, ובזה יובן מה שחלקן לשתים גם כפל מלת נלך ב"פ על שהם ב' בחי' הליכות, או אפשר שירמוז על לעתיד שאז יקומו מתי מדבר ויעמדו בגופם וע"כ כפל עוה"פ נלך. וכמו"כ בחורבן הנורא שהי' בימינו שנאבדו בעוה"ר אלפים ורבבות מישראל, מי יודע אם לא חזרו כבר ונתגלגלו בבנינו ובנותנו, והדור של עכשיו הם חלק מאותו הדור וניצוצי נשמתם, ועלינו מוטל לגדל אלו הבנים בדרך התוה"ק שיזכו לקבל פני משיח צדקינו, ועל כל אב מוטל להשגיח על בניו שיתנהגו בטהרה ולא יתלכלכו בעונות ח"ו ויהיו זכאין ובזה יהי' תיקון גם לנפשנו.
translation: According to this, it can be said that in response to Pharaoh's question of who is going to enter the land, since they will all die in the desert, Moshe Rabbeinu answered with two responses: "With our young and with our old we will go," for it was not decreed that anyone under the age of twenty or over the age of sixty would die, as stated in the Ba'al HaTurim. Furthermore, he answered, "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," for even those who died in the desert will enter the Land of Israel through their children, as stated by the Shach in his commentary on the Torah. This explains why they were divided into two and why the word "we will go" is repeated twice, as they represent two aspects of going. Alternatively, it may hint at the future when the dead of the desert will rise and stand in their bodies, and therefore the repetition of "we will go." Similarly, in the terrible destruction that occurred in our days, when thousands and tens of thousands of Jews were lost, who knows if they have not already returned and been reincarnated in our sons and daughters? The generation of now is part of that generation, and their soul sparks are within us. It is our duty to raise these children in the way of the holy Torah so that they merit to greet the Messiah, our righteous one. And it is incumbent upon every father to ensure that his children behave with purity and do not become tainted by sins, Heaven forbid, so that they may be worthy, and in this way, there will also be a rectification for our own souls.
summary: The passage discusses the responses of Moses to Pharaoh's question about who would enter the Promised Land, emphasizing that the decree of death in the desert did not apply to those under twenty or over sixty. It highlights the belief that the souls of those who died in the desert could be reincarnated in their descendants, suggesting a connection between past generations and the current one. The text underscores the responsibility of parents to raise their children in accordance with Torah values, ensuring they are spiritually pure and prepared for the coming of the Messiah, thus facilitating the rectification of both their souls and those of their ancestors.

passage_content: ולבאר יתר הדקדוקים עה"פ כי חג ה' לנו גם עה"כ גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות וגו', נקדים מ"ד במד"ר (פ' וארא פ' י"א סי' ה') מהו ולא ימות מכל לבני ישראל דבר, אפי' בהמה שהיתה ביד מצרי והי' לו לישראל תרעומת עלי' שיש לו חלק בה היתה ניצולת ובכך ידעו דינן של ישראל עכ"ד המדרש, והנה האומות אומרים אם בגופן שלטו בנשותיהם עאכו"כ, אבל האמת לא כן שהיו ישראל גדורים בעריות ושמרו קדושתם במסנ"פ וכמ"ש רז"ל (ויק"ר פ' ל"ב סימן ה') אחת היתה ופרסמה הכתוב, ובזכות יוסף הצדיק נגדרו כל ישראל בעריות, אכן על מקניהם של ישראל בוודאי שלטו המצריים וגזלו מקנה ישראל, ולא הי' להם מי שיצדיק את דינם, ובערכאותיהם היו מצדיקים את המצרי ונשארו הבהמות אצלם, אבל באמת מצד הדין הרי זה מקנה ישראל אלא שהם ביד המצרי.
translation: To explain the additional nuances of the grammar regarding the verse "For the festival of the Lord is upon us," as well as "You too will give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings," we will first introduce what is stated in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'era, Parashah 11, Section 5): What does it mean "and no one from among the children of Israel shall die"? Even an animal that was in the possession of an Egyptian, if a Jew had a grievance against it because he had a share in it, it was spared, and thus they knew the judgment of Israel. Thus far the Midrash. And behold, the nations say, if they had control over their own bodies, how much more so over their wives! But the truth is not so, for the Israelites were guarded against immorality and preserved their sanctity with great vigilance, as our sages have said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 5): "There was one [woman] and the Scripture made it known." And by the merit of Joseph the Righteous, all of Israel were safeguarded against immorality. However, concerning the livestock of Israel, the Egyptians certainly had dominion over them and seized the property of Israel, and there was no one to justify their judgment. In their courts, they would justify the Egyptian, and the animals remained with them. But in truth, according to the law, it is indeed the property of Israel, only that it is in the hands of the Egyptian.
summary: The passage discusses the divine protection granted to the Israelites during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that even their animals were safeguarded from death, reflecting their spiritual purity and adherence to moral laws. It highlights the distinction between the Israelites and the Egyptians, noting that while the Egyptians could claim ownership over the Israelites' livestock, the true ownership remained with the Israelites due to their righteousness. The text underscores the importance of maintaining holiness and the role of Joseph's righteousness in preserving the moral integrity of the Israelite community. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological concept of divine justice, where true ownership and moral standing are recognized by God, despite external circumstances.
