passage_content: והנה לא מצינו בכל המכות ששלח פרעה לראות אם שלטה גם בבנ"י, ומה נשתנה מכת דבר דכתיב בו וישלח פרעה והנה לא מת ממקנה ישראל עד אחד, ואפ"ל דגם במכה זו לא שלח לראות בבתי ישראל כי כבר ידע כי הפלה ה' להבדיל את ישראל ולהצילם, אבל שלח לבית המצרים לראות אם שלטה הדבר בבהמה שהיתה ביד המצרי והי' לו לישראל תרעומת עלי', וע"ז אמר והנה לא מת ממקנה ישראל עד אחד, שאף אלו לא מתו מפני שהם מקנה ישראל מצד הדין כנ"ל, ואיתא בגמ' גזל ולא נתיאשו הבעלים שניהם אינם יכולים להקדישו, זה מפני שאינו שלו וזה מפני שאינו ברשותו, ולפי"ז המקנה שגזלו המצריים לא יכלו בנ"י להקדישם עד שלא הי' ברשותם, ובזה יובן מה שאמר משה רבינו לפרעה גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות, הכוונה על מקנה ישראל שיחזירום לרשותם, כי משמעות ידו יתפרש ברשותו וכמ"ש ויקח את כל ארצו מידו פירש"י מרשותו, וז"ש גם אתה תתן המקנה שלנו בידינו ר"ל ברשותינו ואז נוכל להקדישו וז"ש ועשינו לה' אלקינו, ואין הכוונה שפרעה יתן משלו כי אין חפץ לה' בזבח רשעים, אלא שיחזיר לישראל את שלהם.
translation: And behold, we do not find in all the plagues that Pharaoh sent to see if it also affected the Children of Israel, and what is different about the plague of pestilence, of which it is written, "And Pharaoh sent, and behold, not one of the livestock of Israel died." And it can be said that also in this plague he did not send to see in the houses of Israel, for he already knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, had distinguished to separate Israel and save them. Rather, he sent to the Egyptians' houses to see if the pestilence affected the livestock that was in the hands of the Egyptians, and the Israelites would have had a grievance against Him. And concerning this, it is said, "And behold, not one of the livestock of Israel died," for even these did not die because they are the livestock of Israel by law, as mentioned above. And it is stated in the Gemara that if one steals and the owners have not despaired, neither can they consecrate it, this is because it is not his, and this is because it is not in his possession. According to this, the livestock that the Egyptians stole could not be consecrated by the Children of Israel until it was in their possession. And this explains what our teacher Moses said to Pharaoh, "You too will give us sacrifices and burnt offerings," meaning concerning the livestock of Israel that they should return to their possession, for the meaning of "hand" will be interpreted as "in his possession," as it is written, "And he took all his land out of his hand," Rashi explains, "from his possession." Therefore, it is said, "You too will give our livestock into our hands," meaning into our possession, and then we will be able to consecrate it, as it is said, "And we will make sacrifices to the Lord our God." And the intention is not that Pharaoh should give from his own, for the Holy One, blessed be He, has no desire for the sacrifices of the wicked, but rather that he should return to Israel what is theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction in the plagues sent by Pharaoh, particularly focusing on the plague of livestock, where not a single animal belonging to the Israelites died. It emphasizes that God separated and protected the Israelites, highlighting the theological concept of divine intervention and justice. The text also explains that the Egyptians could not dedicate the stolen livestock because it was not rightfully theirs, and thus, Moses' request to Pharaoh was for the return of the Israelites' property so they could offer sacrifices to God. This underscores the importance of rightful ownership and the idea that offerings to God must come from what is genuinely one's own.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יובן מה שחזר לומר וגם מקננו ילך עמנו דמיותר ומובן מאליו (עיין קושיא ה') אמנם המקנה של ישראל שהי' ביד המצריים לא נתייאשו ממנו הבעלים שהיו מצפים לישועה שיוסר מעליהם שלטנותם ויחזרוהו להם בהכרח, ואפשר שאעפ"כ לא רצו ליהנות מהם שהוא כמעשה נסים והקדישום לשמים, אבל מקניהם שברשותם אין הכרח להקדיש כולם, ואולי הספיק המקנה שהי' ביד המצריים לכך הדגיש לומר גם מקננו ילך עמנו לא תשאר פרסה כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה' אלקינו, שינה הלשון ולא אמר ועשינו לה' אלקינו כמו במקניהם, ואפ"ל הכוונה עפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה בישמח משה (פ' צו) לפרש הכתוב ואם האכל יאכל וגו' ביום השלישי לא ירצה המקריב אותו לא יחשב לו פגול יהי' וגו', ותוכן הדברים דעיקר הוא דע"י הקרבן ישים החוטא אל לבו, ויחשוב בעצמו מה זה שבשביל שחטאתי אני ישחט תמורתי בע"ח שלא חטאה ואין עול בכפה, ובוודאי אין זה כ"א השתעבדות הפחות להנכבד ממנו, ומזה יבוא החוטא ליקח ק"ו בעצמו, ומה אם הבע"ח לנגד האדם, אשר לא בראו ולא גמלו כל טוב כך, עאכו"כ איך ראוי להאדם להשתעבד ולהכנע לממ"ה הקב"ה שבראו והוציאו מאין ליש, ומזה יבוא לחשוב עם קונהו וישוב בתשובה שלימה וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: And according to this, it will be understood what he repeated to say, "And also our cattle will go with us," which seems superfluous and self-evident (see question 5). However, the cattle of Israel that were in the hands of the Egyptians were not despaired of by their owners, who were hoping for salvation that their dominion would be removed from them, and they would necessarily return it to them. And it is possible that even so, they did not want to benefit from them, as it is like a miracle, and they consecrated them to Heaven. But their cattle that were in their possession do not necessarily all need to be consecrated, and perhaps the cattle that were in the hands of the Egyptians sufficed for this, hence it emphasizes to say, "Also our cattle will go with us," that not a hoof will remain behind, for from it we will take to serve the Lord our God. The language is changed, and it does not say, "And we will do for the Lord our God," as it does with their cattle. And it can be said that the intention is according to what is stated in Psalm 107, as it is said in "Moses rejoiced" (Parashat Tzav) to explain the verse, "And if the meat is eaten... on the third day, the one who offers it will not be accepted; it will be considered piggul," etc. The essence of the matter is that through the offering, the sinner will place it in his heart and think to himself, "What is this, that because I have sinned, I will slaughter my substitute, an animal that has not sinned and bears no guilt?" And certainly, this is nothing but the subjugation of the lesser to the greater. From this, the sinner will come to take a fortiori for himself: if the animal is before man, which he did not create and did not repay with any good, how much more so is it fitting for man to be subjugated and to submit to the Master of the Universe, the Holy One, blessed be He, who created him and brought him from nothing to something. From this, he will come to think with his Creator and return in complete repentance, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' livestock in the context of their liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their owners did not despair of reclaiming it, as they anticipated divine intervention. It highlights the idea that while some livestock may be dedicated to God, not all need to be, and underscores the importance of recognizing the spiritual implications of sacrifices. The act of offering a sacrifice serves as a reminder to the sinner of their wrongdoing and the need for humility before God, prompting genuine repentance and a deeper understanding of their relationship with the Creator.

passage_content: וז"ש וגם מקנינו ילך עמנו אע"פ שלא נקריב כולם לה' זבחים ועולות אבל יש לנו צורך בהם, כי ממנו דייקא נקח לעבוד את ה', דממה ששוחטין בהמה לצורך אכילה יכולין ג"כ ללמוד ק"ו הנ"ל השתעבדות הפחות לנכבד, וכמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה שם דזהו כוונת אמרם ז"ל (ברכות דף נ"ה ע"א) שולחנו של אדם דומה למזבח, דמה ששוחט בהמות ועופות למאכלו ע"כ מטעם השתעבד פחות לנכבד, א"כ גם מזה יקח ק"ו הנ"ל לעצמו להשתעבד לרוממות הבורא ית', וז"פ כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה', אף אם לא נקריבנו לה' זבחים ועולות, יש צורך לנו בהם לעבודת ה', ואנחנו לא נדע מה נעבוד את ה', לעשות חשבון הנ"ל עד בואנו שמה, וכשנבוא שמה נלמוד דרך העבודה ההוא.
translation: And this is what is meant by saying that even our livestock will go with us, even though we will not all bring offerings and burnt sacrifices to the Lord, but we have a need for them, for from them specifically we will take to serve the Lord. For the fact that one slaughters an animal for the purpose of eating, one can also learn a fortiori from this the subjugation of the lesser to the greater, as it is written in the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, that this is the intention of what our sages, of blessed memory, said (Berakhot 55a) that a person's table is like an altar, for the reason that he slaughters animals and fowl for his food, thus it is a matter of subjugating the lesser to the greater. Therefore, from this one can also take the aforementioned a fortiori for oneself to be subjugated to the exaltedness of the Creator, blessed be He. And indeed, from them we will take to serve the Lord, even if we do not bring them as offerings and burnt sacrifices to the Lord, we have a need for them for the service of the Lord, and we will not know how we will serve the Lord, to make the aforementioned accounting until we arrive there. And when we arrive there, we will learn that way of service.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of utilizing one's possessions, even if not directly offered as sacrifices, to serve God. It draws a parallel between the act of slaughtering animals for food and the concept of dedicating lesser things to the divine, highlighting the idea that all aspects of life can be transformed into a form of worship. The text suggests that even without formal offerings, the intention behind using these resources for divine service is crucial. Ultimately, it conveys that the true understanding of how to serve God will be revealed in the future.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר מ"ש רש"י ז"ל בפסוק גם צאנכם גם בקרכם קחו כאשר דברתם ולכו, מהו כאשר דברתם גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות, (עיין קושיא ו') ולדרכינו כוונת הפסוק על מקניהם של ישראל שנטלוהו המצריים שלא כדין, ואז הודה פרעה שהאמת והצדק אתם בטענתם, ועל זה הכוונה אמר משה תחלה גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות וכנ"ל, ועכשיו הודה לדברי משה באומרו גם צאנכם גם בקרכם קחו, ר"ל אותן השייכים באמת לכם כאשר דברתם שהי' לכם תרעומת על המצריים ולא יכולתם להוציאם בדין, עכשיו קחו אותם לכם ולכו.
translation: And this will clarify what Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote on the verse "Also your flocks and also your herds take as you have spoken, and go." What does it mean "as you have spoken, also you will give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings"? (See the question, etc.) According to our approach, the intention of the verse is regarding the cattle of Israel that the Egyptians took from them unjustly. Then Pharaoh admitted that the truth and justice were on their side in their claim. And this is the intention of what Moses said first, "Also you will give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings," as mentioned above. And now he acknowledged Moses' words by saying, "Also your flocks and also your herds take," meaning those that truly belong to you, as you have spoken, that you had a grievance against the Egyptians and could not extract them through justice. Now take them for yourselves and go.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Pharaoh's acknowledgment of the Israelites' rightful claim to their livestock, which had been unjustly taken by the Egyptians. It highlights the concept of divine justice, where Moses asserts that the Israelites are entitled to their sacrifices and offerings as a reflection of their truth and righteousness. Pharaoh's eventual agreement to return the livestock symbolizes a recognition of the moral and ethical claims of the Israelites, reinforcing the idea that justice prevails in the face of oppression. This exchange underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of truth and the ultimate vindication of the oppressed.

passage_content: וזה שאמר משה לפרעה בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך כי חג ה' לנו, פי' שנקח עמנו כל הצאן ובקר אשר לנו כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה' ללמוד חשבון השתעבדות פחות לנכבד, ואף אם לא נקריב כולן זבחים ועולות וכנ"ל, ע"כ סיים ואמר כי חג ה' לנו ר"ל אפילו ממה שנשחוט לעצמינו לצורך החג שצריך להיות חציו לכם גם מזה ניקח חשבון לעבוד את ה', ובזה יובנו שני המדרשים הנ"ל בפסוק כי חג ה' לנו זה חג הסוכות, ובמדרש רבינו בחיי כתב זה חג השבועות, כי עה"פ הנאמר בחג הסוכות עצרת תהי' לכם דרשו בגמ' (פסחים ס"ח ע"ב) שצריך להיות חציו לכם, ובשבועות הכל מודים דבעינן נמי לכם כמו שאמרו שם, ומזה ראי' שגם עבודת האכילה הוא עבודת ה', משא"כ מפסח א"א להביא ראי' כי שם כתיב עצרת לה' אלקיך, אבל מסוכות ושבועות איכא ראי' מדחייבה תורה לעשות חציו לכם ש"מ שגם זהו עבדות ה', וע"כ צריכין אנו למקננו כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה', ומתורץ ג"כ קושית הכלי יקר במאמה"כ כי חג ה' לנו (לעיל קושיא א') והבן.
translation: And this is what Moses said to Pharaoh: "We will go with our flocks and our herds, for we must hold a feast to the Lord." This means that we will take with us all the sheep and cattle that we have, for from them we will take to serve the Lord, to learn the accounting of servitude, which is less than the honorable. And even if we do not offer all of them as sacrifices and burnt offerings, as mentioned above, therefore he concluded and said, "for we must hold a feast to the Lord," meaning that even from what we will slaughter for ourselves for the purpose of the feast, which must be half for you, we will also take into account to serve the Lord. And in this, the two Midrashim mentioned above on the verse "for we must hold a feast to the Lord" will be understood, that this refers to the Feast of Sukkot, and in the Midrash of Rabbeinu Bachaye, it is written that this refers to the Feast of Shavuot, for regarding the verse stated about the Feast of Sukkot, "You shall have a holy convocation," the Gemara (Pesachim 68b) interprets that it must be half for you. And regarding Shavuot, all agree that we also need "for you," as they said there. And from this, it is evident that even the work of eating is the work of the Lord, unlike Passover, from which one cannot bring proof, for there it is written "a holy convocation for the Lord your God." But from Sukkot and Shavuot, there is proof from the obligation of the Torah to make it half for you, which teaches us that this is also the servitude of the Lord. Therefore, we need to take care of our livestock, for from them we will take to serve the Lord. This also resolves the question of the Kli Yakar on the verse "for we must hold a feast to the Lord" (above, question 1), and understand.
summary: Moses' declaration to Pharaoh about taking their livestock for the festival emphasizes the importance of using their resources for divine service, highlighting that even their personal needs can be part of their worship. The passage connects the concept of the festivals, particularly Sukkot and Shavuot, to the idea that the act of eating and celebrating is also a form of serving God, as it requires a balance between personal enjoyment and spiritual obligation. This reflects a deeper understanding of servitude to God, where even mundane activities can be elevated to acts of worship. Ultimately, the text illustrates that all aspects of life, including sustenance and celebration, can be integrated into one's devotion to God.

translation: And Moses said, "We will go with our young and with our old... for it is a festival of the Lord for us." In the Midrash, "for it is a festival of the Lord for us" refers to the festival of Sukkot, and the question remains.
summary: Moses emphasizes the importance of celebrating the festival of Sukkot, indicating that both the young and the old will participate in this sacred observance. The phrase "כי חג ד' לנו" highlights the divine significance of the holiday, suggesting that it is a time for communal unity and spiritual elevation. The reference to Sukkot in the Midrash underscores the connection between physical shelter and divine protection, reflecting a deeper understanding of faith and reliance on God. This passage encapsulates the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of communal worship and the celebration of divine presence in everyday life.

passage_content: ב) משה כה אמר ה' כחצות הלילה אני יוצא בתוך מצרים, בגמ' ברכות (דף ג' ע"ב) הקשו ודוד מי הו' ידע פלגא דלילא אימת, השתא משרע"ה לא ידע דכתיב כחצות לילה וגו' אלמא מספקא לי', ודוד הו' ידע, ותירצו בגמ', דוד סימנא הוה ליה וכו', כינור היה תלוי למעלה ממטתו וכו', וכיון שהגיע חצות לילה בא רוח צפונית ונושבת בו ומנגן מאליו וכו' עכ"ד הגמרא, ולכאורה קושית הגמ' חוזר וניעור, דאף לפי תירוצם אמאי מספקא לי' למשרע"ה ודוד הו' ידע, וכמו"כ הי' יכול משרע"ה לכוין ע"י סימנא דכינור ורוח צפונית.
translation: B) Moses said, "Thus says the Lord: At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt." In the Gemara Berakhot (page 3b), they asked, "And how did David know the exact time of midnight?" Now, since Moshe Rabbeinu did not know, as it is written, "At midnight," it implies that it was uncertain for him, while David did know. The Gemara answers that David had a sign, etc. A harp was hanging above his bed, etc. When midnight arrived, a northern wind would blow upon him and play by itself, etc. Thus concludes the Gemara. And at first glance, the question of the Gemara returns and arises, for even according to their answer, why was it uncertain for Moshe Rabbeinu while David did know? Similarly, Moshe Rabbeinu could have also focused through the sign of the harp and the northern wind.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of God's intervention in Egypt at midnight, as mentioned in the Torah, and contrasts the knowledge of Moses and David regarding this moment. The Talmud raises a question about why Moses was uncertain about the exact time, while David seemed to have a clear sign through a harp that played by itself at midnight. This highlights the theme of divine revelation and the different levels of awareness among the righteous, suggesting that while Moses had a direct connection to God, David's understanding was mediated through signs, reflecting the complexity of spiritual insight and the nature of divine communication.

passage_content: ג) ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, ובמכילתא מהו כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, והקושיא מפורסמת דמה צורך לדרשא, ובודאי שמשה ואהרן קיימו מצות הבוי"ת שצו' לכל ישראל.
translation: 3) And the children of Israel did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; thus they did. And in the Mekilta, what does it mean, "thus they did"? Even Moses and Aaron did so. And the well-known question is, what is the need for the teaching? And certainly, Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandments of the Creator that were commanded to all of Israel.
summary: The passage emphasizes the obedience of the Israelites to God's commands as conveyed through Moses and Aaron, highlighting the importance of following divine instruction. It raises a question about the necessity of interpreting the phrase "they did so" in relation to Moses and Aaron, suggesting that their adherence to God's commandments serves as a model for all of Israel. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the unity between leaders and their community in fulfilling divine will. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of collective observance of commandments as a pathway to spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ד) הקשה עה"פ ועתה נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים במדבר ונזבחה לה' אלקינו (שמות ג'), למה יצו ד' לעשות דרך ערמה, כי ח"ו לא קצור קצרה ידו מפדות ישראל בעל כרחם של מצרים ועיניהם רואות וכלות, ותירץ כי נתכוין ד' בזה להטעותם, כדי שירדפו אחריהם להכבד בפרעה וכו', ודקדקתי בכל הדברים הנאמרים בענין ואין בהם דבר שקר, כי לא הזכירו בלשונם החזרה כלל, ולצד מעלת קדוש אלקי ישראל, לא רצה לכנות הדברים אליו, אלא הם בני ישראל ידברו כזה ולזה אמר תיבת ועתה, פי' לומר כי הם דברי עצמם לא דברי עליון וכו' עכ"ל, אמנם עדיין צ"ב כי כל מה שנכתב בתוה"ק הוא אמת לאמיתו, ודברי משרע"ה אף אם אמרם מפי עצמו הם אמיתיים בכל אופן ואופן, מה גם שחזר ושנה טענה זו פעמים הרבה, כמ"ש שלח עמי ויחוגו לי במדבר, נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה, בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך כי חג ד' לנו, ולא מצינו שהי' הליכתם על מנת לזבוח במדבר, וצ"ב לקרב הענין עפ"י פשוטו.
translation: D) The difficulty arises from the verse, "And now let us go three days' journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God" (Exodus 3:18). Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, command them to take a deceptive route? For, Heaven forbid, His hand is not too short to redeem Israel from the Egyptians against their will, and their eyes see and are consumed. The explanation is that the Holy One intended to mislead them, so that they would pursue them to burden Pharaoh, etc. I have scrutinized all the words mentioned in this matter, and there is nothing false in them, for they did not mention in their language the return at all. And due to the exaltedness of the Holy One of Israel, He did not want to attribute the words to Himself, but rather the Children of Israel would speak in this manner. Therefore, He said the word "and now," meaning to say that these are their own words, not the words of the Supreme, etc. However, it is still necessary to clarify that everything written in the Torah is true in its essence, and the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, even if he spoke them from his own mouth, are true in every way. Moreover, he repeated this claim many times, as it is said, "Let My people go, that they may hold a feast for Me in the wilderness," "Let us go three days' journey and sacrifice," "We will go with our flocks and our herds, for we must hold a feast to the Lord." Yet, we do not find that their going was with the intention to sacrifice in the wilderness, and it is necessary to bring the matter closer according to its simple meaning.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in God's command for the Israelites to take a roundabout route in their escape from Egypt, suggesting that this was a divine strategy to mislead the Egyptians into pursuing them. The author emphasizes that while Moses' words may seem to reflect the Israelites' own intentions, they are nonetheless true and divinely inspired. The text raises questions about the nature of truth in the Torah and the authenticity of Moses' statements, highlighting the complexity of divine communication and human expression in the context of faith. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound relationship between God's will and the actions of His people.

passage_content: ויתבאר הענין בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' יתרו) אתם ראיתם אשר עשיתי למצרים ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים ואביא אתכם אלי ועתה אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי וגו' והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים כי לי כל הארץ, ובתרגום יוב"ע פי' וטענית יתכון על עננין וכו' ואובילית יתכון לאתר בית מקדשא למעבד תמן פסחא וכו', ולכאורה לפירושו צ"ב, דהרי הרבה נסים נעשו לישראל ביציאת מצרים ומדוע הזכיר נס זה דייקא, שהעננים הוליכו את ישראל למקום המקדש לעשות פסחיהן וחזרו אח"כ למצרים, ומהו הקישור אל מה דסמיך לי' ועתה אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי והייתם לי סגולה.
translation: And the matter will be clarified by first explaining the verse (in Parshat Yitro) "You have seen what I did to the Egyptians, and I carried you on the wings of eagles and brought you to Me. And now, if you will listen to My voice, etc., you shall be a treasured people to Me from all the nations, for all the earth is Mine." And in the translation of Yov"an it is explained, "And I will bring you to the site of the Holy Temple to perform the Passover there," etc. And at first glance, according to his explanation, it is puzzling, for many miracles were performed for Israel at the Exodus from Egypt, and why specifically mention this miracle that the clouds led Israel to the place of the Temple to perform their Passover, and then returned to Egypt? And what is the connection to what is stated afterwards, "And now, if you will listen to My voice, you shall be a treasured people to Me"?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's miraculous guidance of the Israelites through clouds during the Exodus, emphasizing that this specific miracle symbolizes a deeper connection to the divine. It raises questions about why this particular miracle is highlighted among many others, suggesting that it serves as a precursor to the covenantal relationship established at Sinai, where the Israelites are called to be a treasured people. The reference to the journey to the Temple for the Passover underscores the importance of spiritual elevation and connection to sacred practices. Ultimately, it illustrates the theme of divine selection and the responsibilities that come with being chosen.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהי' רצון הבוי"ת שישחטו ישראל פסחיהן כדינו בפסח דורות, דאין שוחטין את הפסח אלא בעזרה דכתיב לא תוכל לזבוח את הפסח באחד שעריך, אמנם לא היו ישראל ראויים עדיין ליכנס לארץ ישראל, כי לכל הוקצב זמן מאתו ית', ובפרט ביאת הארץ תליא בזמן כמשה"כ ודור רביעי ישובו הנה, וא"א להקדים אף רגע א' לפני הזמן, ואפשר דלחביבותן של ישראל עשה הקב"ה להם נס, שנעקר מקום המקדש ובא לקראתם במדבר ושם הקריבו קרבן פסח וע"ד שאמרז"ל שנעקר הר המורי' ובא לקראת יעאע"ה שיתפלל בתוכה, ואולי זהו טעם הכתוב נלכה דרך שלשת ימים ונזבחה לד' אלקינו הכוונה על זביחת קרבן פסח שהי' הכרח לפני יציאתם, כאמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' ט"ז סימן ג') אמר הקב"ה חייך אין ישראל יוצאים מכאן עד שישחטו אלהיהן וכו' והנה מצרים היתה מלאה גילולים, ומצינו שמה"ט לא התפלל משה בתוך העיר, ומכ"ש שלא הי' ראוי שיעקר מקום המקדש לתוכה, ועד מהלך ג' ימים אתחזק טומאה, וכדמצינו לגבי טומאת נדה דבג' ימים ראשונים אתחזק טומאתה, ואיתא בזוה"ק דישראל כד נפקו ממצרים הוצרכו ספירת נקיים לצאת מטומאתם כנדה.
translation: And it seems that it was the will of the Blessed Creator that the Jews should slaughter their Passover offerings as is proper during the Passover of generations, for one does not slaughter the Passover except in the Temple courtyard, as it is written, "You shall not sacrifice the Passover in any of your gates." However, the Jews were not yet worthy to enter the Land of Israel, for a time was appointed for everything by Him, blessed be He, and especially the entry into the land is dependent on time, as it is said, "And the fourth generation shall return here," and it is impossible to advance even a single moment before the time. It is possible that for the sake of the beloved of Israel, the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a miracle for them, that the place of the Temple was uprooted and came to meet them in the desert, and there they offered the Passover sacrifice, in accordance with what our Sages of blessed memory said, that the mountain of Moriah was uprooted and came to meet Abraham to pray within it. And perhaps this is the reason for the verse, "Let us go a three days' journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God," referring to the slaughtering of the Passover sacrifice, which was necessary before their departure, as our Sages of blessed memory said in Midrash (Parashat 16, Siman 3), the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I swear, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter their sacrifices," etc. And behold, Egypt was full of idols, and we find that for this reason Moses did not pray within the city, and certainly it was not fitting for the place of the Temple to be uprooted into it. And for a journey of three days, they would become impure, as we find regarding the impurity of a menstruant, that in the first three days, her impurity is strengthened. And it is stated in the Zohar that when Israel left Egypt, they needed to count themselves clean to exit from their impurity like a menstruant.
summary: The passage discusses the divine will for the Israelites to sacrifice the Passover offering in the wilderness, despite their unworthiness to enter the Land of Israel at that time. It emphasizes that the timing of events is predetermined by God, and that a miracle occurred allowing the Temple's location to be moved to accommodate the Israelites in the desert. The text also highlights the necessity of purification for the Israelites, paralleling their need for spiritual readiness with the laws of ritual purity, as they prepared to leave Egypt, a land filled with idolatry.

passage_content: ומעתה נבין כי כל טענותיו של משרע"ה במ"ש נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה לד' וגו', כי חג ד' לנו, ויחוגו לי במדבר, הם כולם אמת ואין בהם עקש ונפתול, ולא על הליכה המוחלטת בקש רשותו, כ"א על הליכה זמנית שילכו להקריב קרבן פסח ויחזרו למצרים, אלא שלא גילה לו פי' הדברים כדי להטעותן שירדפו אחריהם כדברי האוהחה"ק, ומדוייק בלשון התרגום יונתן שמפרש ואובילית יתכון לאתר בית מקדשא, לא אמר לבית מקדשא אלא לאתר בית מקדשא, שנעקר מקום המקדש ובא לקראת ישראל למדבר, ובאתר בית מקדשא הקריבו ישראל פסחיהן.
translation: And from now on we will understand that all of Moshe's arguments in saying, "Let us go a journey of three days and we will sacrifice to the Lord, etc.," for it is a festival for the Lord for us, and "they will celebrate for Me in the desert," are all true and contain no deceit or trickery, and it is not about the absolute journey for which he sought permission, but rather about a temporary journey to go and offer the Passover sacrifice and then return to Egypt. However, he did not reveal to him the meaning of the words in order to mislead them so that they would pursue them, as stated by the holy Baal Shem Tov. And it is precise in the language of the Targum Yonatan, which explains, "and I will lead you to the site of the Holy Temple," he did not say "to the Holy Temple" but "to the site of the Holy Temple," which was uprooted and came to meet Israel in the desert, and at the site of the Holy Temple, Israel offered their Passover sacrifices.
summary: The passage discusses the true intentions behind Moses' request to Pharaoh to allow the Israelites to journey for three days to worship God, emphasizing that this was not merely a request for permission but a temporary measure to facilitate the offering of the Passover sacrifice. It highlights the idea that the location of the future Temple was spiritually present in the desert, as God prepared to meet the Israelites there. The text underscores the belief that the essence of worship and sacrifice transcends physical locations, reflecting a deeper connection between the divine and the people.

passage_content: והנה משה ואהרן גזרה חכמתו ית' עליהם שלא יכנסו לארץ עד ביאה העתידה, וחוץ מטעם המבואר בכתובים, כתב המגלה עמוקות עוד מאה טעמים עיי"ש, ותו"ד דלהפלגת קדושתן לא היו ראויים ליכנס כ"א בקדושת א"י דלעתיד, ומעתה הי' ס"ד, שמשה ואהרן לא נצטרפו עם ישראל בעשיית הפסח במקום המקדש, ע"כ דרשו רז"ל אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, דלא נמנע מהם הכניסה כ"א במקומה הראוי', אבל כשנעקר מקום המקדש למדבר אף הם נצטרפו עם ישראל וכן עשו מצות הפסח עם ישראל.
translation: And behold, Moses and Aaron, the wisdom of the Blessed One decreed upon them that they would not enter the Land until the future coming, and aside from the reason explained in the scriptures, the Megaleh Amukos wrote deeply another hundred reasons, as mentioned there. Furthermore, due to the exalted sanctity of their souls, they were only worthy to enter with the sanctity of the Land of Israel in the future. From this, it was thought that Moses and Aaron did not join Israel in the observance of the Passover at the place of the Temple. Therefore, our Sages taught that even Moses and Aaron did so, for their entrance was not prevented except in its proper place. But when the place of the Temple was uprooted to the wilderness, they too joined with Israel and performed the commandments of Passover with Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the divine decree that Moses and Aaron would not enter the Promised Land until the future redemption, emphasizing their elevated sanctity that required them to enter the land only in its future, perfected state. Despite this, it is noted that they participated in the Passover with the Israelites in the wilderness, highlighting their connection to the people even in a less-than-ideal situation. The text reflects on the profound relationship between holiness, place, and the fulfillment of divine commandments, illustrating the unique status of Moses and Aaron within the broader narrative of Israel's journey.

passage_content: והנה לפי"ז העננים הוליכו את ישראל למדבר והחזירום למצרים, ואמרינן בגמ' (יבמות ע"ב ע"א) דכל מ' שנה שהיו ישראל במדבר לא נשבה להם רוח צפונית, אב"ע דלא נבדוד ענני כבוד פרש"י ז"ל משו"ה לא נשבה שלא יפזרו ענני הכבוד, ואפשר דמה"ט לא נשבה רוח צפונית גם באותו הלילה, וסימנא דכינור היתה ע"י רוח צפונית שמנשבת בחצות לילה, וא"ש דמשרע"ה לא הו"ל סימנא דכינור.
translation: And behold, according to this, the clouds led Israel to the desert and brought them back to Egypt. And we say in the Gemara (Yevamot 72a) that for all forty years that Israel was in the desert, a northern wind did not blow for them. The Abba B. Aharon explains that the clouds of glory did not disperse, therefore a northern wind did not blow so that the clouds of glory would not be scattered. And it is possible that for this reason a northern wind did not blow that night as well, and the sign of the harp was through the northern wind that blows at midnight, and it is understood that from Moshe Rabbeinu there was no sign of the harp.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the clouds that guided the Israelites in the desert and their connection to the divine presence. It highlights that during the forty years in the desert, the northern wind did not blow, which is attributed to the protective nature of the clouds of glory that surrounded the Israelites. This absence of the northern wind symbolizes a lack of dispersion and a continuous divine guidance, emphasizing the importance of divine protection in their journey. Additionally, it notes that the absence of a musical sign, represented by the northern wind at midnight, further illustrates the unique spiritual state of the Israelites under Moses' leadership.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתבאר דברי המדרש כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, עפי"ד הגמ' (סוכה י"א ע"ב) כי בסוכות הושבתי את בנ"י וגו' ר"א אמר ענני כבוד היו, ופסקינן כוותי', נמצא כי שם סוכות ירמוז על ענני הכבוד, ועד"ז רמז לו משרע"ה בבנינו ובבנותנו בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך, לזבוח במקום המקדש, כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, ורמז לו דרך הליכתם עם העננים, אלא שלא גילה לו פירושו כדי להטעותו כנ"ל, ובזה יבואר קישור הכתוב אתם ראיתם וגו' ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים, ונתקרבתם אל הקדושה בלי עמל ויגיעה ובבת אחת שלא על סדר המדריגות, אולם ועתה מזמן הזה ואילך אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי ושמרתם את בריתי אז והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים ותזכו לביאת הארץ והכל תליא במעשיכם.
translation: And according to our path, the words of the Midrash will be clarified, for the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Sukkot, as per the Gemara (Sukkah 11b) that states, "I sat the children of Israel in Sukkot," and Rabbi Eliezer said, "They were clouds of glory," and we rule like him. Thus, it is found that the name Sukkot alludes to the clouds of glory. Similarly, it was hinted to him by Moshe Rabbeinu, "With our sons and our daughters, with our flocks and our herds, we will go to sacrifice to the place of the Temple," for the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Sukkot, and it hints at their journey with the clouds. However, he did not reveal its meaning to him in order to mislead him, as mentioned above. In this, the connection of the verse "You have seen... and I bore you on the wings of eagles" will be clarified, and you will draw near to holiness without toil and effort, all at once, not in the order of the levels. However, from this time onward, if you will listen to My voice and keep My covenant, then you will be a treasured people for Me from all the nations, and you will merit to enter the land, and everything depends on your deeds.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Festival of Sukkot, linking it to the concept of divine protection symbolized by the "clouds of glory" that accompanied the Israelites. It emphasizes that the journey to holiness can occur without labor or struggle, as indicated by the metaphor of being carried on "wings of eagles." However, it also stresses the importance of obedience to God's commandments, suggesting that the fulfillment of divine promises, such as the inheritance of the land, is contingent upon the people's actions and adherence to the covenant.

passage_content: ויהי חשך וגו' פרש"י ז"ל מדברי המד"ר (פר' י"ד סי' ג') ולמה הביא עליהם חשך שהיו בישראל באותו הדור רשעים וכו' ומתו בג' ימי אפילה כדי שלא יראו מצרים במפלתם וכו', יל"ד מדוע הקשה כן במכת חשך דייקא למה הביאן עליהם, ורז"ל נתנו טעם לכל המכות, ומדוע ניחא לי' באחריני וקשיא לי' בחשך לבד.
translation: And there was darkness, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains from the words of the Midrash (Parashat Yud-Daled, section 3) why darkness was brought upon them: because there were wicked ones in Israel in that generation, etc., and they died during the three days of darkness so that the Egyptians would not see their downfall, etc. It is difficult to understand why he specifically asked this regarding the plague of darkness—why it was brought upon them. The Sages provided reasons for all the plagues, so why is it that he is at ease with the others and finds it difficult only with darkness?
summary: The passage discusses the plague of darkness in Egypt, referencing the Midrash that explains it was a punishment for the wickedness of the Israelites in that generation. The darkness allowed the Egyptians to suffer without witnessing the downfall of their oppressors, highlighting a unique aspect of this plague. The author questions why the darkness specifically raises such a theological concern compared to the other plagues, suggesting a deeper significance in the nature of this affliction. This reflects a Hasidic emphasis on the moral and spiritual implications of divine punishment and the interconnectedness of the fate of the righteous and the wicked.

passage_content: ואפ"ל דהנה תכלית המכות הי' להודיעם גבורתו ית' כמפורש בכתובים והרבתי את אתתי ואת מופתי בארץ מצרים וגו' וידעו מצרים כי אני ד' וגו', וכן הזכיר הכתוב ברוב המכות למען תדע כי אין כד' וגומר, למען תדע כי אני ד' ועוד לשונות דוגמתו, והנה כל המכות היו דרך נסיי, ובמכת הדם כתיב ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים בלטיהם ויחזק לב פרעה ולא שמע אליהם, וכתב הראב"ע ז"ל יש הפרש גדול בין מעשה אהרן למעשיהם, כי אהרן הפך כל היאור וכו' וכל מים שהי' בכל גבול מצרים שלא הי' רואה אותם, ועוד כי הפך מים שאינם עומדים רק רצים תמיד ומים אחרים באים, ועוד כי עמדה המכה ז' ימים, והחרטומים לא הראו שהפכו רק מים מועטים עומדים בכלי, וזה הי' רגע א' עד ששב פרעה אל ביתו עכ"ל, הנה אף שהכיר פרעה שאין מעשיהם בערך מעשה אהרן, מ"מ לא שת לבו אל מופת הדם, שכבר הי' לו פ"פ.
translation: And although the purpose of the plagues was to make known His mighty power, as it is explicitly stated in the scriptures, "And I multiplied My signs and My wonders in the land of Egypt," and "And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord," and similarly, the scripture mentions in many of the plagues, "In order that you may know that there is none like the Lord," and "In order that you may know that I am the Lord," and other similar phrases, behold, all the plagues were through miraculous means. And regarding the plague of blood, it is written, "And the magicians of Egypt did so with their enchantments," and Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them. The Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed, wrote that there is a great difference between the act of Aaron and their acts, for Aaron turned all the waters of the Nile, etc., and all the waters that were throughout the borders of Egypt, which he did not see, and also because he turned waters that do not stand still but flow continuously, and other waters come in, and furthermore, the plague lasted seven days, while the magicians did not show that they turned anything except for a few standing waters in vessels, and this was only for a moment until Pharaoh returned to his house. Thus, even though Pharaoh recognized that their actions were not comparable to the act of Aaron, nevertheless, he did not pay attention to the miracle of the blood, for he had already experienced it previously.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the purpose of the plagues in Egypt was to reveal God's might, as stated in the scriptures, so that the Egyptians would recognize His sovereignty. It highlights the miraculous nature of the plagues, particularly the plague of blood, where Aaron's act was fundamentally different from the magicians' tricks, demonstrating God's unparalleled power. Despite Pharaoh's acknowledgment of the distinction, he remained obstinate and did not heed the divine signs. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the struggle between divine authority and human resistance.

passage_content: והנה מכת החשך לא הי' ענין נסיי כלל כמ"ש הרמב"ן והאבן עזרא זלה"ה, וז"ל הראב"ע הנה בים אוקינוס יבא חשך עב שלא יוכל אדם להפריש בין יום ובין לילה ויעמוד זה לפעמים ה' ימים ואני הייתי שם פעמים רבות, והרמב"ן כתב חשך אפילה כלומר איד עב מאוד שירד מן השמים וכו' עיי"ש, ע"כ הקשה לרש"י ז"ל חשך למה הביא עליהם, אם לא הי' בדרך נסיי הרי לא הכירו על ידו להודות בגבורתו ית' ומ"ט הביאו עליהם ומתרץ כדי שלא יראו המצריים במפלתם ויאמרו אף הם לוקין כמונו ואין זה לכבוד שמים וכבודן של ישראל, ועוד שחפשו ישראל וראו את כליהם, וכשיצאו והיו שואלין מהן והיו אומרים אין בידינו כלום, אומר לו אני ראיתיו בביתך ובמקום פלוני הוא, ומזה נצמח כבוד שמים גדול וטובה גדולה לישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, על שעמדו בנסיונם במכת החושך, דהנה המצריים היו כולם ככפותים העומד אינו יכול לישב והיושב אינו יכול לעמוד מחמת כפילת החושך, והי' אפשר להם לישראל ליקח כל כספם וזהבם ולצאת מארצם באין מפריע, ומ"ט המתינו עד שישאלו מהם וא"ל אני ראיתיו בביתך ועי"ז נתרצו ליתן להם, אמנם בנ"י שמרו דבר ד' שלא לצאת מעצמם כי אם עפ"י משה ובעת יבא זמן פקודתם, ולא להקדים אף רגע א' לפני זמנו, גם קיימו מצות השי"ת ליקח רכושם בדרך שאלה דייקא, כמאמה"כ ובנ"י עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וגו', ולא נטלו בזרוע בימי אפילה.
translation: And behold, the plague of darkness was not a miraculous matter at all, as the Ramban and the Ibn Ezra, may their merit protect us, have said. The Ibn Ezra wrote, "Behold, in the ocean sea, a thick darkness will come, such that a person cannot distinguish between day and night, and this can last sometimes for five days. I have been there many times." And the Ramban wrote that darkness is a very thick cloud that descended from the heavens, etc. Therefore, he questioned Rashi, may his memory be blessed, why darkness was brought upon them. If it was not in a miraculous way, then they would not have recognized through it to acknowledge His greatness, blessed be He. And why was it brought upon them? He answers that it was so that the Egyptians would not see their downfall and say, "Even we are suffering like them," and this would not be for the honor of Heaven and the honor of Israel. Furthermore, the Israelites searched and saw their possessions, and when they went out and were asked about them, they would say, "We have nothing in our hands." One would say to them, "I saw it in your house and in such and such a place." And from this, great honor for Heaven and great goodness for Israel arose for all generations, for they stood firm in their trial during the plague of darkness. Behold, the Egyptians were all like bound ones; the standing one could not sit, and the sitting one could not stand because of the intensity of the darkness. It would have been possible for the Israelites to take all their money and gold and leave their land without hindrance. And therefore, they waited until they were asked about them, and one would say, "I saw it in your house," and through this, they were persuaded to give it to them. However, the children of Israel kept the word of the Lord not to leave on their own but only through Moses and at the time of their appointed redemption, and not to advance even a single moment before its time. They also fulfilled the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, to take their possessions in a manner of asking specifically, as it is written, "And the children of Israel did as Moses said, and they asked the Egyptians for silver vessels, etc.," and they did not take by force during the days of darkness.
summary: The passage discusses the plague of darkness in Egypt, emphasizing that it was not a miraculous event but rather a profound darkness that prevented the Egyptians from recognizing their situation. This darkness served a dual purpose: it protected the Israelites from witnessing the Egyptians' downfall and ensured that the Egyptians would not claim they suffered equally. The Israelites adhered strictly to God's command, waiting for Moses to instruct them on when to ask for their possessions, thereby demonstrating their faith and obedience. This act of restraint and adherence to divine timing ultimately brought honor to God and blessings to Israel throughout generations.

passage_content: והזכות הזה עמדה לישראל בכל הדורות ואף לעתיד בעת הגאולה, כמשה"כ (ירמי' ב') זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר ר"ל אחרי דייקא לקיים פקודתו ית', ולא על דעת עצמם כ"א כאשר צו' ד' ולא שינו דבר, ואמרז"ל (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) שאף אחרים יזכו בזכותן לעוה"ב, ובזה יל"פ הפסוק ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, ולכאורה הרי אמרז"ל (קידושין ל"ז ע"א) שכל מקום שנא' מושב אינו אלא לאחר ירושה וישיבה, ואף למ"ד מושב כ"מ שאתם יושבים משמע אבל ארץ מצרים ודאי אינו ראוי ליקרא מושבותם שלא נתיישבו בה כ"א גרים היו בארץ לא להם, ולדרכנו הכוונה על העתיד שע"י שעמדו בנסיונם בימי החשך, זכו לאור שכינתו ית' במושבותם בביאת הארץ ויזכו בזכותו גם בביאה דלעתיד וזה ירמוז ולכל בנ"י הי' אור במושבותם, וזכו לזה במכת החשך ע"י שעמדו בנסיונם.
translation: And this merit has stood for Israel throughout all generations and even for the future at the time of redemption, as it is written (Jeremiah 2) "I remember for you the kindness of your youth," etc., "to follow after Me in the wilderness," meaning specifically to fulfill His command, and not according to their own understanding, but as commanded by the Holy One, blessed be He, and they did not change a thing. And our sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 110b) that even others will merit through their merit in the World to Come. And in this, we can interpret the verse "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings." At first glance, our sages of blessed memory said (Kiddushin 37a) that wherever it says "dwelling," it refers only to after inheritance and settlement. And even according to the opinion that "dwelling" means wherever you are sitting, certainly the land of Egypt is not worthy of being called their dwellings, as they were only strangers in a land not theirs. And in our way, the intention is regarding the future, that through their standing firm in their trials during the days of darkness, they merited the light of His presence in their dwellings upon entering the land, and they will also merit through His merit in the future coming. This is hinted at in "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings," and they merited this through the plague of darkness by standing firm in their trials.
summary: The passage emphasizes the enduring merit of the Jewish people throughout generations, particularly in relation to their faithfulness to God's commandments during their trials in the desert. It highlights that their steadfastness in adhering to divine instructions, even in difficult times, grants them a unique spiritual light and connection to God, both in the present and in the future redemption. The reference to the darkness they faced serves as a testament to their resilience, which ultimately leads to their reward of divine presence in their future settlements. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the transformative power of faith and perseverance in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ויל"פ בזה דברי המדרש הים ראה וינוס ראה רכוש מצרים בידם, דהנה שר של ים הי"ל טענה שעדיין לא השלימו זמן גלותם הנגזר עליהם ת' שנה, וא"כ אין לו לקרוע בפניהם, אמנם ממה שראה רכוש מצרים בידם ר"ל ברשותם, שלא לקחוהו בגזל כ"א עפ"י ציווי השי"ת ורחמנא אפקעא מרשותם, ומזה ראי' גם על יציאתם שהי' עפ"י ה' וכך הוקצב זמנם מאתו ית', ולכך וינוס מפניהם.
translation: And it is explained here in the words of the Midrash: The sea saw and fled, for it saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands. Behold, the minister of the sea had a claim that they had not yet completed the time of their exile decreed upon them for 400 years, and therefore he should not part before them. However, from what he saw, the wealth of Egypt was in their possession, meaning that they did not take it by theft, but rather by the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, who removed it from their possession. And from this, there is also proof regarding their departure, that it was by the will of the Holy One, and thus their time was set by Him. Therefore, it fled from before them.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic interpretation regarding the sea's reluctance to part for the Israelites during the Exodus. The sea's guardian argued that the Israelites had not yet completed their prophesied period of enslavement. However, upon seeing the wealth of Egypt in the Israelites' possession, which they obtained not through theft but by divine command, it became evident that their departure was sanctioned by God. This realization led the sea to yield and part for them, affirming the divine timing of their liberation.

passage_content: דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' ויתן ד' את חן העם בעיני מצרים גם האיש משה גדול מאוד וגו' בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, בגמ' ברכות (דף ט' ע"א) דבר נא באזני העם אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, א"ל הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך, לך ואמור להם לישראל בבקשה מכם, שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, ועבדום וענו אותם קיים בהם, ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם עכ"ד הגמ', ראוי להבין מה צורך להזהרה ובקשה כ"כ, ובודאי יתרצו ישראל במה שהוא לטובתם, גם מה טעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו', והלא זולת טעם זה ראוי שיקיים הבוי"ת הבטחתו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, והבטחתו ית' לטובה אינה חוזרת ריקם, גם דקדקו המפרשים דמלת בהם אך למותר, ויספיק במ"ש ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים ומה צורך להוסיף מלת "בהם" ומובן מאליו שמוסב על בנ"י האמור בקרא, גם הכי יעלה על הדעת שאאע"ה יתרעם על מדותיו ית"ש ומה לו לבצע כסף וחמדת הממון לא נחשב אצלו למאומה.
translation: "Speak now in the ears of the people, and let them ask each man from his neighbor, etc., and the Lord gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and also the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people." In the Gemara Berakhot (page 9a), it states: "Speak now in the ears of the people" – the term 'now' is only a term of request. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, 'I request of you, go and tell them to Israel, I request of you, to ask from the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels, so that that righteous one should not say, "And they will enslave them and afflict them," which is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth' – this is not fulfilled in them, thus concludes the Gemara. It is fitting to understand what is the need for such a warning and request, and certainly the Israelites would agree to what is for their benefit. Also, what is the reason that that righteous one should not say, etc., and behold, aside from this reason, it is fitting that the Blessed One should fulfill His promise and afterwards they would go out with great wealth, and His promise for good does not return empty. Also, the commentators have noted that the word 'in them' is superfluous, and it would suffice to say, 'and afterwards they will go out with great wealth' – it is not fulfilled, and what is the need to add the word 'in them'? It is understood that it refers to the Children of Israel as stated in the verse. Also, it would come to mind that our forefather Abraham would be upset with His attributes, blessed be He, and what does it matter to Him to acquire silver and the desire for wealth, which is not considered anything to Him."
summary: The passage discusses God's instruction to Moses to request the Israelites to ask the Egyptians for silver and gold, emphasizing the importance of this request as a form of divine strategy. It highlights the concept of divine providence, where God ensures that the Israelites leave Egypt with wealth, while also addressing the potential concern that the righteous might question God's justice if they were to leave empty-handed. The text reflects on the necessity of this request, suggesting that it serves both a practical purpose and a deeper theological insight into God's relationship with His people and their journey towards redemption.

passage_content: ב) יל"ד בסיפא דקרא גם האיש משה גדול מאוד בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, ראוי להבין מה ענינו אל השאלת כליהם דעסיק בי', ומשרע"ה לא הי' צריך לחן שלהם כי לא עסק בזה כאמרז"ל (סוטה י"ג ע"א) גם מהו רבותי' שהי' גדול בעיני עבדי פרעה, וכבר ידענא כן מפרשיות הקודמים, ועוד מ"ש גם האיש משה, גם הרבוי צ"ב, ומי כמוהו עוד גדול.
translation: In the end of the verse, it is said that the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people. It is appropriate to understand what his connection is to the question of their vessels that he was involved with, and since Moshe Rabbeinu did not need their favor because he was not engaged in this, as our Sages have said (Sotah 13a). Furthermore, what does it mean that he was great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh? We already know this from the previous sections, and also what is meant by "the man Moses," as the emphasis is puzzling, and who else is as great as he?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses being regarded as "great" in the eyes of Pharaoh's servants and the people, emphasizing his unique status and the divine favor he received. It questions the relevance of this acknowledgment in relation to the request for the Israelites' belongings, suggesting that Moses did not rely on human favor, as he was focused on divine mission. The repetition of "the man Moses" highlights his unparalleled greatness, inviting deeper reflection on his role as a leader and prophet. Overall, it underscores the theme of divine selection and the inherent dignity of Moses in the context of his mission.

passage_content: ג) ישראל עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים וגו', וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום וגו', יל"ד מה צורך להקדמה זו ובנ"י עשו כדבר משה, ובמ"ש וישאלו ממצרים כבר ידענא שעשו כדבר משה, גם מדוע הזכיר עוה"פ וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים, וכבר נזכר לעיל ויתן ד' את חן העם וגו'
translation: 3) Israel did as Moses had said, and they asked of the Egyptians, etc. And the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they let them have, etc. It is asked, what is the need for this introduction, since the Children of Israel did as Moses had said? And regarding the statement "and they asked of the Egyptians," we already know that they did as Moses had said. Also, why is it mentioned here that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, when it was already mentioned above that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor, etc.?
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' obedience to Moses' command to ask the Egyptians for valuables, highlighting the divine favor granted to the Israelites, which made them appealing to the Egyptians. It questions the necessity of reiterating that the Israelites acted as instructed and the mention of God's granting them grace, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine intervention and human action. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the importance of faith and the transformative power of divine grace in the fulfillment of God's will. Ultimately, it emphasizes the interconnectedness of obedience, divine favor, and the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי המדרש תנחומא (וארא סי"ג) א"ר אבין הלוי ברבי ממכת הדם העשירו בני ישראל, כיצד המצרי וישראל בבית א' והגיגית מלאה מים, והמצרי הולך למלאות את הקיתון מתוכה מוציאה מלאה דם, וישראל שותה מים ומצרי דם מתוך הגיגית וכו', וכשהי' לוקח מישראל בדמים יקרים הי' שותה מים, מכאן העשירו בני ישראל עכ"ד המדרש, א"כ לפי"ז מה טעם בטענה הנ"ל ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים, וכבר הי' בידם רכוש ועשירות, ומה צורך עוד להשאלת כליהם, ואפשר ליישב עפי"מ שהקשו בעלי התוס' ז"ל (בפ' וארא) עה"פ ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים וגו', מהיכן לקחו חרטומי מצרים מים להפכו לדם, והרי כל מימי מצרים נהפכו לדם במאמר ד' עפ"י משה, ותירצו שחפרו מים סביבות היאור, אמנם דחו תירוץ זה, כי אח"כ כתיב ויחפרו כל מצרים סביבות היאור, ובחד פרשה לא שייך למימר אין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה, והאוהחה"ק תירץ עפ"י דבריהם ז"ל כי ישראל נתעשרו ממכת היאור, שהיו מוכרים מים למצרים וכו', כפי זה עשו ההחרטומים מהנמכר להם עכ"ל.
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of the Midrash Tanchuma (Va'era, section 13): Rabbi Avin the Levite said in the name of Rabbi, from the plague of blood, the children of Israel became wealthy. How so? The Egyptian and the Israelite were in one house, and the basin was full of water. The Egyptian went to fill the pitcher from it, and it came out full of blood, while the Israelite drank water and the Egyptian drank blood from the basin, etc. And when the Egyptian took from the Israelite at a high price, he would drink water. From here, the children of Israel became wealthy, thus concludes the Midrash. Therefore, according to this, what is the reason for the above claim, and afterwards they went out with great wealth? It was not fulfilled, for they already had wealth and riches, so what need was there to borrow their vessels? It is possible to resolve this according to what the Tosafists asked (in Parashat Va'era) regarding the verse "And the magicians of Egypt did so," from where did the magicians of Egypt take water to turn it into blood, when all the waters of Egypt were turned to blood by the word of G-d through Moses? They answered that they dug for water around the Nile. However, this answer was rejected, for it is written afterwards, "And all Egypt dug around the Nile." And in one section, it is not appropriate to say that there is no earlier or later in the Torah. The holy teacher resolved according to their words that the Israelites became wealthy from the plague of the Nile, as they were selling water to the Egyptians, etc. Based on this, the magicians did what was sold to them.
summary: The passage discusses the wealth of the Israelites during the plague of blood, highlighting that they profited from selling water to the Egyptians while the Egyptians suffered from the plague. It raises questions about the necessity of borrowing vessels if the Israelites were already wealthy. The text suggests that the Egyptians' magicians were able to perform their tricks using the water sold to them by the Israelites, emphasizing the divine orchestration of events where the Israelites' prosperity is intertwined with the Egyptians' suffering. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine judgment and human agency in the context of redemption.

passage_content: והנה ע"י שמכרו מים לחרטומים, השתמשו בהם להכחיש נסי ד' ומעשיהם של משה ואהרן, ואמרו דכמו שעשו הם בכשפים כך מעשיהם ח"ו בכשפים, ובודאי שבנ"י השלימים באמונת הבוי"ת לא היו מתרצים למכור מים להם, אף אם היו נותנים להם כל כסף וזהב שבעולם, ועכ"ח צ"ל שקנו מים מאותן שנתחברו אליהם ולא האמינו בנסי ד', והם שהעשירו ממכת היאור, ומ"ש ז"ל ממכת הדם העשירו בנ"י יתפרש על קצתם וחלק מהם, וכמ"ש בעכן חטא ישראל אף שלא חטא אלא א' מהם, והנה מקצתם עשו תשובה סמוך ליציאתם של ישראל ונצטרפו עמהם לצאת כמו הע"ר, ואלו כבר הי' בידם רכוש רב, אבל בני ישראל הכשרים לא רצו לנגוע בממון כזה, אמנם לענין העבדות והעינוי הי' להיפך כי אותן שהתחברו להמצריים וחרטומיהם לא סבלו כלל שעבוד ועינוי, והמצריים עשו אותן פטרונים, ונתנו להם עשירות עבור שהחזיקו בידם להראות נסיהם ולהכחיש נסי משה ואהרן, אבל בני ישראל הכשרים שהתרחקו מדרכיהם והתחברותם ופנו עורף לנסיהם, הם היו מאוסים בעיני מצרים ושעבדו ועינו אותם, נמצא שאותם שנתקיים בהם ועבדום וענו אותם, לא הי' בידם רכוש לולי השאלת כליהם, ואלו שהי' בידם רכוש לא נתקיים בהם ועבדום וענו אותם.
translation: And behold, by selling water to the magicians, they used it to deny the miracles of G-d and the deeds of Moshe and Aharon, and they said that just as they performed their acts through sorcery, so too were the deeds of Moshe and Aharon, Heaven forbid, through sorcery. Certainly, the complete Jewish people, who believed in the Creator, would not have consented to sell water to them, even if they were offered all the money and gold in the world. Therefore, it must be that they purchased water from those who had joined them and did not believe in the miracles of G-d, and they were the ones who became wealthy from the plague of the Nile. And what our sages said regarding the plague of blood applies to some of them and a portion of them, as it is said about Achan, "Israel has sinned," even though only one of them sinned. And behold, some of them repented close to the departure of Israel and joined them to leave like the mixed multitude. And these already had great wealth in their hands, but the righteous children of Israel did not want to touch such wealth. However, regarding servitude and affliction, it was the opposite, for those who joined the Egyptians and their magicians did not suffer at all from servitude and affliction; the Egyptians made them patrons and gave them wealth for holding on to show their signs and deny the miracles of Moshe and Aharon. But the righteous children of Israel, who distanced themselves from their ways and their associations and turned their backs on their signs, were despised in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they enslaved and afflicted them. Thus, those who were subjected to servitude and affliction had no wealth except for the borrowing of their vessels, while those who had wealth were not subjected to servitude and affliction.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual implications of the Israelites selling water to the Egyptian magicians, suggesting that this act reflected a lack of faith in God's miracles. It contrasts the fates of those who aligned themselves with the Egyptians and their sorcery, who were rewarded with wealth and avoided suffering, with the faithful Israelites who rejected such associations and faced oppression. The text emphasizes that true wealth and spiritual integrity come from steadfast belief in God, while those who compromise their faith for material gain ultimately suffer. Thus, it highlights the importance of maintaining faith and distance from idolatry, even in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר אמרם ז"ל לך ואמור להם לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו', דע"כ הי' הצורך לבקשם ולהזהירם כ"כ, כי בנ"י הכשרים היו מתייראים מליקח רכוש מצרים, כי ראו מה שעלתה להם לאותן שנתעשרו מממונם, ועי"ז הי"ל חלק בהכחשת נסי ד' ולפרסם נסי המכשפים וכוחות הטומאה, אמנם כשהבוי"ת מצוה ליקח רכושם ה"ה ממקור הקדושה ואין זה ממונם של מצרים כי לא מרצונם ניתן להם, אלא וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים שלא כדרך הטבע, כי הרשע שונא לצדיק בטבע, והטעם שהזהירם הבוי"ת על ככה, כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק ועבדום וענו אותם קיים "בהם" במיעוט הכשרים ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, כי אלו הי' בדחקות ועוני במצרים, ויצטער אאע"ה על כובד הנסיונות של בנ"י הכשרים ועל העדר כבוד שמים, שבנ"י המאמינים המה בלחץ ועוני, ועבדום וענו אותם נתקיים בהם, והרכוש לא נתקיים בהם, ואיך יוכלו להתקיים ולעמוד בנסיון שלא ליהנות מממון הרשעים, ולזה הזהירם הקב"ה בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב, ועד"ז יתקיים בהם הבטחת הרכוש ממקור הקדושה.
translation: And this will clarify their saying, may their memory be blessed, "Go and say to the Israelites, 'Please, ask the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels,' etc." Know that there was a need to request them and to warn them so much, for the righteous children of Israel were afraid to take the possessions of Egypt, as they saw what it cost them when they became wealthy from their own money. Thus, they would have a part in denying the miracles of the Holy One, blessed be He, and in publicizing the miracles of the sorcerers and the forces of impurity. However, when the Holy One, blessed be He, commands them to take their possessions, it is from the source of holiness, and it is not the money of the Egyptians, for it was not given to them willingly, but rather the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, contrary to the natural order, for the wicked naturally hate the righteous. The reason the Holy One, blessed be He, warned them in this way was so that the righteous one would not say, "And they enslaved them and oppressed them" applies to the minority of the righteous, and then they would leave with great wealth, which would not apply to them. For if they were in distress and poverty in Egypt, our forefather Abraham would be pained by the heaviness of the trials of the righteous children of Israel and by the lack of the honor of Heaven, that the believing children of Israel are under pressure and in poverty, and "And they enslaved them and oppressed them" was fulfilled in them, while the wealth was not fulfilled in them. And how could they endure and stand in the trial of not benefiting from the money of the wicked? Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, warned them, "Please, ask the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels," and in this way, the promise of wealth from the source of holiness would be fulfilled in them.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for the Israelites to request gold and silver from the Egyptians, emphasizing their initial reluctance due to fear of taking wealth from a corrupt source. It highlights that this wealth, given by God, is not truly Egyptian but rather a divine gift, as God instilled favor in the eyes of the Egyptians contrary to natural enmity. The warning serves to ensure that the Israelites do not feel guilty for receiving this wealth, as it is a fulfillment of God's promise and a means to elevate their spiritual standing, reinforcing the idea that divine providence can transform even the possessions of the wicked into a source of holiness for the righteous.

passage_content: ובזה נבין במאמה"כ להלן ובני ישראל עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים, ולכאורה מה צורך להודעה זו שעשו כדבר משה, ונשמע כן ממ"ש וישאלו ממצרים (עיין קושיא ג') ואפ"ל דהנה ציווי השי"ת הי' שיקחו מהם בדרך שאלה, וא"כ הוצרכו למצוא חן בעיניהם שיבטחו באמונתם ויתרצו להשאיל להם כלי חמדתם, ובדרך הטבע שנאה כבושה לרשע על הצדיק וכמ"ש בישמח משה (פ' בלק) ששומה מאת ד' למען לא יבואו לידי התחברות עיי"ש, ובדרך הטבע לא ימצא חן בעיניהם כ"א ההולך בדרכם והדומה להם, ואיך יצוייר שהמצריים יתנו כלי חמדתם לבנ"י הכשרים שיעשו בהם רצון הבוב"ה, אלא שלא הי' זה בדרך הטבע, אלא וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום ושלא יעלה על דעת אדם לומר, דבשביל שרצו ישראל להשלים רצון הבוי"ת בהשאלת כליהם, בקשו התחברותם גם ויתרו קצת מדרך היראה והקדושה כדי למצוא חן בעיניהם לזה שלל הכתוב לומר ובני ישראל עשו כדבר משה, שלא זזו אף כקוצו של יו"ד מכל דברי משה, ואעפ"כ וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב, כי הי' שלא כדרך הטבע, וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום, ונתן הכתוב ראי' לזה וגם האיש משה גדול מאוד בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, והפלגת צדקתו נודע וברור לכל, ומלפנים ויגרש אותם מאת פני פרעה, ועכשיו הי' גדול בעיני עבדי פרעה וגו' אלא ודאי שלא הי' בדרך הטבע מציאת החן, ועד"ז גם לגבי ישראל לא זזו מיראתם ואמונתם, ומציאת החן הי' בדרך נס ושלא כדרך הטבע, ומה ששאלו רכושם עשו כן רק לקיים מצות הבוי"ת שהזהירם על ככה, וזולת זה נתייראו לנגוע בשלהם, ובאמת כי כל הממון זכה בהם יוסף הצדיק כמ"ש וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף, וה"ה ממקור הקדושה, גם מגיע להם הרכוש עפ"י הדין בשכר העבודה שעבדו להם כאמרז"ל, והטעם העקרי כי נצטוו על ככה בגזירת השי"ת, ורחמנא אפקעא מרשותן, והשי"ת הוא הנותן וה"ז מוסיף כח קדושה.
translation: And with this, we will understand in the verse that follows, "And the children of Israel did as Moses had said, and they asked of the Egyptians," and at first glance, what is the need for this notification that they did as Moses had said? It seems to be implied from what is written, "and they asked of the Egyptians" (see question 3). And it can be said that the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was that they should take from them in the manner of asking. Therefore, they needed to find favor in their eyes so that they would trust in their faith and agree to lend them the vessels of their desire. Naturally, there is a concealed hatred of the wicked towards the righteous, as it is written in "And Moses rejoiced" (Parashat Balak) that it was decreed by God so that they would not come to a connection, as seen there. Naturally, they would not find favor in the eyes of anyone except for one who walks in their way and is similar to them. How could it be imagined that the Egyptians would give their vessels of desire to the children of Israel, the righteous, who would use them to fulfill the will of the Blessed One? Rather, it was not in the natural way; rather, God gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they lent them. And it should not enter the mind of a person to say that because the Israelites wanted to fulfill the will of the Blessed One by asking for their vessels, they sought their connection and also relinquished somewhat from the path of fear and holiness to find favor in their eyes. Therefore, the text negates this by saying, "And the children of Israel did as Moses had said," that they did not deviate even as much as a jot from the words of Moses. And nevertheless, "they asked of the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels," for it was not in the natural way, and God gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they lent them. The text provides evidence for this, "And the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people," and the extent of his righteousness was known and clear to all. Previously, "he drove them away from the presence of Pharaoh," and now he was great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh, etc. But certainly, the finding of favor was not in the natural way. Similarly, regarding Israel, they did not deviate from their fear and faith, and the finding of favor was through a miracle and not in the natural way. And the reason they asked for their possessions was only to fulfill the command of the Blessed One who warned them about this, and aside from this, they were afraid to touch what belonged to them. And indeed, all the wealth was acquired by Joseph the righteous, as it is written, "And Joseph gathered all the money," and it is also from the source of holiness. They are also entitled to the wealth according to the law as a reward for the work they did for them, as our sages have said. The main reason is that they were commanded about this by the decree of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the Merciful One took it out of their possession, and the Holy One, blessed be He, is the giver, and this adds strength to holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous favor that God granted the Israelites in the eyes of the Egyptians, allowing them to borrow valuable items despite the natural animosity that typically exists between oppressors and the oppressed. It emphasizes that the Israelites adhered strictly to Moses' commands without compromising their faith or holiness, and their request for the Egyptians' possessions was a fulfillment of God's directive rather than a result of their own initiative. The text highlights the divine intervention that enabled this exchange, reinforcing the idea that all wealth ultimately belongs to God and is granted to the righteous as a reward for their faithfulness and labor.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יל"פ דברי המד"ר (בפ' נח פ' ל"ו סי' ה') וישלח את העורב זש"ה (תהלים ק"ה) שלח חושך ויחשיך ולא מרו את דברו, עפימ"ש רז"ל (סנהדרין דף ק"ח ע"ב) דלא כתיב וישלח את העורב מאתו כמ"ש ביונה, מכאן שדירתם של צדיקים אצל עופות טהורים, והנה אין הכוונה כפשוטו שדירתן אצל העופות ממש, אבל ירמוז להיות כל דבר נמשך אחר שרשו ועיקרו, ע"כ הצדיקים מתרחקין ממיני הטמאים, והטהורים מתחברין אליהם, וכבר בארנו לעיל שהי' לבנ"י הכשרים נסיונות גדולים במצרים, שהיו מעונים בצער ועוני ואלמלי נתחברו לרשעי ישראל, היו מעניקים להם מטובם כי הי' להם עשירות ולא חסר להם מאומה, ואמרז"ל (עירובין דף מ"א ע"ב) עניות מעביר את האדם על דעתו וע"ד קונו אמנם ע"י השאלת כליהם זכו לעשירות ממקור הקדושה ולא הוצרכו עוד להתחברותם ונפטרו מנסיון הזה ונתחברו רק עם הצדיקים, והנה החשך הי' סיבה להשאלת כליהם כפרש"י ז"ל שחפשו ישראל וראו כליהם וכו', ובזה יבואר המדרש הנ"ל וישלח את העורב ולא כתיב מאתו מכאן שדירתם של הצדיקים עם הטהורים דייקא הה"ד שלח חשך ויחשיך ולא מרו את דברו, דעי"ז ניצולו ישראל מהתחברותן הגורם ר"ל למרות בדברו ית', ועד"ז ירמוז הכתוב ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, עפימ"ש רז"ל במד"ר (בראשית פ"ב ס"ה) אור אלו מעשיהן של צדיקים, כי ע"י החושך נמשך להם האור להתדבק במעשיהן של צדיקים ולהתרחק מהתחברות הרשעים.
translation: And according to this, we can explain the words of the Midrash (in Parashat Noach, section 36, sign 5) "And he sent the raven," as it is written (Psalms 105) "He sent darkness and it darkened, and they did not rebel against His word." As our sages said (Sanhedrin 108b), it is not written "and he sent the raven from Him," as it is written regarding Jonah. From here we learn that the dwelling of the righteous is with pure birds. And the intention is not literally that their dwelling is with the birds themselves, but it hints that everything is drawn after its root and essence. Therefore, the righteous distance themselves from impure species, and the pure ones connect with them. And we have already explained above that the children of Israel had great trials in Egypt, as they were afflicted in pain and poverty, and had they connected with the wicked of Israel, they would have received from their goodness, for they had wealth and lacked nothing. And our sages said (Eruvin 41b) that poverty drives a person out of his mind and out of the mind of his Creator. However, through borrowing their vessels, they merited wealth from the source of holiness and no longer needed to connect with them, and they were freed from this trial and connected only with the righteous. And behold, the darkness was the reason for the borrowing of their vessels, as Rashi explains that Israel searched and found their vessels, etc. And this will clarify the aforementioned Midrash "And he sent the raven," and it is not written "from Him," from here we learn that the dwelling of the righteous is specifically with the pure ones, as it is written "He sent darkness and it darkened, and they did not rebel against His word," for through this Israel was saved from the connection that causes, God forbid, rebellion against His word. And similarly, the verse hints "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings," as our sages said in the Midrash (Genesis 2:2, sign 65) "This light is the deeds of the righteous," for through the darkness the light was drawn to them to cling to the deeds of the righteous and to distance themselves from the connection with the wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the righteous (tzaddikim) and purity, emphasizing that the tzaddikim are spiritually connected to pure entities, symbolized by the clean birds. It highlights that the trials faced by the Israelites in Egypt were mitigated by their refusal to associate with the wicked, allowing them to draw from the holiness of the tzaddikim instead. The text illustrates that darkness serves as a catalyst for seeking light, which represents the righteous deeds of the tzaddikim, ultimately guiding the Israelites away from the influence of the wicked and towards spiritual elevation.

passage_content: עוד יתבאר בדברי הגמ' הנ"ל, שלא יאמר אותו צדיק ועבדום וענו אותם קיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם (והדקדוקים כבר נפרטו לעיל), גם יל"ד במאמה"כ וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו', מדוע יכנה הכתוב המצריים רעהו ורעותה של ישראל, והוזהרו ישראל על התרחקותם, ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר הכתוב (בפ' תולדות) ויאהב יצחק את עשו כי ציד בפיו, פרש"י כתרגומו בפיו של יצחק ובת"א ארי מצידי' הוה אכיל, ומדרשו בפיו של עשו שהי' צד אותו ומרמהו בדבריו, ואמרו בתנחומא שהי' שואלו אבא האיך מעשרין את התבן ואת המלח, כסבור אביו שהוא מדקדק במצות, וכבר ביארו המפרשים ז"ל שהי' סיבה מאת ד' שיטעה יצחק אבינו בו, בשביל שיטול יעקב הברכות בלא דעתי' דיצחק אלא בדעתי' דקוב"ה כדאיתא בזוה"ק, אמנם פי' התרגום קשה להולמו, דלא יתכן לומר על יצחק אבינו דבשביל הנאת מאכליו אהבו, והתינח לדברי המדרש, דסבור יצחק שעשו מדקדק במצות, ויצאע"ה הי' אוהב מצות ע"כ אהבו, והי' סיבה מד' שיחשוב עליו כן, אבל פי' התרגום צ"ב.
translation: It will also be explained in the words of the aforementioned Gemara, that one should not say that the righteous, "and they enslaved them and afflicted them," is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth is not fulfilled in them (and the nuances have already been detailed above). Also, it is to be wondered about the verse, "and they shall ask each man from his neighbor," why does the scripture refer to the Egyptians as the neighbor and companion of Israel, and Israel was warned about their distancing? It seems appropriate to first explain the verse (in Parashat Toldot), "and Isaac loved Esau because he hunted with his mouth." Rashi explains, as his translation, "with the mouth of Isaac," and in Targum, "for he was eating from his hunting." And the Midrash explains that it was with the mouth of Esau that he was deceiving him with his words, and they said in Tanchuma that he would ask his father how to tithe the straw and the salt, thinking that his father believed he was meticulous in the commandments. And the commentators have already explained that it was a reason from the Holy One, blessed be He, that Isaac our father would be misled by him, so that Jacob would take the blessings without Isaac's knowledge, but rather with the knowledge of the Holy One, as it is stated in the Zohar. However, the translation's explanation is difficult to accept, for it cannot be said about Isaac our father that he loved him for the enjoyment of his food. And it can be understood according to the words of the Midrash, that Isaac thought that Esau was meticulous in the commandments, and since he was a lover of commandments, therefore he loved him, and it was a reason from the Holy One that he should think of him this way, but the translation's explanation is questionable.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of divine providence and the nature of love in the context of Isaac's affection for Esau, suggesting that Isaac was misled by appearances into believing Esau was righteous due to his outward observance of mitzvot. This misperception was part of God's plan to ensure that Jacob would receive the blessings without Isaac's awareness, highlighting the theme of divine orchestration in human affairs. The text also reflects on the relationship between the Israelites and the Egyptians, emphasizing the importance of spiritual discernment and the dangers of superficial connections. Overall, it underscores the intricate interplay between divine intention and human understanding in the unfolding of biblical narratives.
