passage_content: ד) במד"ר (שם) משל לאשה שהיתה מצפה לבעלה שפירש למדינת הים, אמר לה יהא סימן הזה בידך, בעת שתראי אותו סימן דעי שאני בא ואני קרוב לבא, כך ישראל מצפין משעמדה אדום, אמר הקב"ה הסימן הזה יהי' בידכם, ביום שעשיתי לכם תשועה ובאותו לילה היו יודעים שאני גואלכם, ואם לאו אל תאמינו שלא קרבה העת, שנא' אני ד' בעתה אחישנה עכ"ד המדרש הרי מבואר שא"א שתהי' הגאולה בזמן אחר זולתו כ"א בניסן ובלילה הזה דייקא, ויקשה ממ"ד בגמ' (ערובין מ"ג ע"א) הריני נזיר ביום שבן דוד בא וכו', אסור לשתות יין כל ימות החול והטעם דכל יומא ויומא זמני' הוא ואמרי' דלמא השתא אתי.
translation: In the Midrash (there), it is likened to a woman who was waiting for her husband who had gone to a distant land. He said to her, "This sign shall be in your hand; when you see this sign, know that I am coming and I am close to coming." Thus, Israel waits since the time of the Red One. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "This sign shall be in your hands, on the day I have done salvation for you, and on that night they will know that I am your Redeemer. And if not, do not believe that the time has not drawn near," as it is said, "I am the Lord; in its time, I will hasten it." Thus, the Midrash makes it clear that the redemption cannot occur at any other time except in Nissan and specifically on this night. And it is difficult from what is stated in the Gemara (Eruvin 43a), "I am a Nazirite on the day that the son of David comes," etc. It is forbidden to drink wine all the days of the week, and the reason is that every day is a time, and we say, "Perhaps he will come now."
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable of a woman waiting for her husband to illustrate the anticipation of the Jewish people for redemption. It emphasizes that God has provided a specific sign for the coming of the Messiah, indicating that redemption will occur at a predetermined time, specifically in the month of Nissan and on that particular night. The text also highlights the importance of faith in this timing, suggesting that one should not doubt the arrival of redemption, as it is divinely ordained. Additionally, it references a Talmudic teaching about the prohibition of wine during the waiting period, underscoring the urgency and seriousness of the expectation for the Messiah's arrival.

passage_content: וכבר תרצנו קושיא זו (בדברנו לעיל) עפימ"ש הנזה"ק (פ' ויחי) לפרש הפסוק אני ד' בעתה אחישנה, ותו"ד ז"ל דאף שהגאולה יש לה זמן קבוע של בעתה, באיזה מזל וכוכב וצירוף שם הוי' המאיר בו יהי' זמנה, אבל ברצונו ית' מעתיקם ממקומם להקדימם ולקבעם ברקיע כרצונו, והבוי"ת משנה עתים ומחליף את הזמנים כשיהי' הרצון מלפניו ית' להחיש עת הגאולה עכת"ד ז"ל, וכעי"ז כתב בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' בא) בשם רבו הה"ק מראפשיטץ זלה"ה דמה שאמחז"ל (סנהדרין דף צ"ח ע"א) זכו אחישנה לא זכו בעתה, הפי' הוא כך דידוע שיש למעלה קץ ידוע, ובשעה שהעולם תחת נקודת הקץ לא יאחר, כי ידוע שהעולמות יש להם הילוך, ובהגיע העולם תחת נקודת הגאולה לא יאוחר, אך אם זכו ישראל יבואו למדריגת אאע"ה שא"ל הקב"ה מאי חזית דקאי צדק במערב, מהדרנא לי' למזרח וכו', כמו"כ אם זכו ישראל יקרא הקב"ה להעולמות ויבואו תחת נקודת הקץ, אבל ח"ו אם לא זכו והלכו העולמות בדרכם, אך עכ"פ בבואם בזמנם לנקודת הקץ לא יאחר הקב"ה מלגאול עכלה"ק עיי"ש.
translation: And we have already answered this question (as mentioned above) according to what is written in the Zohar (Parashat Vayechi) to explain the verse "I am the Lord; in its time I will hasten it." And our teacher, may his memory be blessed, said that although the redemption has a fixed time of "in its time," depending on which constellation and star and the combination of the Name Havayah that shines in it will be its time, yet with His will, He can move them from their place to hasten them and establish them in the heavens as He desires. And the Blessed One changes times and alters the seasons when it is His will to hasten the time of redemption, thus said our teacher, may his memory be blessed. And similarly, it is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parashat Bo) in the name of his teacher, the holy one from Ropshitz, may his memory be blessed, that what our sages, of blessed memory, said (Sanhedrin 98a) "if they merit, it will be hastened; if they do not merit, it will be in its time," means as follows: it is known that there is a known end above, and at the time when the world is under the point of the end, it will not be delayed, for it is known that the worlds have a progression, and when the world reaches the point of redemption, it will not be delayed. However, if Israel merits, they will reach the level of our forefather Abraham, to whom the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Why do you see that righteousness is standing in the west? I will turn it to the east," etc. Likewise, if Israel merits, the Holy One, blessed be He, will call to the worlds, and they will come under the point of the end. But, Heaven forbid, if they do not merit and the worlds go on their way, nevertheless, when they come in their time to the point of the end, the Holy One, blessed be He, will not delay in redeeming His people, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in Hasidic thought, emphasizing that while there is a predetermined time for the redemption (referred to as "be'ita"), it can be hastened ("achishena") through the merit of the Jewish people. It explains that God's will can alter the timing of redemption, allowing for a shift in the cosmic order. The text also highlights that if the Jewish people merit it, they can elevate the world to align with the point of redemption, but if they do not, the world will continue on its path until the appointed time arrives. Ultimately, God's promise to redeem the world remains steadfast, regardless of the circumstances.

passage_content: ובזה יתורץ קושיתנו הנ"ל דבאמת תהי' גאולה העתידה בניסן ובלילה הזה דייקא כמבואר במדרש הנ"ל, אך ברצונו ית' מחליף הזמנים להעתיקם ממקומם כרצונו, והיכולת בידו ית' לקבוע ניסן והמזל והכוכב והצירוף הראוי להיות בו הגאולה, באיזה יום מימות השנה שיעלה הרצון מאתו ית', וע"כ אמרי' דבכל יומא זמני' ודלמא השתא אתי, וא"ש אמרם ז"ל במס' ערובין דאסור לשתות יין כל ימות החול כנ"ל.
translation: And with this, our aforementioned question is resolved, for indeed the future redemption will be in Nissan and specifically on this night, as explained in the aforementioned Midrash. However, His will may change the times and move them from their place as He desires, and the ability is in His hands to establish Nissan, the constellation, the star, and the appropriate combination for the redemption to occur on any day of the year that His will may arise. Therefore, we say that every day has its times, and perhaps it will come this very moment. And it is understood what our Sages said in the tractate Eruvin, that it is forbidden to drink wine on all weekdays, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption, emphasizing that while the future redemption is traditionally expected in the month of Nisan, God has the authority to alter the timing and circumstances of this event according to His will. It highlights the belief that God can determine the appropriate time for redemption, regardless of the calendar, and suggests that every day holds potential for redemption. This reflects a deep theological insight into divine sovereignty and the fluidity of time in relation to spiritual events.

passage_content: והנה כל זה תליא במעשינו כאמרז"ל זכו אחישנה, וז"א החדש הזה לכם ראש חדשים, וע"ד שדרשו ז"ל (ר"ה דף ו') עדות זה מסורה לכם ולדרכינו כי הכל תליא במעשיהם של ישראל, ואם יזכו יקבע הבוי"ת ניסן בא' מכל חדשי השנה ויהי' ראש חדשים וראשון לגאולה, וע"כ הקדים מלת לכם לראש חדשים, לרמוז על בחי' הנ"ל שלכם מסורה לעשותו ראש לחדשים, וח"ו בלא זכו יתקיים הגאולה בעתה בחדש ניסן שכבר נקבע ועומד עפ"י חשבון וזה ירמוז ראשון הוא לכם, הקדים ראשון למלת לכם שכבר נקבע ראשיתה שלא ע"י מעשיכם, ואפשר דע"כ לא נצטוו ישראל בפסח דורות שיהי' טעון בקור ד' ימים, יען כי הקב"ה מצפה שיגיעו ישראל לבחי' זכו ומיד יגאלו, ויקבע הבוי"ת הלילה הזה בא' מלילות השנה, ואין הקב"ה רוצה להמתין עוד ד' ימים זמן ביקור קרבן פסח, אלא יעשו ישראל הפסח מיד כשיעלה רצונו ית' לגאלם.
translation: And behold, all this depends on our actions, as our sages have said, "If they merit, I will hasten it." This is the meaning of "This month shall be for you the head of the months." And according to what our sages have expounded (Rosh Hashanah 6), this testimony is entrusted to you and to your ways, for everything depends on the actions of Israel. If they merit, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will establish the month of Nisan as the first of all the months of the year, and it will be the head of the months and the first for redemption. Therefore, He preceded the word "for you" to "the head of the months," to hint at the above aspect that it is entrusted to you to make it the head of the months. And Heaven forbid, if they do not merit, the redemption will occur in its time in the month of Nisan, which has already been established according to calculation, and this will hint that the first is for you. He preceded "the first" to the word "for you," as its beginning has already been established not through your actions. And it is possible that this is why Israel was not commanded regarding the Passover of generations to require four days of examination for the Passover offering, because the Holy One, Blessed be He, is waiting for Israel to reach the level of "merit," and immediately they will be redeemed, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will establish this night as one of the nights of the year. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not want to wait another four days for the time of examining the Passover offering, but rather Israel should perform the Passover immediately when it arises in His will to redeem them.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the redemption of Israel is contingent upon their actions, as indicated by the phrase "Zochu, Achishena" (if they merit, it will come sooner). It highlights the significance of the month of Nissan as the beginning of months and the first month of redemption, suggesting that if the Israelites merit it, they can establish Nissan as a time of immediate redemption. Conversely, if they do not merit it, the redemption will occur at its appointed time, reinforcing the idea that divine timing is linked to human merit and actions. The text also suggests that God desires an immediate response from the Israelites, indicating a readiness for redemption without delay.

passage_content: ועכשיו לגודל ההסתרה והשפלות לא הגענו לבחי' זכו עדיין, אבל הבוי"ת ברוב חסדו יגאל אותנו למען שמו המחולל בגוים כמ"ש וירא כי אין איש וישתומם כי אין מפגיע, וכתיב למעני למעני אעשה, וישפיע הארת קדושה וטהרה בלבות בנ"י ויעשו תשובה, ועי"ז נזכה לבחי' זכו אחישנה, ואולי ע"ז ירמוז הוא הלילה הזה, הוא לשון נסתר מורה על הסתרה וחשכות הגלות, ובחסדי השי"ת נזכה במהרה שיהי' הלילה "הזה" התגלות הגאולה והתגלות כבוד מלכותו עלינו, ועד אז אין בידנו להקריב קרבן פסח כ"א באמירה ע"ד ונשלמה פרים שפתינו ועל זה ירמוז "לאמר" דברו אל בנ"י לאמר בעשור לחדש הזה וגו' ירמוז על זמן גלותינו שיקיימו ישראל כל מצות הפסח באמירה, או אפ"ל דכוונת לאמר שיתפללו ישראל על הגאולה, לאמר בעשור לחדש הזה ויקחו להם איש שה לבית אבות וגו' ולא יתמהמה ולא יתאחר עוד.
translation: And now, due to the great concealment and degradation, we have not yet reached the level of being pure, but the Blessed One, in His abundant kindness, will redeem us for the sake of His name, which is profaned among the nations, as it is written, "And He saw that there was no man and was astonished that there was no intercessor," and it is written, "For My sake, for My sake I will act." He will bestow a light of holiness and purity in the hearts of the children of Israel, and they will repent, and through this, we will merit the level of purity speedily. And perhaps this is hinted at by "this night," which is a language of concealment indicating the concealment and darkness of the exile. And by the kindness of the Holy One, Blessed be He, may we merit soon that this "night" will be the revelation of redemption and the revelation of the glory of His kingdom upon us. Until then, we are unable to bring the Passover offering except through a verbal declaration, as it is written, "And we will pay the bulls of our lips," and this is hinted at by "saying," "Speak to the children of Israel, saying, on the tenth of this month," which hints at the time of our exile, that Israel will fulfill all the commandments of Passover through verbal declaration, or it can be said that the intention of "saying" is that Israel should pray for redemption, saying, "On the tenth of this month, let them take for themselves each man a lamb for their fathers' houses," and they should not delay or postpone any longer.
summary: The passage reflects on the current state of spiritual concealment and degradation, emphasizing that despite this, God's abundant mercy will ultimately lead to redemption for the sake of His name. It highlights the importance of repentance among the Jewish people, which will enable them to attain a state of purity and merit the imminent arrival of redemption. The text also suggests that the current night symbolizes the hiddenness of exile, yet it anticipates a future revelation of divine glory. Until that time, the Jewish people are encouraged to express their longing for redemption through prayer and the fulfillment of Passover commandments, even in their current circumstances.

passage_content: ואכלתם אתו בחפזון פסח הוא לד', פרש"י הקרבן הוא קרוי פסח ע"ש הדלוג והפסיחה וכו', ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לשם שמים וכו' זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, וצ"ב הקישור והחיוב בכל המצות לעשותם לש"ש ולשם פעלם, ומה ענינו אל הפסיחה והדלוג דייקא, ובספה"ק בני יששכר עמד בדברי רש"י אלו, וכתב שלא ראה עדיין פי' מספיק מתיישב אל הלב.
translation: "And you shall eat it in haste; it is the Passover to the Lord." Rashi explains that the sacrifice is called Passover because of the skipping and the leaping, etc. "And you shall perform all its works for the sake of Heaven," etc. "In remembrance of His name, which is called Passover," thus Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And it is to be questioned the connection and obligation in all the commandments to perform them for the sake of Heaven and in the name of their action, and what is the relevance to the skipping and leaping specifically. And in the holy book "Bnei Yissachar," he stood by these words of Rashi and wrote that he has not yet seen a sufficient explanation that is satisfying to the heart.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing its name "Pesach," which relates to the concepts of leaping and skipping. It raises questions about the obligation to perform all commandments for the sake of Heaven and how this connects specifically to the themes of leaping and skipping. The author references the work of the "Bnei Yissachar," who noted a lack of satisfactory explanations regarding these connections. Overall, it highlights the importance of intention in religious observance and the deeper meanings behind the rituals.

passage_content: ב) שמורים הוא לד' להוציאם מארץ מצרים הוא הלילה הזה לד' שמורים לכל בני ישראל לדורותם, פרש"י ז"ל ליל שמורים הוא לד' שהי' הקב"ה שומר ומצפה לו לקיים הבטחתו להוציאם מארץ מצרים, שמורים לכל בנ"י לדורותם משומר ובא מן המזיקין כענין שנאמר ולא יתן המשחית לבוא אל בתיכם וגו' וצ"ב לפרש"י ז"ל מלת לדורותם אין לו קישור, ובתרגום יוב"ע פי' שמורים לכל בני ישראל לדורותם שהלילה הזה שמור להם לגאולה לדורותם, וע"ד שאמרז"ל שגאולה העתידה תהי' בניסן ובליל פסח דייקא, ולפירושו שמורים לד' ושמורים לבני ישראל תרווייהו בענין הגאולה, אמנם לפרש"י ז"ל סיפא לאו רישא וצ"ב כוונת הקישור.
translation: B) It is a night of watchfulness for the Lord to take them out of the land of Egypt; this night is a night of watchfulness for the Lord for all the children of Israel throughout their generations. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that it is a night of watchfulness for the Lord because the Holy One, blessed be He, was watching and waiting to fulfill His promise to take them out of the land of Egypt. It is a night of watchfulness for all of Israel throughout their generations, protected and safeguarded from harm, as it is stated, "And the destroyer shall not come into your houses," etc. It is difficult to understand Rashi's explanation of the term "throughout their generations," as it does not have a clear connection. In the translation of Yonatan ben Uziel, it is explained that it is a night safeguarded for all the children of Israel throughout their generations, that this night is preserved for them for redemption throughout their generations, in accordance with what our sages of blessed memory said that the future redemption will be in Nissan and specifically on the night of Passover. According to his explanation, both "safeguarded for the Lord" and "safeguarded for the children of Israel" pertain to the matter of redemption. However, according to Rashi's explanation, the end does not connect to the beginning, and it is difficult to understand the intent of the connection.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the night of Passover, which is described as a night "guarded" by God for the purpose of redeeming the Israelites from Egypt. Rashi explains that this night is a time when God awaited the fulfillment of His promise to liberate the Jewish people, emphasizing its importance for future generations. The text also highlights the connection between this night and the future redemption, suggesting that the ultimate redemption will occur in the month of Nisan, specifically on Passover night. Overall, it underscores the theme of divine protection and the continuity of redemption throughout Jewish history.

passage_content: ונל"פ בדרך רמז מוסר בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק (פ' בא דף ל"ו ע"א) א"ר יוסי מ"ד ופסח ד' על הפתח, מאי על הפתח, ופסח ד' עליכם מבעי' לי', אבל על הפתח וכו' זהו פתח הגוף, ואי זהו פתח הגוף הוי אומר זו מילה וכו', ולהלן שם בזוה"ק מפרש ע"ד הסוד מפני מה המילה נקראת פתח הגוף, משום דאיהו פתחא ומשיכא דרוחא וגופא, והיינו רזא דתנינן והוא יושב פתח האוהל משום דאתגלייא יו"ד וכו' עיי"ש, ואפ"ל גם עפ"י דרך הפשט עפימ"ד במכילתא פ' בא ומנין שלא נחשדו ישראל על העריות במצרים, שנא' ויצא בן אשה ישראלית, להודיע שבחן של ישראל שלא הי' ביניהם אלא זה ופרסמו ופרטו הכתוב, ועליהם מפורש בקבלה גן נעול אחותי כלה גל נעול מעין חתום, גן נעול אלו הזכרים גל נעול מעיין חתום אלו הנקבות, ובגמ' פסחים (דף פ"ז ע"א) דרשו רז"ל עה"פ (תהלים קמ"ד) בנותינו כזויות מחוטבות אלו בנות ישראל שאוגדות פתחיהן לבעליהן פרש"י סותמות פתחיהן וכו' ואינן נבעלות לאחרים עיי"ש, ומה"ט כינוהו רז"ל פתחא דגופא באנשים וגם בנקבות מפני שצריך שמירה ונעילה, כי בפרט זה מתגבר היצה"ר מאוד כידוע, גם הוא פתחא דרוחא ונשמתא כמ"ש בזוה"ק, כי שמירת הברית הוא יסוד תקון כל המדות, והוא שער ופתח ליכנס דרך בה לכוחות הקדושה, וחלילה להיפך נעשית לו פתח ליכנס לעומק הקליפות ר"ל, דכל פגם מכניס לכוחות הסט"א, ובכל תיקון מתקרבין אל הקדושה, ולטעם זה נקראת פתח והבן.
translation: And we will explain in a hint of moral teaching, in advance of the words of the Zohar (Parashat Bo, page 36a): Rabbi Yossi said, "And the Lord will pass over the entrance." What does it mean, "over the entrance"? It should have said, "And the Lord will pass over you," but "over the entrance" etc. This is the entrance of the body, and which is the entrance of the body? It means this is circumcision, etc. And further on, the Zohar explains in the manner of the secret why circumcision is called the entrance of the body, because it is the entrance and the conduit of the spirit and the body. And this is the secret of what we learned, "And he was sitting at the entrance of the tent," because the letter Yud was revealed, etc. See there. And it can also be explained according to the simple meaning, as it is stated in the Mekilta, Parashat Bo, and from where do we know that Israel was not suspected of immorality in Egypt? As it is said, "And a son went out of a Hebrew woman," to inform us of the merit of Israel, that there was among them only this, and the text publicized and detailed it. And concerning them, it is explicitly stated in the tradition, "A locked garden is my sister, my bride; a sealed fountain," a locked garden refers to the males, a sealed fountain refers to the females. And in the Gemara Pesachim (page 87a), our sages expounded on the verse (Psalms 144), "Our daughters are like cornerstones, polished after the fashion of a palace," these are the daughters of Israel who bind their entrances to their husbands. Rashi explains that they close their entrances, etc., and they are not defiled by others, see there. And for this reason, our sages called it the entrance of the body in men and also in women, because it requires guarding and locking, for in this particular matter, the evil inclination is greatly strengthened, as is known. It is also the entrance of the spirit and the soul, as it is said in the Zohar, for the guarding of the covenant is the foundation of the rectification of all the attributes, and it is a gate and an entrance to enter through it into the forces of holiness. And, heaven forbid, the opposite happens, it becomes an entrance for him to enter into the depths of the klipot, may God save us, for every blemish brings in the forces of the other side, and with every rectification, we draw closer to holiness. And for this reason, it is called an entrance, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of circumcision as a spiritual "opening" of the body, linking it to the concept of guarding one's purity and the struggle against the evil inclination. It emphasizes that the act of circumcision serves as a protective measure, allowing access to holiness while preventing the entry of negative forces. The text highlights the importance of maintaining moral integrity, particularly in relation to sexual purity, as a means to strengthen one's connection to the divine. Ultimately, it presents the idea that every flaw in this area can lead to spiritual detriment, while every rectification brings one closer to sanctity.

passage_content: והנה אמרז"ל במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שטען שר של ים מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עוע"ז, הללו מגלי עריות והללו, והשיב לו הקב"ה הללו באונס והללו ברצון, והקשו המפרשים ז"ל דהרי טענת אונס בע"ז ליתא, וה"ה ביהרג ואל יעבור, גם הרי כבר פרשו ישראל עצמם מע"ז לפני יציאתם ממצרים, וכמ"ש רז"ל (במד"ר פ' ט"ז סי' ב') משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן למצוה, גם מה שקיטרג הללו והללו מגלי עריות אינו אמת, דהרי כל ישראל נשמרו מעריות במצרים כאמרז"ל (ויק"ר פ' ל"ב סי' ה') אחת היתה ופירסמה הכתוב, וא"כ טענתו מעיקרא ליתא, ומה צורך להצטדקות דאנוסים היו, ואפשר שהקטרוג הי' על חטא ההרהור, דאף שנשמרו ישראל מעריות בפועל, מ"מ להיותם מסובבים בזוהמת מצרים זמן רב, לא נטהרו מחטא ההרהור לגמרי ואף דמחשבה רעה אין הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, אבל מ"מ הי' זה טענה בפי המקטרג, דהרהור ה"ה תולדה דעריות ומביא לידי מעשה ר"ל, ובפרט בע"ז שמענישים אף על ההרהור כמו שדרשו רז"ל (קדושין ל"ט ע"ב) מהכתוב (יחזקאל י"ד) למען תפוש את בית ישראל בלבם עיי"ש, והבוי"ת לימד זכות על ישראל הללו באונס והללו ברצון, דהשעבוד וטירוף הדעת גרם להם כל זה, והמצריים המה הגורמים וראויים שילקו גם על חטאם של ישראל.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that the ministering angel of the sea argued: What is the difference between these and those? These are idol worshippers and those are idol worshippers; these are guilty of illicit relations and those as well. And the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to him: These are coerced and those are willing. The commentators of blessed memory questioned this, for the claim of coercion does not apply to idol worship, and the same applies to the principle of "be killed rather than transgress." Furthermore, the Israelites had already distanced themselves from idol worship before their departure from Egypt, as our Sages of blessed memory stated (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat 16, Section 2): "Withdraw your hands from idol worship and take for yourselves sheep for the mitzvah." Also, the accusation that these and those are guilty of illicit relations is not true, for all of Israel guarded themselves against illicit relations in Egypt, as our Sages of blessed memory said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashat 32, Section 5): "There was one [woman] and the verse publicized it." Therefore, his initial claim is unfounded, and what need is there for the justification that they were coerced? It is possible that the accusation was regarding the sin of improper thoughts, for although the Israelites guarded themselves against illicit relations in action, nevertheless, having been surrounded by the impurity of Egypt for a long time, they were not completely purified from the sin of improper thoughts. And although the Holy One, blessed be He, does not consider an evil thought as an action, nonetheless, this was a claim in the mouth of the accuser, for improper thought is indeed a consequence of illicit relations and can lead to action, G-d forbid. Especially in the case of idol worship, for they are punished even for improper thoughts, as our Sages of blessed memory derived from the verse (Ezekiel 14): "In order to seize the house of Israel in their hearts," as explained there. And the Baal HaTurim taught merit for Israel: these were coerced and those were willing, for the subjugation and confusion of mind caused them all this, and the Egyptians are the ones who caused it and are worthy of being punished for the sin of Israel as well.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic debate regarding the sins of the Israelites in Egypt, contrasting their actions with those of idolaters. It emphasizes that while the Israelites were coerced into sinning, the idolaters acted willingly, highlighting the concept of divine judgment based on intention. The text suggests that although the Israelites maintained physical abstinence from immorality, they were still influenced by the impurity of their surroundings, leading to thoughts of sin. Ultimately, it argues that the Egyptians, as the source of this spiritual corruption, bear responsibility for the Israelites' struggles.

passage_content: ועכ"פ מבואר דבשעת יציאתם ממצרים אף שהופרשו מטומאת מצרים, לא נטהרו לגמרי מזוהמתם עד מתן תורה, כמ"ש ברעיא מהימנא (זוה"ק פ' אמור צ"ז ע"א) וספרתם לכם ממחרת השבת וגו' פקודא דא לספור ספירת העומר וכו' ורזא דא, ישראל אע"ג דאתדכו למעבד פסחא ונפקו ממסאבו, לא הוו שלמין ודכיין כדקא חזי וכו', כאתתא דנפקא ממסאבו, וכיון דנפקא מתמן ולהלאה וספרה לה, אוף הכא ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, ובמתן תורה נזדככו ונטהרו ונתעלו כמלאכי השרת, ואיתא בפדר"א שכל. אותן שעמדו במעמד הנבחר לא ראו קרי מימיהן, ומעיקרא הוציאם השי"ת ממצרים ע"ש זכות העתיד, דקמי שמיא גליא שיטהרו לגמרי בתיקון מדת היסוד בשלימות בשעת מ"ת, ואפשר שנרמז זה בדברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל, ופסח ד' על הפתח, ופסח ד' עליכם מבעי' לי', אבל על הפתח זה פתח הגוף, ואי זהו זו מילה אף שלא השלימו התיקון במידה זו, נשתמרו מן השמים בדרך נס כמו שיבואר להלן, והקדים השי"ת גאולתם ע"ש העתיד.
translation: And nevertheless, it is clear that at the time of their departure from Egypt, even though they were separated from the impurity of Egypt, they were not completely purified from their defilement until the giving of the Torah, as it is written in the Ra'aya Meheimna (Zohar, Parashat Emor 97a) "And you shall count for yourselves from the day after the Sabbath..." This is a commandment to count the Omer, etc., and the secret of this is that Israel, although they were prepared to perform the Passover and left their burdens, were not complete and whole as they should have been, as is evident, etc., like a woman who leaves her burdens. And since they left from there and onward and counted, so too here with Israel, etc., as stated there. And at the giving of the Torah, they were refined, purified, and elevated like the ministering angels. And it is stated in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer that all those who stood at the chosen assembly did not see a blemish in their days. And initially, the Holy One, Blessed be He, took them out of Egypt in the merit of the future, for before Heaven it is revealed that they would be completely purified in the rectification of the attribute of foundation in perfection at the time of the giving of the Torah. And it is possible that this is hinted at in the aforementioned words of the Zohar, "And the Lord will pass over the entrance," and "The Lord will pass over you," but regarding the entrance, this refers to the entrance of the body. And which is this? It is circumcision, for although they did not complete the rectification in this measure, they were preserved from Heaven in a miraculous way, as will be explained below, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, hastened their redemption in the merit of the future.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual state of the Israelites during their exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that although they were separated from the impurity of Egypt, they were not fully purified until the giving of the Torah. It highlights the idea that their redemption was based on future merit, as they were destined to achieve a complete spiritual elevation at Mount Sinai, akin to the angels. The text also suggests that divine protection was granted to them, allowing them to remain untainted despite their incomplete spiritual rectification at that time.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בדברי רש"י ז"ל שמורים לכל בני ישראל לדורותם, משומר ובא מן המזיקין, כענין שנא' ולא יתן המשחית לבוא אל בתיכם וגו', ולכאורה הרי כתיב ועברתי באמ"צ בלילה הזה וגו' ודרשו רז"ל אני ולא מלאך אנו ולא השליח, וא"כ ליתא לחששא דכיון שניתן רשות למשחית אינו מבחין וכו' ומהו שאמה"כ ולא יתן המשחית וגו', ובמכילתא איתא שמורים לכל בני ישראל מגיד שכל ישראל צריכים להשתמר בו עכ"ל וצ"ב הכוונה, ובמרכבת המשנה מפרש הואיל ובאותה הלילה נאמר ואתם אל תצאו איש מפתח ביתו, הוקבעה סכנה זו לדורות שצריכים להשתמר בו, עוד במדרש מגיד שישראל עתידין להשתמר בו עכ"ד המרכבת, ולדרכינו אפ"ל הכוונה, מפני שבליל יציאתם התגברו עליהם כחות הטומאה מאוד להחטיאם ר"ל ולמנוע עי"ז גאולתם, וע"ד שפי' התויו"ט ולא אירע קרי לכה"ג ביום הכפורים, שהי' התגברות היצה"ר גדולה מאוד להחטיאו לפי שבו תלוי כפרתן של כל ישראל, ולזה הי' צורך לנס שימלט מהתגברותן עיי"ש, וכמו"כ בליל היציאה הוצרכו ישראל לשמירה זו בדרך נס, כי אין בכח בשר ודם לעמוד נגד התגברות קשה כ"כ, ולזה הבטיח הבוי"ת להם ולא יתן המשחית לבוא אל בתיכם וגו', ירמוז על נוקבי' דס"מ המחטיא בחטא השחתה ר"ל, ושמה כשם העבירה, משחית ע"ש ההשחתה.
translation: And even though in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, it is stated that it is a safeguard for all the children of Israel for their generations, "guarded and coming from the destroyers," as it is said, "And the destroyer shall not come into your houses," etc., at first glance it is written, "And I will pass through the land of Egypt this night," etc., and our Sages interpreted, "I and not an angel, we and not a messenger." Therefore, there is no concern that since permission was given to the destroyer, he does not distinguish, etc. And what is meant by the verse, "And the destroyer shall not come," etc.? And in the Mekilta it is stated that it is a safeguard for all the children of Israel, indicating that all of Israel must guard themselves with it. Thus, the intention is unclear. And in the Merkevet HaMishnah it is explained that since on that night it was said, "And you shall not go out, each man from the door of his house," this danger was established for generations that they must guard themselves with it. Furthermore, in the Midrash, it is indicated that Israel will need to guard themselves with it in the future. According to our path, the intention may be that on the night of their departure, the forces of impurity greatly intensified to cause them to sin, Heaven forbid, and thereby prevent their redemption. This is in line with the explanation of the Tzayit U'Tziv, that it did not happen to such a degree on Yom Kippur, where the evil inclination was greatly intensified to cause him to sin, for it is dependent on the atonement of all Israel. Therefore, there was a need for a miracle to be saved from their intensification, as stated there. Likewise, on the night of the departure, Israel needed this protection in a miraculous way, for there is no strength in flesh and blood to withstand such a severe intensification. Therefore, the Blessed One promised them, "And the destroyer shall not come into your houses," etc., hinting at the piercing of the evil inclination that causes sin through destruction, Heaven forbid, and there, as the name of the transgression, "destroyer" is named after the destruction.
summary: The passage discusses the divine protection granted to the Israelites during their exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that this protection is not merely a historical event but a lasting safeguard for all generations. It highlights the intense spiritual dangers faced by the Israelites, particularly the forces of impurity that sought to hinder their redemption. The text underscores that God's promise to prevent the destroyer from entering their homes signifies a miraculous intervention necessary to overcome overwhelming spiritual threats. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that reliance on divine protection is essential in the face of powerful negative forces.

passage_content: וז"ש רש"י ז"ל שמורים לכל בנ"י לדורותם, משומר ובא מן המזיקין כענין שנא' ולא יתן המשחית וגו', וירמוז לדורותם שיהיו נשמרים מחטא הנורא שהוא פגם הברית ר"ל, וה"ז הבטחה על שמירת הדורות ג"כ, גם נרמז בזה הבטחה לדורות העתידים, כי גאולה העתידה תהי' ג"כ בליל פסח, ובכל ליל פסח נתעורר כח הגאולה, וע"כ כל ישראל צריכין להשתמר בו מהתגברות כוחות הטומאה כנ"ל, והבטיח הבוי"ת שמורים לכל בנ"י לדורותם שינצלו מהתגברותן כנ"ל, והנה איתא בזוה"ק דהשומר ברית שריא עלי' שם שמים, ובאינו שומר הברית הס"מ שורה עליו ר"ל, ואפשר לרמוז בדברי רש"י ז"ל הנ"ל הקרבן קרוי פסח ע"ש הדלוג והפסיחה וכו' וכענין שנא' ופסח ד' על הפתח ולא יתן המשחית לבוא אל בתיכם וגו', וירמוז על פתחא דגופא כמ"ש בזוה"ק ונשתמרו ישראל בקדושת היסוד בליל היציאה, ולזה סיים ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לשם שמים, להתקדש ולהתטהר בקדושת היסוד ולהשרות עליכם שם שמים זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח.
translation: And this is what Rashi, of blessed memory, says: they are guardians for all the children of Israel for their generations, preserved and protected from harm, as it is stated, "And the destroyer shall not come in," etc. This hints to their generations that they should be safeguarded from the terrible sin which is the blemish of the covenant, may it be said. This is a promise regarding the preservation of the generations as well. It also hints at a promise for future generations, for the future redemption will also be on Passover night, and on every Passover night the power of redemption is awakened. Therefore, all of Israel must guard themselves from the intensification of the forces of impurity, as mentioned above. And the Blessed One has promised guardianship for all the children of Israel for their generations that they will be saved from their intensification, as mentioned above. And it is stated in the Zohar that one who guards the covenant has the Name of Heaven resting upon him, while one who does not guard the covenant has the accuser resting upon him, may it be said. It is possible to hint in the words of Rashi, of blessed memory, that the offering is called Passover because of the leaping and skipping, etc., as it is stated, "And the Lord will pass over the entrance, and He will not allow the destroyer to come into your houses," etc. This hints at the entrance of the body, as stated in the Zohar, and Israel was preserved in the sanctity of the foundation on the night of the exodus. For this reason, it concludes, "And you shall do all His work for the sake of Heaven," to sanctify and purify in the sanctity of the foundation and to have the Name of Heaven rest upon you, a remembrance of His Name which is called Passover.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of safeguarding the covenant, particularly during Passover, as a means of protection from spiritual harm and impurity. It highlights the promise of divine protection for future generations, ensuring that they remain untainted by the forces of evil. The text connects the act of observing Passover with the preservation of holiness and the sanctification of one's actions, reinforcing the idea that maintaining the covenant leads to divine favor and redemption. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of spiritual vigilance and purity in achieving salvation.

passage_content: או אפ"ל בדברי רש"י ז"ל הקרבן קרוי פסח ע"ש הדלוג והפסיחה ירמוז על שדילג הקב"ה וקפץ על הזמן לקרב גאולתם של ישראל, שהי' הגזירה על ת' שנה ונגאלו לסוף רד"ו שנה, וכמ"ש בפייט לפ' החודש דילג פעם וזאת רגעה וכו' זמן קפץ עשות רבות, טס וידא ועידן שינה, שקפץ ודילג הקב"ה על הזמן לקרב גלות, וע"כ נצטוינו לעשות זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח ע"ש הדילוג והקפיצה, לקבוע בלבנו אמונה זו, שדבר זה למהר ולקרב הגאולה בדרך דלוג וקפיצה הוא רק ביד הבוי"ת לבדו וכמו שהי' במצרים, ואין בכח אנושי לעשות שום פעולה לזה, ואסור לנו לעשות שום פעולה בענין דחיקת הקץ, רק לעורר רצון העליון ע"י מעשה המצות, ובכח מצות הפסח שהוא ע"ש הדלוג והפסיחה יתעורר רצון העליון ית"ש להחיש גאולתנו, וז"ש הקרבן קרוי פסח ע"ש הדלוג והפסיחה וכו', ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לשם שמים, לעורר רצון העליון ב"ה למהר גאולתנו, זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח, ונצטווינו לעשות זכר לשמו, כדי לקבוע בלבנו אמונה כזו כנ"ל, וז"ש ליל שמורים הוא לד' להוציאם מארץ מצרים, פרש"י שהי' הקב"ה שומר ומצפה לו לקיים הבטחתו להוציאם מארץ מצרים, ולטעם זה קפץ ודילג על הזמן לקרב גאולתם, שמורים לכל בני ישראל לדורתם משומר ובא מן המזיקין, שכל ישראל צריכים שמירה מן המזיקין, היינו דוחקי הקץ שהן המה גרמו חורבן ואבדון לישראל בכל הדורות, וקשים יותר מן המזיקים רוחות ושדים ר"ל, הבוי"ת ישמרנו ויצילנו מהם ומהמונם.
translation:
The Hebrew text translates to:

"Or alternatively, in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, the sacrifice is called Passover because of the skipping and the leaping, which alludes to how the Holy One, blessed be He, skipped and leaped over time to bring closer the redemption of Israel, as the decree was for 400 years, and they were redeemed after 210 years, as it is said in the piyyut for the month: 'He skipped once, and this calmed, etc., time leaped to do many things, flew and saw, and the time leaped,' that the Holy One, blessed be He, skipped and leaped over time to bring closer the exile. Therefore, we are commanded to make a remembrance of His name, which is called Passover because of the skipping and the leaping, to establish in our hearts this faith, that this matter of hastening and bringing the redemption in a manner of skipping and leaping is solely in the hands of the Creator, blessed be He, just as it was in Egypt, and no human power can do any action towards this. We are forbidden to take any action regarding hastening the end, only to awaken the supreme will through the performance of the commandments, and through the power of the Passover commandment, which is named for the skipping and the leaping, the supreme will, blessed be He, will be aroused to hasten our redemption. And this is what is meant by the sacrifice being called Passover because of the skipping and the leaping, etc. And you shall perform all its services for the sake of Heaven, to awaken the supreme will, blessed be He, to hasten our redemption, a remembrance of His name which is called Passover, and we are commanded to make a remembrance of His name, in order to establish in our hearts such faith as mentioned above. And this is what is meant by 'a night of watchings' is for the Lord to bring them out of the land of Egypt, Rashi explains that the Holy One, blessed be He, was watching and waiting to fulfill His promise to bring them out of the land of Egypt, and for this reason He skipped and leaped over time to bring closer their redemption, a watch for all the children of Israel for their generations, from the watchman and coming from the harmful ones, that all of Israel needs protection from the harmful ones, meaning those who hasten the end, for they have caused destruction and ruin to Israel throughout the generations, and they are more severe than harmful spirits and demons, may the Creator protect us and save us from them and from their multitude."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing that it symbolizes God's miraculous intervention in time to expedite the redemption of the Israelites from Egypt. It highlights the belief that true redemption is solely in God's hands, and human efforts to hasten it are forbidden; instead, one should focus on performing commandments to invoke divine will. The text also underscores the importance of faith in God's promises and the need for divine protection against spiritual dangers that threaten the Jewish people throughout history. Ultimately, it calls for a deep-rooted faith in God's ability to bring about redemption swiftly.

passage_content: במכילתא וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, מהו כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו עכ"ל המכילתא (והובא ברש"י ז"ל עה"ת) וצ"ב מאי למימרא שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הבוב"ה, ומדוע צריך יתור קרא להורות על זה.
translation: In the Mechilta, it is stated, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." What does it mean, "so they did"? It means that even Moses and Aaron did so, as stated in the Mechilta (and brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the Torah). It is necessary to inquire what is the implication that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandments of the Blessed Holy One, and why a superfluous verse is needed to indicate this.
summary: The passage discusses the verse from the Mekilta that emphasizes how the Israelites followed God's commands as instructed to Moses and Aaron, highlighting that even Moses and Aaron adhered to these divine commandments. The inquiry arises regarding the necessity of this emphasis, questioning why it is important to note that Moses and Aaron also fulfilled God's commandments. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the unity and obedience of leadership in fulfilling divine will, illustrating that true leadership is exemplified by adherence to God's instructions.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם מ"ש בזוה"ק וחכמי אמת דהמצות שעושין בעודו מלוכלך בעבירות ר"ל חוטפין הס"א ומוסיפין עי"ז כח בהטומאה ר"ל, והובא בעט"ז ובאר הטב (או"ח סי' תק"ע) עיי"ש, ובספה"ק דרך פקודיך בהקדמתו האריך בענין זה טובא ונעתיק מקצת לשונו, אמר הנביא נירו לכם ניר ואל תזרעו אל הקוצים, כמו שהזורע אל הקוצים קודם שמתקן את האדמה ומסקלה מאבני נגף והקוצים, הנה עמלו לריק ומקלקל את התבואה הנזרעת, ואדרבה נותן כח יותר בהקוצים שיסתבכו וירבו ויגדילו וכו', כמו כן הוא הענין בעניני התורה ותפלה ומצות, אשר יעשה אותם האדם בעודו נקרא רשע, ונסבך בקוצים ואבני נגף מהקליפות וסטרין בישין נותן ח"ו כח בהם, אמנם אל יאמר האדם לכשאפנה מן העבירות אשר בידי ואעשה תשובה הקצובה לכל חטא ועון אז אשנה, ע"כ אמר התנא שלא יאות לומר כן דשמא לא תפנה וכו', אבל ענין התשובה הוא החרטה באמת על מה שעשה והכעיס להבוי"ת ויקבל קבלה אמיתיית שאפי' יהבי לי כל חללי דעלמא לא ישוב עוד לדבר הרע הזה, ואם ככה הוא מחשבתו ולבו טרם עסקו בתורה ומצות, יקובל הכל לרצון לפני השי"ת, ואם לאו הוא ח"ו כזורע אל הקוצים עכ"ל.
translation: And we will explain in advance what is stated in the Zohar and by the true sages, that the commandments performed while one is still stained with transgressions, God forbid, strengthen the forces of impurity and thereby add power to the defilement. This is brought in the "Ateres Zekeinim" and in "Be'er HaTev" (Orach Chaim, Siman 590), see there. And in the holy book "Derech Pekudecha," in its introduction, he elaborates extensively on this matter, and we will quote some of his words. The prophet said, "Plow for yourselves a plowing and do not sow among thorns," just as one who sows among thorns before he prepares the land and clears it of stumbling stones and thorns, his labor is in vain and he ruins the grain that is sown. On the contrary, he gives more strength to the thorns so that they become entangled, multiply, and grow, etc. So too is the matter regarding Torah, prayer, and commandments, which a person performs while still being called wicked, entangled in thorns and stumbling stones from the klipot and the evil forces, God forbid, gives them strength. However, a person should not say, "When I turn away from the transgressions in my hands and do the prescribed repentance for every sin and iniquity, then I will change." Therefore, the Tanna said that one should not say such a thing, for perhaps he will not turn away, etc. But the matter of repentance is true regret for what he has done and angered the Creator, and he should accept a true commitment that even if they give me all the pleasures of the world, I will not return to this evil deed. And if this is his thought and his heart before he engages in Torah and commandments, everything will be accepted favorably before the Holy One, Blessed be He. And if not, he is, God forbid, like one who sows among thorns.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of sincere repentance before engaging in Torah study and mitzvot, emphasizing that performing commandments while still entrenched in sin can inadvertently empower negative forces. It warns against the mindset of postponing repentance until after one has corrected their wrongdoings, as this can lead to spiritual futility. True repentance involves genuine remorse and a firm commitment to change, which, if present, can render one's subsequent religious actions acceptable to God. Without this sincere intention, one risks exacerbating their spiritual entanglement, akin to sowing seeds among thorns.

passage_content: אמנם עדיין לא עלתה לנו מרפא וארוכה בעצה זו, דבערך שפלות דורנו קשה להשיג אף בחי' תשובה כזו, כי הלבבות סתומים ואטומים וזעירין אינון שיוכלו להכניס בלבבם חרטה וקבלה אמיתית שלא ישובו לכסלה עוד ואם נימא שח"ו ימנע האדם מתורה ומצות עד שיגיע לנקודה האמיתית הזאת, לא מצאנו ידינו ורגלינו בביהמ"ד וח"ו תפוג תורה, ולא ניחא לי' למרייהו דלימרו הכי, ובספה"ק אור לישרים (דרוש א') נתן עצה לומר לשם יחוד קוב"ה ושכנתי' קודם כל מעשה המצוה ותורה ותפלה, והוי כמתנה בפירוש שלא לצאת ידי חובתו באופן אחר רק אם יהי' יחוד קוב"ה, וזולת זה הוי מתכוין שלא לצאת י"ח, ובזה כ"ע מודים דאינו יוצא, אפי' למ"ד מצות אין צריכות כוונה, וא"כ אם רוצים הסט"א לחטוף אין להם מה לחטוף. וכיון שאין חוטפין המצוה עולה למעלה עכ"ח בתוס' ביאור כפי מה שביארו ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' תשא עיי"ש).
translation: Indeed, we have not yet attained healing, and this advice is lengthy, for regarding the lowliness of our generation, it is difficult to achieve even such a level of repentance, as the hearts are closed and sealed, and few are those who can instill in their hearts true regret and acceptance that they will not return to folly again. And if we say that, Heaven forbid, a person should refrain from Torah and commandments until they reach this true point, we would find ourselves without hands and feet in the house of study, and Heaven forbid, the Torah would fade away. It is not pleasing to them to say such a thing. And in the holy book "Or L'Yashar" (Drush 1), it was advised to say "for the sake of the unity of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and His Shechinah" before every act of the commandment, Torah, and prayer, and it should be as a gift explicitly that one does not fulfill their obligation in any other way except if there is the unity of the Holy One, Blessed be He. Otherwise, one intends not to fulfill their obligation, and in this, all agree that one does not fulfill, even according to the opinion that commandments do not require intention. Therefore, if the other side wishes to snatch, they have nothing to snatch. And since they do not snatch, the commandment ascends above, as explained in the additions of the commentary according to what was explained by the holy Rabbi Yisroel Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Tisa, see there).
summary: The passage discusses the challenges of achieving true repentance in the current lowly state of the generation, where many hearts are closed and unable to genuinely accept remorse and commitment to not return to sin. It emphasizes the importance of intention in performing mitzvot, suggesting that one should declare a specific intention to unite with the Divine before engaging in any religious act. This approach ensures that the act is not merely a fulfillment of obligation but a meaningful connection with God, thereby preventing any negative spiritual forces from interfering. Ultimately, it highlights the necessity of sincere intention in elevating one's spiritual practice.

passage_content: ועפי"ד הק' אפ"ל קישור דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ פסח הוא לד', הקרבן הוא קרוי פסח ע"ש הדילוג והפסיחה וכו' ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לשם שמים עכ"ל וצ"ב הקישור, גם הרי כל המצות צריך לעשותן לש"ש ומדוע השמיענו בפסח כן, ואפ"ל עפ"י המבואר בדבריהם ז"ל, כי בצאת ישראל ממצרים נתעלו שלא על סדר המדריגות, כ"א מבירא עמיקתא לרום המעלות בפ"א דרך דלוג וקפיצה, וע"ז ירמוז שם הפסח ע"ש הדלוג והקפיצה, ובייט"פ לפ' החדש פ"ב הביא בשם הרב הקדוש רבינו ברוך זצ"ל לפרש בזה מאמה"כ ופסח ד' על הפתח, דהנה אמרז"ל (שיר רבה ה' ג') פתחו לי פתח כפתחו של מחט ואני אפתח לכם פתח כפתחו של אולם, וצריך להקדים אתערותא דלתתא, אבל בפסח מצרים פסח ד' על הפתח. ר"ל שלא המתין עד שיפתחו ישראל כפתחו של מחט רק הקדים והשפיע לישראל הארה גדולה שלא היו ראויים אליו מצד הכנתם, וכ"ז מגודל חסדו וטובו ית' כי ראה בשפלותם שלא יכלו להתמהמה עד כי יתעלו בסדר המדריגות, אמנם לפי"ז איתא להאי חששא הנ"ל, דכיון שלא נטהרו כראוי ממעשיהם הראשונים, פן יחטפו הסט"א מעשה המצות שלהם ומה יועילו, והעצה לזה להתנות בעשיית המצו' שעושין אותה רק לכוונה לשם שמים ולשם יחוד קוב"ה כמבואר לעיל, ובזה יתבאר קישור דברי רש"י ז"ל פסח הוא לד', הקרבן קרוי פסח ע"ש הדילוג והקפיצה, ירמוז שנתעלו ישראל שלא על סדר המדריגות, ע"כ ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לשם שמים להתנות בפי' לשם יחוד קוב"ה ועי"ז תנצלו מחטיפתם.
translation:
According to the holy opinion, one can say that there is a connection to the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "Pesach is for the Lord," that the sacrifice is called Pesach because of the skipping and the leaping, etc. And you shall perform all its works for the sake of Heaven. This requires clarification regarding the connection, for all the commandments must be performed for the sake of Heaven, and why does it emphasize this specifically for Pesach? 

It can be explained according to what is elucidated in their words, may their memory be blessed, that when Israel left Egypt, they ascended not in the order of the levels, but rather from the deep pit to the heights of the levels in a manner of skipping and leaping. And this is hinted at in the name Pesach, because of the skipping and the leaping. 

And in the Yom Tov of the new month, in chapter two, it is brought in the name of the holy Rabbi, our teacher Baruch, may his memory be blessed, to explain this from the verse "And the Lord passed over the door." Behold, our sages said (Song of Songs Rabbah 5:3), "Open for me a door as the eye of a needle, and I will open for you a door as the entrance of a hall." One must first awaken from below, but on Pesach in Egypt, the Lord passed over the door. This means that He did not wait until Israel opened a door like the eye of a needle, but rather He preceded and bestowed upon Israel a great illumination that they were not worthy of due to their preparation. 

And all this is from the greatness of His kindness and goodness, for He saw their lowliness that they could not delay until they ascended in the order of the levels. However, according to this, there is a concern regarding the aforementioned, that since they had not purified themselves properly from their initial deeds, perhaps the other side would seize their acts of the commandments, and what benefit would they have? 

The advice for this is to stipulate in the performance of the commandments that they do them only with the intention for the sake of Heaven and for the sake of the unification of the Holy One, blessed be He, as explained above. And through this, the connection to the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: "Pesach is for the Lord," the sacrifice is called Pesach because of the skipping and the leaping, hinting that Israel ascended not in the order of the levels. Therefore, "And you shall perform all its works for the sake of Heaven" means to stipulate explicitly for the sake of the unification of the Holy One, blessed be He, and through this, you will be saved from their seizing.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing that it symbolizes the divine "leap" or elevation of the Israelites from a low spiritual state to a higher one, bypassing the usual gradual progression. This miraculous elevation reflects God's immense kindness, as He provided them with a great illumination despite their unworthiness. To safeguard their spiritual integrity and prevent negative influences from their past actions, it is essential for them to perform the commandments with the intention of serving God and achieving unity with the Divine. Thus, the connection between the Passover and the requirement to act for the sake of Heaven is highlighted as a means of spiritual protection.

passage_content: ונ"ל עוד עצה עפימ"ש בספה"ק נועם אלימלך זלה"ה בשם אחיו הה"ק מוה"ר ר' זושא זי"ע לפרש אמרם ז"ל (קידושין דף מ' ע"א) מחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, דלשון מצרפה צ"ב והול"ל מחשבה כמעשה, וביאר הוא ז"ל דישנם המקיימים מצות בפועל המעשה, אבל נחסר להם בחי' המחשבה וכוונה הראוי' ונכונה לקיום מצות ד', נמצא יש להם חלק המעשה בלבד, והנה צדיקים יש להם השתוקקות תמיד לקיים מצות ד' יותר מאשר תשיג ידם לקיימו בפועל, נמצא יש להם עודף מחשבת המצות בלי חלק המעשה, והבוי"ת ברוב חסדו מצרף מחשבת המצו' למעשה, ר"ל להמצו' שנעשה במעשה לבד בלי חלק המחשבה ועי"ז נגמר המצו' בשלימות עכתדה"ק.
translation: And it appears to us another insight according to the words of the holy book Noam Elimelech, may his merit protect us, in the name of his brother, the holy Rabbi Zusha, of blessed memory, to explain their statement, may their memory be a blessing (Kiddushin 40a), that a good thought is joined by the Holy One, blessed be He, to the deed. The term "joined" is puzzling, and it could have said "thought is like a deed." He explained that there are those who fulfill the commandments in action, but they lack the aspect of thought and intention that is proper and fitting for the fulfillment of the commandments of God. Thus, they have only a portion of the deed. However, the righteous have a constant yearning to fulfill the commandments of God more than they can achieve in action, resulting in an excess of thought regarding the commandments without a portion of the deed. And the Blessed One, in His abundant kindness, joins the thought of the commandments to the deed, meaning to the commandments that are done in action alone without a portion of thought, and thereby the commandments are completed in perfection, as is written in the holy text.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that while some individuals fulfill commandments through action, they may lack the proper intention and thought behind those actions. In contrast, righteous individuals often have a strong desire to fulfill commandments, even if they cannot do so in practice, resulting in an abundance of good intentions without corresponding actions. The text emphasizes that God, in His kindness, combines these good thoughts with the actions of those who may lack the proper intention, thereby completing the fulfillment of the commandments in a perfect manner.

passage_content: וענין ההצטרפות הנ"ל אפשר להסביר שהוא מדינא דשותפות, ע"ד שתיקנו רז"ל לומר לפני כל מעשה המצוה הריני מקיים מצו' זו לשם יחוד קוב"ה ושכינתי' ביחודא שלים בשם כל ישראל, נמצא כל או"א מישראל מתנה ועושה המצוה בשם כל ישראל, ויש לכולן חלק בה וה"ה כשותפין וע"כ חזי לאצטרופי, וקמי שמיא גליא איך ראוי לצרפם וע"כ הקב"ה מצרף מחשבתו של זה למעשהו של אחר שהרי יש לשניהם דין שותפות במחשבה ובמעשה וחזיא לאצטרופי.
translation: The matter of the aforementioned joining can be explained as a matter of partnership, similar to what our Sages instituted to say before every act of the mitzvah, "I am fulfilling this mitzvah for the sake of the unity of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and His Shechinah, in complete unity on behalf of all Israel." Thus, every individual from Israel conditions and performs the mitzvah on behalf of all Israel, and they all have a share in it, just like partners. Therefore, it is seen as a joining together, and before Heaven, it is clear how it is appropriate to include them. Hence, the Holy One, Blessed be He, combines the thought of one with the action of another, for both have the status of partnership in thought and action, and it is seen as a joining together.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of partnership in the performance of mitzvot, emphasizing that when an individual fulfills a commandment, they do so with the intention of uniting with the Divine and representing all of Israel. This collective intention creates a shared spiritual bond, allowing each person to partake in the merit of the mitzvah. Consequently, God recognizes this partnership, merging the thoughts and actions of individuals, thereby reinforcing the idea of unity among the Jewish people in their service to God.

passage_content: ומעתה עלתה לנו ארוכה מהאי חששא הנ"ל, דכיון שהבוי"ת מצרף מעשינו למחשבת הצדיקים, אינם יכולים הסט"א לחטוף המצות עוד, אף שהעושה אותם עדיין לא נטהר מכתמי נפשו ומלוכלך בעבירות ר"ל, אולם הרי יש ע"ז שותף גדול, ובשלו אין יכולים ליגע, ולהפרידן א"א כיון שהשתתפו ועשוהו בשם כל ישראל, ה"ה שותפין בכל תנועה של המצוה, וא"כ כל מצו' יש עלי' בעלות מצדיקי אמת המשותפין בה, וחלק זה מונע להסט"א מליגע בה.
translation: And from now on, we have a long ascent from this aforementioned concern, for since the Baal HaTanya connects our deeds to the thoughts of the righteous, the forces of evil cannot snatch the mitzvot anymore, even though the one performing them has not yet been purified from the stains of his soul and is still tainted by sins, Heaven forbid. However, there is a great partner in this, and because of him, they cannot touch it, and it is impossible to separate them since they participated and performed it in the name of all Israel. Thus, they are partners in every movement of the mitzvah, and therefore every mitzvah has an ascent through the righteous true ones who are partners in it, and this portion prevents the forces of evil from touching it.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the righteous (tzaddikim) elevate the actions of individuals, allowing their merits to protect those who may still be tainted by sin. Even if a person has not yet purified themselves, the collective intention and participation in mitzvot (commandments) alongside the tzaddikim create a spiritual shield that prevents negative forces (the sitra achra) from interfering. This partnership in performing mitzvot ensures that the divine merit of the tzaddikim is shared, thus safeguarding the sanctity of the commandments. Ultimately, the involvement of the righteous in these actions serves as a barrier against spiritual harm.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המכילתא הנ"ל וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו עכ"ל, ולא בא היתור ללמדנו שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הפסח דמאי למימרא, אמנם אפ"ל בכוונת דרשתם ז"ל שנצטרפו והשתתפו ישראל במעשה מצו' זו עם מעשיהם של משה ואהרן, ע"י שהותנו בעשייתו שעושים אותו על דעתם כפי שקבלו מפי הגבורה, ועי"ז נתעלה מצותיהם לבחי' גדולה מאוד, וז"א וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן ר"ל על דעתם, ואף משה ואהרן כן עשו והצטרפו עם כל ישראל, והנה משה ואהרן הקריבו הקרבן פסח אבל א"א להקריב יותר מפסח א', וא"א לקיים מצות אכילתו בכולו דהרי נאכל למנויו ונאכל על השובע, א"כ לא יכלו לשבוע די סיפוקם מהשתוקקות מצו' גדולה זו, דלעולם לא יספיק להם דאוהב מצו' לא ישבע נפשו מהם, ע"כ נשארו אצלם מחשבת המצו' עודפת על חלק המעשה, ובני ישראל קיימו המצו' במעשה אבל נחסר להם חלק המחשבה הנכונה והראוי', כי היו עדיין משוקעים בטומאת מצרים כנודע, והקב"ה צירף מעשיהם למחשבתם של משה ואהרן ונגמרה המצו' בשלימות ועל בחי' גדולה בערך קדושתם של משה ואהרן, וז"ש אף משה ואהרן כן עשו וה"ה שותפין במעשה ובמחשבה, וממילא לא יכלה הסט"א ליגע בה ונתקבל לרחמים ולרצון.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Mechilta: "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." And the extra wording does not come to teach us that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment of Passover, for what is there to say? However, it can be said in the intent of their teaching that the Israelites joined and participated in this commandment with the actions of Moses and Aaron, by virtue of their intention in performing it according to their understanding as received from the Divine. Through this, their commandments were elevated to a very great level. Thus, it says, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron," meaning according to their understanding, and even Moses and Aaron did so and joined with all of Israel. Now, Moses and Aaron offered the Passover sacrifice, but one cannot offer more than one Passover, and one cannot fulfill the commandment of its consumption entirely, for it is eaten by its designated ones and eaten to satisfaction. Therefore, they could not be satisfied enough from their yearning for this great commandment, for one who loves the commandments will never have his soul satisfied by them. Thus, the thought of the commandment remained with them, exceeding the part of the action, while the children of Israel fulfilled the commandment in action but lacked the part of the correct and proper thought, for they were still immersed in the impurity of Egypt, as is known. And the Holy One, blessed be He, combined their actions with the thoughts of Moses and Aaron, and the commandment was completed in perfection and at a great level in relation to the holiness of Moses and Aaron. This is what is meant by "and even Moses and Aaron did so," and they are partners in action and in thought. Consequently, the Other Side could not touch them, and they were accepted for mercy and favor.
summary: The passage discusses the participation of the Israelites in the Passover sacrifice alongside Moses and Aaron, emphasizing that their actions were elevated by the intention and holiness of their leaders. While the Israelites fulfilled the commandment through their actions, they lacked the proper mindset due to their immersion in the impurities of Egypt. However, God combined their deeds with the pure intentions of Moses and Aaron, resulting in a complete fulfillment of the commandment. This unity of action and thought prevented any negative spiritual forces from interfering, leading to divine acceptance and mercy.

passage_content: ובזה אפשר ליתן טעם על מה שנקרא שבת שבעשור לחודש שלקחו ישראל פסחיהן שבת הגדול, ע"ד מ"ד במד"ר (פ' וירא פר' נ"ג סי' י') והובא ברש"י ז"ל עה"פ ויעש אברהם משתה גדול, שהיו שם גדולי הדור שם ועבר וכו', הרי דבשביל שהשתתפו בו גדולי הדור קראו הכתוב גדול, וכן אירע להם לישראל בשבת זו כי אז קיימו משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן למצו' והגיעם התעוררת קדושה גדולה והשיגו כי עדיין רחוקים הם ממעלת השלימות, ע"כ השתתפו בשמירת וקדושת השבת עם מעשיהם של משה ואהרן וכמו"כ עשו במצות הפסח, נמצא שנתעלה קדושת ומצות שבת זו יותר מכל השבתות ששמרו ישראל עד עכשיו שעשו אותם לעצמן, אבל עכשיו השתתפו במעשיהם עם משה ואהרן, ולפי שהי' בהשתתפות גדולי הדור ע"כ נקרא שבת הגדול, וכמו שדרשו רז"ל משתה גדול ע"ש שהיו מסובין בה גדולי הדור
translation: And with this, it is possible to give reason for why the Sabbath of the tenth of the month, when Israel took their Paschal lambs, is called the Great Sabbath, as stated in the Midrash (Parashat Vayera, Parashat 53, Section 10) and brought by Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And Abraham made a great feast." There were great ones of the generation there, and so on. Thus, because the great ones of the generation participated in it, the scripture calls it great. Similarly, it happened to Israel on this Sabbath, for then they fulfilled "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for the Paschal offering," and they reached a great awakening of holiness and realized that they were still far from the level of perfection. Therefore, they participated in the observance and sanctity of the Sabbath with the deeds of Moses and Aaron, and likewise they did with the commandments of the Passover. It turns out that the sanctity and commandments of this Sabbath were elevated more than all the Sabbaths that Israel had observed until now, which they did for themselves. But now they participated in their deeds with Moses and Aaron, and because there was participation of the great ones of the generation, it is called the Great Sabbath, as our sages of blessed memory expounded, a great feast because the great ones of the generation were gathered there.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Shabbat before Passover, referred to as "Shabbat HaGadol," highlighting that it was a time when the Israelites engaged in a collective act of sanctity by distancing themselves from idolatry and preparing for the Paschal sacrifice. This Shabbat is deemed "great" because it involved the participation of the leaders of the generation, Moses and Aaron, which elevated its holiness beyond that of previous Shabbatot. The text emphasizes the importance of communal involvement in spiritual practices, suggesting that such unity with the great leaders enhances the sanctity of the observance. Ultimately, this Shabbat represents a profound awakening towards achieving a higher level of spiritual completeness.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בביאור דברי רש"י ז"ל הנ"ל פסח הוא לד', הקרבן קרוי פסח ע"ש הדילוג והקפיצה שהקב"ה מדלג בתי ישראל מבין בתי מצרים, וקופץ ממצרי למצרי וישראל אמצעי נמלט, ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לש"ש דרך דלוג וקפיצה זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח, וצ"ב הקישור, גם ראוי להבין מ"ט נקרא הפסח ע"ש הדילוג והקפיצה, והיציאה ממצרים הי' נס גדול ועוד הרבה נסים היו שם ומדוע לא נקרא הקרבן על שמם, עוד יש להעיר מ"ש הכתוב במכת בכורות ומת כל בכור בארץ מצרים וגו' ולכל בנ"י לא יחרץ כלב לשונו וגו' למען תדעון אשר יפלה ד' בין מצרים ובין ישראל, וראוי להבין נתינת טעם זו למען תדעון וגו' וכי הי' הצלתם של ישראל לצורך ידיעה זו בלבד, גם בשאר מכות הובדלו ישראל וניצולו, כמשה"כ והפלה ד' בין מקנה מצרים וגו' וכן באחריני, ולא תלה הכתוב סיבת ההצלה בידיעת ההפלאה, ומ"ש במכת בכורות דייקא.
translation:
It can also be explained in the interpretation of the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, mentioned above: Passover is for the Lord; the sacrifice is called Passover because of the skipping and leaping that the Holy One, blessed be He, skips over the houses of Israel from among the houses of Egypt, and leaps from Egyptian to Egyptian, and Israel, the intermediary, is saved. And you shall perform all its works for the sake of His name in a manner of skipping and leaping, a remembrance of His name which is called Passover. It is also necessary to understand the connection, and it is fitting to understand why it is called Passover because of the skipping and leaping, and the exodus from Egypt was a great miracle, and there were many other miracles there; why then is the sacrifice not named after them? 

Additionally, one should note what the scripture says regarding the plague of the firstborn: "And every firstborn in the land of Egypt died," etc., "and to all the children of Israel not a dog shall whet its tongue," etc., "so that you may know that the Lord distinguishes between Egypt and Israel." It is fitting to understand the reason for this statement, "so that you may know," etc. Was the salvation of Israel solely for the purpose of this knowledge? Also, in the other plagues, Israel was distinguished and saved, as it is written, "And the Lord distinguished between the livestock of Egypt," etc., and similarly in others, and the scripture did not attribute the reason for the salvation to the knowledge of the distinction, and this is specifically stated regarding the plague of the firstborn.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing its name derived from God's "leaping" over the homes of the Israelites during the plague of the firstborn in Egypt. It raises questions about why the sacrifice is specifically associated with this act of divine intervention, despite the many miracles that occurred during the Exodus. The text also highlights the distinction made by God between the Egyptians and the Israelites, suggesting that the purpose of this distinction was not merely for the sake of knowledge but reflects a deeper theological understanding of divine protection and selection.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"ד התרגום יוב"ע פ' יתרו עה"פ ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים, שהטעינם הקב"ה ע"ג העננים והוליכם למקום המקדש לעשות שם הקרבן פסח בליל היציאה, ואח"כ החזירום למצרים וכו', וכבר ביארנו שהי' הצורך להחזירם למצרים כי לא נשלם זמנם לצאת עד יום ט"ו, וא"א להקדים בענין הגאולה אף רגע לפני הזמן, אמנם ראוי להבין דהנה הפסח נאכל לפני חצות דייקא, וא"כ כבר היו כל ישראל במקום המקדש לפני חצות, ומכת בכורות הי' בחצות ממש, ומה צורך הי' להחזירם מיד ולהצילם בדרך נס ע"י דילוג וקפיצה, והי' אפשר שישתהו שם כשעה חדא עד אחר חצות וינצלו בדרך הטבע, וע"ז בא הכתוב לתרץ למען תדעון אשר יפלה ד' בין מצרים ובין ישראל, כי הרבה דרכים לפניו ית' להציל את ישראל, אך למען ללמדנו ידיעה זו של הבדלה והפרשה, אשר א"א לנו להתקיים בגלויות זולתה, וזו תנחומין לדורות ישראל מעורבים ודרים בין האומות, הבוי"ת מצילינו ע"י הבדלה והפרשה, ואנחנו מחוייבים לעשות הבדלה והפרשה מהם ומדרכיהם וזהו קיומנו והצלתנו בגלות, ועל שם כך קרוי הקרבן פסח ע"ש הדילוג והקפיצה כדי לקבוע בלבנו ידיעה זו, דזהו כוונת הקרבן להזכיר הנס, וסיבת הנס הי' למען תדעון אשר יפלה ד' וגו', ובזה יבואר קישור דברי רש"י ז"ל הקרבן קרוי פסח על שם הדילוג והקפיצה וכו', ר"ל כדי לקבוע בלבנו הבדלה והפרשה מדרכי האומות, ואתם עשו כל עבודותיו לש"ש דרך דלוג וקפיצה וכו' לכוונה זו ולא לכוונת המועיל למנוע המשחית, רק לעשות זכר לשמו שקרוי פסח והבן.
translation: And even though according to the translation of the Yov"o in Parshat Yitro on the verse "And I bore you on the wings of eagles," that the Holy One, blessed be He, carried them on the clouds and brought them to the place of the Temple to offer the Passover sacrifice on the night of the exodus, and afterwards returned them to Egypt, etc., we have already explained that there was a need to return them to Egypt because their time to leave was not complete until the fifteenth day, and it is impossible to advance the matter of redemption even a moment before the time. However, it is appropriate to understand that the Passover is eaten precisely before midnight, and therefore all of Israel were already in the place of the Temple before midnight, and the plague of the firstborn occurred exactly at midnight. What was the need to return them immediately and save them through a miracle by skipping and jumping? It would have been possible for them to linger there for an hour until after midnight and be saved through natural means. To this, the verse comes to explain, "so that you may know that the Lord distinguishes between Egypt and Israel," for there are many ways before Him, blessed be He, to save Israel. But in order to teach us this knowledge of distinction and separation, which we cannot exist in the exiles without it, and this is a comfort for the generations of Israel who are mixed and dwell among the nations, the Holy One, blessed be He, saves us through distinction and separation, and we are obligated to make a distinction and separation from them and their ways, and this is our existence and salvation in exile. For this reason, the Passover sacrifice is called by the name of skipping and jumping, to establish this knowledge in our hearts, that this is the intent of the sacrifice to remind us of the miracle, and the reason for the miracle was "so that you may know that the Lord distinguishes," etc. In this, the connection to the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, is explained: the sacrifice is called Passover because of the skipping and jumping, meaning to establish in our hearts the distinction and separation from the ways of the nations. And you should perform all its services for the sake of Heaven through the way of skipping and jumping, etc., for this intention and not for the intention of being effective in preventing the destroyer, but to make a remembrance of His name, which is called Passover, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice and the miraculous deliverance of the Israelites from Egypt, emphasizing the importance of divine separation between Israel and the nations. It highlights that the timing of the Exodus was crucial, as it could not occur before the appointed time, and that the Israelites were brought to the Temple to partake in the Passover before the plague of the firstborn struck. This act of divine intervention serves to teach the essential lesson of distinction and separation from foreign influences, which is vital for the survival of the Jewish people in exile. The Passover sacrifice is thus a reminder of this miraculous separation and the necessity of maintaining one's identity amidst the challenges of living among other nations.

passage_content: ובני ישראל עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וגו', במכילתא וכי מה אמר להם משה לישראל במצרים, הרי הוא אומר דבר נא באזני העם וכן עשו בנ"י עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב מאי קושיא ומאי פירוקא, ונל"פ דהנה לא מצינו בכל המקרא שצוה משרע"ה לישראל וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וגו', רק שצוהו הקב"ה לאמר לישראל דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו, האמנם שהרמב"ן ז"ל (פי"א פסוק א') הניח כלל גדול תמצא בפרשיות רבות בתורה שלפעמים יקצר הכתוב בדבור הקב"ה למשה ויאריך במאמר משה אל העם ולפעמים להיפך עיי"ש ובכ"מ, מ"מ כאן שלא הזכיר הכתוב דברי משה אל העם אף בקיצור, אין הכרח מן הפסוקים שצוה משה רבינו מצוה זו לישראל, וא"כ מנין השיגו ישראל ידיעת מצוה זו. ומבואר במכילתא (ובילקוט פ' שמות רמז קע"ב) לא נחשדו ישראל על לשון הרע שנא' ושאלה אשה משכנתה, כבר הי' בידם י"ב חודש, ואין אתה מוצא באחד מהן שהלשין על חבירו ע"כ, מבואר שידעו ישראל מצוה זו י"ב חודש לפני יציאתם, ומנין ידעו אם לא אמרה משרע"ה להם.
translation: And the children of Israel did as Moses said, and they asked of the Egyptians for silver vessels, etc. In the Mekilta, it asks, what did Moses say to Israel in Egypt? Behold, it says, "Speak now in the ears of the people," and thus did the children of Israel. This is the end of the Mekilta. However, it is puzzling what the difficulty is and what the resolution is. It seems to me that we do not find anywhere in the entire Scripture that Moses commanded Israel to ask of the Egyptians for silver vessels, etc., only that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to say to Israel, "Speak now in the ears of the people, and they shall ask." Indeed, the Ramban, of blessed memory (in Parashat Bo, verse 1), established a great principle that you will find in many sections of the Torah that sometimes the writing shortens the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Moses and lengthens the words of Moses to the people, and sometimes the opposite, as noted there and elsewhere. Nevertheless, here, since the writing does not mention the words of Moses to the people, even briefly, there is no necessity from the verses that Moses our teacher commanded this commandment to Israel. And if so, how did Israel come to know this commandment? It is explained in the Mekilta (and in the Yalkut, Parashat Shemot, hint 182) that Israel was not suspected of gossip, as it is said, "And a woman shall ask of her neighbor." They had already had it for twelve months, and you do not find any one of them who informed on his friend. Therefore, it is clear that Israel knew this commandment twelve months before their departure, and how did they know if Moses did not tell them?
summary: The passage discusses the command given by God to Moses for the Israelites to ask for silver and gold from the Egyptians, highlighting that there is no explicit command from Moses to the people regarding this request. It raises the question of how the Israelites knew to perform this act if it was not directly communicated by Moses. The text suggests that the Israelites were aware of this command for twelve months prior to their departure, indicating a deep spiritual understanding and connection to divine will, which reflects the Hasidic belief in the inherent spiritual awareness of the Jewish people.
